Have you ever tried flaming hot cheetos? That's what their special totopos con Chile tastes like, but with cotija cheese and creme. It's not a bad start for an appetizer, if you like that flavor combination.

 Next, I had their chicharron quesadilla, while my buddy Tim got their fish tacos. The quesadilla was filled with crunchy chicharron and pork.

Although I liked my meal, Tim's portions were small. The fish must have been a guppie because it was barely two bites, so he wound up eating my chips and taking some of my quesadilla. And for $10.00 his plate should have filled him up.

Had I gone alone without seeing his tacos I would have given this place 4 stars.

 I even like their almond horchata; it's not super sweet. 

Yet, due to his small portions and him having to then eat my food, I'm going to have to knock off one star.
author: Jack R.

description:
I feel like giving Nopalito 3 stars would be too harsh, though I did have a bit of a frustrating experience with the service. On the other hand, the food was very good.

Most importantly: Nopalito is really more of a small-plate style meal. My gf and I didn't realize this when ordering, but the best thing to do is go with 3-5 people and split a bunch of plates, that way you can try many of the quesadillas, guacs/salsas, tacos, enchiladas, etc.

Not knowing this, my gf and I ordered the chicken mole and one of the quesadillas. Both were good, the mole was a pretty sizable portion but the quesadilla wouldn't be sufficient for a meal in and of itself. The mole was great and the chicken cooked perfectly served over rice. Came with corn tortillas so you can make a mole taco if you want. 

I do have to say, the service I experienced at Nopalito was poor. I think it was really just the one waitress but she seemed completely disinterested in her job. Her first words when she walked up to the table were "what do you want?" and then we didn't see her again until it came time to pay the check. Additionally, after ordering, I asked where the bathroom was. Turns out you have to leave the porch area and the bathroom is around the corner where you actually place to-go orders. The waitress just said you have to go outside and pointed towards the parking garage. Needless to say, I got lost. That was ridiculous, just take 20 seconds to clearly explain where the bathroom is.

Overall, I want to give Nopalito another try as I'm sure it'll be better now that I know the menu and located the bathroom.
author: Lucas W.

description:
We arrived during lunch service on a Saturday without a reservation so unsurprising the wait for a table was 30-40 minutes. 

We opted to get take out from next door and had the tacos dorados de papa and the quesadilla roja con chicharrón. Yum yum. Both excellent and delicious. Strong flavors but not overwhelming. The tacos were especially great with nice spicy flavors. 

And a much cheaper option than eating in!
author: Gemma H.

description:
Met here for a lunch meeting, after hearing lots of good things about it. The reviews seem spilt between hype and disgust, as seems to be the trend here in SF. 

I enjoyed my meal, but only a 2.5star amount. They were not busy by any means, but no one came for our drinks for a good 10-15 minutes, and we were never given plates for our appetizer. 

Ordered :
- Totopos con Chile to share (1/5) : this isn't an appetizer to dip chips into various sauces. It's a bowl of chips already coated in the salsa, it is instead very messy and pretty bland in taste ...while plentiful in sweaty spices. We also had no plates on which to eat them, and made our table subsequently gross. 
- Empanada Con Deshebrada De Res (3/5) : meat was flavorful, pastry was slightly overcooked making it dry and crumblier than usual, toppings were paired nicely. Enjoyable enough, but simply average. 
- Complimentary cookies that came with the check (4/5) : I believe they were Mexican wedding cookies, and we each were given one.
author: Amanda W.

description: I wonder how they cook pork belly, the most fatty cut of meat, so dry. And also they need more serving staff.
author: Jay R.

description:
I had the famous quesadilla here and it was delicious - 4 stars.   But they earned an additional star because my order was takeout and they forgot to put the avocado on the side in my bag--- and they handled it just how everyone would want to be treated.  

Ok the details:   Nearly $18 on uber fees later to/from my hotel I envisioned eating my dinner just i as I hoped with some pieces of avocado smushed into every bite.   When I got back to my hotel, turned on my tv, I was saddened to see no avocado.   I called the restaurant and they offered to remove it and then later Lauren called back and said they would take care of the whole thing.   Nice.   

Two tips:
1) if u r visiting SF, come here and if u do takeout, check your bag 
2) if you get the quesadilla I really think it needs some more greens and avocado.  It is really quite good but needs a little some green to balance the generous portion of meat.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Came here with cousins for my birthday dinner. Definitely a quality restaurant that lives up to its hype. One of those places that walks the walk with all the talk it gets.

The restaurant:
It's connected to Falletti Foods grocery store on Broderick so it conveniently has it's own parking lot if you're driving. No reservations, but they take wait-list calls two hours in advance. I called at 5:30pm and got a table for 5 at 7:30pm with no problem at all. They have a sorta strict policy of not seating you until your entire party arrives so make sure to be on time unless you want members of your crew waiting outside for you (they can also go wait at the bar of course). 

The food:
We had shots of mezcal to start the night. They normally don't come with the salsa chase that mezcal should be downed with, but I asked our waiter about it and he was nice enough to hook it up. I guess mezcal has nothing to do with the restaurant itself, but I could drink mezcal forever (haha sike), so I'm just very happy they had a large variety of it.

We got the Totopos con Chile as our appetizer. With an extra lime they were the perfect amount of spice and sour I'd want in a chip. I'd recommend this appetizer over any of the others on the menu. For my main dish I got the Birria de Res and I shared it with my cousin's Carne Asada con Nopales. Both dishes were aesthetically basic, but tastefully intricate! We really liked dipping the carne asada in the stew that the Birria de Res was served in. You can also ask for extra tortillas and make a taco out of the meat, black beans, salsa, and fajitas that come with the carne asada! Ended the night with some complimentary cookies that I cannot remember the name of for the life of me, but were a kind gesture on behalf of our waiter.

Overall, would totally recommend for a night that you have a reason/occasion to go out to eat/celebrate. If I had five words to review this place I'd say: Mezcal, mezcal, more mezcal, mezcal?
author: Shayan S.

description:
I went here for dinner. I got the fish tacos and some hibiscus orange juice. Both were good but I think they both didn't make me want to go back. 

I would recommend this place for a date but for regular dinner.
author: Muhammad U.

description:
The first time i heard of this place i was watching Food Network with guy fierri and he rated this place 5 stars so me and my girlfriend decided to try it.

Food: the food is amazing and as a mexican i can say it is really authentic and it took back to the days my mom used to make this food for me at home. I had the sandal, it was great you could taste the lime in the pork and the chorizo was perfect with it.

Service: the servers seemed a little hesitant to seat you i think it might have been open seating i guess. You have to share tables which is fine if your good with people. It took them about 20 minutes to take my order and the food cane fast though so it was compensated. It took them about the same time for me to get an horchata. They could visit you at the table more to ask if we need anything and thats why i denied them the 1 star. 

Overal this place was a good restaurant and i would come here again in the future.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Given the plethora of truly authentic Mexican restaurants in California that serve great food at great prices, I always have tempered expectations when dining at restaurants like Nopalito.

That proved to be wise here. I had the Mole Poblano con Pollo, which was acceptable, but far from the best I have had. The service was fine.

Nopalito doesn't take reservations. Fortunately, I had no problem getting seated at a communal table early on a Saturday evening. I would have regretted waiting.

Pro: there's a free parking garage at the location, a rarity in San Francisco.

Con: besides the disappointingly adequate food, I was surprised that the bathroom is located in the adjacent take-out space and apparently isn't accessible through the restaurant. You need to go outside and walk around to the take-out space if you need to use the loo. Obviously this is not a huge deal (unless you're having a Pepto-Bismol day or drank 4 gallons of water an hour before sitting down to eat), but I still thought it was a noticeably odd setup for an establishment like this.
author: BR C.

description:
Food is decent but the hostess ruined the whole experience for me. Didnt get her name but she was wearing a tight red retroish dress and had a huge attitude. This was on a friday maybe three weeks ago, I hope management is able to find out who she is because due to this situation I will never be going back.
 Me and my date were sitting at a communal table right before closing. I was put at the end of the table and placed my coat on the stool next to me since there was no one sitting there. A  couple walks in shortly after and instead of the hostess sitting them at any of the other free tables or even a few seats down at the communal table she demands that I move my jacket to so she can seat them in the seats directly next to us. I complied to not make a huge deal at the time but I did not see the need to make a customer in the middle of dinner get up to move their jacket when theres multiple free spots at the same table. It would have made everyone more comfortable if she sat them where there was more space and didnt have to push her weight around and try to be controlling.Hospitality is a must and it seemed like she was just trying to make this a difficult experience. I hope this brings light to the issue as this is very unprofessional.
author: Sarah K.

description: One star review not for the food, which I didn't get to try...but for the fact that you have to leave the restaurant and go around the damn corner to use the bathroom. If you can't invest in making a walk way to the bathroom then I can't invest in dinner. Plus the hostess was irritating.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
I tried calling to see if they could make any of their meals vegan but they had a long automated answer and then gave an option to talk to a human (in the kitchen) - I choose that option and the phone rang for about 2 minutes before I gave up. (The location was open when I called too).

Took my business to The Little Chihuahua down the street.
author: Stuart F.

description: Went for Mother's Day/ my birthday. I was slightly apprehensive at first and didn't want to be disappointed with "Americanized" food. However, this place really surprised me! They have what we call a great "sazón". The food is actually quite tasty and very authentic. I'll be back. (Ps. Definitely try the strawberry horchata. It's the best I've ever had!)
author: Sabrina M.

description:
Excellent restaurant with - not so conventional - Mexican food, I mean you don't get standard Tacos, Fajitas, etc, but rather well elaborated plates :-)
Very good food quality and unexpected tastes.
author: Alex G.

description: Would highly recommend the pork sandwich! Also loved the nuts. Awesome food & great service
author: Sophie Z.

description: I love this place. I love Mexican food but I hate cilantro & grease. Delicious, fresh, well prepared, high quality ingredients & great friendly service.
author: Tracy G.

description:
On Saturday, 2/14/15, my girlfriend and I ate at Nopalito for dinner. I had to give this place a try after seeing Nopalito on Taco Trip hosted by Aaron Sanchez. Nopalito was also featured on the Food Network show Diners Drives and Dives. After hearing a lot of positive reviews about Nopalito from famous chefs along with people I know, so I would think this place was going to knock my socks off. Well...it didn't. Here's why...

Atmosphere/Decor:

The restaurant is pretty small. The tables were very close to one another. There were two dining areas. One was a covered patio type dining area and the other was your traditional inside dining area. There's an open kitchen. There's not much to Nopalito. It reminded me of every other restaurant in San Francisco. Kind of plain in a way. 

Food:

We ordered the Carnitas (Braised pork, orange, bay leaf, milk, cinnamon, beer, Cabbage salad, pickled jalapeño and salsa de tomatillo) tortillas, Birria de Res (Grass fed beef stewed in ancho chile, roasted tomatoes, sesame seeds, spices, pickled onion, cilantro, lime, Mexican rice and salsa de arbol) and a side of Whole Pinquito Beans along with a side of crema. 

The Carnitas were okay. In my opinion they were lacking in flavor. There was no wow factor when I was eating the Carnitas. On the positive side they give you a good amount of Carnitas and the texture of the Carnitas was good. I didn't care for the Cabbage salad. It was very plain and lifeless. The salsa de tomatillo was really good. My girlfriend liked this salsa a lot. The tortillas tasted good and fresh. 

The Birria de Res was underwhelming and over salted. The quality of the meat was good and tender. It just wasn't seasoned well. There was also a large amount of fat. I'm not used to eating shredded beef with a lot of fat. I like it better when the fat is trimmed off. The Mexican rice was good but it tasted a little burnt. 

Service:

Our waiter Michael was very nice and attentive throughout our dinner. He always made sure our waters were topped off. The food came out fairly quick. 

Overall:

I had very high hopes for Nopalito. I honestly thought Nopaltio was going to be one of the best Latin infused restaurants I've ever eaten at but it wasn't. The food fell short and left me unsatisfied. If you're in SF and craving Mexican food try Lolo or El Techo de lolinda.
author: David R.

description: Organic Mexican food for the win! Nopalito is one of my favorite restaurants. Since moving away from SF, my husband and I really miss it. Last time we were in town we went there twice in a matter of 2 Days. The Totopos is one of the most addicting things on the planet. And their empanadas have the perfect amount of crisp. Pretty please open a location in Chicago!
author: Alayna R.

description: First I have to say my parents are the most picky Mexican eaters, only because my mother is a great cook. Yes We were very blessed to have such an awesome cook at home which is bad now because we're always comparing Mexican places to her cooking. So with that in mind I must say best thing we had was the tamal de Huitlacoche and mushroom. Keep in mind that this is the tamal made in banana leaf, topped with sour cream and quezo fresco! The totopos con chile are really yummy too not spicy but are flavor full. The gorditas and quesadilla de chicharron were really tasty but needed a bit of salt. We also had the mole enchiladas now if you're like me that likes spicy mole vs sweet mole these are not for you. Of course the parentals were not a fan but my husband really enjoyed them since he doesn't tolerate spicy food. Nothing comes out of microwaves you can watch the kitchen staff being preparing your dishes. My favorite drink was the tepache. Another thing we liked was the service it was quick and all were friendly. We're coming back here for sure!!!
author: Mizz D O.

description:
This review is strictly for takeout.

I did a walk-up and was met by some pretty solid incompetency. I placed my order and waited outside for about 15 minutes. I went back in the takeout window to see how it was coming and was told "Oops! That's the one menu item that we don't do for takeout. Can we get you something else instead?" If you have one menu item that can't be takeout, shouldn't the takeout clerk know this? At what point were you going to come tell me? Anyway, I made another order, waited another 15 minutes, and got my meal - which was C+ food at best.

Probably won't check this place out again - there's too much awesome food in the city.
author: Russ S.

description: Update to my past review. The food is delicious! Different than most places I've tried. Order to go and you'll have better luck.
author: Destinee S.

description:
Pro tip- call ahead to get your name on the list for the night!

Drinks were awesome! We ordered this pumped up quesadilla with chorizo/brisket, the fish tacos, and the chips soaked in some salsa! Was all delicious, especially the quesadilla.
author: Jessica J.

description:
A five star restaurant to me means that you can blindly pick an item in the menu and be WOWed. Nopalito is no exception. We ate tapas /family style and we got to taste everything. Ones that slightly stood out were Ceviche, deep fried quesadilla and the trucha (trout!).

I would go here again and again and again! Wait can be long sometimes but we got lucky this time around and were seated within 10 mins, food came fast too!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Went for dinner last night with my brother and husband for the first time now the only reason I new about this place was cause I saw it on a TV show and it looked good, I'm only giving it 3 stars because of the size of the food and the price was bit too much for what u get plus the place is too small-- 
We didn't have to wait too long to be seated this was a plus -.,  I order the carnitas that was $21 I was expecting at least some rice and beans for that price but it was only the pork with a salsa and some cabbage., it was a let down :-(. My husband had the pork quesadilla and a posole he said it was good- my Brother had the carne asada also good - we also tried the ceviche it was good also but the tortillas that came wit it where so hard.. So with all that it came to 158$ with tip .. Don't think I'll be back .
author: Elizabeth R.

description: This place is cute, definitely loved the area it was in. I enjoyed the food, but it definitely is not a filling meal. You have to order multiple items in order to feel full. The food items are small portions, so if you're a food person like me, you will chow that down and want more food. I enjoyed the food because it was different but they could increase the quantity and the size they give, especially with the prize! I enjoyed the watermelon lemonade, natural and very tasty!
author: Anisha S.

description: Ordered quite a few dishes... chilaquiles, quesadilla de chicharrón, empanada de res and pozole, not all for me of course!!!everything was delicious. I highly recommend Nopalitos.
author: Rosa R.

description:
CARNITAS.

My friend made a same-day reservation for 4 fine ladies at 6 PM on Saturday. Despite calling an hour ahead, we still had to wait 20 minutes to be seated. Thinking back to that night, we should have been more aggressive in terms of our position on the lady's handheld electronic waiting list...

The restaurant buds from the nearby Falletti Foods grocery store, which meant that I mistook it for a very busy cafeteria. Mind you, it is busy, but the interior is anything but cafeteria-like. The indoor and heated&covered outdoor seating house a bustling social ambiance that lends to good conversation with good food.

We were first given a small bowl of complimentary fried garbanzo beans. Spiced with chili, they were a flavored crunchy kick to our taste buds and our appetite. The water came out in a trendy glass bottle (like at Gather in Berkeley), as it's filtered on-site. One friend ordered the horchata, which was more watered down than what I've had at other places but was extra spiced and iced.

For our meal, my friend and I decided to split two dishes, which came to an affordable $15 each for us that evening. We first ordered the CALDO TLALPENO, a soup comprised of chicken consommé, carrots, brussel sprouts, cauliflower, 
garbanzos, avocado, queso fresco, and chipotle adobado for $10 (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ODWobJZkhfWpnsuF90QHmQ/l.jpg). I had my eye on this dish because of its presence on the SF Big Eat 2013 list (http://www.7x7.com/big-eat-2013#/51). The Caldo Tlalpeño has a combination of ingredients that is unique and refreshing, with the creamy avocado chunks, the pleasing queso fresco, the textured brussel sprouts, and the mild zing from the dried chipotle adobado pepper that makes your soup spicier the longer you keep it in your soup. That being said, this soup is a one-time order for me.

The next dish was the CARNITAS for $15.50, which is braised pork seasoned with orange, bay leaf, milk, cinnamon, and beer that comes with 4 small yellow corn tortillas, cabbage salad, pickled jalapeño, and salsa de tomatillo (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/0zxiKpUHJxBQqZK65TTAqA/l.jpg). And WOW, this was AMAZING! Another Yelper, Talia G, had recommended to ask for the carnitas extra fried, and I'm glad I did. The pork chunks were generous with a sublime crispy skin and pockets of devilishly delicious fat, and the pork didn't exactly fall off the bone but was tender enough. The seasoning was subtle, perhaps too subtle since I can only really remember the richness of the pork. The pickled onions on the side were a bit spicy (I stopped eating those haha), and the salsa verde was divine. Making my own mini tacos was so fun with such scrumptious ingredients!

Another friend ordered two vegetarian items, the Naranjas con Chile, Limón y Queso (Cara Cara & blood oranges, grapefruit, pickled red onions, chile de arbol, chile guajillo, lime, and queso fresco), $6, and the Tamal de Amarillo con Calabaza (corn masa, butternut squash, jalapeño, Oaxacan cheese, mole of dried chiles, tomatillos, peanuts, pumpkin seeds, and spices), $6 (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/g_n4W2Itr4hIz9g0bDxztg/l.jpg). Judging by how she finished her plates, they must have been tasty :)

To wrap up the meal, each person was given a complimentary Mexican wedding cookie, a small almond cookie topped with powdered sugar (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/p-zumNhO2IwaByhbR0GnQQ/l.jpg). The crunchy almond cookie was a perfect ending--if only they could give us more than one!

Nopalito has fantastic food with prompt service and an enjoyable ambiance. Make sure to call an hour in advance for their same-day reservations. And get the CARNITAS, extra fried! :B
author: Adele F.

description: We came here because it has good reviews however its not family friendly. A  expensive if your on vacation with your family. No kids menu, small portions so don't expect to get a hearty plate. Service was good though.
author: Maria I.

description: Came at 5:00pm on a weeknight and was seated right away. Loved sitting on the "patio" that was fully enclosed and cozy. Lots of families and kids this early -- wouldn't recommend for a date but it was perfect for a weeknight dinner. I got the carnitas and loved every bite. We liked Nopalito so much, we visited the other location over the weekend. Great experience over all.
author: Chloe M.

description:
A decent higher-end Mexican restaurant from the usual fare; not up to Frontera Grill levels, but serves similar interesting variety of food.  

It's usually not a good sign when the best part of the meal comes at the beginning: the fried chickpeas are really excellent and I can tell why they're sold all over town.  The rest of the meal was flavorful, but the portions oddly decided.  What was a lunch was not clearly a lunch, nor a brunch vs an appetizer, etc.  It's best understood as a many shared plates menu, though it's not set-up that way.

One major complaint is that prices listed on the menu do not reflect the price charged.  As noted at the bottom of the menu there is a "3% Employee Benefit Fee (health insurance)".  I support the goal of offering employees health insurance.  I also support the goal of transparent pricing; if you will pay 3% more per dish, include that in the price listed and brag about offering health insurance elsewhere on the menu.
author: David M.

description:
The food at Nopalito is amazing.  I've never had to wait because I eat early like a geriatric.  When we're trying to think of a place to go eat I'll often have to throw out a "not Nopalito" otherwise I'd happily eat here every day.  Everybody would.  That's why there's so many people here on Yelp complaining about the wait.

Oh, I do have one complaint.  Hey waiter guy, when I said pozole like it rhymes with olay and you said pozole back to me like it rhymes with pole, you were wrong.  I felt bad about myself.  I had to go confirm with multiple videos on the internet and YOU. WERE. WRONG.  That's all.
author: Oliver D.

description:
So I have been to this place a couple of times and to be honest this is by far my one of the favourites places in SF to have lunch or dinner. 
The waiters are cool and the food is good. The only thing is its a  great place for a date. I mean if you are hungry as a hound the quantity is gonna be less for you. If you are on a date and want a good conversation than be here. If you know ur date is there just to eat of your pocket don't be here. :D take her to a Mc Donalds ha ha ha ha. 
But overall great place to eat and connect with friends, family or SO.
Have a good time and order a sangria.
author: Urvish -.

description:
I came here after I saw the other location on Diners, Drive-Ins, & Dives. 

The quesadilla was delightful. Huge, delicious, and inexpensive. The only thing that would keep me from giving 5 stars is that the crispy pork belly inside was not so crispy. The cheese and saucy stewed pork were absolutely dynamite though. Definitely made up for the slightly chewy pork belly crisps. 


They serve complimentary crispy garbanzo beans- spicy with lime and a hint of bacon maybe? So good. 

I want to try everything on the menu.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Nopalito is a trendy Mexican restaurant in the Alamo Square neighborhood. 

Complimentary spicy fried garbanzo beans - not sure what it is about them--they're not quite good, but they're addicting!
Quesadilla roja con chicharrón - so good. Pork belly was crispy and not too chewy or oily
Carnitas- quite a lot of food for how small it looks. Very good--comes with unlimited corn tortillas on the side
Vanilla bean flan - delicious way to end the meal
Two complimentary mini Mexican cookies - not my favorite, but, hey, they're free!
Sangria - slightly disappointed with their sangria--it wasn't bad but not the best I've had.

Pretty solid sit down place (they also have a takeout window), but be ready to wait if you don't have reservations. It's not so big inside, and they do have a "community table" but it's not very big inside.
author: Julia N.

description: Met a friend for brunch and was excited to try Nopalito.  I had the chilaquiles and they were decent, not great.  The issue was the service.  It was non existent pretty much.  We seemed to be a bother to our server.  Maybe she was having an off day, but the hostess was equally as rude and bothered.  I think I'll keep going to Cosecha in Oakland to get my chilaquiles fix.
author: Melissa S.

description:
"Nopalito: Sustainable, organic, Mexican Kitchen" says frou-frou right off the bat, which, don't get me wrong, I'm all about a lot of the time.  That being said, when I eat Mexican I don't necessarily want to pay an extra $4.50 for beans or rice.  You catch my drift?

All in all, this spot was a good dad-date spot.  Reliable beer selection, chips and guac, and an array of meat-heavy entrees.  I really liked the Tacos de Pescado al Pastor, though I admit, I didn't venture too far out of my comfort zone.  Some of the other menu items include pomegranate salads and butternut squash, avocado, cauliflower dishes (uhm, yes please?!)  

I totally get why they ride the sustainable-organic wave & I love them for it.  I just wish, going into this dining experience, that I hadn't expected such traditional, heavy (there, I said it) dishes.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Food:
-Best things were the free fried garbanzo beans that tasted kind of asian and the carnitas, both of which I shamelessly hoarded
-Complimentary mexican almond cookies in the end were also great, maybe I just like all free things
-Ceviche was just ceviche, totopos con chile was just slightly flavored soggy chips, caldo tlapeno was just soup
-Quesadilla roja con chicharron, didn't live up to expectations despite all the friedness/cheeseness/guaranteed heart attack

Service:
-Nice and attentive

Atmosphere:
-Earthy chill (this should be a candle fragrance name)
-Feels like awkward forced speed dating when they seat another party WITH you just because you have one sqft of space left at your table
-Only one bathroom for this decently sized restaurant, don't drink too much horchata if you aren't equipped with a steel bladder
author: Tian Q.

description: I usually don't leave bad reviews but then again this is the first time I've been to a restaurant that has an OK Yelp rating but is pretty awful. The restaurant may use quality ingredients but their execution is awful. Their Horchata tastes great but is overpriced for such a tiny drink. Their Hibiscus-Valencia Orange left much to be desired. Their tacos have no vegetables at all, just meat basically. Totopos con Chile are soggy and taste generic. Their Ensalada de Lechuga con Manzanas had practically nothing but lettuce even though they listed a bunch of other ingredients. Finally their Huarache with Brisket had meat that didn't even taste like beef and was extremely tough.
author: Daniel K.

description: This place is screaming good!! I love all the fresh food. So far I have been here twice in 1 week. The addiction is starting. Tried the pork quesadilla it's absolutely delicious. Love the crunch and texture of the pork rinds inside the quesadilla. Will definitely be back to enjoy more of the delicious foods at this restaurant.
author: Marie S.

description:
Very good first experience! Yes, the wait is long, but typical of SF restaurants on a Saturday night. Friends checked in around 7 and estimated time was 745pm (table for 3, no reservations allowed). There is a wait area outside with a heat lamp, but be sure to dress warm since we are around Divisadero where the fog loves to sneak on in. Once you are closer to being seated, there may be a chance to wait at the bar. We did. We were given complimentary corn nuts (spicy) and sangrias and margaritas. Very good Sangria!

We were seated and wait staff was excellent. My friends typically like to share everything so I had a chance to taste all ordered - pretty tasty! I ordered the Trout over Fava beans. It was so good, I finished it completely. It definitely has a kick, so if you do not like spicy, I would avoid. So flavorful though. The Citrus salad was a perfect starter. My friend's Chicken Mole was so delicious. We had room for dessert and had a citrus flan, also very good. 

Things that can be improved: bathroom is outside, you have to walk and go to the take out area in another door and possibly wait outside if there is a line. Bathroom wasn't as clean or welcoming like the dining area as I hoped. The guacamole was delicious, but portion was small for three people. However, if you noticed, my rating was unaltered! Food and service was enough to meet that. Enjoy!
author: Neville B.

description:
Nopalito is a very white take on Mexican food. If you are going for something traditional, don't go here. I typically am against nontraditional Mexican food, but I like Nopalito. 

I've been to Nopalito a ton of times and have had lots of different items on their menu. 

Totopes con Chile- Delicious. I love the lime crema. But be warned, these are so addictive. 
Empanada- I really like the masa pastry. It's thick and flaky. 
Gordita- This dish is delicious. The braised brisket is so tender and very flavorful. 
Ensalada de Naranjas- LOVE this salad. They only have it in the winter and it is so so good. 
Quesadilla roja con Chicharron- This is good. I really like the crispy pork belly. 

Occasionally on the menu they will have this corn salad that is phenomenal. It's almost like street corn, but in salad form.

Overall, I like Nopalito. But I have to be in the mood for this type of Mexican food.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: If I could give it a zero star I would. Food is over priced, small potions and customer service is horrible.
author: Edith R.

description:
Oh Nopalito, you're so tasty. We came here on a chilly Sunday night. Luckily, they had room for us at the counter, which was awesome because you get to see all the food made.

We got the pork belly quesadilla, beef empanada, fish taco, and the short rib stew. Everything was extremely tasty and the portion sizes were really good. My absolute favorite was the short rib stew. My god, this is one gem of a dish. I love the combination of beef and tomato in a stew. The beef was tender, flavorful, and falls apart with the touch of your fork. And when you pour the stew over the fluffy spanish rice, it's so good. Add a touch of the zesty and spicy tomato salsa, and you got yourself one hell of a bite. They also give you freshly made tortillas, in case you want to make yourself a short rib taco. All in all, this entree oozes with flavor. You won't be disappointed.
author: Sherry L.

description: really yummy nouveau mexican (is that a thing?). the bloody maria was super smoky and on point, great addition to the meal.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Love love loved it!! Absolutely delish food and awesome service to go with it... Couldn't have been happier. We didn't have reservations or names on the daily list..  however we were accommodated at the communal table within 10 mins... (Thats after we agreed to the 2 hr wait list... I think the hostess felt sorry for us ;-) and decided to get us in way sooner !)

You start of your meal with their homemade spiced garbanzo beans... They were sooo good.. could keep snacking on them...

We tried the empanada... Absolutely beautifully presented.. fresh crisp, and the beef filling was the best part... So tender and flavorful !!

We had the panucho de pollo- awesome too... Tender chicken 

The mole coloradito con pollo was really nice too... The chicken breast was super tender, the sauce had an interesting flavor... The fresh tortillas served with it were nice too...

We didn't try any desserts coz I was pretty determined to get some ice cream from bi rite near by... But along with the check they got us some yummy cinnamon and almond cookies ... It satiated my sweet tooth desires.... N that was good bye to my ice cream craving .

Me and my husband have never been fans of Mexican food... In fact we never go to Mexican restaurants. I'm so glad this is the first one we decided to give a try ! After this... We now look at Mexican food differently and will definitely try out some more !
author: Insiya N.

description:
Asked a local friend where they'd go for a casual dinner if they could have just one meal in SF and she recommended Nopalito - she did not let us down. 

Our last night in town and we wanted fresh food we wouldn't get back home, so Nopalito delivered in spades. 

We shared a few plates - 
the totopos con chile were a great start - fresh chips, crumbly cojito and the brightness from lime and cilantro. 
The taquitos were crispy, perfectly fried, full of fresh, seasonal veggies and topped with delcious guac and quesa fresca - these aren't your dorm room taquitos
The empanada was almost too pretty to eat. I'd never had one made with a masa based dough and loved the texture and how it held up. 

We ended the meal with the house-made cinnamon chocolate popsicles and they were the perfect treat - not too sweet and just melt in your mouth delicious.
author: Nicole H.

description: Absolutely delicious! We ordered the totopos, chicharron quesadilla and Birria. We enjoyed every last bite, can't wait to return!
author: Adrianna C.

description:
My Fav here are Totopos con chile and Fish Tacos! Very delicous! 

Improvement wise, im not sure if it is the host or the servers or whatever. We waited almost an hour and it was not even busy. In fact, there were available tables. But nevertheless, their foods are fantastic.!
author: Iya S.

description:
Just okay - 3.5 stars. If you like your Mexican food SPICY, Nopalito is your place. They start the meal with some complimentary, fire-hot garbanzo beans, and they must add the same spice to all of their entrees too. 

We waited an hour to be seated on a Thursday night, and the service was slow/spotty. A group of 3 seated after us got their food before our drinks even came.

The restaurant's decor is a bit plain, and the tables are really close together, so I wouldn't describe is as super-romantic or upscale. I like Tropisueno much better!
author: Margs K.

description:
Opening at 11:30 am, this is not a typical a brunch spot. The menu doesn't offer signature brunch items so factor that into expectations when you choose it!

A bonus, unlike many SF brunch spots, brunch is served well into the afternoon at Nopalito. No mimosas or bloody marys here but if you're feeling boozy, the bloody maria will do the trick. It is a spicy, tequila based, bloody mary and it is quite delicious. 

We didn't end up staying for brunch because we were in the mood for old-fashioned breakfast items but I would come back to try it when I am feeling bit more spicy. The ambiance is great, warm and bright. They have heaters for the outdoor seating area and it was quite lovely.
author: Caroline L.

description:
Some notes about this place:

-Bathroom is not located in the restaurant. You need to exit and enter through the pick-up door and there's the restrooms.
-When entering the restaurant, it is often hard to get noticed. From my experience, it took them awhile to seat us. We weren't sure if we were recognized.
-I like the chickpeas that serve at the table in the beginning. It's like a teaser! It's good - I like the crunch but it's slightly spicy. Good kick!
-This is a fusion, caribbean/cuban type of food. I didn't know what I was getting myself into!
-The server changed our napkin, utensils after our appetizer (basically after each course). 
-Atmosphere: casual but nice. It's a nice place, overall. 
-Menu is small in my opinion. 

Food:

Starter:
- Gordita : Delicious. Crispy, Love the pork! 
Main Dish: 
- Pork Belly Quesadilla: I love the pork belly. The tortilla was crispy as well. I like the vegetables in it too. All the flavors just melt in your mouth. I would recommend this! 
- Cuban Sandwich: It was just okay. I wasn't particularly fond of it. It came with chips but they didn't really have much flavor. It was just deep fried.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Really unhappy with Nopalito. They claim not  to have reservations but , if you are in the know, they do.
They have a system  that you call ahead and get a seat. VERY unfair if you don't know that. Why can't they just agree to open  table. Their "system" is very dishonest and left us potentially standing at the bar for an hour. We left.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Considering how much I enjoy Nopa, I'm going to have to say I was slightly disappointed here. As much as I wanted to love it, I just was not as taken with the food as others have been. 

Let's start with the good. There is plenty of parking in the nearby garage and even better - it's free. This is always a nice surprise here in the city and I always find myself double triple checking the signage to ensure we won't be ticketed, or worse towed. 

Restaurant itself has a lot of natural light and with two dining areas along with a bar. We had no problems with service, everything went smoothly. 

The "so-so". Our orders were just ok, certainly nothing memorable, particularly my order. Even though my huarache had several ingredients in it, I don't know why but it still lacked taste. At least the chips and salsa looked good. 

They did have a decent drink menu consisting of cocktails, beer and wine selections. 

I might be back however it's not the first place I'll think about when craving for Mexican (even for Mexican inspired) fare.
author: Esther A.

description: Delicious way to kill time when at the dmv. Love the open kitchen and the blood orange sangria is definitely on point.
author: Brian R.

description:
Love this place!!! Definitely make a reservation, because it gets booked up. 

Ambiance- any place with outdoor seating with heatlamps gets lots of stars from me!!! Also a cool environment and good location near nopa, lower haight, and hayes valley. 

Food- got the Totopos con Chile because everyone around us did. They were basically fancy nachos- really good but kind of spicy ( the waitress that delivered them to us laughed and said 'you know these are spicy right?'). Regardless they were good and I would order them again. We also got the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón which was AMAZINGGGG. I wish I had ordered mine own and didn't split it. Next time I would order that again, and probably try the empanda. 

Price was on point for food and ambiance. We also got drinks (wine and beer).
author: Jenna G.

description:
Always great ingredients, very good food, and I love the laid back atmosphere here.

* Quesadilla del Campo - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=UBW3Asjmih0nARbBNK3oEA#P0NOC3u3Fjnu89-3dpu2PA
(Corn tortilla, squash blossom, pasilla & anaheim chiles, onion, sweet corn, , cilantro, jack cheese, queso fresco and salsa molcajete. 9.00)
Nice, tasty - really like the sweetness of the corn & the squash!

* Gordita de Picadillo - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=UBW3Asjmih0nARbBNK3oEA#UBW3Asjmih0nARbBNK3oEA
(Fried tortilla pocket, grass-fed beef, potatoes, carrots, refried pinquito beans, queso fresco and salsa de venas. 4.50)
The tortilla is more on the crunchy side, and overall this is a more hearty, heavy, and savory dish, but it all still works pretty well together.

* Birria de Borrego - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=UBW3Asjmih0nARbBNK3oEA#wRy9ecFr-pgtWExj4rJhWw
(Lamb stewed in ancho chile, roasted tomato, sesame seeds, spices, onion, cilantro, rice and salsa milagros. 16.00)
A really, really tasty stew, and the lamb is SUPER tender. The rice is really soft and flavorful as well. The tortilla shells are thick and freshly made.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Thank you Felipe Chavez for creating an unforgettable experience! I will definitely be returning!
author: Breyan D.

description:
7x7 100 Best Things to Eat in SF Before You Die 

2012 - #52 Carnitas at Nopalito
2013 - #52 Caldo Tlapeno at Nopaltio

Me: I will have the Carnitas and the Caldo Tlapeno (chicken consomme)
Waiter: You know that's two entrees right?
My friends: *laughing away*
Me: Yup, I know...I'm a man on a mission! 

I figured I mind as well hit two birds with one stone! =)

The carnitas were tender, moist and exceptional flavorful without the heavy greasy feeling. I enjoyed the accompany pickled vegetables and delicious verde sauce! 

The Caldo Tlapeno had a delicate broth with an interesting medley of vegetables that give the dish many textures to be discovered. It was soup in it's purest form but not something I would go back and try again.

We also ordered Totopos con Chili, Quesadilla de Puerco, Tamal Empipianado Rojo con Pollo, Picadita de Suadero. 

For the most part, everything was executed well and tasted good. 

Overall Thoughts

Carnitas A+!!! It's about time 7x7 and I see eye to eye!
author: Eddie W.

description:
Not bad, not spectacular.

I want to try the mother restaurant but my experience here was good. I wasn't impressed with any of the food. I didn't leave wanting to come back. Maybe I'll need to give this place another chance to try more items.

I think I was rubbed the wrong way a little when my ceviche was supposed to be seafood and it ended up being ALL octopus. I literally couldn't count how many pieces of octopus there was because it was everywhere. I know that's seafood but it's not called octopus ceviche. The flavor was just okay too.

The other cooked plates were good, but not spectacular. 

I'll go and try my luck at Mother Nopa.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
My favorite Mexican restaurant in the city. I love their ceviche. It tasted really fresh, and the thin slices of jalapeño gives it a nice texture and flavors, not spicy at all, so u still can taste the seafood.

I also loved the queso flameado; it's basically flamed melted cheese with chorizo and spices. It's so delicious, so comforting. Omg I want one now!

For the entree, I loved their carnitas. Very simple yet very flavorful. The meat is very tender and juicy. Another main dish that I loved is the Birria de res, which is a braised beef dish cooked with tomato based sauce and spices. It comes with a side of Mexican rice, and for me it's the best Mexican rice I have ever had. Normally a typical Mexican rice is very blend and dry, but the rice here is very tasty and moist. I believe they pan fry it with oil before they serve it (kind of like fried rice?). I'm not sure if this an authentic Mexican rice but it's a damn good one!
author: Sam M.

description: I'm usually pretty underwhelmed by hipster-ized Mexican restaurants, but this place is SO GOOD. Do yourself a favor and eat here asap. We got a variety of dishes and everything was delicious!
author: Lauren N.

description:
Visited this restaurant on vacation with my bf and his brother and I loved everything about it. We got there a little before 2 on a Thursday and we were seated immediately. The decor was a cross between urban and modern. The margarita was strong and delicious. 

We ordered the Totopos con Chile for our appetizer, and it was to die for. Everything we ordered was very tasty, and the staff didn't rush us to leave even after we [attempted to] finished our food. This place is a must visit when in SF. I'd return just to eat here again.
author: Celine F.

description:
We went here while vacationing in SF and we LOVED THIS PLACE. We took advantage of their call ahead policy and placed ourselves on the waiting list so when we arrived we were able to be seated right away. 

My cousin and I decided to share a margarita and they graciously offered to split it into two glasses. My husband tried their housemade ginger lemonade. He enjoyed his and we enjoyed ours. Win/Win. And let me just say that the complimentary crunchy, spiced chickpeas they put on the table are like crack. Seriously, we can't get them out of our heads. Must figure out how to replicate them because I want more desperately.

To start off we ordered the Totopos con Chile ($6.00) to share. It was a very generous portion of tortilla chips, salsa de arbol, cotija cheese, crema and lime. It definitely had some heat but was also extremely flavorful. As an entree my husband ordered the carnitas ($15.50) and said they were possibly the best he has ever had. I  ordered Arroz a la Tumbada ($16.00)  a seafood stew of brown rice, salmon, mussels, shrimp, tomato, onion, morita chile, pickled serrano chile and herbs. It was phenomenal. I would have licked the bowl if i had been eating it at home. My cousin is a vegetarian so the server recommended she try the quesadilla de Primavera. ($ 9.00) which was a corn tortilla filled with asparagus, mushroom, spinach, quesillo, queso fresco, spring onion, cilantro, and salsa de chile puya. She enjoyed it very much. 

We liked Nopalito so much we seriously contemplated going back again before we left town. I just don't have anything bad to say. Service was top notch, the atmosphere was great, the food was incredible all for a very reasonable price. We will definitely be back the next time we are in town.
author: Mimi G.

description: Solid Mexican food in a slightly more upscale atmosphere,  but definitely not pretentious. Shared the torta and pozole with my wife and left perfectly satisfied.
author: Aaron B.

description:
I was very sadly unimpressed with this place. I've been wanting to go here forever but I really don't understand what the hype is all about. 

The food really wasn't that flavorful and it was mostly fried and it left me feeling sick. The Totopos con Chile were pretty good but nothing too special. Chips with salsa, cotija cheese, and sour cream (for $7) overpriced if you ask me. The Empanada con Deshebrada de Res was pretty good - my favorite of the night but I've had better beef empanadas. We also ordered the Quesadilla con Calabaza y Elote Tierno which was pretty good for a veggie quesadilla but once again nothing special. I was also really looking forward to the Tacos Dorados de Papa y Tomate but it really wasn't flavorful again - I wish it was sweeter. The Mexican Cookies they served for free at the end were nice but not very good. 

I will probably give it a shot again since I've heard so much about it. The atmosphere was fun, food was reasonably priced, but at the end of the day it was nothing special.
author: Erica C.

description:
Hanging out with Tasneem and gang. Loved their Horchata , Mole and Ceviche.
They don't take reservations only waitlists.
author: Samreen J.

description: Don't know about the food but had bad experience by using their useless wait list option. There is no point in adding your name to the waiting list. They projected 60 minutes when I called them. So I went to the restaurant after an hour and they asked me to wait for another 30 minutes. Either don't accept wait list or organize better.
author: Alma L.

description:
***Nopalito is an upscale Mexican restaurant from the owners of Nopa; the kitchen utilizes high quality ingredients to create nicely presented and tasty (though maybe not exceptional) Mexican cuisine***

Nopalito is an offshoot of the very popular Nopa restaurant--same owners and a similar name but a much different menu.  While Nopa showcases New American and Californian cuisine, Nopalito features upscale Mexican and Latin cuisine.  This restaurant (this is one of their two locations) has a clean and contemporary look that includes a chef's counter where you get to see obstructed views of the kitchen in action.

Unlike Nopa, Nopalito is open for lunch and their lunch features casual Mexican fare, but more upscale and dinner-esque entrees are also available.  A lot of their plates looked good--their Totopos con Chile looked like delicious and spicy nachos.  Their many tostadas and tacos appeared to be fresh and tasty with all kinds of great textures.  I liked how their lunch menu offered Mexican breakfast/brunch plates too like chilaquiles and a take on huevos rancheros.

I tried a few things and a lot of it was good though not exceptional.  However, ordering other items here might yield a much more satisfying experience.  I started with their complimentary spicy fried chickpeas--addictively crispy, crunchy and a lot of heat.

My first course was a salad of winter citrus (orange, blood orange, grapefruit), avocado, pickled red onions, chile, lime, and queso fresco.  I liked how they were showcasing a seasonal salad at lunch and the citrus was great--bright, sweet, tart, and just the right amount of acid.  I liked the creaminess and freshness of the avocado too.  I wish the cheese had a saltier note.  I also felt the salad needed something crispy or crunchy to balance out the plate.

Next was a corn masa and sweet potato tamale, which was topped with a mole-esque sauce of chile, peanuts, sesame and pumpkin seeds, tomatillo, and onion.  The tamale was good.  It was moist and the corn flavor was really good.  The sweet potato part of the tamale was merely chunks of slightly bland sweet potato stuffed in the tamale.  I thought it was going to have a more pronounced sweet flavor to go with distinct heat and smokiness of the mole-esque sauce.

My next course was a very lightly crispy empanada that was filled with moist grass-fed beef (braised beef).  The filling was good--meaty and moist (very tender beef) that was nicely seasoned.  The empanada was not a traditional empanada shell.  Instead, it was a very thin and crispy shell (very fresh too).  The empanada was topped with cabbage, queso fresco and salsa frita de guajillo.

The lunch ended with a good though small almond butter cookie, which was complimentary.  I do not believe a dessert menu is offered at lunch.

Service was decent.  The food came out at a quick pace and the staff was very attentive; however, while the service was polite and pleasant, it did not feel as friendly and engaging as I have experienced with other restaurants in San Francisco.

Prices felt very reasonable for upscale Mexican cuisine.  A lot of the menu was $10 and below and the portions felt like more than enough food for lunch.

Nopalito is an upscale Mexican restaurant that utilizes high quality ingredients to produce nicely presented and tasty (albeit not excellent) food.  I only tried a small sampling of the menu here and the menu is filled with great sounding dishes and a lot of the food looked great too.  If you enjoy upscale Mexican cuisine and do not mind paying the slightly higher prices (when compared to hole-in-the-walls and not other contemporary restaurants), Nopalito is definitely one to consider for lunch or dinner if you live or spend a lot of time in San Francisco.

Nopalito is part of a retail plaza that has its own free parking lot.  There are not many spaces available though.
author: Anthony N.

description: We come here every time we visit the city, and this experience was well worth it. The Management went above and beyond to make sure that we were taken care of and we definitely will be back! Thank you so much.
author: Torie P.

description: Delicious. I had the Carne Asada. Best ever. Highly recommend. Noisy but fun. Very helpful and friendly staff.
author: Tom F.

description:
While there are many Mexican Restaurants, there are very few that hit this level of authenticity.  The comfy, casual restaurant always seems to have the same couple items with new options offered often. I love the rich flavors, spices and taste an almost home cooked meal. 

The menu isn't the familiar, sure there is ceviche http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=loB7SyTNvNeT15JyVP6ijA and fish tacos http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=i6T2HT0Jr5Dqxzudprn5HQ, but the chiles used in the soup bases will exceed your expectations.

The Caldo de Tlalpeno was flavored with a roasted chile that floated amongst roasted chicken and vegetables. The broth was soothing on a cold night and for only $10, this is a main course.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=T0zZMniJxnPjoubqFrhjmg

The Pozole had a deep chile broth, topped in candy cane beets and served with chips, cilantro and anything else you adorn it with. There is no wrong way to do it. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/055dTcfz2AOAFPed_2KjEQ?select=jnkjWpJceZmkzg27uGAJCA

I always appreciate the flavor over fancy, so I'm glad that Nopalito keeps the gourmet grub inexpensive. Most dishes are between $4-15, which makes it easy to get a couple to share.
author: Rebekah T.

description: The set up is a little confusing. We came late to a reservation, but there was no one outside to greet up or tell us what to do. A lot of people were aimlessly standing around and I couldn't tell if they worked there or not. We walked inside twice and finally had to catch someone like a wild Pokemon to ask where to wait or how to be seated. After that, the experience was much more enjoyable. We were seated right away by the window, which was really nice. We had the taco arabe to start. In hindsight, we really could have ordered just this and be completely satisfied. We were so sad when we finished it! The meat was so warm and soft... I'm drooling just thinking about it! The carnitas was also really good, but I wish it came with more sides. However, the meat was really soft and fall off the bone! The carne asada was really good with the extra tortillas they gave us. Come for a cute dinner! :)
author: Emma P.

description:
I didn't have a good experience in this place. 1st - we arrived at the this restaurant for having lunch and there was nobody in front of us... So instead of the hostess come to talk to us, she was answering phone calls (after seeing us) for reservation and adding them on the list before us. So, we had to wait our turn until she turns off the phone and until there is an available table. 

2nd. The staff used to walk all the time through the restaurant with trash cans... This is very disgusting. 

3rd. I ordered carnita, which was just ok. The whole dish doesn't taste so much. Also empanada is very different from what i am used to seeing: the dough was very greasy.

4th. Except the dark chocolate popsicle, they dont have a dessert menu.  

Not a good restaurant for me, although the waitress was really nice to us.
author: Roberta T.

description:
My and my party of five got there just in time to snag a table at the end of the night. We were given plenty of time to decide what to order, but not so much that we felt abandoned.
The Chincharron taco was TO DIE FOR everyone at my table unanimously decided my order was the best. 
The Bartender, Edgar, made me the MOST AMAZING little tequlia drinks, perfectly balanced and just boozy enough for my tastes. 
Definitely would go again, if only for the salsa sampler!
Excellent food, impeccable service ^_^
author: Alesya J.

description:
I like this location more than the one on 9th street, so this review is specific to Broderick st.

Nopalito is a stand-by for me, whenever I have guests from out of town. The food is reliably excellent and the staff are usually lovely, although service can be somewhat slow when they are busy (and they usually are). I cannot say enough about their tamales -- I dream about them. I wish that was an exaggeration. 

Also worth noting: my mother has celiac disease, and this is one of those places we know she can go and be treated well. With the whole gluten-free fad, servers at some restaurants can be curt or dismissive when we tell them up-front that she really, REALLY cannot have any. Nopalito has many options for her, and perhaps more importantly, servers that are knowledgable about the menu, accommodating, and understanding. Thank you, Nopalito, for always making us feel taken care of!
author: Melinda C.

description:
Pros:
- CARNITAS (so tender, juicy, flaky, and perfect)
- ceviche (flavorful and not fishy)

Cons:
- waiting system is weird (call ahead of time to be put on the list!)
- ginger limeade (it was just alright; something just tasted off about it)

Bottom line: best carnitas I've ever had. I love sharing Nopalito with friends
author: Jiann M.

description: I frequent this location more than the other - it's a bit "younger" feeling and love the atmosphere. Also closer to my house and lots of parking. Check out my other review for dishes and details.. Basically , quesadilla Roja, totopos, tacos de pescado and carnitas. GO!
author: Alyssa H.

description: Great place!! Greater food!! Seven starts not fife  for sure!! Will not be disappointed!! Staff is very professional!
author: Yahia H.

description:
Hmmm... Where to begin?

I went to Nopalito on Saturday with my family and cousins from out of town. The restaurant doesn't take reservations, so we showed up at 3:30 to put our name down for a party of 6. Of course there was a wait, which we expected, so we asked to go to the bar to wait. 

Here's the thing, the bar at Nopalito is pretty much non existent and there isn't much of a waiting space. For a place that doesn't take reservations, you'd expect them to have a solid waiting place where you can grab a drink/apps.

Well my family and I still ended up trying to grab a drink at the barely-there bar where you have to stand, but the bartender (lady with short pixie cut hair) wouldn't even recognize us, let alone look at us for at least 20 minutes. I would understand if she was busy pouring drinks (although a hello would have been nice), but she was just chatting with the other servers. After my mother tried to grab her attention, she was very rude to us, but finally poured us a drink. When we tried to get another round, we had a similar experience and ultimately ended up leaving.

The food here is good, but not good enough for a poor experience.
author: Jalahn W.

description:
Wow what ! This place has some very tasty dishes, mouth watering.

The carnitas dish is cooked perfectly. It comes with picked cabbage , that is a great complement to the pig. 

Fish tacos are amazing as the fish is cooked perfectly, the fish was most and tasty. The sauce on the fish was  just the right seasoning.

The chips and dip was just the right heat with saved cheese as well  a great balance of taste to dance on your tongue.

The service is good and the restaurant is warm with there decorations. They have mirrors on the walls with booths and the green glass lights are a great design element to the restaurant,

Will go again , can not wait til my next visit.
author: P C.

description:
If you like authentic southwestern food... check this place out. Everything from the free spiced chickpea appetizers to the hand crafted 'cocteles' & juicy carnitas, they are doing everything right here. The service could've been better, we did wait for a bit for someone to come over to us - but it's ok because we had a lot of chatting to do.

I just their their lunch for the first time this past weekend and I am so happy I did. It's less crowded and cheaper. I got the Machaca de Camaron con Huevo and my friend got the Enchiladas de Mole con Pollo. Both were very reasonably sized portions. 

I love you Nopalito!!!!
author: Katie P.

description:
Oh Nopalito... never lets me down.  Here are some must-haves:

- Guacamole (obviously)
- Carnitas (the BEST.. good for you paleo folks)
- Tortas (Only tried the ones in Sunset)
- Ceviche (so fresh!)

I usually only go to the Sunset location, but this one wasn't bad. It has a "to go" entrance that can be confused with the main entrance. My one suggestion for the owner... Create a way for guests to get to the bathroom without having to go all the way around the building, outside. Call me lazy, but just seems a little awkward.

Overall, you should come here for the food, and the menu has so much variety; you can't go wrong. Bring friends, have some quality tequila, and eat your heart out!
author: Courtney M.

description:
This just happened to be our first restaurant experience upon entering the city for the weekend. They have a sweet wait list type thing goin on so if you call an hour ahead, it is a smooth arrival. We got seated right away. Ordered the carnitas to share with comes with all the corn tortillas you can eat. It was plenty for me & my beloved to share & we were both famished. The actual meat was tender, juicy, incredibly flavorful, & slightly crispy. Precisely how they should be. 
However, the cabbage salad that comes with it was very astringent & spicy. Some might have a taste for it, but it wasn't our jam. I also would have liked to see more toppings for the actual taco - cotija cheese, spicier salsa, cilantro...& I also prefer flour but they wouldn't let me do that as they only prepare a certain amount every day. 
We also tried the Brussels sprout quesadilla which was unique & tasty enough- but I wouldn't order it again.
My advice, if you love carnitas with toppings & prefer flour, get the marinated pork taco. 
And stick to the classics. All in all, I would definitely come back again.
Also, there is a very convenient parking lot right next door.
author: Sara V.

description:
DELISH! What a fantistic place. I'm so glad I had the chance to go to this adorable Lower Haight restaurant. I ended up here on a late lunch on a Friday randomly just after the holidays with colleagues. Both had dined here and loved it. I love the outdoor seating area it's really cute and almost reminds of a spot you'd see in SoCal or LA. There was a bit of a wait even at 1:30 later lunch time probably because it was still holiday and a Friday. Granted, we waited about 15-20 minutes which wasn't all that bad. I didn't mind at all. 

The food was PHENOMENAL! So much flavor and really still showed you they can do mexican food without an overload of cheese and beans. It was done so right. We started with the Totopos con Chile which was seriously amazing. The tortilla chips and cheese were so good. It wasn't too heavy and one of the best things we ate. It's a great starter and a MUST TRY! It was topped with cotija cheese, lime and their crema. Can't speak more to how good this was and the portion is rather large. I could get full on just this and 3 of us were dining,

We ended up sort of doing family style and ordering a few things to try. I always prefer this when dining. I can never finish a meal on my own. We ordered the fish tacos (which came with 2 tacos) and asked that we order a third. They were fantastic and delicious. I'm a big fan of fish tacos and these just did it. I would highly recommend it.  

I was told to try the carnitas and we ended up getting them. They were delicious just as well. I couldn't have eaten it on my own - way too much food and meat but a few pieces really hit the spot. I would gladly try it again. We also ordered the beet salad to make it a really balanced meal and it was delicious too. I have no compaints about the food - everything was ON POINT!

It was a little slow but I do think it was just busy. We did have a nice waiter and I doubt he was trying to be so slow - but it took quite a while between dishes and overall we spent over 2 hours here. Nonetheless, this is a MUST try in SF and I highly envision going back again.
author: Priya S.

description:
Situation
- Saturday brunch time with a friend
- Ordered Totopos con Chile and Taquitos de Papas Adobodas

Pros
- Ambiance
- The Totopos con Chile was really good
- Decent prices
- Takes credit cards
- The service was good

Cons
- The Taquitos de Papas Adobodas was just okay

Overall
I definitely enjoyed some of the food I had and wouldn't mind trying some other items on the menu.
author: Dipesh G.

description: Excellent restaurant, food tastes great and service is awesome. I've been here a few times for lunch and I'm always impressed.
author: Winston S.

description:
This is a good, "fancier" Mexican restaurant. Few things to call out:

-Most items gluten free. It's a great place to take your friends with Celiac disease. 

-They have a call ahead line. The phone number is 415-535-3969 and using is last weekend I successfully arranged a table for my party of six that involved almost no waiting. 

-I thoroughly enjoyed the braised short ribs my most recent visit. The accompanying house-made tortillas are delicious but rather sadly you only get four at a time and more cost extra. 

-Bar does serve hard alcohol, but basically only tequila. My friend tried to order a rum and coke, and was declined. 

-The chips and salsa appetizer and whatever those spicy nut things are served before the food are crazy spicy. You're going to need your water badly and for goodness sake definitely do not rub your eye after eating either. 

-Save room for the complimentary Mexican wedding cookie at the end! (Not gluten free)
author: Stephanie T.

description:
After a 15 minute wait for a weekday lunch, my friend and I were seated and immediately brought water and a dish of fried chickpeas to snack on while we perused the menu. I decided on the squash blossom quesadilla and my friend ordered the mushroom tamale and beef empanada. I thought the higher price tag of my quesadilla might translate to a bigger portion, but all three dishes were about the same size. My quesadilla was fresh and flavorful. I can't remember the last time I had a quesadilla that didn't weigh me down. I sampled my friend's dishes and neither won me over. The tamale would have been good, but the crema topping had a flavor that reminded me of Elmer's paste (yes, I ate glue as a child). Our check was accompanied by by a dish of small, nutty cookies. A nice sweet end to the meal.

While service was prompt, our meal felt rushed. The restaurant does a brisk business and the high customer turnover made service hurried. Also, the menu felt off balance, not really finding that sweet spot between traditional and creative dishes. That said, if my friend wanted to return I would gladly join her.
author: Nina C.

description:
Stopped by for late lunch while visiting San Francisco. We first tried Nopa but they were closed between lunch and dinner. 
Adam was our server and he was immediately helpful with suggestions of their best dishes. He was also helpful when we were looking for touristy destinations. Best customer service I've had in SF. 
The pork carnitas were excellent and served were a cabbage side and tortillas. 
The pork chicharrone quesadillas were fried and tasted amazing. 
We were so glad to stumble upon this restaurant and would definitely return.
author: Neal M.

description: Great upscale Mexican food. I can recommend the mezcal margarita, the chips with cheese and sauce, ceviche, fish tacos. You have to go outside to the street to get to the bathroom, which is a little odd, but other than that no complaints.
author: Richard K.

description: Everyone has their own palate so please read my review carefully. I normally enjoy spicy food though every dish we had was loaded with hot spices which made it difficult to taste the ingredients. The bloody mary is very smokey and spicy, 1 is all you need. The nachos were good again, just hot!  The pozole was the best part of our meal. I highly reconmend it!
author: Brit B.

description: I loved the ambiance of this place, I loved the service, I loved the concept, and I loved the food presentation.  However, right from the start I was confused by the menu.  The menu had all manner of items from starters to entrees and various price points and it was unclear to me if the idea behind the restaurant was for us to share items, if I was supposed to order multiple items, etc.  We did end up sharing items with our group of four.  The flavors were good, but on the spicy side for us.  I enjoyed the pozole soup, but wasn't a big fan of the taco I ordered and was surprised when it came in a flour tortilla.  The taco was sort of rolled up like a burrito and was the biggest disappointment for me.  The soup was great, the salad was great, and I thought the complimentary wedding cookies were fantastic.  I would go back, but probably not my go-to Mexican restaurant.
author: Ethan F.

description:
I can recommend a bunch of things here. So far everything I've tried has been really good! The staff is friendly and low-key. They don't pressure you but they don't ignore you either. 

Bonus: view of the dmv
author: A R.

description:
The jury is still out on this one. I still can't decide if I like this place or think it's not all that special. Nopalito, I think, deserves another try down the road. For now, here's an explanation for the 3-star rating. 

I recently went in for lunch with a friend. It was a Thursday around lunch hour and it was moderately busy, but definitely not packed. The restaurant was unexpectedly attached to Falletti Foods which threw me off. I was expecting it to be a stand-alone place and not adjacent to a Peet's and a market. Not necessarily a bad thing -- just an observation. Keep that in mind because I was a little confused upon finding this place. 

Anyway, I walk through a door, and woops! It's (I think) the take-out entrance. You have to enter on the Fell St. side (not Broderick). When you go around the corner and find the correct entrance, you briefly walk through a handsome atrium and then a more traditional restaurant set-up. I was immediately met with a server and a hostess. I told them I was waiting for a friend so they took my name in case it got busy. While I waited, I thought it was kind and classy to bring me a glass of water and some spicy chickpeas to pick on while I waited. Definitely did not ask for that, but really appreciated the small gesture. One of the staff, who interestingly enough kinda reminded me of Rick Bayless (of Chicago's Frontera Grill, Xoco, and other restaurants of the Bayless "empire"), warmly welcomed me while I waited. Again, immediate good vibes from the staff.

My friend walks in and we are sat in the atrium area. (There's good lighting there! Perfect for food photo opportunities! Yes, I said it.) We order some libations to get our day going. Yes, we're drinking on a Thursday afternoon, but he and I work very hard. So, why not?I had the El Diablo ($9) which was Pueblo Viejo Blanco, Cassis, lime, and ginger beer. Very refreshing for mid-day, and provided a nice kick! It was perfect to drink when we shared the totopos con chile ($6). Now, let me say, this was quite the shock in terms of presentation... and even value. The table next to us also gasped when they saw this. Granted, this was "just an order of chips and salsa," but a wild version of chips and salsa! The chips were doused in this beautiful red salsa that coated those beautiful corn strands. Yet, amazingly, the chips remained crunchy and firm albeit a bit wet. Hey, I personally like that texture combination. (Reminds me of my days in high school when I was introduced to corn chips and Tapatio shaken in a bag. Don't knock it 'til you've tried it! It's brilliant.) Anyway, the chips had shaved cojita on top and a luxurious crema (that was a little bit on the rich side to be honest, but still delish!). 

For the entrees, my friend and I shared the tacos de pescado al pastor. I liked this, but it wasn't particularly memorable. The fish was nicely cooked, but it lacked that perfect amount of salt. The fresh orange slices added a nice flavor contrast, and you can definitely taste tomatillo. Nevertheless, it was good, but not great. Much to my surprise, I wasn't altogether excited or inspired by the machaca de camaron con huevo y salsa. This cross between a seafood stew and a very wet omelette was also under-seasoned. The overall flavor profile was a bit "boring" to put it crudely. The accompanying corn tortillas were good, but again, nothing particularly spectacular. Now, I don't expect to be "wow-ed" everywhere I go, but for a place regarded by many locals as a "unique place" (I've had several friends recommend it to me), I struggled to find its novelty. 

In terms of service, our server was pleasant and attentive. In fact, it was her who brought me the chickpeas and water at the beginning of this review. Overall, my visit to Nopalito had its pros and cons. The solid service and attention to detail enhanced my experience with mostly pedestrian food. I saw other items on their menu that look delicious so I am willing to visit again another time.
author: James Z.

description:
The Cemita Poblana de Milanesa (Fried Chicken Sandwhich) was wonderful.

And their guacamole is on point, if you like guacamole you won't regret ordering a whole pint.
author: Petar B.

description: Food was fresh and unique while the ambiance can be described as chic  big city neighborhood restaurant.  Yeah, so it is a nice place.  The food was good, but the uniqueness scored more points with me than the overall taste, at least for the fish tacos that I had.
author: Dan O.

description: You are paying for the service and the atmosphere here. I've been about 5 times, and every time I feel a bit disappointed. The portions are small, flavor is hit or miss, and the prices are about double what you can pay at a more authentic taqueria in San Francisco.  I really don't understand why this place is so popular, when there are so many better options for latin american food.  If you are on a date or are taking your mom out, go here for the service and atmosphere. But I think I won't come again.  This goes for this location and the one on 9th ave as well.
author: Jackson W.

description: We had two delicious dinners at Nopalito on a recent trip to SF; I love feasting from the small plates portion of the menu - the entrees are generous portions and it's easy to over-order here. Don't miss out on the ceviche! Also, for vegetarians, Nopalito has a "secret" vegetarian entree that you can ask about, so don't be fooled by the carnivorous main offerings.
author: Sohini R.

description: First time eating at Nopalito...likely not coming back.  Food overall was very bland, lacked flavor, still was super spicy.  The margarita was good but served in a small glass filled with ice, in other words, you pay $11 for a few sips.  The sangria tasted nothing like sangria.  Service was friendly but not super attentive (had to waive to the waiter 3 times).
author: R X.

description:
I think I am the very last local foodie to FINALLY adventure here. Overall the place is fantastic, but I guess because I'm an Oaklander I have a hard time seeing it as "all that" in the context of Nido, Comal, and Cosecha--all closer to home with less of a too-cool-for-school vibe. Or Lolo for an equal competitor in that arena in SF.

Our food was EXCELLENT, our service was uneven, and the front-of-house person could basically "not be bothered," but it was 4 p.m. on a Saturday and who knows whether she'd been dealing with "New San Francisco" DBs all day long, so I can cut her some slack.

I will say--what's the point of advertising that you can call ahead for a wait list add when they don't add you?! Just take reservations or abandon that option if it's really not an option--or rather, an optional option if the person who answered the phone felt like or had time to walk over to write down your name.

My honey and I shared yummy vegetarian plates and walked away stuffed and satisfied. No question this is A+ food. Our issues were never being asked by our server how anything was and having things doled out one at a time. We couldn't have our tamale until our salad was gone, etc. Odd. And if our server had bothered to ask we could have told him this or that our cocktails were yucky.

They need to better call out what is mezcal. Those of us not versed in that vs. tequila can spend a lot of $ on SMOKE SMOKE SMOKE. My partner ordered the mezcal (unknowingly) version of a Bee's Knees, which I drank to save him from the smoke, and I ordered the Diablo, which he drank to save me from the boring. (Very watery and no ginger/cassis coming forward.) Both drinks very unbalanced.

We shared a seasonal salad with everything summer and wonderful--$11 for a large plate of little gems, avo, cuke, stone fruit, etc. etc. Perfect. We followed that with a small on size but BIG on richness and flavor tamale, and then ended with a fresh and amazing blue corn quesadilla with squash blossoms. All expertly prepared and freshest of fresh, but as I mentioned nothing better than our options closer to home. When in SF a great stop to return to, but not a destination in itself.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
