I sampled some of my roommates' enchiladas potosinas de camaron and carnitas. The enchiladas were pretty good, given that I normally do not like enchiladas. The carnitas was exceptional. The braised pork was super tender and flavorful. Plus this dish is super hearty, as it comes with a pouch of warm tortillas to wrap your meat in...(keke). 

Homemade popsicles for dessert? Just lovely. I was fan of the strawberry, which was really fresh and each bite came with a bit of fruit. 

Overall, this was one of the best eating experiences I've had in recent memory. Enough said.
author: Allan Y.

description: Best Mexican food I've had!  Incredible flavor.  Ambiance is great...totally 5 stars!  Try the Chocolate/Cinnamon Popsicle!
author: Michael B.

description:
I followed through on my commitment to try out the actual restaurant.  In your face, judgmental jerks who say I never finish anything I start!  

We called ahead for the waiting list and the place was not that crowded on the Saturday evening so we were only about halfway through a beer before we were at our table for 4.  

I had the empanada again (it was good again), but didn't get to try other things besides their chip app like I planned because the tostada I ordered never arrived.  But I did get another beer that I didn't order.  So the visit wasn't bump free.  

I wasn't that upset though because after a 9 hour day on the bike and wolfing down some emergency pizza at 4:30 I was more thirsty than hungry.  Still Nopalito should probably not make a habit of assuming their guests are fluid starved grazers who don't actually want to eat.

The service (besides that) was really great.  Nice people, the culture of customer service is evident.  I could take a star off for getting my order technically wrong, but I'd have to give it back because they brought all four of us splitting the bill on our cards individual pens!
author: Luke M.

description:
Disappointing lunch. The 3 items we ordered were all dry, lacking in flavor. 

Chicken mole enchiladas: Not much meat. Fairly austere sauce. Tasted like the low-fat version of some better dish.

Chicken pibil: basically a single chicken taco. Not much meat, boring sauce.  The thick tortilla it was on was nice.

Pork sandwich: Dry, lacking in flavor. 

On the plus side, they use a minimum of salt and put sea salt on the table. 
Pretty good service and the kitchen was quick. Flabby, unattractive servers. Nice-looking room with an open kitchen and a view of the Panhandle. 
Whole experience was downhill from what the buzz would seem to promise. I note that Yelp ratings have been on a fairly steady downtrend since sometime in August.
author: John H.

description:
We tried this place with a bunch of friends. The food was good and everyone liked it. Some of our friends are vegetarian and it is not that easy finding a place with vegetarian choices is not that easy in San Fran unfortunately.

We ended up ordering mostly appetizers and were pretty happy with those. Our favorites were the nachos with cheese and the spicy garbanzo beans. The chicken mole was quite tasty too and the rice that came with it was super good. I was missing some kind of vegetables though with my dish.
My husband had the pork and the meat was nice and tender. However, his dish only came with a kind of salad and no rice at all...

What I didn't like was, that they do not take reservations. We had a group of 8 and even though we called a couple hours early to get on their list, they still made us wait more than 45 minutes. I don't like spending my evenings waiting for a table and even though the food is good, it is not worth this long of a wait.
author: Isa T.

description: Totopos con chile is amazing. I will return again and again for this appetizer. Everyone on the staff are very friendly.
author: LT B.

description: Waited a while to be seated but was worth the wait. Carnitas and the margarita is a must!!
author: Maria C.

description:
We were disappointed with our experience here.  We went for lunch on 9/27/14, at about 3 pm. We'd hoped to circumvent all the problems mentioned in other reviews with the wait/list. The first thing we saw when we walked up was a hostess being quite snippy with another party. Although she was fine to us, that wasn't the best first impression. 

We were seated at a communal table--though the hostess hadn't let us know that's where we were headed. Our server was polite enough in greeting us but didn't give her name. When I described reading something on the website about being able to combine the aguas frescas with...maybe the margarita (I said I couldn't remember exactly), she looked at me like I must have been hallucinating and condescendingly told me they didn't have anything like that. After a few more confused seconds, it turned out there was the option to mix the juices with sparkling wine. Now, I'll take my share of responsibility for not knowing exactly what I was talking about, but her attitude was surprising, especially given that they do have an alcoholic/juice mix on the menu. 

We ordered the totopos, the quesadilla de flor de calabaza, and the machaca de camaron.  The totopos were great--a big portion, everything you always wanted Doritos to be that they weren't. We asked for extra sour cream, and were surprised the portion was so small since it was fifty cents. The quesadilla seemed more like a soft taco, with zucchini rather than the butternut squash we expected ( that's on us though--we didn't ask). It was tasty but small for the price. Finally, although the machaca came with four nice corn tortillas, it was not special--I really feel we could make something quite similar with Trader Joe's enchilada sauce, scallions, shrimp & scrambled eggs.

The server who refilled our waters was friendly. A different server came and asked to clear our plates before we were finished, which made me feel rushed. All in all, for $50+ for lunch, we won't be back.
author: S H.

description:
nopalito is easy to miss, because its connected to a grocery store of which the name escapes me. the inside is warm and bustling, and there is outside seating heated by heat lamps. comfortable, very nice ambiance. and good service. and cute shot glasses that look like mini wine glasses. 

as soon as you are seated you are served a small bowl of dried and seasoned garbanzo beans...these were quite addicting

the menu looks inventive and appetizing. it was hard for us to decide what to order. i was soo excited and was certain i was about to have an exciting meal.

ALAS...IN MY DREAMS

what we ordered vs. what we got -- 

what we ordered -- GORDITA GAMPECHANA $4.50
fried tortilla pocket, braised grass-fed beef brisket, chorizo, cabbage, onion, cilantro and salsa taquera de tomatillo

...what we got -- a small, oily, fried tortilla pocket. a few shreds of beef  inside the tortilla that were really bland. nonexistent salsa. dry cabbage shreds filling up half the tortilla. on the side - a tablespoonful of diced onion, sprinkled with cilantro on top.

what we ordered -- TOSTADA CON TINGA DE POLLO $4.50
crispy tortilla, pinquito beans, shredded chicken, tomato, chipotle chile, epazote, cabbage, crema and avocado

...what we got -- a REALLY OILY tortilla. a thin layer of beans spread over half the tortilla. a few pieces of dry, bland, shredded chicken. dry shredded cabbage on top. 3 slices of avocado on top. a few drops of sour cream on top.

what we ordered: QUESADILLA ROJA CON CHICARRON $9.00 (this dish looks soo massive and impressive in pictures. don't be shallow, don't order this)
mulato chile-corn tortilla, crispy pork belly, salsa guajillo, jack cheese, queso fresco, onion and cilantro

...what we got -- a hefty and EXTREMELY oily tortilla that had NO flavor and was dripping oil. all the tortillas were HELLA bland. a few spoonfuls of tasteless, shredded pork in the tortilla that wasn't fatty or crispy at all. :( some cheese. it appears that they do not like to give you any sorts of extras on the side such as even a dab of sour cream or some guacamole.

what we ordered -- CEVICHE VERDE DE PESCADO Y CALAMARE $10.00
marinated rock cod, calamari, lime, tomatillo, jalapeño, cilantro, avocado and tortilla chips

...what we got -- green salsa with raw squid tentacles (sooo not my thing) and a few small pieces of rock cod. a few slices of avocado. the thick tortilla chips were actually the highlight of our entire meal.

if you didn't read my sad descriptions, this is all you need to know -- 

OUR FOOD WAS FACKING OILY. there was orange grease relentlessly dripping from the quesadilla and gordita...oil ran down my fingers, whenever i picked something up to take a bite :( 

OUR FOOD WAS SO BLAND. we felt the need to squeeze lemon juice onto everything we ate and it still didn't help. it was like eating cardboard the entire meal...i'm being completely serious. 

i don't like eating cardboard.

people apparently seem to be impressed with the carnitas and carne asada. unless i am oblivious to some cryptic secret of nopalito, i am very skeptical that they are the LEAST bit tasty. if the appetizers were so bland...there can't be that big of an improvement in the entrees. 

at least there were complimentary almond cookie balls for us at the end.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I love my neighborhood, and Nopalito is a wonderful recent addition.
I was anxious to try the Nopa counterpart, as I heard from my old roomie how good the food is, and also looked up the reviews of my fellow yelpers.

It was a rainy Sunday afternoon, and since Nopalito doesn't take ressies, I decided to call and put my name down on the wait list. The friendly gal on the other end of the phone said if I got there in 20-30 minutes, finding a table wouldn't be problematic, but she still took down my name and digits. She also assured me that parking shouldn't be a problem as ample spaces (for unlimited hours) are available at the Falletti Foods garage. SWEET! Usually, I'd walk but since it was pouring rain outside, I decide to be a lazy arse and drive!

I met my lunch date, and notice the vacant tables in the outdoor patio area. We sit down at a table that was directly under a heat lamp. I was a bit warm under the heat lamp, but not totally uncomfy, as I enjoyed being outside to watch and hear the rain fall and not get wet. Anywho, my date and I were so engrossed in our convo that we had our server, Anne, stop by at least 2 times and we still hadn't quite decided what to order. She let us know that we could flag her or the other server, also named Anne, when we were ready. So, after Anne #1 gives us fried seasoned garbanzo beans on the house, I ask her to take our orders of the Enchiladas de Mole con Pollo - Tortillas with mole poblano, shredded chicken and queso fresco; and Carnitas - Long braised pork, orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer. Cabbage salad, pickled jalapeños, tomatillo salsa.
To accompany our lunch entrees, we order a few beers from the fine selection of draft and bottled beers.

The food arrived within what seemed like 5 minutes, and I thoroughly enjoyed my chicken enchilada. The mole sauce was savory with a spicy kick to it and the chicken, which was shredded, was tender and flavorful. The carnitas were served with fresh, warm tortillas, which my date really enjoyed.

The service was outstanding, and seemed like whenever we needed a water refill, one of the Annes was there to refill our glasses or our water carafe. We never felt like we were bothered or rushed, which was so nice. It was a very lovely, easy Sunday afternoon lunch.
Before we got our bill. Anne #1 dropped off some powdered almond cookies. They were so yummy and the perfect sweet to end the savory and mildly spicy meal.

Nopalito is such a casual, yet still manages to be a fine dining experience. It's much smaller and prices are cheaper than NOPA, but you still get that same comfortable vibe. The set up is great with the outdoor patio seating and the indoor seating with the kitchen and counter in plain view.  Service is outstanding, with friendly and efficient servers. The food is fresh and can really taste the quality ingredients. I'll definitely be back to try their other entrees, and look forward to their to-go service when its ready.
author: Gill C.

description:
Ay dios mío, the folks at Nopa have done it just right with Nopalito! It's a complete departure, not just in terms of cuisine (Mexican), but in style (casual, family), price (noticeably less), occasion, and these are all good things. 

It's a small space that can seat maybe about forty people, and given its current popularity, you should almost expect to wait during peak lunch and dinner hours (they have a semi-enclosed patio to hang out in). 

Everything is extremely fresh, and you can taste it with each bite. Our waitress was more than ready to offer up some suggestions, and easily my two favorites were totopos con chile and the carnitas. Well, the enchiladas de mole were another flavorful surprise.  

While they have some top notch beers and wines to choose from, I went with one of their housemade non-alcoholic options, the grapefruit-piloncillo, which was a perfect thirst quencher. 

Can't wait to head back, and to all the staff, I apologize on behalf of our son Dash for his uncanny ability to get most of his rice and beans on the floor as opposed to in his mouth (he also likes their quesadilla de acelgas!).
author: Nish N.

description: This place is ok at best. The reservation method they use is very strange. You call, ask them to put you on the list, they text you 45 minutes or so later to let you know your table is almost ready, you check in with the hostess, only for her to tell you it will be a bit longer (like 15 min longer). It's communal seating, which is fine, but they pack you in like sardines and you feel like you are on top of the person next to you. The food is ok not great. Can't see myself shlepping across town to eat here again. So many other better places without the chaos. BTW, the woman who I believe is the manager is so rude and just flat out arrogant.
author: N R.

description: Wow, I love this place.  Whenever I'm in SF I make point to come for lunch.  This trip was the best yet!  The chicken mole is always the very best.  The vibe from the staff is terrific and they all seem to really love being a part of the experience.  ( with one exception on the day.  Maybe she was just having a bad day, fortunately I had little to do with her.  I Hope her day gets better).  The bartender took pride in the fresh juices and drinks that she created.  She hand delivered mine. As always a terrific experience and Meal.  I'll be back.
author: Mimi C.

description:
Pooooooooooooooooooooooooork! Their carnitas that is. Drinks, service, direction of the food, everything is great.

I am looking forward to their new place in my hood sometime this Fall, indeed!
author: Joe Bob J.

description: The food is five stars, no doubt about it. The service was aloof. Perhaps the staff were ready for the night to end. We did arrive later. But seriously, we each tasted heaven in our mouths repeatedly. We almost gave up on going here, as our gps led us astray and we walked for just short of an eternity. Our appetites were not shy upon arrival. Just good. That's all.
author: Holly L.

description:
Love this place.

I like to call it white people's Mexican food. Definitely more upscale than anything you'd find in the Mission. And you pay for it. But don't worry, the restaurant is conveniently located right next to a BofA.

They don't take reservations, so call ahead and put your name on the list. Definitely worth the wait. And they have plenty of parking in the structure next to the restaurant.

I always order the carnitas, tamal, and pork belly quesadilla. Those are my Nopalito staples and I've never been disappointed. They also have a great selection of Mescal and salsas.

It's one of my favorite places to take my out-of-town friends and family. So far, no one has been disappointed. The only thing they've been disappointed by is the wait to be seated and the check that I stick them with at the end of the meal.
author: Page K.

description:
5 stars for everything. Food, service, taste, everything. All organic Mexican food.

We arrived at 950 and they were not seating anymore. Our sad faces got to the hosts heart and he said "please have a seat, and please order quickly." We were ESTACTIC. Not only that, but when we ordered, he said to take our time eating and not to feel rushed. What service right before closing.

We ordered the favorites:
- Taco de Pescado al Pastor
- Carnitas
- Tamal Enchilado de Queso y Puerco
- Ceviche Verde de Pescado

They served fried garbanzo beans that are like corn nuts but even more addicting and delicious. The tamal enchilado is my favorite. The cheese pairs perfectly with the meat. The Carnitas is also yummy and fattening, but so delightfully flavorful. The taco del pescado is good too, but I was fine with just a tasting. And the ceviche is not that authentic, but still refreshing with the mozzarella cheese. 

I can't wait to come back to SF and eat more here.
author: Debby L.

description:
Four of us went for dinner at the Broderick St. location this evening.  First, we were disappointed by how few of the items were vegetarian, and hardly any (if any) were vegan.
We had the few vegetarian items on the menu plus the fish tacos.  Everything was fine, but perhaps we were expecting far more than fine for a restaurant rated one of the top 100 in San Francisco.  It made us think that there must not be that many great restaurants in the area for this to make the list.  
Just for comparison's sake, we LOVE Oyamel in Washington, DC.  Now that is a Mexican restaurant worth spending your money on.  All the stuff at Nopalito was stuff I could VERY easily make at home.  
THe place has zero ambience; there is nothing to recommend it in terms of looks.
I will say, on the positive side, that our waiter was charming and adorable.
author: Amy S.

description:
Amazing food.  Can't praise them enough.  Best Mexican food I've had that wasn't in Mexico.  Sort of pricey but definitely worth it.  Always impressed by their hand-made tortillas and omg, those esquites!  My boyfriend and I always order a bunch of things to share so we've pretty much had it and liked it all.  I don't really like spicy food but I make an exception for this place.  

The service is also really good.  Always friendly and the one time we had a complaint (no chicharrones on a chicharron quesadilla) our server immediately apologized and offered to replace it.  

Visitors are always taken there and we've never had anyone refute our claim that it's the best Mexican food north of the border.  I am Mexican and spend about 1/4 of the year there so I feel pretty confident in saying that. 

Some advice though: their micheladas are really heavy and spicy.  Combined with the spice of the food, I had a stomachache the first time I dined there.  It says something that I was willing to go back after that. 

Also, for those complaining about the wait- they don't take reservations but they do allow you to call ahead and put your name on the waiting list as well as give you a time estimate.

If you're in the area, you have to come here.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Anahi G.

description: This place is mhmm mhmm tasty. I had the Quesadilla Rosa which was incredible. Tasted authentic and had so much flavor.
author: Maey P.

description:
Yummy town! this place is so good. whether youre flying on the cheap ($2.50 modelos and snacks between 5 or 8 bucks), or dining big, they have all options. i love the torta and the chips with the cream. i hardly ever try anything else. my previous love was the chicken MOLE which they altered and while its good, its not the same... 

i also really enjoy the atmosphere here...families, dates, dogs, and no one is presumptious. love it when the little hood of "nopa" delivers :)
author: Carolina S.

description:
I went there for the first time this week after someone I know was raving about it.  I was kinda disappointed.  We ordered the Chicken Mole, veggie quesadilla, totopos, hibiscus/juice drink, and an almond horchata.

I wasn't stoked about the mole.  They seared the chicken, so it tasted a lot like blackened chicken with a mildly spiced sauce thrown on top.  I enjoy chicken mole that's falls apart at the touch of the fork and has some zing.  The rice was just alright too.

The quesadilla was nothing like a traditional quesadilla.  In fact, it reminded me of a large taco that was awkward to eat.

The totopos were alright, but they reminded me of a hybrid of Chile Fritos and Doritos.  

The best part of our meals were probably the drinks.  The Almond horchata was just sweet enough, and hit the spot.

I don't think I'm going back there again.  In a city stacked with great Mexican cuisine, I'd rather go elsewhere.
author: Lyz L.

description:
Nopalito was just okay for me. I came here for a late lunch with the boyfriend, and to say that we were starvin' would be an understatement. 

Once we sat down ( you can sit anywhere, btw) I was upset that they didn't offer complimentary chips and salsa. I didn't see any seasoned garbanzo beans, that other reviews mentioned, either. I was surprised since pretty much any taqueria and Mexican restaurant give you chips and salsa. 

We ordered the taquitos to start with, and we both really liked those. The ingredients tasted fresh and the salsa verde was good. I felt that it needed like a glop of pico de gallo or something on top though. 

We also ordered the chilaquiles and the huevos de caja. The portions were on point and everything tasted good. It was pretty mediocre and I STILL felt that there needed to be something added to up the flavor. 

It was an overall good experience at Nopalito, and the service was great, the food just needs a pinch of a little somethin' somethin'.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here for lunch and I wanted to try everything on the menu. After coming back from Mexico City the month before I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food was. Its authentic Mexican food but with an SF twist. 

The wait wasn't bad either. It was around 1:30 PM on a Sunday and my friend and I got seated within 10 mins. of arriving.
author: Eduardo R.

description: Lovely space, but over-priced for what it is, and scant by way of vegetarians.  They were kind enough to make a veggie version of their chicken mole dish, but the mole was salty and tasted of molasses.  The margarita was fine, but cost $9, and was over-priced.  Service was a-ok.  Overall, there is cheaper food of the same caliber elsewhere.
author: Elle T.

description:
Went here because most of their menu is gluten free.  Yeay! +1 star
Service is not good, walked in to a half empty restaurant on a Saturday night yet we were told by a pretty arrogant hostess that all the tables were reserved, so we had to eat at the bar.  She indicated that we had to sit at the end of a long table facing each other.  Hmm OK lady, the bar is half empty too, but whatever.
Server explains that some dishes are not GF so I take out a pen to mark which ones we can't look at but he said I can't mark his paper menu because he can't afford to replace it. Ughhh - by now I want to leave, but don't want to look for another GF spot so we just say bring us your top 4 small menu items that are GF.  Here's what we got:

Totopos: glorified chips and salsa.  Each chip was covered with sticky sauce, hard to eat - who wants to eat chips with a fork? And really not that good.  Wouldn't recommend

Ceviche on a tostada - yummy, absolutely delish

Quesadilla with zucchini flowers - ewww this was just plain gross, bad flavor and yucky texture inside that made it hard to even swallow the bite I took.

Corn covered with cheese and salsa - ok, decent flavor but nothing too great.  Basically corn peeled off the cob with cheese and salsa.

My hubby had the worst sangria we've ever tasted - really, stay away.

Overall this place is super pretentious, half the place stayed empty throughout our entire meal yet we couldnt sit at a table and the food is barely OK.  If you are not pressed to eat here because of GF there are many other better places out there.
author: Lili C.

description:
I love that they use high-quality, sustainable ingredients.  Their carnitas are some of the best, if not THE best, I've ever had.  Ceviche is fantastic...and I LOVE ceviche.  I also had the empanada which I found to be scrumptious.  Plus, they bring you these delectable little Mexican almond cookies at the end of your meal.

I love this place because you can get a bunch of  small things or a large plate (or both) depending on your mood.

I'm a fan.
author: Laura L.

description:
Home of the "Bullshit Seating System".

While this restaurant has excellent food your very first encounter (unless you call ahead) is their blatant disregard for customers. We walked up at 2:30p on a Saturday afternoon with 2 visibly empty tables for 4 and were asked if we called ahead. We said no and were told it was a 45 minute wait. As my husband was insistent on trying this place out we waited. In 45 min, the hostess turned away 4 groups of 4 guests who "walked up". Meanwhile as we were sitting there 3 parties walked up who had called ahead - one group of 10 and 2 groups of 4. Two of the parties with a group of 4 were both reprimanded for arriving late and not responding to being called by the restaurant. This all happened as we were starving, waiting and seeing empty tables stay empty for a good 25 minutes. Shouldn't we have been seated and fed by then and let these people wait the 15 minutes for us to finish? Oh NO not at Nopalito. Instead after the stern reprimand, they immediately walked in like they were gold.

The food is excellent, albeit a bit one-note with the heavy handed use of one specific spice but there's enough variety in the menu to keep it interesting. Look at the photos and other reviews to see how good the food is.

In the end, I remember the awful first impression (hello Nopalito get a clue) of giving priority to customers who weren't there over customers ready to eat and spend money. I certainly hope they get their act together. Or do as the others do. Call ahead, put your name on the list, roll in late and still get to cut everyone else there.
author: Meg W.

description:
First off, they have popsicles (huh?) that are ridiculously good. We have even stopped to get them on the way home. There is a chocolate one that will knock your socks off. 
Carnitas are good. Drinks are good. Totopos (chips) are good. Anything with eggs is good. Like the vibe too.
author: Bing B.

description:
I cant really say anything bad about this place, it was pretty good.  I thought the empenadas and ceviche were pretty good, but was not impressed with the mole chicken plate.  

I went at dinner time and was not super enthralled with the atmosphere.  I could see this being a really nice lunch spot.  

 All in all - solid, but nothing to write mom home about.
author: Aasim K.

description: Some of the servers here were really snobby like their food was super awesome but I was not impressed at all. You could tell the ingredients were good quality but the result was blah. They seem like they're trying really hard to be cool but I'm not buying it.
author: The Coach 1.

description: Door lady was incredibly rude and told us the wait was 1hr which grew to 1.5 hrs despite the fact she promised us a table after thirty minutes. She then let 3 four tops ahead of us and when we asked what the deal was she said we did not have a complete party so she was not sitting US.  If we had not asked we would have never been sat. A four top and a 3 top is the same in my book. She did not use eye contact and did not ever apologize or make us feel she cared about our experience at all. Worst service and incredibly rude staff. Makes the good taste bad. Also charge extra for sauce which is tacky.
author: Eileen M.

description:
I practically inhaled my glass of Allagash white when the drinks arrived, so by the time the beet salad came out, I was a darn dipsy asian girl with no real alcohol tolerance. So my review may be a bit biased due to inebriation. But in a good way. 

The quesadilla roja con chicharron was a pure dream, and the two-color beet salad was a tasty starter. My ling cod with olives and capers was tasty and pretty strong in flavor. Usually I avoid tortillas but I happily wrapped the cod, olives, and capers in the tortillas and it was delicious! The service was nice and the food quite tasty. We are definitely coming back for more. I want to try the ceviche -- they had run out of it by 9PM on a Sunday night.
author: Angie C.

description: If you like Mexican- You got to be here! My previous office was just 2 streets down this place and we group of colleaguesoften used to come here for lunch. I'm not much fond of Mexican food, but eating out in a place like this made me fond of the cuisine to a certain levels.  There is no trend of reservation or long queues. The staff is quite accomodaitng, especially if you're their regualr cusomer. The menu has a vareity of food options to explore, and the price is reasonable too. And wht's better, you can always order a glass of wine or cold beer with your meal, if you don't intend to go back to the office. :p
author: Dinkar K.

description: Definitely give it 5 stars. Never heard of it before but I was walking through exploring the city and stumbled upon it. Not very big but service was great. Seated upon arrival, drinks brought promptly, didn't wait long for the order to be brought out but food was delicious and fresh! Split the carnitas and the quesadilla rojo con chicharron which were both amazing! Prices were very reasonable! Definitely coming back next time I'm in town!
author: Julie N.

description:
I don't know what to tell you that hasn't already been mentioned.

Except the Pozole, I didn't see anyone mention that which is a shame because it's a little smoky and the hominy is toothsome but not tough and it's overall pretty pleasant eating.

And the beef empanada, which is delicate and done perfectly.The chicken tamale with mole on top is good but not a stand out so I can see why it hasn't been mentioned. yet. Not that it isn't worth trying. 

Someone mentioned that the serve micheladas, but no one has commented on the conspicuous absence of those bud light & clamato cocktails on the menu. 

Lots of people have written about how busy it gets, and how you may end up waiting even though it looks like there are tables available, so I don't have much to add there.

In fact, just read the other reviews and skip this one. I'll try harder next time. sorry.
author: matthew r.

description:
Given the number of Yelp reviews for Nopalito, I don't expect my two cents to add a lot of differentiation or value for that matter.  This place is a gem as I find it to be fairly unique to SF with super high quality food that rarely disappoints.  I wish they had more chicken oriented items at times but this is just me.  I have driven across town just to pick up the totopos on numerous occassions.  The grocery store next door is a sleeper with amazing prepared foods and Humphrey Slocombes if you are looking for a twofer.
Nopalito on my short list for out of town people plus the NOPA area is fun for a walk around.
author: mike s.

description:
Supernommy. As in delicious. I am obsessed with this place, can't wait to go back! I don't know about these haters, but this place is both authentic (my roommate just went with a friend who is from Mexico, and he gives it the thumbs up) and gives the twist of innovation that comes with fantastic San Franciscan flair. I went in December, and I'm writing this review in May, and I still remember this tamale that was like a sweet potato infused into a tamale, that was also sweet corn, and a delicious tamale... truly one of my most memorable meals in SF.  I like that it doesn't take reservations also because it keeps the atmosphere unpretentious and more casual than its counterpart, NOPA, where it can be difficult to get a reservation within the month.   
Also I've seen some reviews below, and one person went to this place expecting tapas.  If you go to this place expecting tapas (and not in an appetizer-like way), you are wrong.  Tapas are Spanish, and this is a Mexican restaurant.  They are different countries (Spain, Mexico) on different continents (Europe, North America) with different cuisines. 
Please don't let my betchiness in pointing out that last obvious fact deter you from checking out Nopalito!
author: Dana B.

description:
Brought to you by the awesome team behind Nopa, Nopalito finally makes its long-awaited debut next to Falletti's.  This means free parking and easy access to groceries in addition to delicious and authentic Mexican cookery.

We stopped by on opening night around 7:45pm to a 1.5 hour wait; night #2, with many friends of the house still arriving, was much more resonable at a 15-20 minute wait.  They have heat lamps and gladly serve drinks as you bide the time on the patio.

The greeter carries with her probably the most amiable babe in arms ever, and it makes you happy that establishments with such family-friendly policies for its employees exist.

On to the food:
Amuse: fried spiced chickpeas. (Nopa style) 

There is a list of smaller dishes ranging from $4-9.50.  In the $4 range, Totopos (house-made chips) with spicy chiles de arbol or the amazing Tamal de Hongos y Huitlachoche (Mushroom + Corn Truffle Tamales).  On the higher end is the Quesedilla de Acelgas (Erbette chard and jack cheese, queso fresco), $8; and the Quesadilla Enchilada con Guiso de Puerco (Pork Belly, jack cheese, guajillo salsa), $9.

For mains ($11-$14) the husbear chose Enchiladas Placeras - Pan-seared ancho chicken breast and tortillas, potatoes, carrots and queso fresco. A note - their house pickled carrots were *very* spicy that evening -- even for someone who likes spicy food ($13).

I chose the Birria de Chivo: Goat stewed in chiles, spices, chocolate, with roasted pinquinto beans and salsa de arbol ($13). Delicious tender goat (tastes like beef) in a marvelous sauce served with a nice vinegary, spicy salsa.  Take your tortillas, dab in a bit of salsa and add the beans and goat.  Try not to drip. 

Complimentary dessert bite: Mexican wedding cookie (cinnamony)!

Note that anything with arbol chiles are bound to be a tad hot on your tongue... but the flavours are wonderfully rich and complex.

Take out  and lunch service are scheduled to arrive in a couple of weeks.  For now - make sure to arrive with an appetite (you'll want to sample everything) and patience.  The resto is small, and you'll likely share a 5, 6, or 8 top with other folks.  It's definitely worth it, however.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Lunch Gem!
The Huevos de Caja is so so good. I could eat it every morning forever.
author: Ryan L.

description: I expected better food from this place but some of the dishes needed a tad more flavor.  I had the carnitas, which were a little too dry but the cabbage salad was pretty good.  Had a bite of the shrimp enchiladas, which were pretty tasty. Also, I've had better Micheladas elsewhere...it was a bit bland here.  Nonetheless, I give it 2.5 stars because they strive for organic Mexican food and much of it is made from locally sourced ingredients.  I would come here again to give it a second try.  Any how, the company I was with totally made up for the average food.
author: MyGirl L.

description:
VERY impressed.
Service was very friendly.
The menu was delightful.
Already thinking of my next visit.
The carnitas dish was enough to split three ways.
A friend almost drowned in his bowl of chicken pozole it was so big.
And the red quesadilla in tortilla mulatta was divine.

Almond cookies for dessert on the house.  Coffee was delicious, and comes in press-pot which was a nice touch.

The layout is a bit wonky.  The entrance from the street is for the take-out window.
To get into the restaurant, enter from the parking lot.
author: Ken B.

description: Fantastic food. We had to wait a long time before we were seated, but it was a Friday night. The portions are a little small for the price, but the quality definitely makes up for it.
author: Dylan H.

description: Totopos con chile, pork belly quesadilla, sangria are my faves!  Consistently good food with good service.   You can't go wrong.
author: Em D.

description:
The sister restaurant of Nopa (also in NoPa) serves up equally delicious food with a Cal/Mex slant.

Served Tapas style in a pretty casual atmosphere, the variety of small dishes we tried were all pretty tasty.

Lots of lime, corn masa, and chili flavors permeated most of the dishes, and all had a very light and fresh taste. 

Would definitely try the place again, and recommend it to anyone in the area.
author: Raza M.

description:
I popped into Nopalito for a lone lunch late on a Thursday afternoon. I sat at the counter and enjoyed the easygoing vibe of the place. The waitress/bartender helped guide me through the menu, and in the end I ordered the totopos con chile (chips unlike the typical bowl you get at a Mexican restaurant) and gordita (no, not like Taco Bell). Both were delicious with authentic flavors and preparation - a very nice change from the normal SF taqueria (nothing against those, this is just different).

At the very off-peak hour I was there, service was super quick - and you could fill up on the cheap. But I imagine this place jumps off on weekends and peak weeknights, and as the booze flows, your check - not so cheap.
author: Kiesha R.

description: I'm not usually a fan of Mexican food, but this place was really really good! I made a reservation for a party of two on a weekend, and good thing I did! It was packed when I got there around lunchtime. My boyfriend and I ordered huevos de caja and the carnitas. Huevos de caja was my favorite!!! I've never before had anything like it. For those who don't know what that is, it was refried black beans, poached eggs, salsa de cilantro, and jack cheese on a corn tortilla. The carnitas fell apart and melted in your mouth. MmmmMmm gooood. Last but not least, we ordered the oaxacan style horchata, which is basically horchata with some strawberry pureé. It was delicious! and the waitress recommended it as a dessert actually so that's what we did. I was so bloated after this meal. And to top it all off they gave us complimentary cookies at the end. Prices were reasonable, would definitely come back!
author: Amanda C.

description: My favorite restaurant of all time. Totopos are amazing! Can you guys open up a location in Boston? I'll miss this restaurant tons.
author: Christine L.

description: I AM IN CHOCOLATE HEAVEN!!!  Just had one of their homemade dark chocolate popsicles--so very yummy.  Made up for the rather underwhelming meal.  I am a huge fan of NOPA, having been there many times so I had pretty high expectations for this "spin-off," but I think it was the case of having too high of expectations.  Pricey mediocre Mexican food.
author: C L.

description:
Amazing mexican food,

Is the brother of the restaurant "NOPA", and as the brother, really good.

Delicious mexican food, and is not usual, but not very heavy.

We order the some calabacin tacos, quesadilla de carnada and huevos a la cazuela. Everything really good. If you like mexican food you should stop by and try it!
author: Alejandro G.

description: Everything here is delicious and there are many healthy options. The subtle chocolate flavor makes anything made with mole worth trying. The natural design and decor creates a beautiful ambiance. The shaded patio is wonderful on a nice day. The margaritas are a bit pricy but very good.
author: Megha V.

description:
I had the pork belly sandwich.  It was okay.  The sauce kinda overpowered the flavors
The place is pretty noisy.
Best part is the free parking.
author: Julie G.

description: This was the first restaurant we dined in when we arrived in San Francisco at the beginning of the summer. The Carne Asada was great, and so were the margaritas. The staff, though overwhelmed with many customers, were very polite and attentive. I would have liked more menu choices, especially for entrees, but it was a great introduction to the food scene in San Francisco for sure!
author: Ezgi A.

description: Place atmosphere is supposed to be cozy but me and my boyfriend were sat at the bar on stools with no backs *hence I have back problems already* I was literally sitting on top of this random girl next to me. I think since the debut of the show on food network the place has just molded into a stereotypical san francisco restaurant organic with bland tasting food. I ordered the pizole they literally handed me a water down bowl of oil and made it worse by bringing out a separate place full of spices I was unaware I was supposed to prepare the food myself! It's highly overrated and nothing I tried was tasteful!
author: Bianca R.

description:
Great food & warm atmosphere! We had the Totopos con Chile, Taquitos de Camote & Enchiladas Potosinas de Camaron which were all amazing.

Also tried the Michelada beer- NOT A FAN. The housemade beverages, Hibiscus-Valencia Orange, was OK but bitter.

The waitress was very nice and prompt; she even removed the beer from our bill once she saw we were not enjoying it. I would recommended trying this place at least once!
author: Shelly W.

description:
The food is always delicious, but sometimes the service is awful enough to affect your whole night. 

A story: after waiting two hours, the waitlist manager called to tell us we had 15 minutes to arrive. We got there well within the window 12 minutes later, and they already gave away our table! We had a party of six, so we had to wait another hour. When it's crowded, they lose track of details and really go downhill. 

Somehow, they still haven't lost me, though. Carnitas, fish tacos, empanadas, and mole are my favorites.
author: Kristen C.

description: Very reasonably priced! The staff was accommodating to our large group. The food was excellent and very dense in protein which was PERFECT for my Paleo brunch-mate. We will definitely be back!
author: Brandon G.

description:
Nopalito is not your typical Mexican restaurant. It prides itself on its use of local, organic, and sustainable ingredients and this is apparent in the flavor and color of their dishes. 

This is a review of their Brunch Menu.

Came here for late lunch (linner) this past weekend and we were seated quickly by a really nice waitress. Here's a breakdown:

Pre-meal snack: These yummy but spicy garbonzo beans. I have a pretty low spice tolerance but these were tasty regardless. I would've been content with a bowl of tortilla chips, but Nopalito does things their way!

I got the Quesadilla con Flor de Calabaza (9.00):
"Corn tortilla, squash blossoms, zucchini, jack cheese, queso fresco, cilantro and salsa de tomatillo y chile puya." It was the perfect size for me and the veggies were fresh and flavorful, not to mention really nice to look at. It came with a house-made salsa that wasn't spicy (thank god, i would have cried) and it had a slight smokey flavor. Very unique and very tasty. Those with a larger appetite might not feel like they got a good bang for their buck but it was perfect for me.

My date got the Huevos de Caja (9.00"):
"Poached eggs, refried black beans, corn tortilla, jack cheese and salsa de cilantro" Of course I had to taste some before he doused it in a habanero salsa that would have literally sent me to the hospital (my eyes watered just smelling it) but if you like spicy, apparently it's delicious! The eggs were poached nicely and this is also a unique and flavorful dish. 

Margerita (i dont remember which one i got): STRONG. just how i like it

They brought out these complimentary bite sized cookies for dessert which were really good but would be better if i were drinking tea....

So if you're looking for your typical greasy and cheap Mexican food joint (which sounds gross typing out, but when eating, is delicious) then Nopalito is not for you. If you want a unique and fresh Mexican dining experience and don't mind spending the extra cash, then head straight to Nopalito! Great place for dates!

And the Peet's next door has the COOLEST baristas if you want a post-meal coffee or tea---a suuuper cute boy used to work there but i haven't seen him in a while. sad:(
author: An-Nhien L.

description: This place is so good. We sat in the bar. Our server/bartender Edgar was amazing. Very attentive and quick to suggest good things to try I had the Brussels sprout quesadilla and the empenada. Both amazing we also had bloody marias to drink which were also delicious. They have a salsa sampler platter which was also very good. Great variety and I highly recomend this place. Thanks Edgar for a fabulous dining experience
author: Heather K.

description:
If you like pork you'll like Nopalito. Two of us ate at the bar and stuffed surgeon a variety of pork dishes. Keep in mind that I'd just come from a bbq so yes, the food was very good.

One additional note:  the bathroom setup is odd, but waiting outside isn't the worst thing because the restaurant, especially near the kitchen, can be quite warm.
author: Mike H.

description:
El Diablo - 5 stars! refreshing and delicious

Taquitos de pato - 2.5 stars.  the duck confit inside was too tough.  all the sauces in and on top of it tasted awesome though!

Torta Chilorio - 4 stars.  i thought the flavors were great.  the husband wasn't wowed by it though.

Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron - 4.5 stars.  crispy goodness.  saw this on diners, drive-ins and dives and is really the reason why we came here.  it didn't disappoint.
author: G. P.

description:
I heard a great deal of hype about this place. It was really a very chic set up but the food was only ok. I LOVE mexican food. I love it flavorful and spicy and just absolutely DELICIOUS. I had the enchiladas, which were only ok. I am not sure I was the biggest fan. I also tried the Empanada which was, honestly, quite delicious. Not the typical mexican haunte, but it was a fun experience.  

(+) Parking is easy, available and free.
(-) The wait is obnoxiously long and the food is nothing to write home about.
author: Suravi T.

description: Who cares if they don't take reservations....  The food and the service is so out of this world!  This place is a must!  #iammexicantoo  #luvuguys
author: Carlos A.

description:
I am in love with the food here.  
Service is great, drinks are great and the food is amazing!   The Carnitas looks amazing, but haven't tried it yet.
author: Matt V.

description: Arrive on weekend for lunch, with no line at all. Food was great and the server constantly checking in. All food order were tasty and moderate in portion. Not too much, but not too little. The atmosphere were comfortable and very enjoyable overall. Will definitely recommend to try out.
author: J Y.

description: Farewell casual dinner with 5 girlfriends. We wanted to order a jug of sangria but decided to taste it first. The white sangria tasted ghastly so we each opted for individual drinks. How can one go wrong with Sangria!!! We ordered a guacamole for the table which was very mediocre... When we asked to order a 2nd one  the waiter told us that they were out at avocado. It was only 9pm in the evening. Food overall was VERY average. I would sooner go back to rosa Mexicano (which rocks) or even la urbana in Nopa (fantastic). People have raved about this place & it comes up in many blogs as highly recommended. Ignore all of that. I would not go back with so many other good Mexican places in the city.
author: Ree M.

description:
I have always wanted to try to 'little brother' restaurant of Nopa.  Nopalito definitely did NOT disappoint.   The food was fresh, organic, and delicious.  My 'date' and I shared the brussel sprout quesadillas and the ceviche.  Both were amazing!  I'm not a big eater of anything that used to be alive, so the tentacles on the octopus kind of freaked me out....BUT I tried it none the less, and enjoyed it!  The ceviche had a nice lime flavor to it--not too overpowering, just right.

The tortilla on the brussel sprout quesadilla was was definitely made in-house.  So good!  I'm definitely coming back to try more of the yummy items on the menu.  

PS- Skip the sangria...it's adequate, at best.  I mean, it doesn't even come close to the gloriousness of the libation at ChaChaChas!

Bonus:  There is a parking lot right outside where you can snag a spot if you're lucky.  Also, to avoid a wait, I would suggest you call them ahead of time and put your name on the wait list.  You'll be glad you did!
author: Christina H.

description: A wonderful experience! The food was outstanding and creative. The service was even better.  Suggestion: the restaurant does not take reservations but does allow you to call within two hours of the time you expect to arrive and put your name on a waiting list. I strongly advise you to do this if you want to go on a Saturday night. At 6:30PM the wait was 1-1 1/2 hours!
author: Georgia M.

description:
Finally getting a chance to try Nopalito on a sunny lunch hour, I walked in and was immediately seated in a busy dining area.  It's very nice with lots of open views and covered patio seating.  The interior seating has a street view and a view of the busy kitchen operation.  The service was attentive but when I had a few questions about the food, the server wasn't too well versed.  He did mention that some portions are small and some were large enough for a meal.  I ended up with a great iced tea and ordered two plates to have a filling lunch.  The food was really good.  Exceptional for Mexican cuisine.  Unfortunately, because the portions were small, it made the meal expensive and I wasn't truly full.  I felt a bit let down because it was so good I did want more.  I just didn't feel like spending 20 bucks for a Mexican food lunch.
It seemed this place is for the crowd that's uncomfortable in a Mission taqueria.  And although I give the food a big thumbs up on flavor and creativity, it gets a thumb down on portion size and price.  I'll come back if someone treats.
Parking is tough in their lot and nearby streets.
author: Pablo R.

description:
Went here for lunch on Saturday.  I have lived two blocks away for two years and cannot believe I have never tried this place.  I am pretty sure I will become a regular.  The servers were nice, attentive, and explained everything about the menu.  My parent's were visiting me to help me out with some domestic stuff while I battle law school and some medical problems.  My Dad had gotten the Carnitas take-out on the way back to his hotel the night before, and when it came to the lunch debate it was Magnolia's or Nopalito.  I didn't want to deal with the pretentious, "I am too cool for you" servers at Magnolia's.  Glad we decided to go here.  

Our server answered all of our questions  - even noting which items were better for lunch than a huge dinner (as my dad had loved - but was not feeling carnitas again).  My mom got their soup - and when it arrived the server asked if she had had it before and then explained what to do with the limes, and pointed out the pepper - and when to pull it out based on taste preferences.  I loved my chicken taco - the server mentioned it was a light lunch, but I don't eat a whole lot at one time.  It was perfect.  Corn tortilla filled with black beans and perfectly spicy.  Only $4.50 with a ton of meat.  My dad had fish tacos and liked them as well.  

The fried chickpeas and complimentary almond cookie desserts were amazing.  Oh!  Almost forgot - pomegranate jalepeno sangria.  Delicious!  I shop at Faletti's a lot.  And the Nopalito take-out window is sure to become a frequent stop.
author: Chelsea J.

description: Great ambience and delicious Mexican food. Best for small groups of 2-4 so you can all hear each other. I am definitely coming back.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
The minute I walked in here I loved the decor and the little extras that make you feel special. The whole place is cozy. We sat in the covered area that was much like a sun room, with all windows (an indoor/outdoor area) that had heating lamps as well. The light wooden benches and tables are cute, and the waitstaff was very attentive and friendly. They also use an empty milk gallon as a water bottle for the table, and give you complimentary dried spiced garbanzo beans to start, and almond cookies to finish your meal.

However, the food was slightly overpriced for how much you get. I suppose you're paying for the setting, and yes the food tasted good, but portions were small. The vegetarian quesadilla came with a really good smoky salsa. I was slightly disappointed in my shrimp enchilada, because there were seriously almost no shrimp in it. The bits of shrimp i did find were, for lack of a better word, shrimpy, and I could barely taste them under all the other toppings.  

I do look forward to trying their carnitas which are on SF Best of 2010, and this place is too cute not to give it another go.

BTW, owner of Nopalito, please don't give out paper menus, they get dirty and feel flimsy, and I'm sure you have to replace them often, if not all the time. For a place that uses grass fed beef and organic ingredients, this is not very green of you.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Restaurant was good, very solid.  Came here after the new years revelry was over to help nurse the head and stomach after a night of drinking and carousing.  Had an empanada with the carnitas.  very tasty tho the carnitas was a bit on the dry side.  my wife had the Pozole and kept raving about it.  the margaritas were above average as was the bloody mary.  everything was so filling that it required a walk to the Haight and then back home to work it off.

would I repeat?  absolutely provided the wait was shorter.  definitely a place worth going to on a chilly afternoon to warm up.
author: Robert M.

description:
This place has nailed the secret vibe sauce - I'm still not quite sure how they managed to blend together the casual, laid back feel of a taqueria with a modern urban hang out look, but they did. Went there with a friend last night (a Thursday) and was told the wait would be an hour and a half, but 1 drink and 30 minutes later we were seated at the counter. 

The waitress recommended we split an entree and two appetizers since we weren't that hungry. The carnitas were the obvious choice and also an indicator to me that we're getting way too competitive about the 7x7 "100 Things to Try Before You Die" list - neither of us like pork but this is on the list! We also got the chicken tamale and some fish tacos. The tamale was definitely lackluster and lackflavor, but everything else was just "pretty good." The carnitas were juicy and so easily shredable, plus make-your-own-taco has always given me that arts and crafts feel we all miss from our youth. Okay, yeah fine so I'm 23 and we did arts and crafts in my sorority in college, but anywayyy. 

Halfway through, the waitress convinced us that sipping on some tequila with accompanying "sangrita" (no, that's not a little thing of sangria. It's basically really spicy tomato juice) would go well with the meal/is just the thing you do here. So from here on out it's tough to say if the meal really got better or if I just got drunker, but either way I left feeling satisfied, happy, and accomplished (yay 7x7 list) - a perfect way to gear up for the weekend - though I couldn't help but scowl at all the cute little dating couples on my way out, as I made a mental note to tell the next "pizza place down the street" date suggestion that we're going to Nopalito!

+4 stars for the great vibe, friendly staff, and overall experience. Minus 1 because the food was just okay.
author: Joanne S.

description:
I wanted to like this place, I really did. But it just wasn't for me (or the two people I was with): The portions are very small, the food had a decent flavor but wasn't worth the price, and the wait was longer than it should have been considering the crowd.

With such a limited menu, I figured the food had to be amazing. "They must really have these few options down!" I thought. I went with the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron (AKA a pork quesadilla). It was tasty, definitely! But for $9, I usually expect to get something a little bigger than what I got: somthing slightly larger than those small taco shells, folded in half. All I could taste was meat (too easy), which, again, was tasty, but not what I hoped for. Fortunately we got two appetizers that were pretty good- The taquitos and the chips & salsa. Good thing, we we're hungry! However, I will commend them on their salsa and their margarita.

My final verdict: There's better food out there.
author: Jeff D.

description: I love it. Food is good, easy parking and the Guava water is phenomenal!
author: Gabriel G.

description: My favorite dish is the ceviche with avocado and chips! They has two locations in the city, make sure to tell your friends at which location you are meeting.
author: Lulu X.

description: Went here with some friends from class because they wanted to try Mexican food... A friend invited me for my bday a couple months ago and remembered it was amazing so figured it would be a great option this time too. Food was amazing, the pozole, chilaquiles, ceviche.... I wish the chicharron quesadilla would have been made with chicharron prensado instead of the cracklings though, but it was still good. However, the michelada was nothing like the real micheladas! It just tasted bland and sour... Like cold soup with beer :( but everything else was good and I will definitely go back and just steer clear from the michelada
author: Alexandra V.

description:
I don't get what all the fuss is about with this place. 

I ordered two appetizers last night and didn't really like either, and I was 5 glasses of wine in! 

Usually, anything tastes amazing after a big happy hour.
author: Elaine B.

description: Food was really good but service was terrible. Waiter was rude and food took a long time to come.
author: Daniel S.

description: I was deeply impressed by the food here.  I especially recommend the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón.  The Pozole was also really good.  The drinks are pretty special too!
author: Deanna D.

description: Excellent Mexican food, the trout tostada highly recommended!
author: Jorge G.

description:
This four-star rating for Nopalito is huge.  Immense.  Gigantic.

No, it's not one of those businesses for which I had a tough time deciding between a four- and five-star rating.  What I mean is the fact that I'm publicly admitting that I like Nopalito is huge.  Immense.  Gigantic.

See, I hate NOPA.  Not the neighborhood, but the restaurant.  I've hated it almost from the moment it opened its doors and streams of middle-aged couples from Pacific Heights began arriving in my neighborhood on their double dates in their BMW SUVs.  These people would scurry into the restaurant, enjoy themselves, and then escape as quickly as possible, I assume because they felt the neighborhood had nothing else to offer them.  And maybe the Popeye's across the street worried them.  Hell, I don't know, but the first year that NOPA was open, I spent at least an hour total each week waiting at the bus stop across the street around dinnertime, and the homogeneity of the clientele was comical and slightly frightening.

In case you didn't know, NOPA is named after my neighborhood.  Well, technically, it's named after the cutesy acronym that real-estate agents gave to my neighborhood in order to signal its future gentrification and, I assume, to disassociate it from the larger neighborhood of which it is a part, the Western Addition.  Outright racism being out of bounds--except in the Tea Party, apparently--said real-estate agents can get away with the things they can get away with because classism is still A-OK in the United States, and it's easy to talk about property values and up-and-coming and improving neighborhoods without ever mentioning the people you have to get rid of to gentrify these neighborhoods.

But here's the funny part.  NOPA isn't even in NOPA, at least not technically.  According to the North of Panhandle Neighborhood Association, NOPA's eastern boundary is Divisadero, which means that NOPA is actually in the Alamo Square neighborhood.  Funny how that stuff works.  A few years down the road, and NOPA attracts a much more diverse crowd.  That's good, although I still hate the restaurant.  Which brings me to Nopalito.  Like its big sister, Nopalito isn't technically in NOPA.  See, the Panhandle is due west of Nopalito, so it should probably be called Eopalito.  In any case, I was all lined up to hate this place, but then I actually had a nice meal here.

The food is delicious.  The people who work here are nice.  Although it's crowded, once you're seated, you don't feel like you're being rushed.  I'm not the biggest fan of small foodie portions, but when the food is this good, I can handle them.  Still, I wouldn't suggest coming here if you're really hungry.

So NOPA still sucks and Nopalito is great.
author: John S.

description:
Well triple D got me to try this place out and I must say. It was great!!! Service was very good and personal. 
Took authentic Mexican food, tuned it up a notch in flavor and 3 notches in presentation. 
It is a bit pricey but worth it!!!
author: Henry M.

description: Forgot to leave this before. Great service and bomb chilaquilas!!!! The only thing that makes me look forward to going to DMV (nopalito is across the street) my advice, after u go to DMV treat yourself to an amazing meal here and your
author: Kayla C.

description:
Had lunch there today and was not impressed.  Server was friendly, but not very competent.  Had to ask several times for several items like napkins, ice (for water), etc.

We started with the Totopos. These were WAY TOO hot (spicy).  I have had these at the other Nopalito location in the Sunset and the ones here were much different.  Too hot to eat.  We sent them back.  

I ordered the fish tacos and the portion size was more like an appetizer than a lunch entree.  For the price of this dish, it should have at least included rice or something.  Also, the dish was dry.  The tacos needed some sort of sauce or something to counter the dryness.

I do like the fact that they have a good selection of Gluten Free options, but I will not go back here.  There are better options in SF.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Excellent food. The chef really knows how to use Mexican condiments without overpowering the over all taste. I tried the carnitas chicharron quesadilla it was delicious. The orchata drinks are also pretty good. This is as authentic as you can get. The service was good too. I wish I lived closer.
author: Veronica R.

description:
oh. em. gee. 

Last night I went on a pleasant little roommate date night and as we were deciding between all the greatness that there is on Divisadero, we decided on Nopalito.  It was 845 and they were scheduled to close at 9, but they so graciously let us take a seat at the bar and enjoy a meal. My roommate is vegetarian, and luckily there was no shortage of meals that we could choose from. 

We both started the night off with some beers and all I was really craving was a pescado taco and maybe some veggie taquiots.  My roommate opted for a pescado taco as well, and the veggie quesadilla.  We thought that was sufficient enough food for us both, but our server recommended that we add an additional plate to split because the portion sizes of our meals were a little small- so we got the salmon plate.  

Our night at last came to an end after a full belly of veggies and fish and some beers.  The service was incredibly friendly welcoming, they made great recommendations and the food was so delicious, full of flavor!  The entire experience was delightful.
author: Alexa V.

description: I loved every item we ordered here. The chicken mole, the beef empanada, the totopos, the tamale, the and especially the shortbread cookies at the end of the meal - they're all delicious and I can't wait to try even more of the menu.
author: Amin S.

description: Amazing restaurant an amazing service love the fish tacos. Also the ceviche was smacking!!
author: The D.

description: Wow! The best Mexican food I've had in SF and maybe the best I've had in the US period. The staff was friendly the setting was cool and the food was delicious. We had a panucho, an empanada, carne asada, and a popsicle; all perfect!
author: Graeson N.

description: A little worried when I first got here. Spotted mostly hipsters and youngsters. The tamal and carnitas were delicious . The ceviche was eh and the totopos are a little to thick for my taste. The service is good and it's a great place for a late weekend lunch
author: Sam G.

description: look I love the color green, but if you want good service, you'd better be a good looking man. otherwise, make those ten chips in the guacamole count, because there will be no more. same for your cocktail.
author: KC G.

description:
You walk into Nopalito and just know you're about to be in for a treat.  It just has that vibe.  

We started standing at the bar waiting for our table.  The bartender was seriously putting his heart and soul into every drink creation.  They definitely have some delicious cocktails.  I drank the margarita, but my friends cocktail which was some tequila and ginger concoction was amazing.

They have a lot of small plates and we tried almost all of them.  Apparently they change the menu often.  We had the ceviche, which was probably the top two ceviches I've ever had (the other one being in Mexico from a seafood stand, so def in good company).  

We also tried some chicken birria dish, which is probably sacrilegious to some hardcore Mexican foodies but it was really good.  The beef gordita was also amazing.  

Would definitely check this place out.   Best part is that it is really reasonably priced, if you don't drink like a fish.
author: Pej K.

description:
Had brunch here yesterday and I've got to say that this was the best food I've had in a long time. Amazing, affordable menu. I took my son here, and he eats like a horse, everything in sight. We had the gordita (he ended up having two), the corn, the machaca, and the panucho. I wasn't that impressed with the panucho, but everything else was absolutely delicious... especially the corn!

I wish I had known about the sparkling water! I wish our waiter had told us about that! And also the garbanzo beans... all the tables around us had them but they didn't bring them to us for some reason.
author: Dalila S.

description:
I have to go with three stars for Nopalito, which saddens me since I love its papa restaurant (NOPA) so much.  I've been here three times and, while I love how fresh and creative the menu is, I feel that it lacks seasoning and flavor.  I truly feel bad for giving them three stars because you can see the care that goes into their food and service - homemade tortillas, little cookies at the end of your meal, great explanations of the menu for the non-spanish speaking - but every time I come here I'm a bit underwhelmed. It may be because I'm expecting at least a hint of the bold Mexican flavors we've come to expect in California and you don't really get them here. I do really love the two salads I've had though. 

This place is definitely worth a try to see what you think. I know a lot of people that love the place. If you go, try a salad and maybe only one thing that involves corn tortillas (i'm telling you, they're bland).  If you want more classic Mexican flavor a spice, go to Green Chile up the street.
author: Jillian R.

description: Love it!! Order totopos they are delish. It's best to call and put your name in before heading over, the wait can be very long.
author: Dee Dee C.

description:
Yeah, I'll take my mom here. She loves Mexican cuisine, and this place has a pretty authentic flavor. She might balk a bit at the bustle, though. (And this woman likes a crowd.) Monday night - full to the brim. Didn't wait long for a table, ahem, two stools along a tiny bar counter, and the service was impeccable. 
Full, beautiful bar with dozens of tequilas.
Pretty neat decor; I like that the cooking and preparing is done in full view and that everyone's milling in the same space.

But honestly, for a glorified tacqueria, this place should be most esteemed for its crisp, bold flavors, and I wouldn't give the dishes I tried more than 3 stars.
Ceviche - tart as a motherf***er, with no alternate edge to cut the sourness. Same with the beet and tangerine salad. Pass the salt!!!
Granted, there's a little bowl of coarse salt on every table, but something else was missing from the seasoning and I can't tell what. All's I can say is my taste buds were left hankering.

Pork belly was scrumptious, I must admit. And I suppose there's something to be said about letting a flavorful, tender meat speak for itself, but I think I was half-hoping for some kind of unique garnish - just a dab woulda done me - and there just wasn't any.

Maybe I'm done with Mexican food, I dunno. On second thought - nope. Think I'll head to El Farolito on Mission & 24th to restore my faith in the unadulterated joy of a Supreme Quesadilla, and wait in a line that actually leads somewhere.
author: Eva L.

description:
Moderately upscale Mexican, at least when compared to your average taqueria, Nopalito is a satisfying, and unique take on Hispanic cuisine with fresh ingredients and tasteful combinations. I believe the menu changes as I had been here once before a year or so ago, and some of the items such as the swordfish tacos, which were spectacular, were not on the menu. 

Service: 2 STARS
I came to Nopalito last night on a date. Having noted that the place was PACKED the last time I had came, I decided to call ahead and try to make a reservation. They don't make reservations, but assured me if I left my name and number on the wait list, I would have a table for two within an hour. I received a txt message roughly 45 minutes later claiming my table was ready. I was excited and pleased by the seeming efficacy of their service. When I arrived there my name was on the list being held by one of the hostesses on an iPad, "how modern", I thought. The hostess declared my "table was ready" and had to be reset after cleaning. Up to this point I was pleased. Little did I know when they said they would have a table for 2 ready within one hour,  they really meant they were packed on a Sunday night and were going to force us to sit at the bar.

Like lambs to the slaughter our hostess led us, as I glanced around hopefully for an open table, only to be led to the bar. She attemped to dress up the seating, calling it the "chef's table", or some nonsense like that. It was the bar, plain and simple: stools and everything.  Although I had called, and put my name on the list an hour in advance, I had no option but to sit at the bar with my date crammed between the throngs of hungry patrons. Nopalito follows a tapas style of food and service similar to Cha Cha Cha, which made the service very awkward. The server had to stand behind us and reach around between us and the other patrons of the bar to place the food in front of us as each dish came. This repeated three or so times. Our server was not particularly friendly or pleasant. At first we were given one small water glass for two, then eventually another glass, significantly larger and clearly from a different set than the first, was brought with an empty glass bottle full of water.

The Food: 4 STARS
Delicious, tasteful, yet restrained Nopalito understands how to bring subtly to a cuisine which generally rests on the bombastic.

Totopo's con Chile: $6
Essentially a reconstructed chips and salsa appetizer, the Totopo's themselves are corn tortilla pieces which have been fried in a oil and a red chile sauce making them spicy and greasy while not necessary "wet". Perfect for whetting one's appetite, they are served garnished with cotija cheese and cilantro, which are served with a small dish of sour cream aka "crema". The crema, I felt, was unwarranted. The amount they give you is quite excessive, especially in juxtaposition to the relative mildness of the totopo's themselves. Had that small bowl have been replaced with a small portion of guacamole I believe this dish could go from a 3 STAR appetizer to a 4 STAR. 

Taquitos de Papa con Espinaca: $6.00
This was definitely an interesting take on taquitos! Instead of being stuffed with god awful gas station ground beef and nacho cheese these taquitos are artfully stuffed with a much more tantalizing combination of  potato and spinach. Garnished with cabbage and served (YES!) with a side of guacamole and a side of crema. My girlfriend, a vegetarian, was OBSESSED. This is definitely a 4 STAR appetizer, which could be elevated to 5 STARS if it was served with a side of spicy salsa or enchilada sauce. I say this because the umami overload of the potato, crema, and guacamole is a little heavy, muddying the dish, and could use some spice to clear it up! 

Quesadilla Rojo Con Chicarron: $9.50
An absolutely delicious quesadilla! The shell is extremely crispy, and inside there is delicious, tender pork belly with salsa, onion, cilantro, and cheese. Easily a 4 STAR dish. My only complaint is that the proportion is a little small considering the $3.50 markup from other items on the small plate menu.  You're essentially paying $3.50 more for the same sized plate with the inclusion of meat. None the less I would highly recommend this quesadilla! 

Total not including tax and tip: $21.50

The Bottom Line: 3 STARS
Oh Nopalito, how I long to give you a 4 star review overall. The food is delicious, the dishes are interesting, and the flavor is just right which is why I give their food a solid 4 STAR review. Unfortunately, last night the service was terrible. Who sits at the bar after calling an hour in advance?! This isn't exactly Gary Danko's, it is moderately dressed up and date appropriate Mexican food. We held back from ordering drinks and more plates because of the disappointment of seating and service. At that point we just wanted to get in and out. Food was great as always. Will come back again soon and give them another chance at winning me over.
author: Tomas K.

description: Food is Excellent! I got the crane asada. Was good but my wife ordered the chicken plate which was to die for. I can't remember the exact names of each plate. Chips were seasoned and really good. Margaritas were very Fresh tasting. Obviously all fresh ingredients only.  I thought they would have a larger selection of Mexican beer which is my only complaint. If you're going on a Friday or Saturday evening the wait can be LONG so best to call ahead to get put on their "wait list!" You're welcome! Great place for Modern Mex overall.
author: Todd H.

description:
I can only speak to the food and takeout service.  YUM! We stopped in to get a late dinner to bring home on a thursday night and were not disappointed.  we ordered the carnitas and the birria and both were so delicious!  A little expensive for mexican food, but it wasnt just your average burrito.  I would definitely want to come back and try more things on the menu.

The people at the takeout counter were friendly and helpful.
author: Lisa C.

description: Love this place! The margaritas are fab, the food is so tasty and the staff is always friendly!
author: Galina H.

description: The food is good but a 45 min wait after getting a reservation for a birthday dinner is a bit much. Also they sat us and asked us to move after we got comfortable. Seriously try for customer service next time.
author: Taylor H.

description: It's been awhile since I've been back but  even as long as its been - I can't forget how much I enjoyed the food here. The tender carnitas, the fresh ceviche, and the famous refreshing white grape sangria!
author: Charlene R.

description:
HUGELY disappointing. After reading all the great Yelp reviews, I was really looking forward to trying this place out.

First of all, we asked for a table for two in a 2/3 full restaurant. The hostess passed over 3 tables for two and sat us at a table for 6. I don't mind sharing, usually, but the other diners were really loud so we couldn't hear ourselves think let alone talk to each other. 

Had the ceviche which was quite nice. (That, the wine and the wait staff were the saving graces of this meal.)

I had the Carne Asada y Acelgas as la Mexicana. It was okay. The meat was tough and bland - I was felt the need for some serious flossing afterwards - the braised greens were tasty, but the black beans were mushy and tasteless. The mole sauce was probably the best part of the dish.

Big G had the Enchiladas Placeras...um...the chicken was UNDERCOOKED. Unfortunately, because of the red spices on the chicken and the lighting, neither of us notice it until we'd eaten half a piece each. Hellooooo, people...you should know better than that!!! 

$50 for an appetizer, one glass of wine and two entrees in a Mexican restaurant? It strikes me as Mexican food for folks who are too middle class to venture into the Mission.
author: Mi M.

description:
Organic Mexican food...sounds like an oxymoron right? But Nopalito does it right. Everything does taste a bit "cleaner" and the food is simple but with surprising twists on flavors. 

Some of my favs:
-Chips and salsa: perfect appetizer to kick off the meal ($5)
-Ceviche: refreshing and comes with a side of chips for dipping ($10)
-Carnitas: definitely recommend this. If you're gonna get one bigger entree, stick with this ($11)
-Pork belly quesadilla: damn good

For drinks, I loved the organic watermelon sangria ($8 glass/$28 bottle). The name itself is just appealing right?? It is SO good...refreshing and the liquor totally will creep on you so be careful.

I came with a group of 7. We called in around 530 to put ourselves on the waitlist for 730. We got there around 740 and waited for another 25-30min before we got seated. All in all, not too bad. Definitely call ahead for the wait list as they don't take reservations. This place is perfect for bigger groups...that way you can order more and eat family style since most of the plates are tapas-style.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
I came here the other evening with a good friend for dinner, and was immediately at ease by the aesthetically appealing ambiance. We were seated on the enclosed (read: warm) patio next to a beautiful border of plant boxes - with exquisitely chosen bright green pants, contrasting dark dirt. (Yes, this sounds very simplistic, to comment on plants & dirt, but from an interior design perspective, the contrast was clean & crisp, which set the stage for the beginning to a delectable dinner.) 

Onto the food...

We started with the following two appetizers:
* Ensalada de Betabeles: Salad of mixed beets, carrot-orange juice, queso fresco and chile-lime pickled onion
*Tamal de Frijoles Negros Con Hongos: Black bean-corn masa, mushroom, poblano pepper, onion, epazote, crema, queso fresco and salsa poblano mulato

and later moved onto trying the following two entrees:
* Enchiladas Placeras: Tortillas, chile mulato, carrots, potatoes, queso fresco, seared chicken breast and pickled jalapeños
