* Carnitas: Long braised pork, orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer Cabbage salad, pickled jalapeños, salsa de tomatillo 

Everything we ordered was, frankly, phenomenal. The Beet Salad was delicious, especially with the lime squeezed atop. And the tamale was incredible. Of course the enchiladas were yummy. But best of all, was the Carnitas, which my dining companion had deemed the house dish - it was definitely my favorite of the four.

Our server was a bit too boisterous, though friendly with good intentions.

And best of all, the price was particularly affordable, especially taking into account all that we ordered. 

If you're on a budget, but looking for a restaurant with a visually appealing ambiance, as well as good food, I recommend Nopalito. And once the budget gives way to more wiggle room, we'll be onto NOPA! ;)
author: Sally M.

description: Nopalito is a great restaurant for a variety of Mexican specialties. Great selection of small plates, good attention to detail and very friendly service. Nice atmosphere albeit a little too close for comfort in some areas of the restaurant. Definitely worth it and great food!
author: Tim H.

description: The Caldo Tlalpeño con Pollo and Carnitas were delicious --- great home cooking flavor. I'm looking forward to trying their pozole.
author: Irene F.

description:
One word: NOM. VERY yummy appetizer and entree! Love the decor except if you sit too close to the kitchen, it's very hot (it's an open kitchen). But yes def go with friends or on a fun date! 

I had the blackbean stuffed tortila chicken meal for an appetizer and the chicken mole poblano for an entree. VERY much loved it. 

Dessert was a tad weird tho - popsicles? Not quite sure how that came about.
author: Pamela K.

description:
I shop the grocery store (Faletti) in the plaza regularly, and I'm always stepping around folks happily waiting an hour for a Nopalito table. It's because of this Emperor's-new-clothes phenomenon that I tried Nopalito not one, not two, but THREE times before finally admitting that it's just not that good.  In fact, it's just plain not good!

My first visit was for lunch shortly after the restaurant's grand opening: overpriced drinks, undersized portions for the prices (and yes, I'm factoring the cost of organically and sustainably raised foods), and CHEWY ceviche. In short, yuck.

My second visit was a take-away order mid-December 2010: some overpriced burrito-type thing that I can't believe was fried, and which relied on its dipping sauce for flavor.

My third visit was just on Wednesday (mid-February 2011) for dinner, and my dining companion and I, for the first time in each of our 21st-century experiences, sent our entrees back.

Her albondigas disintegrated at the touch of her fork, and their near-black color resembled something so unappetizing (think HazMat) that I couldn't state it until the plate was taken away. Their flavor was promising at first taste (yum, cumin!), but faded into nothing in just two seconds. I never salt my food, but I did these, and it did not help.

My mole was so beautifully presented (see user's picture) that it brought a tear to my eye, and the chicken was the tenderest and most flavorful I've tasted at a restaurant in a long time--and it had better be, at $14 for about 3 ounces of leg meat. But the mole itself? BURNED! The telltale bitterness of burned chiles. Oh, so bitter. [wipes tongue at the memory of it]

I prize my dinner companion above the food we're sharing, but when our server approached us both picking at our plates, we confessed our dissatisfaction. She took our plates and offered us some guacamole while she adjusted the bill. The bill came back with only my friend's albondigas removed, and get this: a charge for the guacamole! Unbelievable, especially since it consisted of about 1/4 of an *overripe* avocado, bland as ever, to boot. The manager responded, and we insisted that both my mole and the guac be removed. He begrudgingly complied. We even asked if there had been a change in kitchen staff, a vain attempt to defend our server's perfectly fine service.

We tipped 20% on what would have been the total, paying only for two $8 glasses (short pours, barely 3 ounces) of mediocre red wine plus some of the BEST-tasting tortilla chips ever created--and I never thought I'd say this--*if* you salt them.

Why the two stars, then? It would be just one, but for the sustainable organic foods offered.
author: Diana P.

description: Good food, very delicious, carnitas pork was melting in our mouth, highly recommended .
author: John S.

description:
Their taquitos are the best

Went there with a group of 6 and the service was amazing

Margaritas were $38 a pitcher and delicious

I would go there again.
author: farah b.

description:
Now this is tasty Mx food!!! I know it's done by the same masterminds that brought us Nopa, so I don't know how "authentic" it is, but it is sooo good.  Like wo o  ow good.  Great horchata, cookies, tortillas, beef, nopalitos (of course), pork, beans, drinks, veggies, service, management, restrooms, and decor.  Priced decently for what you get, but it will be packed all the way til closing so be ready to order para llevar.  
To be honest the salsa wasn't as delicious as I demand it to be, but it did go well with the dish. I wish they would have tastier salsa.  Everything else was perrrrfecto.
author: Joshua K.

description:
went once with a friend who frequents.  I found it a bit contrived, (no guacamole in a mexican place) but the carnitas were very good and the service was good.  
Overall i would come again and recommend it to second date kind of people or you know, some random out of town person you need to get a quick dinner with.
author: e c.

description:
Funny things about NOPAlito and SF society:

1) "Organic food" translates to food suitable for caucasians that you can feel happy to pay more for.

2) Caucasians feel better going to a restaurant where all the staff is caucasian and all the cooking staff isn't.

3) Caucasians enjoy feeling exotic buying food in a different language and washing it down with a foreign sounding alcohol.

In sum, NOPAlito is charming place for those SF residents that "voted for Obama" and "do yoga," therefore are "cultural."

Ole!
author: S. K.

description:
Context: we called ahead around 1pm on a saturday and when we arrived, we were seated fairly quickly, about 30 minutes after our call. The place was very busy and only slowed down after 2pm.

Atmosphere: large outdoor enclosed patio and smaller insides space with one big communal table, bar seating and several two tops. The place is packed and sitting at the bar is kind of like what a Pringles potato chip must feel like stacked in its canister, but let me tell you the coziness is worth the food!  If you want more space try to get a table outside.  The place has lots of light. The one bathroom is reached by going outside and around the building.

Service: a bit brusque at the door but she was sifting through lots of people and the system is not efficient. People with dogs are trying to get seated outside, big parties need multiple tables, people are calling ahead and others are walking up asking how long, in a very congested space. One can't help but ask, what is the purpose of no reservations except to perpetuate chaos?
Inside, once we were snuggled together, our waitress literally had to come up behind us, get our attention and hand us stuff over our shoulder, but she was friendly, efficient and seemed unphased.

Food: I would put up with a lot, including pringlization, to eat this food. There were so many yummy looking things on the menu and others being cooked in front of us, it was hard to know where to begin. Watching other food led us to pick the chips covered in chili sauce, sprinkled with cheese and white onion (do not even think nachos), the stew with white beans, pork bacon, cilantro, and the thick corn tortilla with pork, chorizo and cabbage on top. It was impossible to chose. The mole enchiladas looked fantastic, as did the posole and this fried quesadilla thing. 
First, let me say that everything we had was fantastic, and they all tasted different. What a pleasure to have three such distinct dishes. The chips are crispy with just a big of chew, spicy and they give you a sour cream like thing (crema) to dip them in but it's not necessary. The stew has large, almost firm white beans, chunks of bacon, and a red flavorful sauce. It's served with warm, chewy corn tortillas. And the thick corn tortilla dish was a mix of textures and tastes with a lightly spicy bite.

Drinks: they have beers, margaritas, and a variety of non alcoholic Mexican bevs. We had a hibiscus orange drink that was light, refreshing and just slightly sweet, exactly like a similar drink I had in Mexico. We had the mex beer Indio which is a lighter dark beer.
author: Vivek V.

description: We walked into a very busy Nopalito today with a reservation. After a 45 minute wait, the hostess told us we were next and would be seated soon. We watched what we thought was our table being prepared but were then told we couldn't have that table because there was a group coming with small children. They instead gave us a bar seat. Not a huge deal but we had been waiting 45 minutes and specifically asked if we could please have the window seat. They again refused. 10 minutes later a group walked in with NO children and took the table we requested.  This party was obviously being given special privileges for whatever reason. We waited for 45 minutes and they walked in With no wait and sat at a prime table. But here's the bad part. I asked that  they at least give us an apology and maybe buy us another round. That would have fixed everything. Instead they were completely unapologetic and brushed it off as "not their problem."  They just lost three regular customers.
author: Michael A.

description: Great vibe, friendly service, bomb mole and really, really good margaritas.  Love this place.
author: Ted T.

description:
My gf surprised me and brought me here last nite for my birthday dinner! I was excited to try Nopalito even though i haven't even tried NOPA yet. lame i know but hey, I will try NOPA very soon! :) The wait for this place can be pretty long and they don't take reservations but apparently you can call ahead to get on the wait list. We ended up having to wait around 45 mins for a table but it was worth the wait. At least for the food but not the company that came with it. 

We ordered the following:

-Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamari- which was a combination of marinated rock cod, tomatillo, calamari, lime, cilantro and topped with avocado. I found this to be my favorite among the two appetizers we ordered. It had a spicy kick to it that i loved, I keep coming back for more. Until there was none :(

-Taco De Pescado al Pastor: which is a taco that contained a piece of fish that is seared in adobo, a chili, orange, onion, cilantro and salsa de morita y tamatillo. Unlike Fro-yo Girls experience our fish was not dry and i thought the flavors mixed well but agree that the orange was a bit too sweet.

For our main courses:

-The gf got the Carnitas: The braised pork was delicious and flavorful but it was a little bit dry for my taste.

-I got the Enchiladas Placeras: Which contained tortillas, chili mulatos,  around teh plate where scattered summer squash, carrrots and potatoes. The was a pretty good amount of queso sprinkled everywhere on the plate. The seared chicken breast was perfectly cooked, it was tender, juicy and carried alot of flavor.


Now that i talked about the food, I thought it might be funny to tell you about the people near us. So when we were seated, we noticed that the table of two was very close to us. It looked as if they had split a table of 4 and didn't have room to move the tables much, so the clearance wasn't that much. First off we had an old lady with another laady  making comments about our food and just kept trying to make conversation with us as we were trying to eat our food. Once they left then a couple sat down and they were annoying as ever. 

The girl starts talking to her bf about this guy at the bar area. She said he looked like a "12 yr old boy and shouldn't be with such a hot girl." O.o Her bf then chimes in and says well maybe he is "packing" and the gf agrees by saying its probably the only reason she is with him. The bf's response to this is he probably uses a penis pump. At this point, I was getting reallie annoyed that they couldn't shut the hell up and eat!!! I mean WTF, I am trying to eat here SHIT! If i wanted commentary I would have gotten take out and sat in front of the TV. After we finished eating, I wasn't even in the mood to check out the dessert. I just felt like leaving and the gf was in total agreement with me. Despite this crazy convo's we heard and encountered I would like to come back and check out a more of their dishes as well as the dessert the next time around. Until then, I will have to hit up NOPA :D
author: Jonathan W.

description:
This place is a seriously bad time.  I ordered some Sangria at the bar and they cut it with about 92% ice.  By the time I got halfway through the drink, I could barely taste it anymore because it was almost all melted ice.  But I finished it, what are you gonna do?

Once I sat down, I ordered another Sangria, this time without ice.  Instead of coming in a half-pint glass, it came in a half-full wine glass.  I asked why they weren't serving it to me in the same size glass - and the waitress said, and I kid you not - "It's the same amount of alcohol that you would get if there was ice in the drink."

Just in case they were any way in the right here, I asked my friend who bartended for many years and also owned a bar and restaurant.  He said, in no uncertain terms, that it was unacceptable for them to do that with sangria.  With a mixed drink, it's the bar's call - it costs you a bit more, but you get repeat customers if it doesn't seem like you're nickel-and-diming people.  But with Sangria, which costs basically nothing, it just makes no sense - you're not saving money and you're pissing off a customer. But at Nopalito, it ain't about the customer.
author: Gabriel D.

description: Finally a restaurant that serves only healthy food. You do not leave the table here with heart burn or clogged arteries. The food is simple Mexican faire of the type one would really find in Mexico. The choices were limited but great. The drinks were excellent. The prices were reasonable. What a nice surprise this place is!
author: Jack W.

description: As one of Nopa's sisters, you know this will be good. We had deliciously clean ceviche, the best quesadilla I've ever had (pork belly) and a very good pulled pork sandwich for lunch. The tequila and cocktails rocked, really good service and to finish it off, restaurant made popsicles. Going back before we head home.
author: Mike J.

description:
I give way too many 5 stars, but SF really has a lot of great food! 

Been wanting to go here (and even more so Nopa) for more than two years, but i really have a hurdle with trying out places that are not on Open Table :) well Nopa is (but good luck getting something thats not 10pm!... well that cant be true, coz i am sure i am just looking too late)... anyways,

called ahead at 6.40 and said i could get in at 8.20!!! ridiculous wait, but luckily i wanted to get there at 8.30, so by pure luck it worked out perfect! it was a reunion of sorts for my husband and his two high school buddies. I mean we have seen them before, but all three of them + wives was a first time. so we definitely needed a good dining experience :)

Two of us were vegetarian and four the more adventurous animal eating type...

E Diablo (super yumm and strong)
Mezcal Paloma (didn't try but heard it was good)
Mexican Coffee (spiked)
Blue Bottle Coffee (drank it to the last drip)
Totopos con Chile (tortilla chips, crema and cotija cheese) - i love me some fried food and this was so spectacular, for reals!
Tamale - it was very flavorful and artfully (delicate) prepared
Veggie Quesadilla (squash blossoms, zucchini, cheese, tomatillo salsa)... so creative! loved it
all the rest of the food was also very very well received - chicken mole, carnitas, ceviche, shrimp enchiladas

the service was good (nothing memorable) and we were unfotunately seated by the door on a cold day, but the food was so good and we were having such a great time, that noone really noticed or cared.

Later we went to Madrone (same owner) and I had some original cocktail there too - it was super smooth and lovely!

The food here is fantastic - one of the best Mexican food in the city!
author: Sapna E.

description: Friendly staff, awesome food, and great dessert! Glad I went to this place. I recommend the agua de horchata with almond milk and micheladas for drinks. The good has a modern twist to Mexican food. Very hip for young crowed. The homemade paletas very tasty so save done room.
author: Angel S.

description:
I have this tendency to describe things I really like in a very specific manner:

-If it's a liquid, I want to cover my body in it
-If it's a solid, I want to make sweet love to it

Nopalito better have a lot of paper towels because it's about to get messy up in hurr.

I had a dream about the Totopos con Chile last night. It was a weird since it also involved an ex and Mrs. Borleske, my high school Chemistry teacher, explaining Pv=nrt, but the Totopos was still a prominent character. 

Upon my friend's suggestion, we ordered this as an appetizer (despite having a cupcake AND cookie from the supermarket bakery while we waited to be sat). I know people rave about the Carnitas, but I would wait in line again just to savor the sauce that these chips are soaked in. 

Taking the suggestion of our waitress, I ventured from my typical Mexican comfort zone and ordered the Quesadilla de Flor de Calabaza. It was my first time enjoying squash blossoms (loved them) which were situated next to zucchini, leeks, jalapenos and cilantro. Topped with jack cheese, queso fresco, onions and cilantro, this summery dish was top notch. 

Hearty, but light. 
Flavorful, but distinct.

Nopalito is gourmet Mexican. You're not leaving overwhelmingly full from a massive burrito. You're enjoying well-crafted dishes and variations on typical meals. 

Although really delectable, the line can get seriously long. We waited a half hour to only be sat at the last two stools at the bar, within centimeters of where the food is prepared and sent off to hungry stomachs. I wouldn't wait much past this. 

Unless you're coming just for the Totopos con Chile. Then bring your tent, buy a cinnamon cupcake and wait for the perfection known as this dish to arrive in front of you. Let it live long in your memories and travel into your dreams where Mrs. Borleske will be waiting for you.
author: Jared S.

description:
Hyped up. Not hype worthy.

The scene is buzzing and energetic. Prepare to wait for your table, and while drinks are an option, making your way up to the small bar counter is challenging. Really liked the modern design, and the heat lamps outside will make it feel like a warm summer evening no matter how brutal the wind and fog.

Food portions were generous and well-priced, and some of the items were rather inventive. But overall a mixed bag. The veggie quesadilla surprisingly had more veggies than cheese (score), but the chicken enchilada, while having no shortage of chicken, could have used more veggies and way, way less oil. Our takeout container was getting stained. Never good.

Ceviche was unmemorable, and the black bean stuffed tortilla seemed to be missing black beans. Small layer on the bottom.

Service was OK, attentive at times and then a miss at others, like when we said we were sharing the pecan popsicle dipped in caramel (a highlight) but were not given the tools (i.e. fork, plate) to share.

While not overly impressed with the food, the space and price were just right. A weak three stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
Visited the smelly DMV yesterday :-( Afterwards, feeling lost, dirty and scared of standing in one place for too long, I started marching hoping I would make it across 2 blocks with being poked.
Not more than 10 paces in, I stumbled upon a beautiful sight.... NOPALITO.

The hostess and my server were welcoming and made me feel they were inviting me into their kitchen for a "slap your mama" good meal surrounded by intriguingly good looking people. I like good looking people...

What I had:

Killer Bee cocktail: I had two of these bad boys at 3:30pm. Killer Bees  stung me oh so softly

Totopos con chile: What did I just put in my mouth? This is chips and salsa reinvented! So good! I have to say the chips have a bit of heat but I like my food SPICY. Nopalito brought me extra heat with a house made habanero sauce.

Taco de pescado al pastor: I'm of those people who likes to only devour the taco filling and discard the tortilla so I can save room for more food but I couldn't in this case. Another winner!

Ceviche verde de pescado y calamare: This one made me cry first, because of the realization that I was already full and could order no more, second because the combination of fresh salsa verde, avocado, seafood and citrus was mouthwateringly good. I have so far only really enjoyed ceviche mixto at Limon Rotisserie and Nopalito's has been added to my list.

Nopalito has been on my list of places to try and it was such a pleasure to stumble upon it yesterday. My only gripe is that I did not have a lunch mate there so I could order more dishes.
author: Coco M.

description:
Came here with friends for the first time a while ago.

The food was good.  We ordered the Totopos con Chile as our appetizer (soooo good!), and I had the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón as my meal, which was delicious.

Portions are pretty small, and prices are pretty big.  That was really my only gripe with the place.  (Aside from being surprised that the girl who brought out our appetizer was a past fling of my boyfriend's.... but that's a whole other story in itself.)
author: Tamara N.

description:
Was good when it was new, but the last time (2014) the service treated us very rudely, most notably the manager. After waiting patiently outside in the cold for 45 minutes (the hostess said there'd be a 20 minute wait), the hostess acknowledged she forgot about us and apologized and said she'd try to seat the three of us soon. 

When they sat us, there were 2 tables that opened up at the same time. They sat us at a two top table with the third chair placed in the small walkway the servers use to get to the different ends of the restaurant and bumped into my back several times in the few minutes I was seated in that third seat. I asked if we could be at the four top instead that had opened up at the same time, but was told by the manager that because they were so busy they couldn't afford to sit us at the four top because there were only three of us. "Ok" I said. But then the manager sat a party of three at the very table I asked about. At that point I got up and asked her why she denied us the three top when we were there first and I had asked for that table AND the hostess had made a mistake and made us wait longer because she simply forgot about us. She said (in a rude manner) because they were so busy, and turned around and simply walked away. 

I didn't want to make a scene so I just sat back down and had just resolved never to come back. But my out of town guests had heard and saw the exchange with the manager and one of them got up and confronted the manager. That out of town guest was both my senior and the manager's senior, but the manager simply said that she was sorry we felt slighted and if we didn't like it, we didn't have to eat there. WOW!! The audacity of that manager stunned me! I had been a waiter at several restaurants and had never witnessed such behavior from a manager! Then one of the waiters came to our table and apologized for the manager's behavior. I was shocked again! A waiter apologizing for the manager's behavior?!  Needless to say, I won't return and warn my friends that if they like to wait a long time and get lack luster service, and pay twice as much for Mexican?! food, This is the place to go. Their hip-ness has clearly gone to their head. As for the food, I can't even remember what we ate because the experience only left a sour taste.
author: gary a.

description:
1 star mostly due to the stupid policy that they can't seat more than 6 people together & they don't make ANY exceptions to that rule. Nor do they take reservations. So if you wanna have any kind of Birthday (or whatever) group dinner I would strongly suggest going elsewhere.
As for the food...the deep fried garbonzo beans they serve as a free appetizer are SUPER dry & really not all that tasty. Not a fan.
author: Maryann R.

description: I drop in for lunch on weekly basis. Food is consistently good and service is friendly and efficient. Been here over dozen times and left happy every time.
author: Marco M.

description: We're a fan! Having just moved to the neighborhood, this is a great place to meet up with friends for a casual brunch. 2 of the 6 of us were late but we were seated anyway as we'd arrived at 11:30AM on a Sunday. I had the ceviche, and we're so glad we ordered the totopos con chile, takes like doritos with extra cheese on top! Overall great meal, the service was a little slow - hard to get ahold of our particular waiter, who later switched to a different waitress to serve us.
author: Shang S.

description: I went here for lunch with a friend of mine I haven't seen in a while. I've seen it on TV and heard good things about it, so I gave it a try. I ordered the chicken enchiladas and my friend ordered the carnitas, and we also got totopos to share. Good thing we got the totopos because the portions were a little smaller than I expected, especially for the prices. The prices aren't crazy high, I just thought I was going to get more food. It was good food, and all in all it was a nice place and a good experience. I'm only giving it a 3 because it was average. I was expecting more, but for me, it didn't live up to the hype.
author: John A.

description:
The only "Mexican" restaurant  that I left hungry and had to go to 
the deli next door for a sandwich after eating at this phony 
boutique Mexican bistro. 

Made to feel foolish when having the guts to ask if they had 
burritos. The Anglo waiter stated you will not find those in Mexico. 
I told him that in Mexico you will will not find finger sized enchiladas 
for $11.00 and you ,at least, get tortillas with your meal. 

Overpriced small portions with attitude. 

$30.00 lunch was 4 small enchiladas. 

Walk on by and get a full sized meal at one of the many 
Mexican spots in the City. You will get your money's worth 
without the phoniness.
author: Ed E.

description:
Good dishes but they tended to be a bit on the pricey side and smaller in scale.  Well thought out menu for tasting.  Very artsy and pretentious.  The favors just weren't there.  Everything was fresh but...didn't quite jive.

 Maybe I'm used to authentic Mexican places in South City...
author: MTBer I.

description:
#53 on 100 Things to Eat Before I Die in SF: Carnitas

So, let me first start off by saying that Chavo's in the Mission has some of THE juiciest, best-tasting carnitas I've ever tasted.  Forget La Taqueria down the street - Chavo's is awesome...and they give you so much!

That said, I had to see what the more modern idea of carnitas is by checking out the famed dish at Nopalito.  First time I've been there, and what a treat.  The wait was 45 minutes, so we trekked up the street and around the corner to The Page for a beer during the wait.  Dark, seedy, and a no-nonsense and not entirely friendly bartender awaited us.  I knew we weren't there for long, but it was definitely not my cup of tea.  The two pool tables, though, are a nice addition.

But, I digress...

From the succulent garden that surrounds the heated outdoor area of the fairly small restaurant, to the extremely nice servers, Nopalito is a nice little tucked away place to get some fine grub.  We ordered the ceviche, which was so fresh and delicious I almost devoured the whole thing before my companion could get a fork in, edgewise.  We also tried what I'd like to consider dinner's take on chilaquiles - I forget what it's called but it was the first item on the menu.  It was made with a red sauce that I wasn't too into, but overall it was a good dish, especially when you're at the top of the chip pile and all the cheese is there waiting for you.  

Moved onto the carnitas (finally, what this review is about).  Arrived in a nice little paper bag with sides of green salsa, pickled pepper, carrot, and onion, and a cabbage mixture.  Came with tortillas, in which I did not partake.  Simply delicious.  It was maybe a total of 6oz of meat, but I could have downed another 6.  So good.  

On the other hand, my dining companion had the pork quesadilla, which came in a really brown tortilla and I can't figure out how it got that brown.  Maybe it's deep-fried?  Anyway, the catcher on this one is that the quesadilla arrives with pork belly cracklings cooked inside.  Now, it sounded absolutely divine when I ordered it, but to eat it was...crunchy.  And the uncomfortable kind of crunchy, the one that you're not quite expecting and think you might lose a tooth if you ever crunch it again.
author: Tamar D.

description:
The atmosphere is super warm and inviting hostess and waiters were really friendly and gave lots of recommendations. Great location. But nothing fancy, you can just quickly drop by with friends.

Food overall was tasty and filling, if you like mexican food this has to be a stop you make. 

My only problem was with their sangria, not tasty at all. Also, before you get your main course, they give you these deep fried beans that I guess is their version of "bread". Amazing. I had to buy a whole container to-go, which is even more awesome that they have a store where you can purchase some of their stuff. And I've been dreaming about them since, so delicious!
author: Sunny D.

description: food was okay.  i ordered fish tacos, wasn't impressed at all.  my wife had the tamale which she enjoyed. good service though.
author: Chris W.

description:
Changed my idea of "mexican" food! Wonderful - every dish we ordered (family of four) was unique in texture and flavor (though most had the same corn-tortillas done in different ways). Food felt fresh and tasted delicious.

Attentive service - we ordered family style and they brought the dishes by course, timing it well with the previous course.

The drinks are good too and the complimentary little "dessert style" bites were amazing! I'm a fan now.
author: Pablo R.

description:
Horchata, carnitas, gorditas, mole and popsicles made in-house (tried all 3 flavors: chocolate cinnamon, cafe con leche with blue bottle coffee and mango)

Had this a month ago and I'm still drooling. Mole was my favorite- the meat was so tender! My sister and I practically licked the dish clean (no joke- I have photos) and their horchata is really good.

Service is really great, and food is served promptly. ps their horchata is really good.

Place is smaller than I imagined and is connected to the market, but if you call ahead of time, they can add you to the waiting list over the phone. huzzah!

Did I mention their horchata is really good?!
author: Kathy D.

description:
I've tried to come here a few times before, but was always deterred by the long wait when I was with a group of 4 or 5.  Then...over the weekend I went with a friend, and was told that there was a half an hour wait for a private table...OR we could share a table and be seated right away.  The only caveat, she said, was that we would be sharing the table with a couple who has a toddler.

My outside reaction: "Oh...mmm I guess that's fine."
Inside: "YESSSSS BABYYYYY AKA FRUIT OF THE EARTH."

Once we went inside the restaurant, we realize that we are basically in Babies: The Movie (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1020938/).  I counted no less than three toddlers just on my way to the table.  For some, this may be a -1 star, but for me, this is in fact +20, but alas, I am not reviewing a preschool, so I am not factoring this into the star count.

After we were seated, I ordered a hibiscus-blood orange agua fresca.  It was just okay, and frankly kind of small and filled with ice.  My friend's almond horchata was probably the better choice.

For my entree I ordered the Pozole Rojo, which came with a side dish of garnishes - oregano, paprika, onions, lime, and tortilla chips - that I can add myself to the already bright-red soup, filled with hominy and pork.  It was quite, quite delicious, and perfect for a winter's night.

All in all, this place is great when you want something a little more than what a taqueria can offer.  Do, however, expect a wait...and apparently babies on a Saturday night.
author: jon y.

description: I had the Birria (beef stew) and my wife had the Carnitas (pork) and both were perfect. Waiting is about an hour without reservation but it's worth the wait. This is real authentic Mexican food hard to find unless you're in Mexico and am from Mexico so believe me. I visited San Francisco from Dallas and food this good it's hard to find in Dallas. You'll find Tex-Mex food in Dallas but it's not as good and authentic as in Nopalito. Both the Birria and Carnitas were as good as you'll find in Mexico. Everything looked good and definitely going back next time am in San Fran.
author: Joel M.

description:
OH.EM.JIZZLES.

foodgasm.

I give it 5 stars b/c of the food AND the service. I went on a Tuesday night, they said the wait would be 30 min, but they called us 6 minutes later saying that there was  table available! Playing hard to get... but it's cool, I get it. 

I started off by asking the waiter what on the menu he would recommend. Thank god because the waiter, unfortunately I didn't get his name, but he SURE knew what he was talking about. He was not only able to describe the dishes with detail that helped me decide, he was also able to give me a whole history of how the alcohol was made... something about being made in the rustic countryside in Mexico... while this may not be for everyone, I definitely enjoyed hearing all about it. 

Dishes: LOVED the totopos con chile. the description on the menu makes it seem kind of bland.. but when it came out, it was like a flavor/textures explosion in my mouth. Also.. I like 'em thick, and that's how the chips came. thick and flavorful. 
Quesadilla con chicharron: Delicious! I liked how the quesadilla was crunchy rather than a typical softer quesadilla. 
Carnitas: as good as they say. 
meatBALLs: extremely unique and flavorful. Probably not for everyone, but I really enjoyed it. It had a nice smoky flavor that seemed to be a common characteristic in both their food AND drinks (ask about the alcohol that the sangria is made with)

will be back!
author: Nanette W.

description: Had the Totopos chips & a beef brisket gordita at Off The Grid @ the Presidio. My bf & I loved both, but surprisingly enjoyed the chips more. I would love to check out the actual restaurant. Also, my bf really loved the ginger lemonade.
author: Kristine C.

description:
Fool me once, shame on me--Fool me twice...you lose my business.

My GF lives about 10 minutes away (walking) from this restaurant and ever since it opened we've been eager to try it. 

The first time we walked over to try the restaurant, it was 8pm on a Saturday night (I know--the craziest possible time to try and get a table anywhere in the city). 

We arrived and there was no one at the entrance to greet us--just a stainless steel rollaway cart and a clipboard with a long list of names.  So we did what we thought was obvious--we added our name to the list and waited by the entrance for the host/hostess to give us more information. 

So we waited about ten minutes with no host/hostess in sight. Other diners also signed up on the clipboard and we were all milling about, waiting to talk to someone. All the while, waiters and waitresses were busy running around serving customers inside. 

Another ten minutes go by, and finally(!) a man comes out to look at the clipboard. He's on the phone, writing down people's names on the list. When he finally gets off the phone, instead of greeting us, he asks whether or not or name is on the list and declare to the whole group that the wait will be at least an hour. 

At this point it was eight o'clock, so we felt like it wasn't worth the wait. We took our name off the list and decided that next time we try to eat here we'd call ahead to put our name on the list before arriving. 

At this point I'm mildly annoyed by the host's attitude and the lack of service, but whatever--it's a Saturday night and everyone is busy. I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt.

About two weeks later, we decided we want to try eating at Nopalto's again. Once again, it's about 6 at night and we decide to call ahead.  My GF gets on the phone and tries to call--busy signal. She tries again a few minutes later--no answer. She tries yet again, and no answer.

At this point we're getting hungry, so we decide to walk over and see if we'll get lucky. My girlfriend continues to try and call as we walk.

 We arrive and once again, there's no one at the door. We put our names down on the clipboard that's next to a cordless phone that's ringing off the hook. 

We wait ten minutes and the same man finally comes to the entrance and picks up the ringing phone. He once again writes down names and then turns his attention to the gaggle of people outside the door. We ask him how long the wait will be, and this time he says an hour and a half.  He says that to us as we're looking through the windows and see three of four open tables. We ask him about those tables and he says that the other groups waiting are about to be seated, but instead of seating them, he lets the tables sit there empty for another ten minutes...

We left at that point. Why wait to eat at restaurant that doesn't make an effort to keep your business?

Before anyone gets too riled up, I DO know that Saturdays are busy and that we should have tried to call sooner, yada yada. That's not the point. 

What upset me about Nopalito's experience were a few things:
1) Nopalito's does not take reservations. You have to call ahead to put  your name on the list.
Fine--that business decision is their prerogative. But, IF that's the decision you choose to make, then you should have someone staffing the phone at all times--especially on a Saturday night. We called and kept calling. Not answering is not an option. 

2) They don't have a greeter/host:
What's their problem--are they short staffed? On a Saturday night? Come on! That's just plain stupid.  There are tons of people looking for jobs right now and they decide to run their seemingly busy restaurant without a competent host? I know that my experience would have been a ton better if they had 1) someone dedicated to running the list of diners waiting to be seated and 2) to welcoming potential diners and seating them instead of leaving tables empty for 10-20 minutes until magically deciding that they can be seated. 

Eating out is supposed to be an experience--from walking in to walking out the door. Restaurants should be judged for that complete experience, not just on their food. 

Nopalito's needs to work on the basics before I'll consider trying to eat here again.
author: Laura M.

description:
If NOPA was soo good, why not try Nopalito. We tried the recommended carnitas w/ a side of Tamal Dulce de Calabaza y Atole Champurrado - some kinda of corn dish. The portions were a bit small w/ sort of spendy prices, but it is a mexican version of NOPA. I think I'll stick to the authentic mexican taquerias for my preferences. 

It's no Mamacita...
author: Minh V.

description:
It's at first a little confusing how to get into this place (my first time, I felt like a dog running laps around a food bowl), but once you do you won't want to leave for a while.

The food here is karate chop yo' ass flavorful!  Scrumptious!  Aaaachingly good.  Makes mouths happy.  Do you understand?

The carnitas and the pozole rojo are my personal favourites, but I am partial to pork.  The taco de pescado is the best I've ever had in SF.  Any morsel I've ever had the good fortune to savour here has been breathtakingly enjoyable.

Portions aren't large, nor is the parking lot, but this place remains a true treat for SF restaurant-goers.

They don't take reservations, per se, but you can call ahead to put your name on the waiting list.  I've never had that long of a wait.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
I love this place, Great food, Great drinks, NIce atmosphere, efficient staff, good location.....
Only remark, I love avocado and the three time I went there, I notice that the avocado they use are never ripe enough. Way too hard. 
They could get another star from me if they get more ripe avocados !
author: Fred M.

description: Got the carnitas, and taquitos.  Both were very good.
author: Michael E.

description: Owner showed disrespect and doubted us thinking that we got seated without anyone helping us although we did checkin properly at front counter with the lady and she accompanied us to the table. We felt racially differentiated .
author: Yelp S.

description:
Came here starving and I'm glad I did.  We got the totopos(sp?) which were pretty good but the main course was the carnitas.  reading reviews on here before we ordered everyone made it sound like this was the must order item on the menu and they were correct.  The meat completely melts in your mouth!  My friend said her margarita was really good but you would have to take her word for it I was recovering from tailgating at candlestick earlier in the day.

The Service wasn't great but it was mostly due to the part that they seemed pretty understaffed, The girl who helped us was very friendly and helpful when we ordered, we just hardly saw her.
author: Brandon N.

description:
I really liked this place! 

Friend and I split the shrimp enchilada and vegetarian quesadilla.  I really enjoyed both, and though there was barely any shrimp in the enchilada, the flavors and other ingredients were great and I didn't mind at all.

Portions on the smaller side.

I like that they start your meal and end your meal with a complimentary little something. Friendly, casual service and great outdoor (heated) patio seating.
author: Richa A.

description: This restaurant has a fun & funky environment the drinks were refreshing from the strawberry orchata to the sangria.  Crispy pork quesadilla & the chicken torta was so full of flavor. We will be back!
author: Raych J.

description:
This place was amazing! By far some of the best Mexican food I've tasted in SF. The wait can be a bit long but if you put your name in and go for a drink by the time you get back you'll be ready for your reservation.

The enchiladas were amazing and the totopos were delicious. My dining partners ordered the mole which had really intense delicious flavors as well. This place uses some really high quality ingredients and the dishes are really freshly prepared.
author: Josh G.

description:
Went for lunch today with my mom and definitely enjoyed myself.  We got there a bit late for normal brunch hours so we were seated immediately.  My mommy got one of there house-made sodas which was different, but pretty refreshing.  
For lunch my mommy went with the tostada and I went with the machaca. Both were good. If you are hungry, the tostada was a bit small but an excellent blend of ingredients and flavors with nothing overwhelming. The machaca filled me up. The black beans were an excellent touch, and the shrimp was perfectly balanced.
Service was prompt and courteous. No complaints and I feel for the food the prices were totally fair. Will be back for more!
author: Rob B.

description: I try and take all of my out-of-town friends here or at least make it a recommendation for anyone visiting. My experiences here area always delightful. Service is quick and food is outstanding! While a little on the pricey side, if you go with a friend and split the dishes you can get away with not paying too much. I am a HUGE fan of the empanadas and carnitas, goes great with a house margarita! Great tip, the wait can get long so be sure and call the call ahead list and beat out the long line!
author: Megan T.

description: OK were not people that leave a bad review because of bad service or atmosphere. The problem with this place is two of our dishes we Killer!! The other two the exact opposite, flavorless and well after one bite I pushed the dish away! The carnitas was good and the quesadilla was good also. My daughter got the ribs and they were mostly fat and I think for being the most expensive thing on the menu that I would expect my 12 year old to leave full, but she was very disappoint and wanting more food. Lastly the Ceviche was a bit disappointing also. The salad was good though. Anyways I did give them 3 starts because a couple of the dishes were pretty good, but the rest not so much.... I would not go back!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description:
Carnitas, bitches!  Overall: solid 4 stars.  Reasonably priced, good ambiance.  It's a good thing I worked out b/f going to Nopalito for dinner b/c damn the carnitas were fatty, but delicious, and tender.  Encountered lots of fatty bits, but juicy and I ate up every bit. But enough about carnitas.  We had the stewed lingcod too, which was surprisingly good and came with perfectly cooked and seasoned rice.  Definitely an underrated dish--great to balance out the heavy carnitas.

Thanks to yelp I called same evening to reserve a table. Guess it was a slow Sunday night b/c we sat immediately and everything was easy breezy going and staff was super nice.
author: Caroline I.

description: I wish this place could cater my wedding. Too bad I live in Texas. From the moment the totopos (I think that's what the chips were called) hit my mouth, I was in love. They were fantastic. The cheese, the red sauce, the thickness of the chip, mmmmm. Everything my fiancée, our friend and I ate that night was marvelous. we had about 7 of their dishes including starters and enjoyed every single bite. Definitely worth waiting for over an hour for a table.
author: Maria J.

description: Great food!!!! The staff is so fun, they help you pick wonderful food and drink. All FRESH. Worth every calorie!!!!!
author: Carhy Z.

description:
We ate here with friends on a rainy night. Perhaps due to the rain, it wasn't crowded and we were seated right away.

We started with the horchata, made with almond milk instead of rice milk, according to the menu. Then we shared the tortilla chips, which come pre-soaked in salsa (making them tasty and kept us from needing our own salsa bowls).  I had the Pozole, which was great and gigantic!, and he had a duck taco and the chicken mole tamale. Our friends had Ablondigas and veggie enchiladas.  The meal was finished with two of their chocolate popsicles which are more like frozen cinnamon-fudge bars on sticks. To die for! 

In addition to offering delicious food, the complex where the restaurant is located has free parking. What more could a San Franciscan ask for!?
author: Karen C.

description: I love that they have Gluten free options! Love the food...our service was just "eh," but usually it's pretty good.
author: Sheryl P.

description: Food was okay was too grease.  Staff should be more attentive.  Waited 25 mins for anyone too acknowledge us and ask what we wanted to drink.  Don't think I would go back.  Wasn't impressed and didn't live up too all the hype.
author: Brenda B.

description:
They describe themselves as "A vibrant neighborhood Mexican kitchen, celebrating the traditional cookery of Mexico and utilizing our philosophy of purchasing local, organic and sustainable ingredients."

That sums it up, it's not a taqueria place you'd go for a burrito (which I love too). It's an awesomely fresh and delicious mexican restaurant.

The food is packed with Insanely fresh and unique flavors, and contains textures I've never experienced with tortillas let alone any kind of mexican food. 

We just ordered off the left side of the menu, which was more like tapas plates. We ordered 6 plates total, and walked away satisfied and amazed at the reasonable prices. We'll be back again real soon. I think we found a new favorite.

Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón dish and Carnitas were amazing.
author: Brendan M.

description: Great food from the folks at Nopa.  Now with tequila to boot.  The kitchen continues to put out very good regional mexican dishes.
author: G R.

description:
NO-pa-lease-NO, 

Hey ya fockers that gave me bad food that has me sick and unable to sleep on a work night. Yea you. Here is why I'll never be back.

1st and Foremost, your disorganized staff is the reason people wait 2 hours to get food not because your place is unjustly popular. The front of the house person sat the group that checked in immediately before us after 30 mins. So how the heck did we get seated after 1 hour 15 mins, 30 mins beyond our estimated wait? Once I got inside I realized why, not only is the staff running back and forth like chickens with their heads cut off they aren't communicating. The table next to us asked for a special salsa on the side. You brought them the salsa after a few minutes then a few minutes later someone else brought them the same salsa only to have it sent back because, guess what, somebody already took care of it. So you waste a few minutes here waste a few there and it adds up to bitter customers pacing in front of your restaurant. I seriously suggest the owner taking the whole staff on a field trip up to that Puerto Rican spot in San Rafael to see in person how a super busy place can communicate, stay organized and pump out happy customers like a machine.

2nd, after waiting a total of 2 hours to be handed $40s in food. We were presented with steak that was pink in the middle yet chewy(is this an indicator of cheap meat?), chorizo that was greasy, homemade tortillas that were gummy, and a shrimp salsa that was fishy mushy and blah. I swear I could slap a cook when I bite into a taco and all the chewy meat pulls out on the first bite leaving a hollow tortilla. Come On Man that's not cool and certainly not a $15 taco plate. Also your Enchiladas Potosinas aren't Enchiladas Potosinas they are tacos rojos and not worthy of being called Enchiladas Potosinas. I suggest you fly the cooks happy asses to San Luis Potosi and serve them the real deal maybe a light bulb will go off and they'll realize maybe we should change the name.

3rd your guajillo salsa tastes good but it wasn't pushed through a strainer so I got a mouthful of impossible to chew bitter chunks of dried chili. No Bueno. I can't say gnawing on bitter dried chili peppers is a desire of mine. Your salsa would be killer if you made it smoother.

4th and finally. You did me dirty. I don't know if it was your salsa, fishy shrimp, rubber steak or greasy chorizo but I have a horrible pain in my stomach thanks to you mother lovers. Now I've gotta be up for work soon and I can't sleep because I feel like the alien from SpaceBalls is going to pop out my stomach any moment and start singing, "Hello! ma baby: Hello! ma honey: Hello! ma ragtime gal"

So yea good luck to ya.
author: R J.

description:
It took my friend and I three tries to get seats at Nopalito. This place does not take reservation, but you may put down your name by phone as you are on your way there. I did that two times, which still left us needing to wait for an hour or so. But by the third time, like a charm, we got seated right away. 

I came here to try their carnita because it was on the 7x7.com 2010 SF Big Eat List. If it's on the list it must be good right? That wasn't the only reason I wanted to dine at Nopalito though. It was more so because Nopalito is not any Mexican restaurant...it is an ORGANIC Mexican restaurant. Also, I'd been wanting to try this Mexican stable sauce call Mole. 

Upon seated, the waiter gave us water and a small bowl of fried chickpeas. And as hungry as I was, I started munching on them. They were good. Not too greasy, not too salty, just how I like them to be. I had looked at the menu so many times before since I'd been wanting to try this place for awhile. 

We ordered what was on the list, the Carnitas. I think what got this carnitas on the list was that unlike many Mexican restaurant, which served their carnitas shredded, Nopalito served it as a whole in a baked parchment paper. Using a folk, the carnitas could be easily shredded apart. Very juicy and tender, but just not as juicy as most carnitas you get at other Mexican restaurants. I think it was because other Mexican restaurant then soaked them in grease. Nopalito's carnitas was good, but just not something I would go back purposely for. 

We also ordered Mole Chicken since I wanted to try Mole. My coworker told me about how mole was made with chocolate, so I expected it to be sweet, but it wasn't as sweet as I could have imagined. The sauce tasted very unique. It was a little sweet yet bitter as the sweetness trailed off. I didn't really enjoy it much. I had to scoop some sauce away and just ate the chicken by itself. The poached chicken was really tender. I like it a lot. The rice was really good too. It was cooked with tomato, so it was very appetizing. 

What I love the most out of everything I ate at Nopalito that night though, was their Housemade Corn Tortillas. Both the entrees were served with homemade corn tortilla. Now I think this tortilla should have been on the list instead. It was so good, especially when warm!

I don't think I would wait in line too long for Nopalito, but I would order take out as they have a take out window. But the food probably taste better when it's hot out right?
author: Mandy C.

description: All in all awesome experience here.  I mean the fact that there is parking is a major major plus.  The service was excellent and everyone was very happy with their meal.  Excellent tortillas and excellent soups.  The carnitas was to die for and definitely something I would get the next time.  I also liked their take away window too.  Very cool if you live in the neighborhood and want some really good Mexican food to go.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
So yummy! Took the advice of yelpers and got the Totopos con Chile and they were great. All the hype about the Carnitas is... totally true! They are amazing!

You can't make reservations here, but what you can do is call in advance and walk over... except last time we did that we still ended up waiting another 45 minutes on top. Friday night... what can you do? But the hostess was really friendly and apologetic. Actually, the entire wait staff is really friendly. Perfect place for date night :-)

sidenote: if you happen to be sitting under the heaters you're a little too warm, but if you're not sitting under them you're a little too cold... what a conundrum.
author: Abbey S.

description:
Nopalito never disappoints! I am such a huge fan. Every time I want some yummy Mexican food with fresh ingredients and flavor twists, I had to Nopalito. 

For starters they give you these addictive little fried chickpeas that are snack-a-rific! Then they hit you with a famous margarita or one of their other fabulous concoctions. Then you get to dive into the yumminess. My favorites are the veggie quesidilla and the pork, but you really can't go wrong with the menu. 

The service is top-notch, take out is always on time and on target. The only drag is that while dining in, you have to go outside and come back in another door to use the restroom. But for food this good at such a right price, I'll take that one drawback! 

Nopalito for life!
author: Nissa A.

description: The food was delicious! I would recommend the Totopos and Quesadilla with Chicharron.  Can't wait to go back again!
author: Gil F.

description:
If you want more salt and savory in your beer, try the Michelada. I ordered the ceviche and found all the seafood ingredients from the fish to the squid to be fresh. The tamal had a mole sauce that was very complex and left me contemplating the mix between chocolate, tangy and savory.

The presentation with the pork in a paper wrapper was a bit difficult to navigate, but I'm sure
The staff was friendly and very accommodating.


I would definitely hit this place up again.
author: Jim B.

description:
In a David-vs-Goliath upset of epic proportion, Nopalito's rock cod ceviche (a modest $10) beats La Mar's cebiche (don't be confused, the Peruvians like to use the "b" instead of the "v" to feel special) hands down.

Take that overpriced, Embarcadero tourist and business crowd! Wut?!  Awwwww yeah...

Ok, I'm getting carried away.  All's I'm saying is Nopalito's ceviche is bomb.  I literally ate every bite and then lapped up the leftover juice.  Don't worry, I had a napkin tucked in my shirt in case of spillage.  

Oh yeah, I had something else too, but I honestly can't remember what it was...
author: Susan L.

description:
My BF and I came here at the recommendation of an Inn Keeper from the Chateau Tivoli (please see review for Chateau Tivoli). The food is solidly good. I had issue with the Pozole: I am used to more homine in my grandmother's pozole. Still the red broth was good and the rest of the food we ate satisfied. 

So, 3 stars instead of 4: service. We found the staff not as attentive to us as they wer toward other tables. Our water glasses sat empty while servers walked by other tables and filled half full/empty glasses for other guests. Never did we get asked if there was anything more would we like. Not quite sure why we were treated so, but the food is not exceptional to merit going back.
author: Robert A.

description: We love this place. Yes, it's hard to get a seat sometimes, but the call-first system works pretty well. And on 11/17/13 the hostess was SO NICE and accommodating, we didn't really mind waiting a bit. Even for a non-meat-eater, there's plenty of fabulous food on the menu. The cafe con leche ice cream bar for dessert was simply to die for. The service was efficient, fast and friendly. And for an all-organic, sustainable menu, it's very reasonable.
author: Holly M.

description: A friend and I came to this Restaurant before going to a giants game. When we arrive the entrance was a little confusing but it works well once you find it. My friend who is from the city said it would be hard to find parking however I had o problem finding a spot as I drove in. We ordered a few Items to share however I was looking to order the Pambazo which they said is only at their other location on 9th street. I also ordeed the Pozole and it was ok. the meet was not tender and the flavor was not as great as other Pozoles I have had all over the States and All over Mexico. I must say the Quesadilla with chicharon was amazing and the Tamale was also great. I gave it a 4 star because the other items were very good. Just don't order the Pozole here.
author: JC L.

description:
It's so nice to write a great review! This was a wholly great experience and worth every penny! For the first time dining in this city, I got the check and said, OUTLOUD, "That's it?" The food was diverse, as were the ingredients used. The presentation of every dish was beautiful. The people were genuinely happy to be of service. A mistake was made and the corrected it and overcompensated, but within reason. The interior seemed cozy without feeling cramped, and it was full. Just take one look at the online menu and see if you don't get hungry.

ENJOY!
author: Robert M.

description:
My fiance and I went here with my parents on a whim after visiting the impressionist exhibit at the de young.  Got seated on a Friday evening right away at 5:30.  Maybe we were lucky?  

As always with good restaurants, the food speaks for itself.  Usually when I go to these top 100s, they give you like a child's size portion of meat.  Not at Nopalito.  My fiance got the carnitas and it was like a pile the size of a pitcher's mound (err, a bit of an exaggeration).  I got the chicken mole and the plate was full of food.  I don't even think I finished what I had.

Other random pluses:
I really like the complimentary corn nuts they give you. I'm also severely allergic to peanuts, pine nuts, & hate cilantro and they were VERY attentive to all my needs.  Service was friendly & casual!  My margarita was simply but refreshing.

My only knock is the bathroom situation.  It was pretty cold out and you have to go outside the restaurant and walk all the way around to the other side.  That felt weird.  Also, did anyone else have trouble finding the opening to the main door curtain?  I don' think I was that drunk . . .. but I've been wrong before.

Solid restaurant, great fancy Mexican food that doesn't skimp, fresh ingredients, good time.
author: Annie F.

description:
Five of us dropped in on a Thursday Night. Was about a ten minute wait with no reservations and the entire wait staff (host, waitress, and bartender) were very friendly.

I'm not sure what it is, but I always seem to order the blandest dish. I opted for the pork shoulder stew, which was still decent and they bring out their restaurant-grown crushed pepper, onions, and cabbage to help you bring the dish to your own taste.

The girl had the carnitas, which was stellar. Very flavorful and the meat was tender. 

Friend went for the braised duck leg, which was succulent and tasty (as duck tends to be, I guess).

Best friend went for the chicken consumme, and I don't know how a dish including turnips cauliflower, and garbanzo beans has a bolder flavor than a pork shoulder stew, but it did (in a good way).

The corn tortillas they bring out are a little starchier and dryer than I'm used to, but I suppose that helps balance out just how strong the drink flavours are. We were initially going to pass but the bartender was entertaining as he kept hawking his wares and I'll be honest, they were worth it. I had the Mezcal Paloma, which essentially tasted like a combination of grapefruit and smoke - loved it. Best friend went with the Bloody Maria, which was basically a Bloody Mary using beer instead of vodka. Not my thing (as I don't like tomato juice) but he enjoyed it.

One oddity of the restaurant (as two of our party found out) is that you have to exit the building to use the restroom (they're by the takeout station and there's no clear path without going through the food prep area). 

There were LOTS of groups (I think the entire restaurant was filled with parties of four or more, except for one pair on a date) which is a good idea since there are no sides included with your entrees. We just kept passing our dishes to the right, but if on a date I'd definitely order some smaller dishes to split.
author: Justin B.

description:
I stopped here for a quick lunch with a friend today, and left very satisfied and impressed, without having been appalled at the bill.  The staff treated us as if they knew us already, which is good for me because I'm a big dork who likes to spazz in enthusiasm about great food, and I didn't feel judged for my flailing.  There was a group of 5 or 6 ladies lunching at a nearby table, along with a toddler, and it seemed an appropriate setting for group or family gatherings.  And lordy, the food at Nopalito was fantastic.  I think I'll need to visit a couple more times before maybe upgrading my rating to five stars, but believe me, it won't be a chore.

I ordered a margarita, which was nice, but I wish I had followed my friend's recommendation and ordered a mezcal cocktail -- same price, more adventurous, and quite tasty according to my friend and previous Yelp reviewers.  We split the fish taco (Taco de Pescado al Pastor), squash blossom quesadilla (Quesadilla con Flor de Calabaza), beef empanada (Empanada con Deshebrada de Res), and chicken enchilladas with mole sauce (Enchiladas de Mole con Pollo). I love fish tacos, but my personal preference for tacos is more like sloppy street vendor food rather than what was served at Nopalito; however it was undeniably delicious and high-quality.  The enchiladas were my first mole experience, and it was a great introduction, though sweeter than I was expecting.  I think I'll have to try mole at a few more places before I figure out my preference.

My favorites were, in ascending order, the empanada (delicious, crispy, again with the fresh ingredients, and the beef was excellently prepared) and the quesadilla.  Holy crow, that quesadilla may have changed my life.  I had never had squash blossoms, and their crispness, combined with the subtle creaminess of the queso fresco, was such a delightful surprise.  

There's plenty of parking in back, prices are reasonable (definitely not Mission taco prices, but you can get something small and completely delicious for $5), and the flavors are pure and clean, and combined in an obviously thoughtful and loving way to provide you with a full and robust bunch of mouthfuls.  The waitstaff was quite friendly and prompt -- maybe they're in such good moods because they get to eat at Nopalito all the time.
author: Kelly F.

description:
Fresh tasting food, good for the body and karma. Love that most ingredients are local and organic, and that the prices don't make you feel the words "local and organic" are going to rob you completely blind. Mid-range prices definitely worth the quality of food, comfort of dining experience and uniqueness of flavor.

You may have to wait a while if you come at peak dinner time, so plan on putting in your name early and/or hanging out at the bar (standing). The mezcla cocktails are delicious!
author: Jen N.

description: this place doesn't need any more reviews, but i'm sort of perplexed about not having reviewed it years ago when it first opened. i've been back plenty of times and love LOVE this place. the totopos con chile are always a must and it's hard for me to stray away from the quesadilla roja as well. pricey for mexican, yes, but just go there with that expectation and you'll be alright.
author: Regina C.

description:
Would I give this place another try? Hell no! I'd rather eat cat shit with a knitting needle!

Everything was bland... made by a chef that had never heard of a spice rack.  And what kind of Mexican food isn't loaded with grease and cheese anyway?  When I'm looking to blow my diet.... I head directly for two things (1) deep fried oreos with powdered sugar and caramel and (2) Mexican food. This place left much to be desired.  Honestly, I can't even remember what I tried... since I didn't eat anything!

Besides that.. you have to walk outside... in the cold... in SF... around the building to go to the solo restroom. Wait amongst all the "take out" patrons while watching your group chow down from behind the glass. It was a torturous experience!  After we left, I hopped next door (grocery store) and picked up some mac and cheese with brussel sprouts.  Comfort food.... mmm.
author: Kai P.

description:
I really enjoyed this place even though I was very skeptical. We shared the empanada, quesadilla con chicharron as well as their version of chips and salsa (totopas con chile) which was bomb. I thought the menu nicely twisted classic Mexican dishes.

It's a cute little place with a very friendly wait staff. Of course it's a tad expensive for what it is...but you have to take into consideration the neighborhood you're in. 

I'll definitely go back.
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
I'll try to work in some less than stellar reviews, because I only have 5 star reviews right now. Problem is, I don't really post unless it was just amazing. But I'll work on providing sme criticism here soon, but this trip to Nopalito will not be the genesis. hands down ***** stars. 

Nopalito uses local/fresh ingredients andf list their purveyors of all products on their website.

I'd been to Nopalito a few times before, mostly for takeout. But it was a downpour, and being on foot in the Haight, finding food and shelter were paramount, and i knew just the spot. Luckily we were seated immediately, right under the heat lamp to thaw/dry out with:

Margaritas: (4 stars) 
[Review: a little sweet fot my taste, but ok overall]

Beer: Modelo (4 stars) 
[Review: no bohemia here. but modelo is my 2nd]

Totopos con Chile (5 Stars)
Tortilla chips, salsa de arbol, cotija cheese, crema and lime
[Review: Love the way they do the chips and sauce here. The chips are smothered in the sauce and heated, with an arrangement of condiments, which we asked for on the side, so we could dress the chios as each of us liked. I'm all in, but if you have dairy sensative people in your group its a good option. Just the chips with sauce is still good]

Taquitos: (4 Star)
They are taquitos, What do you want? =) No really though. Not greasy, very assertive flavors and a decent 2nd starter.

Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamari (5 Stars)!!!
Marinated rock cod, calamari, lime, tomatillo, jalapeños, cilantro, avocado and housemade tortilla chips
[Review: The server maintained that it is the best ceviche in the city. Having only been to the cevecheria in the FiDi, I don't have much to compare, but its equally as good as ive had anywhere, and may edge themout for cleaner fresher notes. Very fresh, very clean flavors/texture, and a perfect course to have before the entree]

Carne Asada y Acelgas a la Mexicana (5 Stars)
Seared flank steak, braised greens, onion, tomato, cilantro, jalapeños , black beans, queso fresco and salsa pasilla
[Review: We shared this, because we were getting kinda full, and this was really only a pitstop, so they did a split at no charge, and this carnes asada plate was perfect size for two of us. Nopalito sources the beef from Marin Sun Farms and its 100% grass fed. Just saying.]

Mezcal Margarita - (5 Stars)
[Review: Maybe it was because I was already several drinks deep when I ordered this, but it was awesome. My fellow diner didn't like it, and I can see how it might be an aquired taste but I thought it was great. The agave plant is smoked when making mescal, so expect a very smoky margarita, if ur not used to this flavor. very good i thought]

No dessert. In fact I've never had desert here, but I have had the pozole, the carnitas, the beet salad, and others at various times, and everything here at Nopalito is good. They take the food industry seriously, and you cannot do yourself wrong, but stopping here, as the prices are reasonable. 5 Star Experience.
author: Jason F.

description:
I've heard everyone rave about this place for a while and finally decided to see what the hype was all about. 

We decided to get 4 small tapas-style plates and two drinks.

I got the Almond Horchata- DISGUSTING. My friend got the Tamarind and that was tasty.

For appetizers, we got the Taquitos de Calabaza, which was my favorite item of the night- the roasted butternut squash was great.

It was all down hill from here...

The ceviche wasn't good and the 'Taco de Pescado al Pastor', which is a seared fish taco was just OK, I personally prefer the fish tacos at El Metate.

and finally the "Tamal de Camote con Mole Amarillo" came and again, was just OK.

I wanted to like this place, I really did but its just decent mexican food with nice decor. If you want REAL mexican food get down to the Mission. If you have a medial palate, this place will serve you just fine.
author: S K.

description: Every part of this meal was delicious! All ingredients were so fresh and complimented each other so well. Try the carnitas...you won't regret it. The freshly made tortillas make all the difference.
author: Ashley J.

description:
Finally went to Nopalito for the 1st time the other night. We ordered a few plates to share. The food was good & prices reasonable. The service was slooooow. Our server greeted us promptly, delivered drinks, took our order and then we got our first dish a few mins later. Then, we didn't see him again. Other people were giving us our order and someone else brought the check. He would just walk right past us & not even ask how we we were doing or if we needed anything. 

Yummy dishes but there is always a wait to eat here. If I was craving mexican, I would still hit up the Little Chihuahua down the street instead. But, NOpalito is a nice, local spot to check out once and awhile.
author: Heather M.

description: The food is ok, nothing special, small portions. costumer service no so ok. I had guests from out of town with 2 kids. Took my guests to the restaurant for lunch on a week day when most of their tables were available. The hostess basically gave us a hard time and attitude for having a stroller and I think mentioned something like strollers were not allowed. I informed her that we got there by cab, and didn't have a car to store the stroller in,  but she still wasn't very friendly and accommodating. She ended up giving us a table, but I did not enjoy the experience.
author: Monica R B.

description: This place is legit. Knowledgeable and friendly staff. I ordered a shot of some great tequila and the Pescado for lunch. We will definitely be back!
author: Michael H.

description:
5 stars for the carnitas (ooh my lordie....meat eaters dream)
4 stars for the ambiance and indoor/outdoor feel
3 stars for the wait

equals

I will be back for brunch again! :) (and order the carnitas...)
author: Deann M.

description:
Wow, wow, wow.  This is real Mexican food.  Not taqueria food.  Real mexican food, like you'll experience in Mexico (if away from a resort town).

The folks at Nopalito really turn it out.  Consistently amazing food.

THE SCENE
Indoor and outdoor seating.  Clean, uncomplicated aesthetic.  And generally, plenty of tables.  Some nights you can end up waiting like 30 or more minutes, but if that's the case, you can always wait next door at Peets :)

THE FOOD
The dishes are simple.  We're not talking about beans and rice plates.  If you order Carnitas, that's what you get and nothing more.  The portions are large and can be shared (if you also have an appetizer).  Speaking of appetizers...you have to try the TOTOPOS CON CHILE -- they are addictive chile rubbed chips.  Also, whatever you have to eat, you should definitely try their HORCHATA -- it's home made and is so much better than any other horchata you'll try other places.  

Some people's reviews say that the food is bland.  That's just not true.  It's not bland - it's subtle.  It's not a "knock em over with super aggressive chile flavors and salsas"  It's more like, "use traditional spices how they were intended to be used -- let the spices subtly enhance the great ingredients."

TAKEOUT
If you are there to order take-out, then walk around the side of the restaurant.  There's a back door for those orders.
author: michael l.

description: tasty small plates and parking! I have always wanted to try Nopalito and finally got the chance a few weeks ago. Tried several different dishes that all had unusual names so cant remember them now- but one was the quesadilla which was tasty and the fish tacos were good too! Reasonably priced but keep in mind if you are actually hungry one dish probably won't fill you up.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I didnt know this was related to Nopa until I came here. I thought it was trying to rip off from the famous restaurant down the street, little did I know they were connected :)

Anyways, the food was very good and I'd love to come back. The ceviche and samosa was delicious and easily fed for 4 people. We also ordered a pitcher of  their white peach frozen cherry sangria, how can you not order this, the name itself makes anyone curious!

I ordered their Enchilada Placeras, little did I know how tasty the dish would be. The chicken was surprisingly good and in combination with the Tortillas made me give the entree a solid grade of an A

I definitely will be back here.
author: Eric A.

description:
We come to nopalito because of:

1. the dog friendly enclosed patio
2. the michelada and organic almond horchata
3. the popsicles
4. the free parking

The menu items we've had so far are hit or miss. The carnitas are probably the best thing on the menu. The chilaquiles, which I usually love, are a huge disappointment here. The tortilla chips are really heavy and the sauce is not flavorful enough to save it. The gordita, quesadillas, enchilada, and tamale are good, but nothing i'd write home about.

The one thing I will write about are the popsicles.  No matter how full you are after your meal, I highly recommend you have whatever flavor they have that day.
author: Lisa C.

description:
t's a cute little restaurant that serves organic Mexican food. Every time I hear the word organic though, it kind of sends chills down my spine. Not because I think it tastes bad, but there's usually a premium in the price tag and I can never tell a difference in organic vs non-organic foods.

For drinks, I ordered a Horchata. Note to self: You do not like Horchatas. It was a weird sweet almond taste that was not well received by my palette. It's definitely a personal thing.

We started off with an Empinada appetizer, which turned out to be a really bad idea because it was huge. I was almost full before I even got to my main entree. It was also sort of dry and bland. 

For the main entree the boyfriend got the Carnitas and I got the Enchilada. I had expected the chicken to already be inside the tortilla, but it wasn't. I've also come to realize I don't like mulato. The chicken was a little dry, but it was white meat afterall. The potatoes on the side were yummy though.The Carnitas was definitely a much better entree. The meat was 10x softer and juicier than my chicken.

I don't think this is right for me. When I think Mexican, I think dense flavors. This was too simple and bland.
author: Thy L.

description: Another check of the 7 by 7 list. I ordered the carnitas and I have to say I was not impressed. There isn't anything special about the meat or the accompaniments. The carnitas was lacking in flavor but was made better with the salsa and the cabbage salad. The place itself is cute and the service was friendly. It's an okay meal, nothing memorable.
author: Eve C.

description:
i love nopalito. you have to wait in line for this one so I like to go during my days off. the modelo especial is refreshing with the perfectly seasoned deep fried soy beans. 

i've had everything on the left-hand side of the second page on the dinner menu. I especially enjoyed the totopos, taco, panucho and tamal. enjoy!
author: Jane C.

description:
I've been here once. One time that is deserving of three stars, but I really dislike giving this rating without multiple visits. but the carnitas. damn tasty. falling apart stringy pork deliciousness on fresh corn tortillas and that salsa...oh man. that salsa was something else.

not to mention all the little treats they give you before and after the actual meal. such fun stuff.

i'm comin back, trying something else and i fully expect it to be a 5 star experience again.
author: Victor B.

description: Whatever the chip appetizer was, was delicious. Yummy margaritas (I would go back just for those). Their reservation process is weird so call ahead and see what they can do
author: Andrea H.

description:
