Ever since this place moved into my neighborhood, I've been visiting it with friends and family regularly. This is not casual Mexcican or taco style food joint, it's gourmet style Mexican and closer to restaurants like Frontera Grill in Chicago. Although they are not a Rick Bayless restaurant (Food Network people will know what I mean) they could very well be as good as his restaurants. They make their own tortillas in house, use organic products for all their food, and make delicious traditional meals. This means they may take a little time and you should order the totopos and a beer while you wait. Or try an almond horchata -- they are divine! I don't know about the mixed drinks, I'm more of a beer or horchata drinker.

I dream about the posole, mole, enchilada, and totopos when I want Mexican food. I also love their variety of entrees - they do them all so well.  Their food is fresh and organic and so it will cost a bit more than your burrito from down in the Mission, but they still keep their prices really reasonable.

If you're coming here, make a reservation, call in early if you must, especially for a party of more than 2. Or, better yet, go during lunch and save yourself the trouble of waiting in line. This place is my go-to for a nice meal. You can even put in an order and get it to go!
author: Sari S.

description:
jeez, yelpers, i am disappointed in your low reviews of this place.  dont listen to those people that are like, "eew, i had to wait, like, an hour to sit down" or "what is this?  i was looking for something greasy and unhealthy!"  the reason there is a wait is because IT'S GOOD!  the reason its not greasy and loaded down with grease is because its a hell of a lot more authentic than chevy's or el torito.

we had:

- flautas papas - nice and crispy taquitos with a tasty, albeit benign, potato filling.  the potatoes were seasoned with some kind of chili, but it wasn't overpowering.

- the chips and salsa - homemade chips, lime juice, crema and a tasty homemade salsa.  kind of expensive, but it was a more like nachos than chips and salsa.  a great starter.

- chicharron quesadilla - a crispy red tortilla stuffed with cheese and crispy pork belly.  it was amazingly delicious.

- carnitas - WOW!  amazing.  the best carnitas i have ever had.  they basically just plop down a hunk of unbelievably tender, pull apart with a fork, pork.  it was crispy on the outside, moist on the inside... just like it should be.  the smell of the tortillas alone are to die for and they taste even better.  the tomatillo salsa they serve with it was perfect.

two of us shared plates, had alcoholic beverages, were very full by the end of the meal, and our bill came out to $25 each which isn't too bad for an upscale eatery.  i definitely plan on coming back and it is definitely recommended for those who appreciate the finer details of mexican cuisine.
author: Christian C.

description:
I had been wanting to eat here for a long time, and I am sad that I cannot give it more than three stars given that Nopa is my favorite restaurant in the world.

They don't take reservations, and had to wait 45 minutes to sit down, so we drank beers from Falletti while we waited, which was fine.

First, it seems silly to only have one unisex bathroom, and to have to walk outside to get to it.  

Second, the apps are definitely better than the entrees.

Finally, and it's not like I was expecting Chevy's-sized portions or anything, but they are surprisingly small. Especially as compared to Nopa's.

The apps:  Totopos con Chile was great, and the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron was truly amazing.

The entrees:  Carnitas and Birria de Chivo were meager and just okay. We laughed out loud at a side dish of beans that came with one of them -- the "dish" was about the size of a silver dollar and about one centimeter deep and had at most 20 beans in it!

I have no doubt that their ingredients and preparation are wholly authentic, slow-cooked, and sustainable, so we couldn't fathom how that mindset could translate into such insufficient and skimpy servings.

"Nopalito" must translate as "less than Nopa?"
author: Adam Z.

description: Its a big step up from your normal taco joint, but just below a fancy Mexican restaurant.  The vibe is causal and the food is high quality just like nopa. Things are a little pricey, but you get what you pay for in terms of food quality and preparation.  They have some normal everyday things like carnitas but they also have things I haven't really seen on other menus before.  Get adventurous and try something different here and you will be happy, if you go with the carnitas you will probably be underwhelmed for the price.
author: Vince C.

description:
Nopalito=post-DMV rejuvenation

Somewhere in O'Hare my lonely driver's license is mingling with well traveled dust bunnies and so it was time for another dreaded DMV appointment. My DMV appointment wasn't terrible, but that's another review. What was fantastic was finally getting to try out Nopalito afterwards.

The taquitos were brilliant and the quesadilla perfect. The waitress was awesome and described the menu and options with great recommendations. Simply one of the best lunches I've had in SF!
author: Ennis O.

description:
Can you ask for more from a restaurant than great qualify food, fresh ingredients, friendly service and reasonable prices?  Oh, how about it being right in my neighborhood!  Seriously, I LOVE this place.

I have dreams about the carnitas (which I hear are marinated in beer, orange and cinnamon).  The first bite of the piping hot, homemade tortilla stuffed with the juicy pork, pickled veggies and cabbage and tomatillo is incomparable.  

Yesterday for a party of five, we ventured beyond the carnitas (although we got two orders of those as well). We also ordered the:

- posole rojo (pork shoulder stew with side of fresh tortilla chips, which was the perfect starter)
- the chicken mole (the mole is so complex-tasting: equal parts sweet (from the chocolate), toasty (nuts) and tangy (various spices and chile)
- vegetarian quesadilla (nice balance to the meat dishes - very hearty and a good-size app portion

As for drinks, the almond horchata is hands down my favorite.  The cinnamony sweet drink is so refreshing and balances out the spices from our food.  Less impressive was the highly touted michelada - beer with tomato juice, salt and lime.  It seemed bland (but then again maybe it's because I was expecting it taste like a bloody mary).

The only downside is the ridiculously wait (being able to call in and leave your name is essential).  Of course it was a Saturday night, but the wait ended up being 2 1/2 hours!  I didn't mind since I live close by but the restaurant were so appreciative that they gave us an extra veggie quesadilla and the totopos con chile (chips with cheese, cream and salsa), which were fantastic, by the way.

Hands down, one of my favorites.
author: F. P.

description:
My girlfriend and I took a holiday to San Francisco over Memorial Day to visit some friends.  One of them recommended Nopalito for dinner on our last night...she had wanted to try it for a while.  The place was hopping when we showed up...all the tables were full so we had to wait for 15 minutes.  No problem, it gave us time to look at all the dishes as they came out.  We were sat at a communal table and started perusing the menu.  A couple was sat at the remaining two seats and after about five minutes decided to move to the next table (despite it being another communal table).  It was weird, but whatever, time to order.

We decided to go for one appetizer and one entree apiece to have dinner family style.  As apps, we ordered: tostada de tinga, tamal enchilado de queso & puerco, and quesadilla roja con chicharron ( i am a fan of any sort of fried pork product so i could not resist).  They arrived quickly and all were delicious, but i think the tostada was my favorite.  The quesadilla was deep fried and i think i was just expecting the chicharron to be fried.  I was not a big fan of the "taco-like" shell.  Next up for dinner we ordered: carne asada, mole poblano con pollo, and stewed cod (i cannot remember nor pronounce my dish to save my life).  All were decent.  My cod was stewed with tomatoes, peppers, onions, and capers.  It was slightly spicy and sweet at the same time.  I tried both other dishes and believe that mine was the best of the trio.  

Dinner was a good experience.  I think all three of us would return, however, we would revise our strategy.  The appetizer section of the menu definitely was the better part of the meal.  Service was also a bit spotty.  I know it was busy, but we were sometimes neglected by the waitress.  Also, b/c the waitress disappeared for a bit, it took a while for the appetizers to arrive.  Then the entrees showed up before we were finished with our appetizers.  Since there is a take out window my advice is to go to it, buy your apps, and enjoy them at home.  

One last note...the bathroom is in the take-out area.  So, you have to leave the main restaurant, walk outside, and go in to the separate part of the restaurant.  It also is a single bathroom so lines can form depending on how busy the place is.
author: Jamie J.

description: Loved this place, but wish it was more vegetarian friendly in the entree department. I ended up having the quesadilla as an entree, which was done really- perfect amount of food and delicious. We started with the totopas, these got hotter the more we ate them! Really yummy though. BF ordered mole poblano con pollo and raved about it. I tasted the mole and wow! I want a jar to take back to DC. I had the quesadilla de flor de calabaza. Soft but thick, sweet corn tortilla filled with zucchini flowers, zucchini, and cheese. Delicious! As for cocktails, I had the sangria (like no other sangria I have ever had, savory and zesty), and BF had mezcal I think, and el diablo. Call ahead to get on the wait list!
author: Laura N.

description:
I have been here 5 times too many. The last (and I do mean the LAST) time I ate here the bill for 2 of us was $70+ tip. We had one drink each and one shared appetizer (the chips), plus entrees (if you can call them that). The portions are extraordinarily small, and everything tastes the same...overly spiced and HOT!!! The tacos are bare. The rice and beans are a joke. The wine "mugs" are not cute -- they are pathetic. 

$70 is obscene for mexican food. No thank you. Never again.
author: Lars J.

description:
Let me tell it to ya straight-

All organic everythang..
Fresh as the summer day is long..
Ceviche that has calamari (unique touch, pass the lime wedges)..
White wine sangria w/ seasonal fruit (rarely is romance this succinct)..
Great service, lively yet casual atmosphere, extremely well-priced..
And did i mention sparkling water on tap?
Yup, i've gone to heaven.. 
This is a meal where you leave thinkin': what have i done to deserve such greatness??! Don't ask, don't tell ;)
author: Rachel S.

description:
My review from when Nopalito opened is due for a revision:

things have fallen into place nicely at Nopalito, never been disappointed again.

Have been back quite a few times lately, from weekend brunch to weeday lunch breaks - never a dull meal.
author: Francis S.

description:
This is NOT mexican food. You will wait for a table, well it is San Francisco, or so we are led to believe. Who cares about parking when the service is completely inadequate and the food is bland. Bland mexican food is a no go. 

Party of 4 and our experience: 

Ordered 2 bloody mary's, server said 'it will be about 10 minutes and they mixing up the base'. When WE asked again 20 minutes later, and said any word on the bloody mary's we were told in a VERY condescending english accent that it has only been 12 minutes and that was that! 

Requested their spiciest sauce for the huevos and our bandana head clad server brought me mashed up grapefruit, infused with orange juice, and I quote. I tasted it and asked for anything with some spice or maybe a tomato based salsa, he looked at me as if I was crazy and then stated in yet another condescending manner 'we have NOTHING with a tomatoe base or spicier. Walked away and then when we got the bill they charged us $5.00 for the 'hot sauce'. BTW-my daughter dumped the grapefruit mash in our margarita and it was MUCH improved margarita!

So we were made to feel like idiot customers and they NEVER did bring the bloody mary's or offer an alternative, AND they charged us more for hot sauce. Will never go back as they seem to be truly elitist in their treatment of customer. Where is the manager here? No decent bloody mary mix on a sunday, surly employees and disasterous hot sauce from a mexican restaurant....really?

I have been to Nopa and it is a 100 times BETTER experience. Do you care about parking or a good meal from people who care about their customers?
author: Jayne K.

description:
A group of 8 of us gathered around a communal bar-style table with high chairs before adventuring to opening weekend of Rango at the Kabuki. 

A friend of mine and I split the Pozole for our entree, and we ordered a bunch of apps! Get the Totopos con Chile - it's amazing. Everyone at the table couldn't keep their hands out of our appetizers! 

Oh and order the margaritas with salt on the rocks - you won't regret that!

If you can GET in - it's a great place to go :) especially on a date!
author: Leanne D.

description:
This was the first place we stopped to eat on a recent trip to SF.  I normally don't seek out Mexican when we go out of town because we have so many good options in SD but this had been highly recommended by a reliable source. 

Overall, I enjoyed the look of the place, the service, the unique options, and the food.  I was tempted to give this place 5 stars but some of the dishes, while well presented didn't deliver on taste.  The ceviche looked really good but the corn chips seemed to overpower the seafood itself.  I wasn't crazy about the machaca de camarones but my wife really liked it.  The chicken mole was very good and something I would suggest trying.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Precious, precious.

Overpriced Mexican for white people who are offended by tacqueria servers with Mexican accents.
author: Cheezy P.

description:
We went for the carnitas, as suggested on the Big Eat list. I left a believer in the chile peanut mole duck leg. And of Modelo in a can with salted lime, yesss. 
With our food came a nice stack of hot corn tortillas, my favorite. I will put anything into a corn tortilla and make it a mini taco. So naturally, I started shredding my duck meat off the leg, plopped some of the flavorful, hint of spice, mole sauce in, and topped it with a bit of the butternut squash that comes on the side and bingo!! Best damn mini taco I've ever had! I think it was the best vehicle for experiencing all the flavors and textures at once. 
But seriously, great service, delectable menu items, warm atmosphere and not to mention sustainable and organic. It's a win.
author: Claudia F.

description:
Again I've tried most of the menu.  Love the totopos con chile.  Aiy so spicy but delectable.  Ask for an extra side of crema to kill the burn.  The carnitas are a must try. There's a lot of pork in this dish so I usually ask for extra tortillas.  Moist, flavorful, and mmm mmm good.  The quesadilla con chicharron is also lovely.  Fatty crunchy fried pork pops in your mouth and does not disappoint.  Oh and the torta de chilorio is what you are having if you decide to lunch here because it is only available for lunch.  It comes with house made potato chips and the bread is a nice ole squishy bun.  It's a sloppy joe gone Mexican- delish!

The bonus take out window on the side so you can get in and out with your food without pushing your way through the crowd is brilliant.  

Note- the smaller lower priced items are indeed smaller.  So if you are hungry like I am most of the time, you might want 2 or 3 of them to the one bigger dish.  

At the end of the meal, you get these tiny little Mexican wedding cookies, which are so dry you'll be wondering why you didn't order a glass of milk.  Be sure to have something to wash it down.  Tasty but chokingly dry.
author: CHRISTINE L.

description:
Wow.  Absolutely amazing.

Three of my friends and I went here last night to celebrate 2 of their birthdays.  What an experience.  Our server, Emmanuel, was very helpful and patient with us Nopalito virgins.  The restaurant is not huge.  It has an indoor and outdoor patio area that is covered and very well heated for those cold nights.  I love exhibition kitchens and they have that as well.  Once sat we were given a small dish of salted chickpeas(?).  

I had the much talked about Michelada.  Never had it before and it was good.  Next time I will try the Sangria. I was the DD, so I couldn't partake in too many adult bevs.  **One thing to note about the Sangria (as told by our server) is that the fruit that accompanies the Sangria differs depending on what is in Season.**  Makes sense, but we were salivating from the white wine sangria w/ frozen grapes picture.  Yesterday they had it with Oranges.    

We decided upon the Totopos con Chile and Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamari.  Both were delicious.  I'm lactose myself, but I didn't want my friends to miss out on one of their popular apps.  I just made sure I had one of the chips from below.  Still yummy.  They got a little kick to them from the sauce it's covered in.  But, the crema compliments it nicely and cools it down a bit.  

We all ordered separate entrees and decided to just grab a piece from each as needed to try.  I already knew that I wanted to have the Carnitas from the get.  It was so damn tasty and moist.  I could have just eaten that without everything else that came with it.  I guess you could think of it as the one of best Atkins meal out there.  All Meat and Veggies.  My other friends ordered the Enchiladas Placeras (chicken was tender and moist.  sauce was light and not too overwhelming), Mole Poblano con Pollo (my first mole and it was surprising good...subtly sweet and yummy), Albondigas al Chilmole (recommended by our server as an "adventurous" dish...meatballs were done perfectly - not dry - and though the ingredients were indeed a bit adventurous they all seemed to work great together).  **I know some people have said remarks about their portions, but we found their portions perfect sized.  So much so that we didn't have room for dessert as you'll read below.  And we are all about desserts**

We were so stuffed that we couldn't indulge in dessert (boooo).  But, our server was so thoughtful and brought our (2) birthday celebrants Mexican cookies with a candle for each.  Sooo sweet.  They were a perfect way to end our meal.  

Our bill for 2 apps, 2 drinks, 1 bottle, 4 entrees = $116 and change.  Not bad for real good organic Mexican food with local, sustainable ingredients.  Service was amazing.  Even though our water was next to us, we never had to refill it ourselves.  The staff are very attentive and so nice.  We shall be back Nopalito!  Count on it.  

Things to Note:
- Free Parking in Parking Garage next door
- They don't take reservations, but you can call ahead and say you're on your way.  They'll really put your name down on the wait list as they're talking to you on the phone.  
- They offer Complimentary Still and Sparkling Water.
- The Carnitas is on 7x7's 2010 Big Eat SF (100 Things to Eat Before You Die).  They weren't kidding.
author: Heizel M.

description: love the ambiance, super chill, open and clean.  Empanada was delicious & the Carne Asada and Chorizo plate was a hit.  the Paloma cocktail & white Sangria were fantastic.  yummmmm
author: Mimi X.

description:
This review is only for take out.... but I called ahead and ordered 1 quesadilla roja and a ginger lemonade to go. Best part was that there is a separate window for to-go orders, so you don't have to meander through the restaurant looking for someone to help you. Just go to the separate entrance!

The quesadilla roja was amazing... perfectly cooked, so flavorful...ah! The ginger lemonade was refreshing, and now I'm dying to eat a real meal here.
author: K. D.

description:
I don't know why I leave the mission to try Mexican food. 
The food was actually really good.  
But very "white".  

The service was just ok. Nothing special and no special attention given. 

The drinks are waaaaaaaaaaay over priced!
C'mon $9 for a ok margarita, the size of coffee cup. 
I guess I prefer to get my magaritas by the $20 pitcher.
This place is not on my list for a return trip.
author: O. S.

description:
I live across the street & probably eat there 3-5x a week, it's that good. I've taken numerous people there and they too love it.

The reason I eat there is it's all organic & the meat is organic, grass fed, etc. It's hard to find specific restaurants that are all organic, especially right across from where you live.

The Totopos & the Panucho are my favorites, I eat them all the time!

The staff is great, especially when you're a regular like me.

Oh, and the almond cookie they give you at the end is FANTASTIC. I could eat a whole try!

RUN to NoPalito!
author: John S.

description:
We went to Nopalito on a Saturday, so admittedly, there was a long wait. We ordered a pitcher of margaritas at the bar which were very strong and tasty. After an hours wait, we were very hungry, so it was nice that they brought us some complimentary appetizers as soon as we sat down. Suddenly I was no longer upset. 

The real standouts were the carnitas and the vegetable enchiladas, but in general, the food at Nopalita was a fresh, tasty spin on the a traditional Mexican cantina. We will definitely go back, and I don't even mind waiting an hour if they give us more free food.
author: Rakesh J.

description: OK, I love this place, but here's the deal!  I work in the City, but live in the east bay. I come here on weeknights by myself and sit at the bar. No wait, free parking! no crowding and you get to talk to the bartender. They're not shy about showing you how they make the best House margaritas in the Bay Area.  Yes, I've had some things I was not crazy about - like the smashed shrimp? enchiladas.  Bu try the sweet potato taquitos, vegetarian and the best. Carnitas, mole poblano, pozole rojo - the best. A little expensive?  Try Comal in Berkeley - that's expensive! Add parking for Comal subtract it for the Nopalitos Broderick and it's a deal! The service excels, even for the lone diner at the counter.
author: Robert B.

description:
After visiting a friend at the hospital, his family took my husband and me out to Nopalito for lunch.  It was great.  I had the melt-in-your-mouth carnitas and it was lovely. It came with corn tortillas that tasted like...corn...you could taste the corn.  If I had to describe it surreally, I'd say, it felt like being taken back into the womb, I felt so protected and in a different zone when I had bites of the carnitas.

The other folks like the food a lot also, but I was too busy with my food and loving it to even notice what the others ordered.

Great tacos too.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
Fish Tacos at lunch. The fish is fantastic, and I'm not a big fish person, and those tortillas!

Mole for dinner. Best Mole around.  You could put it on cardboard and I think I'd still eat it.

ooo and those toasted spicy garbonzo beans, holy heck, I'm happy they don't sell them because I'd go through pounds of them.

Done.
author: Nicole B.

description: Staff service was great! Always checked upon. Food was wonderful. Wish it was served with something or they had actual combo plates. Ordered a pitcher of their margarita, was perfect for three people. Spent $23 per person including tip. Probably going to go back!
author: Daphne A.

description:
My second visit was today and again was amazed!!  

I tried the pork sandwich which blew my mind..the bread tasted like butter and whatever the meat was marinated in was soo good!!

I go on my lunchbreak so I can't par take in the margaritas but the tea and hibiscus drinks are very refreshing!!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Now that I've eaten at Nopalito about 10 times, I feel qualified to write a review. I live in the building above and couldn't have been more excited when I heard Nopa's little sister was opening downstairs. Other than the carnitas, my first impression was that it was overpriced. But as I explored more of the menu, I found real value. 

Here's my formula for a $50 dinner for 2 at Nopalito (assumes 2 beers each).
1. Drink beer on tap (cocktails are still a work in progress and $9)
2. Get the carnitas every time (the enchiladas placeras are a good alternative)
3. Order one Empanada and one quesadilla
author: Seth B.

description:
Overall, I had a great experience at Nopalito and would absolutely return.  The service was good (not excellent) and there's a parking lot (major  bonus).

The place has a great vibe! The bartender was teasing us because we struggled to make a decision since the menu has so many delicious options.  We finally settled on Carnitas, Chicken Mole, Tortillas and a Naranja salad.  That was a lot of food for two of us. Of all those, the Chicken Mole was my favorite, which was surprising because I am a big fan of carnitas.  In this case, the carnitas were a bit dry for my taste.  

I would definitely go back, but I would be hesitant to go with any group  larger than 4. It is a rather intimate restaurant and you can't make reservations.  You can call ahead, though, and waiting in the bar is fun if there is a wait for a table.  There's also take out, FYI.
author: Katie M.

description:
Love, love, love this place. Admittedly, I usually have para llevar (take out), but I have eaten at the restaurant a few times. Decor and ambiance is minimalist. Menu changes quite frequently, but a handful of staples stay the same. They do a good job of updating their website with menu changes to check before you go or order.

My fave dishes include: Totopos, Panucho, Carnitas. My wife really likes their veggie quesadillas. Currently, the Empanda is great. I have noticed that the food is not always consistent. It's probably 90% consistent. Otherwise, I would have rated 5 stars. 

The fact that I eat here once a week on average probably says it all.

Insider Tip: if you call ahead of time, they'll write your name down on the waiting list before you even arrive. Yeah, kinda cool. Just don't abuse it...
author: Scott N.

description:
We were feeling like a casual din and stopped here. Plates are small, but it just gives me a better reason to order a variety of items. Open kitchen allowing me a view of the cooks doing what they know best. 

-almond horchata
-fish taco
-pork belly quesadilla
-shrimp enchilada
author: Lola D.

description:
This place is Nopa's totally underrated, cheaper, eaiser-to-get-into younger brother.  I don't know if I'll ever understand why there is always a bigger line outside of Nopa instead of here, but whatever.  People have weird taste I guess.

The wait tends to be around 30-45 minutes (for 2-3 people) whenever I go, but you can opt to get a text when your table is ready rather than waiting outside.  Sometimes the amount of time they tell you you have to wait can be drastically off though -- Once I was told the wait would be an hour and they texted me after only 30 minutes, so you may not want to wander too far.

Absolutely everything I've ever had here was totally delicious (and I've had almost everything on the menu).  The enchiladas are particularly good, but it's so hard to pick a favorite when everything is delicious.  Also the portions are perfectly sized - I always finish up the night full but without leftovers.

Last but not least, Their bar is AMAZING.  I'm a huge cocktail/booze snob and I am totally in love with their Killer Bee.  Everything else I've had (pretty much the entire cocktail menu) is quite good but the Killer Bee is just spectacular.  I also love that they have various tequilas and mezcals available for sipping and they even bring you sangrita to sip with it.
author: Moira T.

description: Great food - lots of options and not absurdly expensive. You definitely need to make reservations beforehand. We went to the standing bar before we had dinner. There is a great assortment of drinks and lots of tequila spin-offs. The ceviche is absolutely incredible - must try!
author: Alyssa D.

description: Delicious Mexican food and cocktails. Very helpful staff and a very nice looking place.
author: Paul B.

description: The food is very tasty. But is it so tasty you'd happily wait 2.5 hours?  I'm not sure it is.  The primary reason this review gets three stars is the slow service.  Also, they do not have chips and guacamole(!) After waiting for 2.5 hours and not sitting down until 10pm some chips and guac to satiate your hunger would be nice!
author: Rebecca N.

description: Such a nice and relaxing place to go and eat. The food is very good and ethnic.
author: Lauren W.

description:
In the beginning, I was really impressed by the service, the quality of food, and the price.  We were able to get our names on the waiting list and sit at our table 20 minutes after we arrived.

I ordered two appetizers as my meal - the Empanada de Picadillo and the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron.  The empanada was disappointing because it was too bland for me.  And the pork belly quesadilla was good but I wouldn't order it again.  I didn't expect the pork to be shredded.  I wanted more fat! However, my friend ordered the carnitas which I thought was really flavorful and juicy.  And I also tried the lingcod which I thought was good. 

We also had the margaritas (very strong) and the Totopos con Chile (simple but very addicting!).  I hear lunch here is good so I might have to come back try it!
author: Helen V.

description:
Walked right in at 6p on a weeknight, and sat right down at the four-seat bar over looking the kitchen.  Ordered a Michelada, which was close to the Mexico City original of my memories.  Dinner was a Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón (w/ pork belly) - GOOD! + Tamal Enpipianado de Puerco (only OK ... even house made masa needs to be properly seasoned) + Birria de Chivo (goat stew, which was good if you like goat).

All in all I'd go there again.  I really liked seeing families with young children there, and retired couples on a date ... fairly low on the "can be annoying" SF hipster scene!

GO!
author: Jason G.

description: This place sucks.  We've been waiting for 2 hours and we called ahead.  We could have been seated but they gave an 8 person table to 4 people who refused to leave.
author: ALEX S.

description:
Ah, Nopalito. The food never ceases to disappoint and the margaritas, though expensive, are straight up delish. The carnitas are the best! They are served with cabbage, spicy carrots, and a pickled jalapeno. For an appetizer we usually order the totopos con chile...so spicy, so amazing. They also have HOMEMADE POPSICLES! Yes! 

They don't take reservations and the wait is absolutely ridiculous, so call ahead to put your name on the list. The hostesses suck. They are so slow and unorganized!
author: Aviana B.

description:
Torpid. Lonely. Disinterested.

Despite being the first and only person at Nopalito, it took one glance at the watch too long for my solo quesadilla to come out.  While the thought of someone nursing my cheesy fold over to perfection was ideal, it would be unfortunate if service was even slower as foot traffic picked up.

Service was friendly but aloof.  
No hot water aside from tap is surprising.
Entrance is confusing and uninviting.

Quesadilla was a depressing blue-corn greasy semi circle of sadness that lacked oozey goozey cheese. Mild (cotija?) cheese didn't stand a chance against the chewy (not soft) grease marinated tortilla.  Crispy pork belly was deliciously crispy, but seemed thrown on as an afterthought.  

Ques: Who gets complimentary starter snacks and who doesn't?  
Ans: Couple sitting next to me; me - seriously though, how does this work?

$$10 apps
$$20-25 entrees
Filling but not satisfying
author: Jane L.

description: For all the hype I was so underwhelmed. I was super excited to come for my birthday and had a terrible time. I spilled my margarita, they did not give me a new one, the pitchers were $33 and barely enough to feed 4 and the food was just ok.  I will not be back!
author: Christie T.

description:
I should probably go back to Nopalito BEFORE writing this review, because I only tried the Pozole and had a beer, but I felt the service was so awesome and the execution of the dish I had was so perfect, that a review was in order.

1st off, this is a nice little spot, just in terms of location, etc.  2ndly - the one dish I had, was done to perfection - the stew was amazing - spiced but not over the top - well portioned - and all the ingredients were cooked properly. I went in wanting something warm and hearty, and didn't leave disappointed. 

The service was impeccable - our waitress was really friendly, helped with questions, was attentive but not up in our faces, and was overall very pleasant. Wish I coulda caught her name so I could give her a shout! 

At any rate, I keep hearing the Carnitas at Nopalito is to die for, and since Carnitas is my all time favorite Mexican dish, I have to go back. 

The price point is fairly reasonable for the location and portions, the food really seemed to be done well, and again, the staff was really helpful. 

I definitely suggest giving these folks a shot!
author: Marco M.

description:
I never thought I'd like an "upscale taqueria" but Nopalito proved my resistance futile. The cute, casual space manages to strike a delicate balance between classy and comfortable with an open sun room and the melodic "sit wherever you feel comfortable!" when you walk through the door. 

My huckleberry lemonade soda was yummy, though I'm more a straight water gal so not a typical order for me. The grapefruit soda is incredible tho - so bittersweet fans go at it! 

We decided to share three of the small plates between the two of us. The totopos con chile definitely had a kick and translated to corn tortilla chips with spicy salsa cooked into it. Topped with (too meager) shavings of cotija cheese and a dollop of sour cream. The heat definitely was on the edge of too hot for me, but I'm a total wuss about spicey food. Then the Gordita de Picadillo and Tamal Enchilado de Puerco y Queso came out on a shared plate. The tamale was made with homemade dark masa and definitely the winner of the meal...lasting less than 30 seconds on the plate. The gordita was like a mini taco shaped like a pita sandwich (you know, circle with an opening in it stuffed with food) and the taco seemed a little stale but the insides more than made up for it. 

The food was great and mind you, these dishes were tiny and had we been looking for a full meal this wouldn't have sufficed but as a snack it was superb. Since it was halloween all the servers had hilarious costumes on and I double heart the wonderful waitress, Hilary, who made our meal extra enjoyable with lots of funny banter and great menu recommendations. 

Now back to NYC where I have to suffer through stale chimichangas for my Mexicano fix...sigh.
author: Jane K.

description: My husband calls this place authentic, however I see this as a fusion of authentic ingredients served bistro style. The food is really good, and served in my favorite style....Small plates! Small plates are the best way to taste a lot of food, and share with all of your friends. I highly recommend the Totopos con chile for starters, and even though I am not a huge fan of pork, the Pozole Rojo!
author: Lauren B.

description:
Michaledas.  I am addicted.

Go and taste the awesomeness that is beers spices and tomato juice.
author: Amelia M.

description:
Visited for dinner twice in last two weeks.  Both times ordered the pork carnitas and a margarita.  Both times savored each and was fully impressed.  Made the mistake of asking how the carnitas were made.  Let's just say it's not the healthiest dish on the menu...but those packing a wallop of flavor never are.  I will definitely both next time I go.  Should mention that the carnitas are big enough for two to split or one to eat and take delicious leftovers home to tomorrow's lunch.

The Naranjas y Cebolla con Chile, Limon y Queso salad was amazing the first time and less so the second time.  Perhaps because we split it between two people the first time and three the second and I didn't get enough to satisfy me.  Dinner companion ordered and liked the Bacalao Fresco Estilo Toluca (lingcod dish).

For dessert, we tried the Paletas Hechas en Casa - Housemade Popsicles.  I liked my Orange-Cream flavor okay (very creamy), but my two dinner companions nor I cared for the Chocolate-Cinnamon flavor.  We found it far too dense and concentrated and left it half-eaten to melt on it's wrapper.

Bonus fun: Sit at the counter and watch the bartender hand squeeze limes for the margaritas then use a straw to extract a tiny taste of each drink she makes.  I have no idea how she stays standing after a entire night of tasting drinks to be sure they are perfect, but that's a skilled pro for you!
author: Rolfe B.

description:
Absolutely amazing; I'm assuming the only reason Nopalito doesn't have 5-Stars is because American's are so boring in their taste- commonly preferring Chevy's or Taco Bell over authentic taste and flavor which all too commonly is heaven for the palate.  And, all for a few dollars more, if not less.

The only thing non-Mexican about Nopalito is the atmosphere and staff- along with the occassionaly "stuck-up" clientele.  I personally prefer authentic settings, similar to those found at Chava's, El Paisa, and El Zocolo in the Mission.  The environment at Nopalito is definitely enjoyable- especially the full-view kitchen.  I must admit though, I feel sorry for the chef's and line cooks (they have no privacy!).  Plenty of light during the day, and the restaurant is located in a new and contemporary shopping center.  

If you prefer Tex-Mex (American-infused Mexican food) then you may want to pass on Nopalito.  The food is of superb quality; I personally care less about organic food, however combined with the high quality of the ingredients it's an added bonus.    Try the Birria con Chivo, absolutely superb, although in Mexico, it's simply called Birria.  Unless you're Jewish- aka a Kosher dieter- you'll enjoy everything on the menu.  You'll be so excited that you'll come back again simply to try something new.  And in the two years I've been coming here, their menu has never changed.  The quality of the meats, cheeses, vegetables and other ingredients combined with the heavy authentic spices is what makes the meal.  

The type of Mexican food found at Nopalito is mostly Jalisco style combined with a Southern Mexico flavor as well.  Your Northern Mexico taqueria food cannot be found here, (aka, tacos, burritos).  

I'm a German/Italian (eating a lot to support both my German size and Italian hunger) so the only problem is the SMALL (I mean -small-) portions.  When I go here I usually order two entrees- and no I'm not a pig!  If you're looking for a cozy authentic Mexican meal and are not in a rush and must have full flavor, then please, stop by.  Lastly, this reminds me that Nopalito does not take reservations, and wait times commonly exceed one hour.  The DMV is across the street, so since they make you wait two hours to be called, simply run across the street to Nopalito and enjoy a wonderful meal and maybe even a cerveza (beer).

I also find this to be a perfect restaurant for dates: I've taken two here myself.  It's not loud, so you can listen and talk with your date, but it's also not quiet to the point that you're nervous.  It's very casual and, put simply, happy.

Enjoy.
author: Robert L.

description:
Really. I really dont understand what is so good about this place that people rave about it so much. Maybe just that it is a SWPL type of place...

We went there for sunday brunch. The wait took 40 mins, and yet another 25 mins before food showed up (and I dont have an issue with this since I understand its a sunday and everyone is out for brunch).

But when the food did show up, I found it to be failry mediocre. We had the shrimp machaca, a fish taco, a torta and a pinucho. there seemed to be something amiss in each of the dishes. Maybe it lacked the intensity of flavor... So we ordered a hot sauce, and were given something that mildly resembled relish (i.e. not spicy at all). We asked for something else, and kept waiting, then we asked another person, and waited more. Then asked yet another person and waited some more. Finally, after 15 mins of waiting (our food was getting cold all this while), we actually went almost into the kitchen to get it ourselves.. 

The litte cookie at the end was a nice touch, but the service was totally lacklustre. And the food was meh. Definitely not worth the wait. Or the money. You'd have better luck just walking into any taqueria in the Mission in terms of food.
author: Priya K.

description:
Very cute place. Went there for lunch and had the Pork Stew. The dish seemed more like soup than stew. The consistency was very watery and the flavors were extremely subtle. They serve it with a side of crushed chili powder and mexican oregano and you're supposed to season to your liking. I used it all and still wanted more. Plus I added salt and tried to squeeze the very dry half lime they gave me. It still lacked the pizazz I was craving. My partner had the Pork Sandwich (so did about 2 others around us) and it was delicious. Kind of a small portion, but great flavor. 

Service was very nice and attentive. 

I will go back for more, but I won't have the stew again.
author: Foodie F.

description:
Came here for lunch today. My bestie lives down the street and I've been eyeing nopalito ever since she moved to the hood, esp during trips over to the neighboring peet's and falletti's. Plus I love eating nopales (cactus) in mexican cuisine, so I was attracted to the name because it reminded me of that.  

We liked the tented eating area - it had that outdoor green-housey feel to it, but you are covered and flanked by heat lamps. I had the quesadilla azul, which was one of the only vegetarian options on the lunch menu (beside from maybe a salad and a chips and salsa plate). It had braised veggies and two types of cheese and it came with a good spicy salsa on the side. My friend had a chicken taco and a pork dish. They were all nice-sized small plates - I'm sure some would say that the portion sizes were too small for the price, but we happen to like small plates so no complaints there - I just know how some people think. Good flavors and fresh ingredients. 

I also liked the little touches, like the homemade "corn nuts" they served when we sat down and the little cookies that came with the bill - mexican wedding cookies, anyone? Felt like a high end "ladies lunching" kind of experience but was not too pricey. I do have a feeling dinner would be pricier. I also didn't know they were linked to NOPA until i read a few other reviews here just now. but that makes sense.
author: Shannon R.

description:
One of my good friends decided to take me here for my birthday dinner.  We were excited to get seated after only 15 minutes, when we were originally told it would be about an hour (you can't make reservations, but you can call and say you're on the way, and they put you on the list as if you're there).  There's free parking for 2 hours in the Falletti's garage.

Our server, Emanuel, was very knowledgeable, friendly, and helpful.  As you sit, you're given a small bowl of...toasted corn? toasted chickpeas? anyhoo, they're tasty and crunchy and delicious.  I had the mint-lemonade, everyone else had the sangria and the michelada-there were empty glasses of everything as we got up to leave, so you can feel free to form your own opinions there.  note: your meal comes with FREE still or sparkling water, which is a rare treat in san francisco restaurants these days.  the sangria was tasty, made with oranges this time, and surprisingly strong for the taste!

for apps, we had the totopos con chile-AWESOME.  think tortilla chips smothered in a spicy sauce, sprinkled with cheese, served with sour cream on the side.  the spiciness of the chips can kick your butt a little bit, but the sour cream calms it down right away.  a verrrrry delicious treat.  they also had the ceviche, which i couldn't eat, but everyone said was very fresh and delicious.

we each ordered an entree. i was very happy with mine, the enchiladas-the chicken was so tender, moist, juicy, and flavorful, and the enchiladas were perfectly cheesy.  there was a side of veggies-carrots and potatoes. everything was great! i had bites of my friend's carnitas-also amazing.  tender, moist, perfectly salty, and the green salsa that came with it was good.  

now, this is just me, and my amateur palate..but to me, personally, i didn't see what the big deal was about the carnitas.  yes, they were tasty and soft and moist...but to be on all these "things to eat before you die" lists and stuff? really?  to be fair, though, i usually don't eat carnitas, or much pork in general.  i also personally didn't care too much for the mole chicken or the meatballs.  again, i'll say, my friends seemed to enjoy their dishes very much, but they just weren't for me.  i found the meatballs to be too smokey for me, and i may just not be a mole fan in general. 

when we were ordering, the server was very conscientious to tell us that the meatballs were good, but an adventurous dish.  they were soft, and flavorful...just not my personal flavors.  this doesn't mean these aren't good dishes, just not to my personal liking.

the food and drink was good enough that we didn't have room for dessert...but our server was sweet enough to bring us mexican cookies for dessert.  

all in all, i would definitely eat here again, and recommend it to people, but i just know what i for sure what i would and would not order.  the service was great, and the stuff i liked, i really really liked.
author: asia c.

description: This restaurant is absolutely incredible. Everything is done with the utmost care, and it is clear from the moment you walk in the door. I came alone and sat at the chef's counter where I watched the bartender prepare the myriad of tasty cocktails available. I had the Mezcal Palomita, which had a wonderful smoky flavor and reminded me of mezcal I had once in the mountains of Guerrero. To start, they bring spicy garbanzo beans instead of the traditional chips and salsa. Quite hot! I ordered the duck confit huarache, topped with cabbage, queso fresco, and chorizo. An interesting take on the traditional dish. Loved it. I also had the ceviche, which was equally delicious and had a green tomatillo sauce, more the style I've seen in Peruvian restaurants. Their coffee is brewed French press and a butter almond cookie is provided gratis at the end of your meal. Something I've left out is that the waitstaff was tremendously friendly and helpful. Their service was so on point and seamless, I was compelled to leave a twenty dollar tip on my 37 dollar meal. They chatted me up and made me feel extremely welcome. When I returned from the restroom, my napkin was folded on the table, something I've only otherwise seen in high-end restaurants. This place is an absolute must, and this review does not even begin to do justice to this gem!
author: Frederick R.

description:
5 stars for the carnitas, which was the only food we ordered. It was tender, juicy and slightly sweet. Served in butcher paper to keep those juices and fats close at hand.
The tomatillo sauce added the perfect amount of zing to balance the carnitas. Housemade masa tortillas, and finely sliced veggies came with, and we wrapped it all up and stuffed it in our gobs.
It cost $15 for a hefty portion that sated the three of us, and we weren't looking for a big gut-buster meal.

A little snackule of baked/fried chickpeas came to the table at the beginning, and three little Mexican wedding cookies came at the end.

I also had the huckleberry lemonade. Very refreshing. Meanwhile, the carnitas were so awesome that I hardly even thought, "what the hell is a huckleberry?"
author: Lemonjelly L.

description: I LOVE this place!  I am pretty particular about my Mexican food and this place really surprised me, in a good way.  The pozole is great!  I always try to make time to stop in for a meal when I am in SF.
author: Gabriela H.

description: Stopped by here after a visit to the DMV and ordered the totopos con chile and carnitas. The carnitas was top quality - tender, juicy, melt in your mouth - paired with some lettuce and corn tortillas. Totopos was so-so. Nice and attentive waiters. Worth a visit if your in the area.
author: Daniel K.

description:
So the food is really great.  But 3 stars instead is of 4 is because it was such a long wait to get a table on a Monday night.  We waited for almost a hour and it was a bit chilly outside.  Otherwise, it's a pretty nice atmosphere instead.

The food is delicious.  The taquitos were nice and crunchy, with a hint of spice.  The horchata, which tasted like cinnamon and almond milk, was very refreshing to sip in between the dishes.  The Tamal con Birria de Pollo, the seared fish taco, and veggie quesadilla were great.  The cookies were a nice touch to end the dinner.
author: Rose C.

description:
I think the 3.5 stars that Nopalito has right now is just right. 

I've been here twice now and I definitely recommend it for "clean" Mexican food. Don't get me wrong, I love me some dirty taqueria Mexican food but sometimes when I go overboard, I end up paying for my tacos and burritos in other ways. Wait, I think I've revealed too much...

I recently visited and had a fantastic caldo/soup dish. I wanted something lighter because it hadn't been that long since I ate lunch and this was the perfect dish. It was chicken consomme with a charred chile (I can't remember what kind but it was pretty huge), avocado chunks, caulflower, hominy, cilantro and a few other healthy goodies. The server told me that the longer I kept the chile in there for, the spicier it would be (and also if I poked at it or aggravated it). It was awesome because it imparted a soft smokiness throughout the broth. Yum! It was definitely a feel-good dish. 

I also had the ceviche, which was great as well. It was in a green salsa type liquid with fish, squid and baby scallops. Nice and spicy - and the chips that accompany it are perfectly crispy and firm. 

I would probably pass on the quesadilla with crispy pork belly. It was a pretty greasy affair.

The carnitas is always awesome looking (I never order it because it's too intense for me but I've been lucky enough to sneak a few bites both times I've been here). It comes with lots of warm corn tortillas and some pickled veggies on the side. 

Lastly, the popsicles. Mmmm, I'd say pass on these. They're really intense popsicles that seem barely frozen in a way. The chili chocolate one tastes more like a cold truffle on a stick and the arroz con leche one was, well, really rice-y and glutinous. I know you're thinking, what did you expect? But it wasn't very sweet, just really chunky. I think you're better off just eating the little cookies that come with the check. 

Ooh, I almost forgot about the fried garbanzo beans! They taste like refined corn nuts. They're awesome. 

Only real complaint about Nopalito is that the bathrooms are located outside, even though you can see them in the restaurant. It's right next to the takeout window. Whaa? Why?
author: Alli J.

description: Although tough to get a table for eight, the ever changing Sangria recipes and killer totopos are addictive and worth the wait. Authentic, flavorful dishes prepared with beautiful local ingredients - you won't be disappointed.
author: Summit S.

description: REALLY good!  We called ahead on Saturday evening and put our name on the list - that's a must.  Food was fantastic.  We tried almost all the appetizers and several entrees.  All great.  Drinks are great too!  Really good food, casual and relaxed atmosphere.  Yum!
author: Karen N.

description:
Came here last night (Wednesday) with my foodie buddy, LC. They don't take reservations, but you can call in and put  your name down, which is what we did. By about 6:45-7:00, all the tables were full. We sat in the outdoor area, where they had the heaters on -- a bit too high, in my opinion, but since it was cold and windy outside, it felt nice.

The food is a contemporary twist on your traditional Mexican dishes. They use local, organic, and sustainable ingredients; portion sizes are on the smaller side given the prices; and the dishes are sort of hit or miss, depending on what you order. 

We split the taquitos, primavera quesadilla, ceviche verde, and each got a fish taco. The taco was tasty -- seared fish in a tortilla with onion and cilantro, ancho chile sauce, orange slices, and salsa. The orange slices added a sweet-and-tangy flavor that went really well with the ancho chile sauce.

The ceviche was probably our 2nd favorite dish. There was a lot more calamari than rock cod and it was a bit on the lime-ey side, but the salty chips and avocado slices made it delightful. Our table neighbors had to totopos, and that definitely didn't look as good as the ceviche. I'd highly recommend it if you like calamari and want an alternative to plain ol' chips-and-salsa.

The taquitos were nice and cripsy (but not oily), but you only get 4 pieces -- which is really 2 cigar-ish sized taquitos cut in half. The quesdailla wasn't anything special (esp. since it was a veggie one) and lacked taste. Thank goodness for the salsa they give you with it. It didn't save the dish, but made it bearable.

They've got a decent mix of tequilas and a handful of tequila-based cocktails. The service can be slow at times, especially when all the tables are full. We waited about 10 minutes after drinks came to order food. So be prepared to hang out a bit when you come here.
author: Denise E.

description:
4 words: Torta de Chorizo Verde. Man, it was one of those dishes that had it all. I'd definitely split that with someone and order a salad to balance the richness of it.

AMAZING. 

Also, the pork Tamale was BANGIN! 

Service was excellent.

Ok, so why not 5 stars? This was our second time there. The first time was lacking in food quality. The carnitas were so-so, but it's obvious we didn't order properly before. I will go back a few more times before giving it a fiver.

Great for hang-over brunch...dangerously close is the grocery store where you can get some pay-check shopping done. :)
author: Trinity M.

description:
Adore this place! Their mint lemonade was deliciouso and the price was right. The portion sizes were small, but a) worht the price and b) freakin delicious so it was definately a quality over quantity deal.
The only downside is that it can get very busy for dinner and you can't really make reservations for this place....
Other than that I'm obsessed! Try their pudding with mexican chocolate for dessert....mmmmm im in heaven! :)
author: Charlotte P.

description:
Heavenly, heavenly Nopalito.  Today was my first time, and there were several items that were the best I have ever experienced.  The horchata was amazing,  I honestly wish that they would have a all you can drink deal.  I wanted them to keep on coming, as I would soon understand would not only pertains to the horchata.  I ordered todays special which was a spring tostada.  It was small but delicious.  Next my sister and I shared a chicken tostada with habenero salsa and black beans.  This had the best flavor ever.  the last thing that we ordered were the carnitas, which our server Timmy said that he has dreams about and that we had to try it.  

They are totally worth dreaming about.  So delicious.  They come with four corn tortillas and after those were gone, Timmy was more than kind to bring more, no charge.  

I was a bit worried at first that we wouldn't be getting enough food for how hungry we were.  But I left super stuffed and soooooo ready to come back for more.  

The ambiance was also amazing and there was no wait at all when we got there around 12:30.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
So disappointed with this place!!

I really wanted to like it, I've been wanting to go here for awhile and I haven't been this disappointed with a place in a LONG time.  We started with the Totopos con chile; they are delicious and the only reason why this place is getting 2 stars.  After we had those, I was so excited to try the rest of the food, but it was downhill from there.

fish taco - looks great, but left a fishy aftertaste in your mouth
Gordita de Picadillo - so greasy that you could barely pick it up, grease dripping all over the place
side of rice - I asked the waiter for a side of rice for my 15 month old daughter, it was so spicy I couldn't eat it!  I asked the waiter about it and he just said "yeah, it's really spicy", I wish he would've warned us up front, he knew who it was for!  i asked if they could make a non-spicy version and he said they could not.  They did credit this on our bill.  However...when I received the side of rice with my dinner, it was NOT spicy at all!  Pretty inconsistent and seems that they do have some control of the spice in the rice.
Birria de Borrego - this is the lamb and the only good thing i can say about this was that the meat was tender.  the portion was incredibly small, you could put everything in one of the corn tortillas they serve with it and it would barely be enough.  Which is not what I expected considering this was a $16 dish!  Other than having a slightly gamey flavor, there was no taste to it.  the sauce they served with it could have been mole out of a jar. 

And, our dining experience was totally ruined by the extremely hot lamps they had going full blast out on the closed-in dining patio.  We asked the waiter if they could be turned down and he said that they could not.  It was so hot and uncomfortable, I had to walk outside to get a break from the electric hot wires that were blasting above our heads. our faces were so hot after dinner it literally took hours for our faces to cool off after the restaurant.
author: Rachel R.

description:
We enjoyed our dinner here enough, but would give it 3.5 stars. First, the wait is not fun and since they don't take reservations, there's not much you can do about. Next, it's the LOUDEST restaurant I've been in, including sportsbars, etc. You can't have a conversation, well actually, you can't focus on a conversation b/c you hear everything everyone around you is saying. The space is also really tight, so if you are waiting for a table, and trying to get a drink inside while doing so, there's no where to stand, you''re constantly in the way. The 'bar' is actual seating so you can sit down there even if a spot it open.

Onto the food... Now if the atmosphere had been a little better (not so loud), and reservations were offered/not so long wait, then I think I would come back to this place as the food is pretty good. But based on those issues, the food wasn't that amazing to make me go to the trouble. Here's what we ordered:

-pork belly quesadilla
-empanada
-carnitas
-carne asada

The food came out quickly, the apps separately, as they were ready, which worked out well. Everything was good and we were definitely full when we left. They were good about keeping water filled, but as the place was so packed, our waiter didn't check in often and my husband would have had at least another drink if he's been asked. We both liked our mains, although I hate to say it, I still love the carnitas at Colibri.

I think this is a fun place, a good place for groups, but again, due to how crowded it was, the long wait and being so loud, it just isn't worth a return for the food. Maybe eventually we'll try lunch one day at an off time (even dinner we tried to go around 6 to avoid crowds, still waited 1h15mins)
author: Lauren M.

description: Fabulous! We had their nachos appetizer to share (huge) and then one of us ate the fish tacos while the other scarfed down a brussels sprouts quesadilla. All highly recommended. The environment at this location is okay though. I like their Inner Sunset ambiance a bit more because it fits more in the external environment. This one is connected to a grocery store and a Peet's Coffee, which feels awkward.
author: Nicholas M.

description:
Yummy yummy!

The food: we ordered ceviche, taquitos, empanadas, and quesadilla roja. All were tasty. The ceviche was full of lime flavor, but you could still taste the fresh fish. The taquitos were very well-seasoned and had great toppings. The empanada was good--the meat could have been a bit more tender--and had a red sauce. The quesadilla was deliciously hearty.

The service--we were seated right away by an incredibly competent hostess. Everything was prompt.

The place was a bit noisy and it was easier for me to eavesdrop on the conversation happening at the table next to me than it was to talk to my dinner companion across the table.
author: Julia Z.

description:
This review concerns service more than actual food. Service is what got this one to be a 1 star review and why I'll remember this place.

I went to Nopalito today with 8 other friends, some of whom I was meeting for the first time.  It turned out to be a bad evening, and a less than optimal way to get to know them.

There were problems from the start. While we were waiting they asked us to move out. Alright I understand that.  But then they should have tried making up for it in some way. Instead, they escalated things by  snapping at some of my friends when we reached for an unused chair. We wanted to accomodate a person who showed up last minute.  

Then the food. The flavor was alright, but they took a long time to bring food to one of us.  They brought his appetizers later than they bought the main course for the rest of us!  You should wait to have all 9 dishes done before bringing them.  

Then came time for the bill. Some of our friends would have benefited from having separate, itemized, bills. Unfortunately we did not mention this before dinner. Our fault? sure, but they were not at all willing to help on this. Other restaurants have done this kind of adjustment before. Some grumble, but do it, the best just do it. (And we go back to those)

Okay, then instead we take the time to specify how much to charge each card. Give them the bill with the numbers. Then they take it and spend 20 mins without getting back to us.  

Meanwhile, their heating system can only either grill you if you are below it or otherwise leave you pretty much to the mercy of cold San Francisco weather. A few of us needed to step away from the heat lamp. This seemed to only annoy the waiters more. If we stood in one place, they would want to walk in that place exactly. Then when we moved,  thats where the waiter wanted to walk, 3 times. And they were not nice about it.

Finally, they came back with the wrong bills. They decided it was too complicated to do, so they simply split the bill on equal parts in the end. Some of us had consumed very different amounts than others, and they had already taken 30 mins to do this! we were not going to now sit and go through it again.  We were leaving the place, and some of us made clear how dissatisfied we were with the whole situation.  

We were about to leave, when a waiter comes out to inform the manager that we did not leave enough signed receipts. Really? well there were enough. And they found them, but this just made things more tense.

It seems they just cannot handle a group of more than 3 people, they should make this very very clear rather than provide mediocre service. And sure, we maybe were too many, but they could have tried to help rather than grow hostile.
author: Osberto M.

description:
First off, I have to say that as a Mexican person it's always hard to go to "fancy" Mexican restaurants because you will always be comparing the food to home cooking. 

My first hint that the place was going to be disappointing was the fact that nowhere on the menu did they have "nopales", the namesake of this restaurant. That's like going to a McDonalds where they serve no hamburgers. 

We started off with the empanada, which the waitress forgot to tell us would take awhile, but the portion was very generous and it could stand alone as an entree. 

I moved on to pozole and my friend to the albondigas. The pozole was decent, the albdondigas were not. They were very smoky and unflavorful. My poor friend didn't even finish his plate. 

Overall decent, but would not visit again.
author: Susana M.

description: The food was mediocre.  I went there based on an article that I read on the best pozole in San Francisco, it was lame.  My girlfriend and I ordered many things on the menu like: pozole, chilaquiles, totopos con salsa, gordita de chorizo con papas & quesadilla de chicharron.  The only item that we truly enjoyed were the totopos con salsa, they are more like chilaquiles.  The cooks kept goofing around and being super loud and obnoxious, laughing over the food while preparing it and serving it.  My girlfriend and I got super sick (food poisoning) from eating Nopalito.  We are both Mexican and there's nothing authentic about this food.  It was a joke.  All of the Caucasian customers were getting super great service, but we felt ignored.  Never again!
author: Anna P.

description:
I love this place. The food is awesome and if you're in the mood I suggest ordering off the tapas side...and just get one of each of them. Portions are small and delicious. The consomme is fantastic. The tortillas are freshly made everyday. 

The place is always packed but you can call them and put your name down if you need to. If you're there and waiting for a table, they'll call you on your cell and let you know you're table is ready. 

If it's cold outside, try not to get the table near the curtain to the outside patio where everyone enters...because it's freezing.
author: Philip H.

description: Quesadilla roja Ron chicharron is definitely the beast! Crispy pork belly~~~
author: Kate C.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time I loved it and the second time I liked it so I'm giving it 3 stars.

I do like the quesadilla with the crispy pork belly. as well as the variety of small plates.

I also really liked the carnitas.  

It's definitely a little more upscale than your typical taqueria, and the food is also a bit more pricey than that too.  However, I thought it was good enough to go back, and honestly i'll probably end up back there again at some point.

Try to call ahead so you can minimize your wait time, otherwise you may end up gorging yourself at the nearby market and then be too full for dinner .(yes i might be speaking from experience...)
author: Lu E.

description:
The food is super duper fresh and super duper delicious but it ain't cheap for the portion sizes. My cecina enchilada was perfectly cooked, nice and juicy and lots of flavor. Totopos con chile were spicy and tangy and very unique.

I dig the ambiance too, lots of glass walls and a nice little bar area overlooking the kitchen that you can perch at for a casual bite with a friend. Try the cafe con leche paleta dessert (aka coffee popsicle), you won't be sorry.
author: Lisa P.

description: This place has been on my list for a long while but I finally made it there.  Wow.  Phenomenally good and fresh with wonderful Flavors.  We had four small plates--tacos dorados, panuchos, the tortilla chips starter and a sweet potato corn tamal.  With non alcoholic drinks, tax, and tip it was still under $50.  There were complimentary chile fried chickpeas for a snack and butter cookies with the bill.  The lime sherbet popsicle (paletas) was a refreshing end to a great meal.  What's more, there is a parking lot here!  Loved every bite.  We will be back.
author: Harriet P.

description:
Very high quality and delicious mexican-ish food.

Finally tried Nopalito... yesh! I have had this on my list for ages. It met every expectation. 

Well, to start, I had a quesadilla which had a crispy fried tortilla and tender pork belly.

I had the carnitas which came in paper. There was a green and spicy salsa and a cabbage slaw. The meal also comes with some fresh corn tortillas. 

My friend had the Mole sauce which was some of the best Mole I have ever had. The chicken was a plump quarter of dark meat. 

They have a good beer selection including Death and Taxes on tap and Green Flash "Hop Head" Red in the bottle to name a few.

The staff was quick and even though they do not take reservations, they are willing to take your number and give you a call when your table is ready. This part of western addition has a few interesting places to check out so I did not mind the quick wait at all. Check out the market next door.
author: Eric G.

description:
I was in San Fran (yet again) and a peer from LA suggested I try this place. I discovered I'd driven by it several times and never noticed it. One harrowing cab ride later and we were there. Not a hole in the wall AT ALL - which is what I've come to expect from somewhere worth eating lately.

The wait was long, but you can call ahead and get your name on the list. We did that, got there 40 minutes later and still waited about 30 minutes. It was worth it, though.

I highly recommend listening to the server, ours made excellent recommendations. And, of course, you have to try the carnitas.
author: Brent R.

description:
When you can get an authentic Latin American meal in the mission for no more than $15 a person, including a beer, it's hard to give into the idea of "fine dining" Latin American good that costs $50 a person with beverage. Then again, that's not bad at all considering we had two appetizers and two alcoholic beverages each, on top of our entrees which were large portions. 

And even still, for the price, I wasn't that enthused by Nopalito. Let's start with the appetizers:

1. Topotos con chile- GREAT, and not at all soggy by the cojita cheese and lime sauce.

2. Civiche*- Fresh, but not original in flavor. Like any other civiche you've had. My co-worker MADE a MUCH better version once... on his lunch break!

*comes with chips. Why the waitress didn't tell us this, we don't know. It was pointless having two heaping sides of chips for 2 people.

Entrees:

1. Carnitas para mi- ok, so it's on the 7x7 list and I thus had to try it. I wasn't too thrilled I did. Sure, the meat was very well cooked and tender, BUT where was the flavor?!?! Donde?! The carnitas are supposedly braised in beer, orange, cinnamon, and bay leaf, but I could not taste a single one of those spices or flavors to save my life. A little disappointing. The cabbage salad with pickled jalapenos was very good, though. A much healthier, fresher, version than what you get at taquerias.

2. Pescado a la Talla para mi amiga- I didn't try it, but my friend said it was good, however not memorably interesting in flavor...again. 

To drink, we had some Malbec (always nice to see a Malbec on a menu) and I tried a glass of their white-peach sangria with frozen cherries. Perhaps the best part of the entire meal! Very refreshing, strong, and an original concept for sangria.

I recommend coming here and bellying up to the bar for some sangria and an appetizer or two. The other appetizers we spotted on tables looked great...but again, in terms of flavor, it could be a gamble. Maybe Nopalito is one of those places where the food is hit and miss. Depending on what you order, its either exciting or completely uninspired. I do like the atmosphere, and the servers are very friendly. I also didn't wait an hour to sit, as I dropped in to add our names an hour before we were even going to be ready to eat, so I wasn't too disappointed with the food for that. If I had to wait forever as many seem to do, this review would have probably been a lot worse.
author: Raquel C.

description: I actually really enjoyed this place.  It was nice because it was right down the street, but the environment was casual and comfortable while also giving the feel of a nice date night out.  The service was efficient and friendly as well.  I loved the seafood soup, and the carnitas was really tasty, even though I do not really even like pulled pork all that much!  We went late enough (around 9 PM) so that the fact that they do not take reservations did not affect us at all.  I would definitely go back - it was a cute place!
author: Rebecca D.

description:
I love Nopa, and I love carnitas.  So when I read about 7x7's list and the carnitas at Nopalito, I had to go.  

Suffice to say the food was great.  Its not your usual mexican fare and I'd say there is a little more effort to make it more than just simple mexican food.  

The funny part is that my girlfriend got the carnitas and I got the mole.  One can't find mole everywhere and one can't find good mole anywhere.  When I read that they had mole on their menu I sortof jumped on it and my girlfriend got the carnitas.  I loved both of out meals.

Try and get the popsicles. 

They don't take reservations.  However, you can call ahead and put your name on a list.  They are really cool about it.  I called and left a message that the two of us were coming and they didn't even take my name.  They forgot and I forgot.  We went anyways and when we got there they had a spot (for when I called) on their list with no name on it.  Pretty cool.  

Parking sucks in the panhandle but you probably already know that.
author: Mark K.

description:
Imaginative, fresh, delicious, modern Mexican food. It's a lovely ambience, and a good value for a mid-range, sit-down place.

It's a huge bowl of pozole for $11, a huge bowl of birria for $10, and some meat-heavy appetizers (like chicken pibil) for $4. Is it better than a giant $5 burrito at your favorite taco truck? Not better, just different - and very very good. And, there is Bohemia beer for $3.25 - you will pay that much for it in a mid-range restaurant in Guadalajara. (You will pay $2.50 for it in a cheap bar in Guadalajara).

The problem with arguments are "authenticity" in Mexican food, is: 
 1) Mexican cooking styles are both regional and individual (you'd never call someone's mom's macaroni and cheese "inauthethic" because it's not exactly like your mom's). The food at Nopalito is not like the food my family makes, but it's still delicious. 
2) It locks a culture's food into a place in time. Mexican chefs in Mexico put their own twist into traditional dishes, just like every other chef. To decide that dishes have to be prepared exactly as they were 50 years ago is absurd.

Service was just ok, but the food was great.
author: Jacqueline W.

description:
One of my favorite mexican restaurants in SF. Ingredients are organic and fresh. every dish is rich in flavor and texture. Fresh squeezed juices and agua frescas. Mole, tamales, pozole, and Birria are awesome. 

They even have homemade popsicles (paletas) for dessert. a small piece of childhood here in sf.

Even the small almond cookie you get at the end when you get your check is awesome.
author: Gabe H.

description:
I went to Nopalito when it first opened and decided to make a second trip there this past week. Of course, it was just as delicious as I remembered.

I ordered the white wine sangria which definitely stands out from other sangrias I've tried (white or red) in that it has a bit of an herby flavor to it, which is great for those of us who aren't into super-fruity-flavored drinks.

For food, my boyfriend and I split an empanada and a gordita -- small plates that we remembered fondly (read: salivating) from our first visit. They were FABULOUS. The meat is juicy and loaded with amazing seasonings, the masa is fried to perfection and not greasy(!), and both small plates were topped with tons of cotija. My only complaint is the price difference, which doesn't make any sense -- the gordita is $4.50 and the empanada is $7.00, although they are roughly the same size and are very similar food items. Regardless, both are worth ordering.

I was also happy to see that the check is still delivered with a Mexican Wedding Cookie for each person in your party. Delicious! 

I will definitely be back! (Though it's location on 9th, closer to Lincoln, makes it hard to remember it's there!)
author: Tiffany S.

description: Loved the tamale, carnitas, pork shoulder soup and don't skip the Popsicles!! Excellent food!!
author: Lisa B.

description:
I love that the scuzzy old Bank of America parking lot is now home to fancy shops and a restaurant. I know this happened a while ago, but I finally just made it to Nopalito. I'm not exactly "on-trend" when it comes to restaurants.

Usually, Mexican food for me is get-yer-grub-on comfort food, and I steer clear of "small plates" style food (I'm gluttonous). The warm weather today prompted me to want something less filling, so my friend and I split the taquitos de papas, the beet salad, and the huevos. I guess for most people that would be a lot, but as I said, I'm gluttonous.

All the food was yummy and very fresh. I especially liked the pickled onions in the beet salad. The fried garbanzos at the beginning and little cookies at the end were a nice touch. And you can't beat the fact that there's a parking lot.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Nopalito is to Mexican food as House of Nanking is to Chinese food. Both nontraditional, modern takes on food and atmosphere, they appeal to the masses and foodies alike. And unlike the more familiar Mexican food of the Mission, you won't find anything typical here. Although Nopalito is a small establishment, they really have utilized the space that they have next to Falletti's Foods extremely well. Decorated in earthy brown and green hues, from the burlap art on the wall to the one-of a-kind lamp shade with cactus illustrations hanging over the bar, this place makes me feel right at home.

While you peruse the menu they serve you a small dish of their homemade crispy chickpeas. I really wish they sold those by the bag to take home! Their menu has small dishes akin to Spanish tapas perfect for sampling on the left and larger portioned meals on the right. The staff is very friendly and I love that they labeled my food that I took home. They are also very accommodating. The dishes here are mostly non-vegetarian fare, but they gladly changed up a dish for a vegie friend who also doesn't eat mushrooms.

Items I recommend trying: Huevos de Caja, Carnitas, Esquite Tostado con Crema y Queso, Pozole Rojo, and their own Organic Almond Horchata.

Perhaps one of the biggest perk to eating here is that Nopalito shares their parking lot (yes parking lot!) with Bank of America, Falletti Foods and Delessio's Market & Bakery. 4 great places and free parking for every one of them. I never come to Nopalito without doing some errands too.
author: Kira R.

description:
food: two stars (* *)
I ordered the carnitas, which I can safely say tasted mediocre.  All of the other carnitas I've had in the city at other Mexican restaurants were just as good, and oftentimes better.  I was also disappointed that they were only accompanied by some corn tortillas, a shanty salad that consisted of some shredded cabbage and a sliced japapeño (who the hell is going to eat that?).
