It was just meat and some vegetable with no real effort put into it.  Was it all tasty?  Yes, but that is inherent to carnitas--Nopalito did nothing to further this dish.

environment/service: two stars (* *)
I called ahead to put my name on the list.  My group arrived and was told to wait 15 minutes.  I had to use the restroom and had to walk outside the restaurant to a tiny waiting room where three others were waiting for a single stall.  Is it the end of the world?  No, but this could have been solved in the planning/layout phase of the restaurant.  Our server Kristina was unfriendly and visited our table once after 10 minutes to get our order and then never again, except to hand us the bill.  I was shocked considering the attentive and knowledgeable service I've received at Nopa.

value: two stars (* *)
This was not an expensive dinner but for what you got, it was overpriced.  Speaking for myself, the carnitas, at $14, were double what I would pay for the same portion of food at any other Mexican restaurant in San Francisco (and mediocre, at best).

average of
food: two stars
environment/service: two stars
value: two stars
================
averaged grand total: two stars

estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$15-25

would i recommend it to others?
No, skip the chi-chi organic feel-good bullsh*t Mexican food and go somewhere where you'll pay half the cost and be far more satisfied.

would i return?
No.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
A client of mine took me out to lunch this week and recommended coming to Nopalito. Since we've both never been here we decided to give it a try.

Luckily we arrived a little before noon because seats started to fill right at 12'oclock. My client ordered a corn type of salad and I ordered a quesadilla. We both enjoyed our meal and the free nuts and the lil cookielike dessert that they gave us at the end. 

NOTE** portions here are really small so either eat slow or order more!

The service here was beyond excellent. Our server came back and checked on us and our cups were refilled without being asked.
author: M W.

description: My friend and I went during the day, so I don't know if it's a better vibe during dinner. The place was busy. They have a cute outdoor seating area. The inside was also cute and modern looking. I had a major problem with seating. There was no host in the host stand so we were very confused on how the seating worked. Even when we walked in the restaurant, nobody bothered to seat us. We finally had to ask someone how it worked and he kindly sat us. The worse part was that we waited 15 minutes before a waiter came to our table. It was absolutely ridiculous. The place is not even remotely big so I know they saw us. After 20 minutes, I decided to flag a waiter down. He was nice, but not apologetic. We order a Tecate (that's the only beer on the menu) and a Michelada. The Michelada was ok. It was definitely a twist of the original recipe (I hate when people f**k with original recipes). It had a chipotle smoky flavor to it. The ceviche verde was very tasty and fresh; the chips it comes with are also very crispy and not greasy. We ate the potato taquitos and the beef emapanada. They were very good!!! but nothing to rave about.
author: Lilly P.

description:
What the . . . 

I returned to Nopalito last night, and this time, I ate there.  Last time, I ordered take out - carnitas - and complained about the amount of pork being skimpy.  So this time I ordered chicken mole and someone else got the carnitas.  And when the carnitas came out, the amount of pork was freakin' huge!  It was literally the size of two fists.  What the hell?  Does Nopalito skimp on its carnitas take out orders?  What is going on here?  I remember the take out carnitas as being about half the size of the eat-in carnitas.  I'm going  to have to test Nopalito out a few more times to figure it out . . .

Oh, and service was friendly, but my god, it was slow. And our waters were constantly empty.  Salty, fatty Mexican food requires a lot of water so they need to get on that.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I really really enjoyed this place (for lunch) and can't wait to go back for dinner someday!

Everything is very fresh and organic and nicely prepared. 

The totopos con chile are like a better version of chips/salsa and essential to start with (but don't get too full!). 

Other recommendations:
-panucho de pollo al pibil
-Chilaquiles Rojos en Cazuela

They give you little cookies at the end which are a great way to satisfy a sweet craving without having to go for a full dessert (though they look delicious).


The bathroom is at the back of the restaurant and you have to walk around outside to get to it. Kind of strange setup.
author: Lina L.

description: Just because the menu is written in Spanish does not make this goofy hipster joint a Mexican food restaurant.  Spicy garbanzo beans as the preappetizer?  When's the last time you've had "baby kale" and cauliflower at a Mexican restaurant.
author: Ronnie B.

description: My husband and I don't live far so we have come here often. I feel like recently when we have come the food has still be good, but service has gone down hill a little. I don't know if it's because the servers are new or what. We like to share plates so we order a bunch of different things and our servers have been really good at pacing. The past few times we went all the food started coming out all at once and we had to ask them to slow things down a little so we could finish and make room on the table. On our last visit we couldn't finish our carnitas so one of the guys who was clearing our table asked if we wanted to take the rest with us. I told him yes and to make sure to pack the green sauce with it. He said no problem. A minute later our server came by and put the check down and we were about to put a card down when the guy who packed our food picked it back up. He said he needed to add the sauce to it. My husband and I looked at eachother, then at him and he actually said don't worry it's not a lot and walked away with the check. I guess there wasn't enough green sauce to pack up, but I feel like if it's going to be more he should have come back to us and gave us the option first. It was only like a $1 more, but I just didn't really like how it all went down.  I hope it's just a matter of training the new staff!
author: Kimberly W.

description:
The carnitas torta was pretty much off the hook.  Messy enough to qualify, but put together well, with fresh slices of zabuca....mmmmmm.

We asked for chips and salsa and got something refreshing and new.  Chips with a spicy dash and queso sprinkles, and sour cream to dip.  I could have eaten this alone, sort of like with chips and salsa.  You get all greedy and full on the chips and salsa that you end up taking your food home....and later throwing it away because left over Mexican food just ain't the same.
author: Andre S.

description: Such a cute little spot, my faves included the sangria and enchiladas-- super fresh and delicious!
author: Jill G.

description: Aside from the ridiculously long wait and the slightly surly (or was she simply overwhelmed?) server, I love this place.  The food is delicious (especially if you like it hot!) and the drinks are strong.  Would love to come back here anytime.  Well, anytime I feel like I can stand the wait, that is...
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Some of the best Mexican food I've had outside of Mexico.  This is a great eatery.  Casual atmosphere, very busy on the weekends.  We called recently on a saturday evening (5pm) and were told it was a 2+ hr. waiting list.  No reservations, but they do have a waiting list which is convenient.

We had Topos for the app, and Carnitas for main, which were off the charts good.  kind of a limited mex beer selection, but the food easily covers that gap.
author: Richard A.

description:
Fresh is the first word that comes to mind when I think about Nopalito. You can truly taste the freshness of their ingredients, which bring their Mexican dishes to life. Nopalito's food has a contemporary California flair, but still stays true to traditional Mexican flavors.

Taco de Pescado al Pastor (seared fish in adobo, chile ancho, orange, onion, salsa) - pretty good, but the taco could have used more fish. The tangy orange was a nice contrast to the spice. 

Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón (chile mulato corn tortilla, crispy pork belly, salsa guajillo, jack cheese, queso fresco) - my favorite dish. The crunchy tortilla had a vibrant corn taste, while the flavors of the savory pork belly were accentuated by the little crispy bits of fried pork skin. I also appreciated how the quesadilla had a lot of substance without being too heavy or greasy. 

Enchiladas de Mole con Pollo (tortillas, shredded chicken, sauce of chiles, chocolate, and nuts) - my hubby is more of a mole fan than I am, but I enjoyed the subtle sweetness and spice of this mole. A simple and well-balanced dish.

BATHROOM GOERS BEWARE:  Nopalito only has ONE bathroom for its 60 guests, requiring a lengthy wait for those with small bladders. Not a good idea to drink too many cervezas here!
author: Karin V.

description:
Warning: Do not come here if you are hungry. The portions are designed for Chihuahuas. 

Another star remover is that the kitchen keeps to a siesta style pace, which means you will have time to nap while waiting for your food. As we waited for our food we theorized that Nopalito must be Spanish for Wait for a F'N long time. Yes, everything took this long. 

Food is good, but be prepared to order multiple times to fill your tank, which makes this a 3 - $ dollar sign place. 

I will never come here again.
author: art s.

description:
Thanks but NO thanks NOpalito. My friends who had been were not impressed with the food at Nopalito. I thought their "no reservation policy" was bullshit-ish but I figured what the heck! Lets give it a go! We called in and waited ten minutes and we were seated. 

I looked at the menu and I was totally lost. We both were. One star for our waiter who was very helpful and knowledgeable of the menu. My favorite part of the meal was their chip dish. It was very unique and tasty! I also ordered an enchilada appetizer thing (I saw quac in the description so it was a done deal) which was pretty good. I did not care for the tostada app. I thought it lacked flavor. 

I won't come back here again. I wanted this place to be good since it's right down the street from me but it just wasn't my bag.
author: Jackie M.

description: This review is on their drinks only.  I thought it was a bit bland... not a fan.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Fresh ingredients, careful preparation, high quality authetic mexican flavors.  

Pretty interesting selection of different dishes.  

Fresh lime margarits and a few creative drink selections.  

(Not under-priced, however.)

Recommended.
author: Bruce M.

description: Very slow waitress served our brunch.  I gave $zero tip.  I had to prompt her on every step through our meal.  Canitas is hands down.  Go for canitas.
author: Miyako U.

description: Really good dinner. The service was really good as well our waitress was super nice and attentive. I had the carnitas and it was a great recommendation by our server. My husband had the chicken soup. I didn't care for it much but he was very happy with it. The margarita was not good and would not have that again but the chick peas they serve was good to munch on while looking at the menu.
author: Andrea D.

description: So tasty. I love every single item on the menu, and their margaritas are delish.
author: Raquel G.

description: I love the carnitas at Nopalito and basically everything else on their menu. We used to live around the corner from the location off Fell Street and now live on the other side of the city. Regardless, we always make our way over at least twice a month to enjoy their amazing food and great service.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Great service, great environment, great food! 

My husband and I ate vegetarian and there were plenty of choices if you eat appetizers and get creative. Our neighbors sitting next to us ordered a meat dish and were so jealous of the stuff they brought out to us. I guess because we ordered a bunch of small dishes we had a ton of variety and they were stuck with their one giant meat dish, whatever it was.

Yes, it was pricey but definitely worth the price. I can't say I'd eat here all the time because I like to eat cheap but I'll definitely be coming back when I feel like splurging. I can't wait to take all of my out of town friends and family members. This is a very impressive restaurant that really represents what fresh, sustainable, imaginative California Mex cuisine is all about.

This is not a place to get your typical a la carte burrito/taco like most taquerias. This place is about creativity and ingenuity. Expect to pay a little more than most Mex restaurants but expect great service and excellent food.
author: L. L.

description:
Walking out of Nopalito I thought I had just ate one of the best mexican dinners I'd had in a while. An hour later I realize just how much salt and grease I'd consumed as I curl up in bed trying to drink a gallon of water to counteract dinner.

Being vegetarian I was a little unsure how dinner here would go, but they were very accommodating in showing us the veggie options on the menu, and even turning a few meat items into veggie meals. We were very grateful. We wanted to share small plates instead of ordering appetizers, because from a veggie point of view, the apps are much more diverse and delicious sounding. We were informed that 4 would be the correct amount of food for 2 people. So we ordered, and after our food arrived it was gone 5 minutes later. Bother because it was delicious, but also because it was teeny tiny. We ended up having to order even more food.

The service was decent, the wait staff was very pleasant are fairly attentive, although they did forget to bring two dishes to the table until we asked about them 20 minutes later. I think generally speaking, I felt a little cheated out of time having to wait so long for food to come out of the kitchen and the plates to be so small and barren. Because I'm willing to wait for my food, but not if I'm only going to get three bites out of it after it arrives.

All in all, the prices are good, the strawberry sangria awesome, and the food delicious. I'll probably go back when I happen to be in that part of the city, but I'm not sure I'd specifically plan another trip there.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Hey! A tasty treat! A good deal considering everything is fresh, local organic, etc. etc. 

The rice pudding and enchilladas placeras were AMAZING, the mole poblano con puerco was pretty good, too.

nom nom nom nom.
author: Lesley P.

description:
If you are coming to Nopalito for your standard Mexican fare of burritos and tacos, then you'll be disappointed.  But if you are coming to have a refreshing take on Mexican cuisine, then you are visiting the right place.  Nestled in the bustling new Broderick complex, Nopalito is a great place to visit on a sunny San Francisco day.  The place is full of windows and makes good use of their limited space.  

The food, which is for the most part organic and sustanable based products, is satisfying for both my growing need to try new things and my larger than normal appetite.  I really enjoyed the Ceviche and the fresh plump pieces of fish, as well as the Totopos (thich tortilla chips covered in a red sauce and cheese.)  I'm a huge fan of Carnitas and while Nopalito isn't the moistest one I've had, I did enjoy the hunk of well flavored pork sitting in the cermamic bowl.  It was more than enough for two people to share.  The (non-alcoholic) drinks are all worth trying, especially the Horchata.  Try not to leave with out getting one of their desserts on a stick.  ;)
author: Jason A.

description:
Wow, this place sucks. It's not really authentic first off, and I knew that going in, but little did I know I would be paying $9 for a piece of tortilla (burnt almost black/brown), some undercooked pork, a little bit of some onions and cilantro. No sides. Nothing. Just a burnt piece of tortilla in half. I did not dine in when I came here, just took my food and left, and when I got to the bus stop and opened up my lunch- I almost cried. 

WHAT A RIP OFF.
author: Lauren S.

description:
How are you supposed to review this place? Is it Mexican? Is it the offspring of Nopa? Is it ethnic cuisine that is repackaged and watered-down then tossed with a bit of the organic and green theme to appeal to the so-called "foodies" of San Francisco? By george I think I've got it!

I'm not saying this place isn't good. I'm just saying you have to temper your expectations. Let's get SAT with this...

                                    Yank Sing:Chinese::Nopalito:Mexican

And I'm not saying Yank Sing is bad. I'm just saying you have to temper your expectations. If you really wanted good Chinese, you'd go to Chinatown. If you really wanted good Mexican, you'd go to the Mission. 

That being said, let's talk about the food. The Totopos con Chile (tortilla chips tossed in chile de arbol and topped with cojita cheese and lime) was a cute idea, but it just didn't have that yum factor. I would've been happier with simple housemade chips and salsa. No, they don't have that. And that's the last time I pay $14 for Carnitas. I'd much rather have Gordos or El Farlito. Actually I didn't pay for it, and I'm still complaining! She had the Carne Asada steak which was a perfectly cooked skirt steak that was tender and flavorful. It was accented nicely with a peppery mole (mo-lay!) sauce. I'm glad she doesn't eat much. Awesome!

So I'm not saying this place is not good. You just have to know what you're getting yourself into when you go here. I'll be back at some point to have the Carne Asada steak, but you might find me at the El Toyanese truck at some pioint sooner.
author: Al L.

description:
I don't care if it's organic (I put enough "chemicals" in my body that a few pesticides are the least of my worries). I don't care if it's locally sourced. I don't care if all the servers are adorable gay boy hipsters with boyscout hips and happy meal sized asses I just want to slap every time they walk by.  I don't even care that their chicken consomme is possibly the best soup in the world.

I do care that every time I've been there (be it empty or packed), I've waited 20 minutes to order, 30 minutes for soup and a taco to come out, and what feels like an eternity to get my check and even longer for them to actually collect my card, run it, and bring it back. It feels like everything at Nopalito moves in slow motion. For a jittery, shakey, nervous nelly like myself who can't still for more than 20 minutes without tranquilizers and a box of wine, this is the equivalent of an eternity of pushing a giant rock up a neverending hill (and you all know that story).

So, Nopalito: you rock. Your interior and decor rock. Your seats could use some cushioning for those of the boney ass persuasion like myself but aside from that, my only complaint is the never-ending story that is the wait for everything imaginable within your walls. Give the cook and those servers some speed and we'll bump you up to 5 stars.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I LOVE this place.  I always get the Totopos con Chili...why does no one else toss their chips with salsa???  AND crema to dip them in??  Delicious.

Both lunch and dinner are equally good here.  My favorite thing to get for lunch is the torta and for dinner, without a doubt the carnitas.

The prices here are also surprisingly good.  The carnitas are perfect for 2 people to split it's such a large portion and at $15, it makes quite a deal for dinner.

I also love their homemade tortillas.  Everything always tastes really fresh and is presented beautifully.
author: Erin B.

description:
The food is good, people seem to have that covered. The loss of two stars is for 1) being a bit pricey, 2) small portions, and 3) a terrible bathroom set up. 

But what I was surprised to see is that my two favorite things about this restaurant are not much talked about. 
1) The Micheladas (their Red Beer - beer with bloody mary mix and salt on the rim). Theirs is soo good, maybe the best i have ever had. Great spices and flavor but not overly spicy. These are not the most common in SF but are more popular in TX where I grew up and are a great addition to a Saturday lunch. 
2) I used to live about 2 blocks away and when it is busy, they let you call in and they will put your name on the clipboard. Then they will call you back when your name is getting close so you can head down to the restaurant. Great on a Friday night when you can stay at your apt with friends sharing a bottle of wine rather than stand in front of Falletti's freezing in the SF weather.
author: Meagan C.

description:
I live about 2 blocks away and wanted to come here for a while..but had a hard time thinking about spending so much on Mexican food. SO had my mom take us when she was here! She and I were leaving town that night, so she, the bf and I went about 545 on a thursday and had no problem getting a table ASAP-but I see people waiting wayyyy too long all the time.

Food was really good! They had a really yummy ceviche and this corn / cheese dish (?) that was new and fun. We had a tasty quesadilla with a savory/sweet quesadillla as well. The carnitas were outta this world, served as a big ol slab of meat and you pull it off yourself-some of the best carnitas I've had. The only eh thing was the tamale-pretty dry and lacking filling. I'd stick with authentic street tamales. 

Overall:  Good food, nice casual atmosphere and good service. However, too $ and NOT worth an hour wait
author: Afton T.

description:
I would give this place a higher rating as I thought it was charming and most of my friends enjoyed the food immensely.  To be fair I gave it three stars because I am hoping what happened to me is an isolated incident.  I had the huevos de cata (I think that's the name).  12 hours later, I came down with a bad bout of food poisoning which feels like Salmonella poisoning I had in college at one point.  

From what I garnered Salmonella can be in certain products and not in others.  All I can say is while this place is very cute, making sure their food is well done is important.  If I had followed these steps, I likely would be okay.
author: Caryn B.

description:
I read about Nopalito's a few months ago and I decided that I would eat here on one of my trips to the Bay Area.  Tonight, I did so and it was good.

The restaurant is casual and the food is good, like you're part of the family.  One of my dining friends lives close by and eats there every once in a while, she was recognized with a friendly greeting.

We had called in and were on the waiting list, while driving in to the City and the outdoor table was waiting for us.  Even on a cold San Francisco summer day, their covered outdoor seating with radiant heaters would be a pleasant place for dinner.

We ordered and the food came promptly, but not so quick that it was waiting to be ordered.  I had the chicken mole, though the carnitas are highly recommended.  

The Meyer Lemonade was really good, but my dinner mate didn't like her Hibicus-Valencia Orange beverage.

The menu also indicates that the food is organic and locally sourced, but it doesn't make a big deal of it.  I like the idea of organic and eating locally, but it doesn't have to be thrown in your face like they do at some restaurants.  Nopalito rides on the the quality of its food!
author: Beau R.

description: The carnitas here are amazing.  The meat just melts in your mouth and the freshly made corn tortillas are some of the best I've ever had.  On my last visit, I tried the seafood stew.  I'm not usually big on seafood dishes, but this one blew me away.  The white fish was cooked to perfection and the flavor of the soup was amazing.  Definitely recommend trying both dishes.
author: Josh F.

description:
Honestly, make the portions 50% bigger, the price 33% lower, or throw in some free beer with every order.  Otherwise, I'm not impressed.  

Over-rated.
author: Ashley W.

description:
I'm a long-time resident of NOPA and was pleased when this place opened. It's close to home and has quality food for cheap prices. Been there at least a couple times per month and am left craving for more every time I leave. 

The occasional long wait for a table can be annoying but the chicken tostadas and carnitas make up for it. The best carnitas around. Everything on the menu is flavorful. Order the mezcal paloma cocktail, you will not be disappointed. My girlfriend got me hooked on those. 

I am a loyal customer!
author: David N.

description:
Service was fantastic, Started with the nachos for an appetizer and they were phenomenal. I wouldn't call them healthy, but they were clearly better than regular nachos with a ton more flavor. The portion size was gigantic. So much so that my gf and I couldn't finish if we intended on eating our entree. The tequila selection is excellent and there are a ton of local beers that I love, but I do wish there was more a craft Mexican beer selection available (Is there even such a thing that exists?). My gf had the quesadilla for dinner which is not like a normal quesadilla. It's almost like a large soft taco folded over with mushrooms and cotija inside along with some really fresh greens. I'm not fan of mushrooms, but my gf (a vegetarian) loved it. 

I ordered the posole. To me posole is sacred, it's like going to an Italian restaurant an ordering the Chicken Parmesan or the meatballs or a pub and ordering fish & chips. If they can't get this right then how can I expect anything else to be good? The posole was the best I've had since I was a boy and my best friend's mother used to make it. It was hearty and just spicy enough, there was enough pork shoulder in it to create a fantastic flavor, but not too much to over power the dish. Tons of hominy and chips, onions, oregano and spices on the side to fix it up to your own specifications. 

I wish I remembered my server's name, instead I'll have to describe him. He wore black rimmed glasses, with black hair and was very attentive. Not in the overbearing sort of way, but just enough to know that if we wanted something he'd be there. He knew the dishes, let us take our time and was very very nice. He made us feel like we were not just customers, but guests. We also were helped by either a second server, a food runner or a busser, I'm not sure what his title was, but he boxed up my posole, dropped the check and was very witty and funny in his small interactions with us, It was the epitome of team work and at no time did I feel like they were overbearing or annoying.

This is the best casual plus dining food I've had in the city and we're going to definitely make this our go-to place.
author: Matt D.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Great place to share small plates with friends. The housemade tortillas and drinks are to die for. Went here on my birthday because I love it so much!
author: Steve P.

description:
My wife and I were excited to visit Nopalito and try it out on a Friday night.  I want to describe our outing as the Good, the Bad and the Ugly.  

Good:  The food and the price.  We loved the Carnitas and also shared the Ceviche, and the Tamal.  The corn tortillas were great too.  

Bad:  Service and wine.  This is the kind of place that you need to order as soon as the wait staff show or you are in for a nice, long wait.  We were eating at 8:30 p.m. so I don't know if our waitress was tired, working too many tables (7+ tables), or just didn't care.  We ordered some wine (I know this is lame at a Mexican place) but it was terrible.  My wife ordered the Syrah-Carignane and I ordered the Carignane.  We are not wine snobs but the Syrah-Carignane tasted like they took a scorpion and squeezed it into a small wine glass.  They should nix the wine and just stick to beer until they get a license to serve hard alcohol.

Ugly:  The wait.  You are looking at at least 90 minutes to 2 hours at a minimum on a weekend.  You can call ahead to get your name on a list but you still have to wait.  The host was nice and accommodating but he was managing a six page list (back and front) and you have to track him down by going into the restaurant.   They take your name and phone number and then promise to call you back.  We hung out at a bar on Divisadero.  I think we could have saved ourselves some grief by just showing up at 9:15 or 9:30 p.m. and pretend we live in South America.

Side Note: There was a couple on a date beside us and they waited longer than we did.  We told them that we experienced the same thing but the food was quite good.  The guy's date looked pissed and he was looking frantically for a waitress to order since his date looked like she was about to eat the silverware.

My suggestion to the restaurant would be to take reservations to save everyone some grief.   The host looked beaten down and spent all his time with an ever expanding list.   The patrons looked unhappy due to the chaos associated with a list and not knowing when they would be served.

I am not ranting here but I wanted to make sure people have realistic expectations for a place that has good food but needs to work out some kinks in service.
author: James B.

description:
Nopalito is such a darling little place. I don't even mind putting my name on the waiting list, because you really feel like you've arrived somewhere special upon walking in. The covered patio is just lovely between the beautiful organic wood furniture and the sun streaming through the windows.

First thing's first! You gotta order up your Micheladas. I was a Michelada virgin before today, but no more! I love the combination of the light Mexican beer, chili, salt and lime. There's just nothing quite so thirst quenchingly good, and I'm sure there are many more in my future.

On to the important part -- the food! The Totopos con Chile (chips) were pretty amazing and simple with fresh cheese on the top and a side of sour cream. The cheese quesadilla with oyster mushrooms was delicious and rich with a smathering of spicy salsa. Surprisingly, only the famed carnitas disappointed -- the meat was fatty and the flavors didn't pop like I expected.

Our server was suuuuper slow, and after waiting for a long while for him to pick up our credit cards, we noticed him eating at the counter. Ugh. Definitely hit up the counter instead if you're in a hurry. Too bad they don't serve Micheladas to go. I'd be brown bagging it all over town!
author: Nicole G.

description:
#4 out of #100.  

Caldo Tlalpeño sucks!!!  The best thing about Nopalito is the super hand blower once you get to the bathroom, but it will take forever to get to the bathroom because there is only one bathroom.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I wish I could give this 3.5 stars.

This is a healthy, organic restaurant with all aspects (including grinding the corn to make the tortillas) done in-house using local sustainable sources.  This is not your standard greasy spoon Mexican.  If you want that then choose another option.

Because it is a sister restaurant of Nopa, which I love, I did start off with high expectations of wonderfully spiced and balanced food.  I was a bit disappointed. To be clear, the flavors of the food we had were wonderful and the ingredients were super fresh, but each dish that had a tortilla was overpowered by it, and unfortunately just about every dish I ordered had it.  If Nopalito could make those tortillas thinner it would balance the dishes in terms of flavor so that the tortilla would be a side note rather than the main attraction.  The dryness and thickness of the tortillas really do detract from the experience. Seriously nopalito- change this one thing and it would take you over the top, bringing you on par with your sister, nopa.  

That being said, I think the food, the ambiance and the service was very good. I imagine that there might be a few dishes that I will decide are *the* dishes and it will become the four stars I feel it can be (which is why I rounded up). When I go back, I will try the chips & salsa as the tortillas alone are wonderful if they are the main attraction, and will also try other dishes that do not have the tortillas & will update.

Oh! whatever you do, if you are a chocolate lover- you MUST order the hot chocolate.  I cannot say enough about how the flavors dance on the palate.  It is like a dessert you drink. oh. my. god.  I wish they had more options in terms of dessert here. Considering how well nopa does the pot de creme (to die for) I imagine that they could do an amazing flan or tres leches.  

We had the taquitos, fish taco, empanada, quesadilla, and carnitas.  We also tried the sangria, sparkling & hibiscus valencia orange, and the sparkling & strawberry lemonade.  Oh.. and the hot chocolate. 

The carnitas were very good.  I would definitely order this again.

The taquitos were good also.  Again, wish the tortillas were thinner- or if not then there was more filling to balance it out. I would order this again, but not jumping to- I will try the other appetizers first.  

The empanada filling was wonderful and more plentiful than the taquito and because of the deep frying, it ended up having the tortillas taste less dry. It also could have been heavier on the filling & wish it did.  I would definitely order this again.

The fish taco dish was good but the balance was off because the tortilla is thick & dry. The sauce was good and helped, but I would not order this dish again.

The veggie quesdilla filling was good but of all the dishes this had the most serious balance issue and the bites tasted dry.  The filling was good but sadly, because of the dryness I would not recommend this dish unless they were willing to put double the amount of filling in it. That would certainly help to balance it out.

Again... did I say ORDER THE HOT CHOCOLATE? The hot chocolate was out of this world amazing!!! THIS was the one thing I had at the restaurant that truly had my taste buds smile.
author: N A.

description:
My tongue never ceases to be amazed by the dishes here.  Sure there are a few misses but when they're on, they're really on.

Dishes that have recently dazzled my palate (i.e. party in my mouth)

Sandia con Chile y Limón 6.00
Yellow Orchid watermelon, chile de arbol, chile guajillo
and lime

Carnitas 14.00
Long braised pork, orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer. Cabbage salad, pickled jalapeños, salsa de tomatillo

Gordita de Guisado de Res al Pasilla 4.50
Stewed grassfed beef, chile pasilla, chile negro, tomatillos, jalapeños, pinquito beans, guacamole and queso fresco

Enjitomatadas con Papas 5.50
Tortillas with queso fresco, tomato sauce, potatoes, whole pinquito beans and crema

Panucho de Pollo al Pibil 4.00
Black bean stuffed tortilla, citrus-achiote chicken, pickled red onion and salsa habanera
(tasty, although a bit greasy)

Dishes to avoid (will update this as needed):

Quesadilla Azul de Flor de Calabasas 8.00
Blue corn tortilla, squash blossoms, zucchini, poblanos, jack cheese, queso fresco and pico de gallo de tomatillo
(bland)

I stand by my previous review in the sense that the prices are totally worth it for the wonderful flavors and fresh ingredients.  We always have great service and knowledgeable waiters.  Great go-to option for lunch/dinner.
author: LaSha G.

description: generally not crazy about "fancy" Mexican food, being more of a taqueria fan, but this place is over the top good! We had the Carnitas (best I've ever had, except maybe from a food truck on International Blvd in Oakland), birria, and fish tacos.  Also the totopos - DELISH and well worth the calories.  You will not go wrong with any of these orders. We called ahead and put our name in (Tuesday nite) and had no trouble getting seated.  Only quibble - we were seated under one of the heat lamps on the enclosed patio and nearly fried!  Server - though sweet - checked with the boss and said they could not be turned off.  Never mind, I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Mary D.

description:
For a moment, imagine drinking watermelon flavored jolly ranchers.  How good does that sound/taste?  Well Nopalita has got something similar, Organic Watermelon Sangria?!?!  I cant say anything other than, "Its awesome!"  :)  

This place is great.  The ambiance is friendly, fun and upbeat.  The smell of the food from the kitchen lingers throughout the whole place and will cause you to temporarily think about ordering everything on the menu.  I had the empanadas and mole chicken.  Both were good not incredible but good.  However the gazpacho was great.   

I definitely recommend it for good eats with good friends.  woohoo...
author: samit P.

description:
My friend Irv called me up last Sunday and suggested we go to Napolito for dinner. We took the Hayes st bus from Civic Center and in minutes were deposited just two small blocks from Napolito which is across the street from the DMV parking lot. The place was busy, we were asked to stand at a side bar for 10-15minutes until our table became available which was fine by me because I like checking out the "Cocineros" or cooks in action. The bar tender asked us for our drink order, I chose the Strawberry Ginger drink which was refreshing! 

We were seated at a table for two which wasn't too close to the next table (Pet peeve of mine) so we both had some elbow room and didn't have to hear our table mates conversation. My only comment about this table, in the semi permanent room just as you enter the main dining room is it sits underneath the heater which made us feel too warm. Several times during the meal we asked our server to turn the heater off, somebody else asked to turn it on, well you see how this game was played throughout the evening.

Our server was a lovely young woman, asked us if we had been to Nopalito and since we had she didn't go into great detail about the restaurant and took our order. Here is what we ordered:

Totopos con Chile:Tortilla chips, salsa de arbol, cotija cheese, crema and lime.  

In a paralel universe, Totopos con Chile would be served in every Mexican restaurant instead of the typical "Chips n Salsa". These are just amazing, the tortilla chips are fresh AND crisp, tossed with a spiced red sauce but not so spicy that lightweights like Irv will cry about it but spicy enough so that heat/spice lovers like myself are still satisfied. I love the salsa crema served with it to cool it down and the squeeze of lime adds the perfect touch to this starter.

Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón: Chile mulato corn tortilla, crispy pork belly, salsa guajillo, jack cheese, queso fresco, onions and cilantro. 
 
As a teen I worked in a Mexican restaurant and made tons of Chicharones, the perfect Chicharon has the perfect balance of fat and meat; the Chicharones served at Napolito's were perefect! I'm also a fan of quesadillas, and I loved the combination of meat, salsa, cheese, cilantro and onions, it played out very well, was a joy to eat.

Gaspacho de Frutas Estilo Morelia:Salad of peaches, nectarines, apricots, orange juice, chile, lime, queso fresco and Nopalito hot sauce.

 This is not your Gaspacho from Espanya! In fact I would call this a fruit salad to be quite honest but doesn't Gaspacho sound better? The fruit was ripe AND sweet, the perfect dish after the Totopos and Quesadilla and still not filling which left plenty of room for the main course, CARNITAS.

Carnitas:Long braised pork, orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer, Cabbage salad, pickled jalapeños, salsa de tomatillo.

Ok, I died and went to culinary heaven with this dish, it's all about the Carnitas. Again, I'm no rookie with Carnitas but these are not just ordinary Carnitas. A typical Carnita seems to be a mound of shredded meat and you add salt to bring out the taste, more seems to be better. The Carnitas at Napolito's had a wonderful taste of spices, very moist, tender, loved how they arrived in a pocket of parchment paper which I think is how they keep their cooked meats from being overdone. Loved the Cabbage salad on the side and picked jalapenos, these two items only enhanced the carnitas taste.....oh I forgot, the home made tortillas are delicious, again, these are not the typical corn tortillas you buy by the dozen at any mercado or Safeway, these are home made and you can definitely taste that stone ground corn goodness in them.

I'm not a big dessert eater not because I don't like dessert but I felt perfectly content at this point (Panza llena, corazon contento) and one more morsel of food even in the form of dessert would have put me over the edge from content to uncomfortably full. Irv on the other hand ordered the Home made Paletas or popsicles with blueberry and white peach; he loved it, especially nice on one of our few warm evenings. I did enjoy the little sugar cookie at the end that is brought with the bill, I'll say it again, those should be on the dessert menu! The combination of light and airy cookie, sugar and spice just melts in your mouth.

A big thank you to the staff at  Nopalito for making another memorable meal, regresare' pronto! (I'll be back soon).
author: David P.

description:
The service here is awesome.  The people seem to really like their jobs and for that reason I decided to come back and give it another shot.  The wait is intense, but whatever, I'll wait for good service/food.  

I'm vegetarian and had eaten here once before.  I've now tried all the veggie options they have or will customize and overall I'd say the food is not bad, but it is a bit bland.  Quite greasy.  One may beg to differ and say the food is delicate and the flavors are soft.  Overall, nothing to write home about.  I'll go back, but not right away.
author: Bobby B.

description:
I gave this 2 stars for the michelada - a refreshing tomato beer with lime and spices.  

HOWEVER, that was the only thing in the menu that we tasted that had spices.  We shared an appetizer and 3 dishes:  everything was unspecial and had NO taste of spice, including salt.  Ironically, the menu sure talked about how many spices each dish contained - and man were those descriptions fancy.  Our pork stew had tiny pieces of pork floating in a mass of red broth that tasted of nothing.  I kept adding salt to it, hoping the taste would change.  The goat came out, about 5 small pieces - nicely tenderized, but tasteless.  The fish was fishy and served with bland tomato rice.

Only hipsters would force the opening of a "waiting list" restaurant for mexican food in a town with the best tacquerias.  

Oh yeah, the wait staff was nice.  Too bad the food sucked.
author: Priya R.

description:
We had the panucho de pollo, taco de pescado, and the enchiladas de Mole con Pollo. 

-As far as fish tacos go it was decent--perfectly battered and fried fish. The orange slices overpowered the other ingredients. Since citrus has such a strong flavor I would have rather had the oranges incorporated as part of the sauce.
-The panucho was my favorite. We liked the spice of the sauce with the pickled onions. 
-The mole was strange. Way way way too chocolately. After one bite I didn't want to eat anymore at all but I felt bad when they came to collect the plates and I had barely touched it so I just stuffed the rest in my mouth in a couple big bites.

Overall nice bright and cheery decor and good service. I definitely will come back to try some of the other menu items.
author: Jeanne L.

description: delicious carnitas and quesadilla; awesome service by Edgar ( I think thats his name), and the local IPA was fantastic and even the coffee was amazing!!! keep it up
author: Gonzalez A.

description:
Meh...okay, but not great.  Portions are small, prices are large, and our waitress was clearly thinking about Tony...where he is, what he is doing, and whether he will ever come back to her...because she could not have given a lesser damn about us.  There were not enough glasses on the table when we sat down, and I had to ask three times for one to be brought.  Most of the food looked good, and tasted fine, but I was led to believe it was going to be MUCH better, based in part on some of the over-enthusiastic reviews here on Yelp.  

I might give them one more chance, but I doubt it will be any time soon.
author: Brendon O.

description:
Ended up here with SMS girls on DW's suggestion cuz its in her hood.

AMBIANCE: Nopalito has a trendy cafeteria-ish feel to it-- totally not what I expected.  The space is on the small side, although there are several larger tables in the outer covered courtyard area (there are heat lamps, so no worries about being cold).

SERVICE: Every single staff member we encountered was very friendly (although occasionally a bit brusque... which I assume is b/c they were in a rush).  Our waitress took pretty good care of us, considering all the other tables she had to cover.

FOOD: Beware, just about everything is deep fried (not what I expected).  Reminiscent of classy street food.  We shared several dishes:
- Totopos con Chile ($6): Not bad.  Not as mindblowing as others made them out to be.  They're like weird soggy Doritos with a generous sprinkling of cotija cheese on top.  The fact that Nopalito's chips are extra thick is a nice touch.
- Panucho de Pollo al Pibil ($4.50): Good flavors, but the chicken was so dry.
- Gordita de Picadillo ($4.50): My least favorite dish.  Bland and greasy.
- Empanada con Deshebrada de Res ($6): Very beefy/gamey.  Wished there was something to mellow out that flavor... onions?  
- Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamari ($11): The citrus/acid was very refreshing.  The fish and calamari were both very tender.  It was one of our only non-oil-drenched dishes.
- Carnitas ($15.50): Table favorite.  I thought the flavors were only ok.  The pork was a mixed bag-- some was fork-tender while other bits were really dry.  I adored the pickled items (jalapeno, onion, carrot) and the cabbage slaw.  Yum.  
- Chilpachole de Jaiba y Pescado ($15): A brothy soup that ended up being super fishy.  Not a huge fan.

OVERALL: The complimentary almond butter cookies that came with the check were a nice, sweet touch.  Total came out to $27/person (including tax+tip).  Seemed kinda hefty for the amount of food we got, although to be fair, I think we were all stuffed and ready to burst at the seams (didn't stop us from going to Humphrey Slocombe later though haha).  I wouldn't object if someone wanted to go there, but it wouldn't be my first choice, and I would never suggest it on my own.
author: Susanna W.

description: The food in this restaurant is tasty and the service is good. The only complain is that very noisy.  They don't take reservations but one can call ahead and register on a list.  Because they are so popular it is best to go either early or late.
author: Sushi C.

description: I give one star to the junkie shooting up in the bathroom. One star for the one bathroom with one toilet that you have to leave the restaurant to use...go out the door, through the parking lot, down the block and into a door open to the public. One star to said heroin addict for not smoking the reefer hanging out of his mouth when he emerged after keeping me waiting for 5 minutes. The bathroom didn't smell, so thanks man! One star for the big blue smack baggie he disposed of in the toilet, shredded and spreading across the water like a sea animal. (Hate to see the plumbing bill on that!) One star for the waiter who gave me the code to the bathroom in the grocery store at the end of the block. One star to the guy there who had no idea what I was saying. One star for the employee who did shout out the code as I wandered back behind the butcher counter looking for the bathroom. One star for the lunch that cost $120 so that a junkie could walk in off the street and indulge his habit. And a big fat collective ONE STAR to the myriad supercilious, unsmiling, so-hip-I-don't-have-to- care staff who populate this stunningly mediocre restaurant-cum-shooting gallery.
author: laura N.

description: The food was very good here.  Amanda RAVED about the carnitas, and my chilaquiles was good, not fantastic though.  Amanda was especially interested in the brunch cocktails, but the one she got ended up being really not that interesting and kinda watered down.  The menu mentioned notes of all kinds of flavors that you really just couldn't taste.  Food was good though, would come back for that.
author: Phil J.

description:
It's gotten so I can only give things five stars anymore, and without dragging you down psychoanalysis lane, I've become a much more "if you don't have anything nice to say" person than I used to be. That said, sometimes even for the princess of hyperbole, things can just be good. Not AWESOME or MINDBLOWING and not at all bad or even "meh" (the kids aren't saying that anymore, FYI), but just solid good. Decent, better than that even. 

Nopalito is good. I won't calibrate its goodness against potential influencing factors like duration of time spent getting the door open (hella long), or the fact that when you're sitting in their little enclosed glass porch looking at new construction it feels disconcertingly suburban (even if this *is* what the neighborhood thought they wanted), I'll just let its goodness be by itself. In a little corner of... goodness.

Vegetarian options abound, things like masa and crema and tacos take on the gourmetfying flavors of boutique mushrooms, and the horchata is really the best $4.00 you'll spend all day.  I can walk home from it quickly and comfortably. Todo esta bien.
author: Megan W.

description:
Great concept, well-thought out dishes - certainly a refreshing departure from the typical fare offered at most Mexican joints. You do pay for it, esp considering the meager portions of some dishes (I didn't try the quesadilla, but it looked pretty thin for $8).

We made the big mistake of sitting at the counter facing the kitchen during rush hour, and it was _stressful_ watching the whole operation on full throttle for 40 mins while we waited for our food. They seem way short staffed to handle a full dinner crowd & an unrelenting stream of orders from the take-out window, and it was nothing less than chaos in the galley - shouting, dropping/breaking things, hastily prepared dishes, sweating cooks....I felt exhausted when I left! 

I'd like to come back when it's not Sunday night, and I think if you order the right things, it can still be a bargain bite - the fish taco for $4.5 w/ a sizable fillet was pretty filling, as was the tamale. My husbands' lamb in  banana leaf was disappointing-bland & soggy. Ceviche was excellent but wish it came with more than 8 chips.
author: Kathy Y.

description: This place is delicious even if it's not authentic, but americanized Mexican food! We had the Totopos con Chile, Panucho de Pollo al Pibil, and Carnitas. It was delicious. Service was kind of weird. They were attentive, but they took forever to bring the bill and pick it up! Do you want the tip or not people!?
author: Jennifer H.

description: OMG parking in the city?  Really convenient.  Great service, and drinks too if you like Mezcal.  Knocking off a star for the wait and the food was just alright.  Carnitas weren't bad but I wasn't blown away, I think my expectations were too high seeing everyone else talk them up.  Brussel sprout quesidilla was interesting.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
It's hard to find mexican restaurants in SF.  We have a taqueria on every damn corner, but nowhere where I can order some damn pozole or ceviche.  

Nopalito has it going on.  

The mole was delicious, not the best I've had, but very tasty...sweet, smoky and the chicken was cooked to perfection.  

The ceviche was some AMAZINGLY taste bud tingling...my only complaint is that it was lacking in looks.  Ceviche should have some color, not look like a green colored fish bits.  Throw some red peppers and red onions in it.  

The Cecina Enchilada con Rajas was wonderful, except that it wasn't an enchilada dish.  Um...confused.  The meat was marinated to perfection with the right amount of citrus that I love.  It came with tortillas on the side.  Um...confused.  Aren't enchiladas usually meat wrapped in tortillas with some chesse and sauce??  They should really think about changing the name on the menu.  Very misleading.

Handmade tortillas get two thumbs up.

Seriously though, I think their black beans impressed me the most.  Black beans can be kinda on the boring side.  Nopalito does something special to their beans.  I can't quite put my finger on it or detect the secret with my super powered taste buds, but I will experiment in my kitchen.

Also, I don't think the portions were too small.  Shared the three dishes between me and one other person.  I had leftovers for lunch the next day.

P.S.  The tortilla chips RULE and the salsa SUCKS!
author: Christina S.

description:
Maybe it was the hype, maybe the anticipation of a new neighborhood gem set the bar too high.  Maybe I ordered the wrong dish.

Very disappointing.  I still can't believe I paid $8 for a cheese quesadilla, not even very big.  The mixture of cheeses and use of blue corn tortilla was nice and the flavors were good, but the amount of cheese was skimpy and for $8 you'd think you'd get a little guac or avoacado on top, nope.  

And half way through I found a hair, definatly not my color, gross!

Left hungry and won't hurry back.
author: Gucci M.

description:
Been back quit a few times since last time I reviewed. So far I've hand one dish that I wouldn't order again and that's the guacamole special they had last night. It didn't taste freshly made and it lacked flavor. So far these are the dishes that have become our favorites and are what we consistently order. 

1. Carnitas
2. Corn with Crema y Queso
3. Ceviche
4. Quesadilla (they always change)
author: Rolo A.

description:
SFgate top 100.  I don't think so.  Went to 2 places on the list today.  
I'm beginning to think M. Bauer is paid for his selection.

Gordita is tasty but the fried tortilla is slightly chewy.

Tamale is different - the masa is mixed in with all the ingredients.  Its just okay.

Ceviche - fresh but kinda small - can get better at limon

Carnitas nice and tender good portion size

Huevos de caja a little rich need something refreshing on the side
White wine sangria - kinda week

Don't think I will go back.
author: David L.

description: Excellent food and service. The food is very fresh and the portions are perfect. I recommend the steak with black beans and the tostada appetizer.
author: Brendan R.

description: It was pretty good. Again its a popular destination so get there and put your name on the list and be prepared to wait. Food is solid.
author: Chris L.

description:
Nopalito... cha, more like No Burrito!

I shared several small items with some co-workers the other day and felt compelled to say a lil sumthin sumthin.

I munched heavily on the Gorditas and Tamales and will do so again.

What stuck out most on my flavorometer was the distinct and separate  flavors of the chicken and pork.  The chicken had a roasted, sweet flavor and a spiciness that crept up on you. The pork was bold and smokey, though not all that spicy, but that is what sauces are for.

Masa was great on the tamales. No corn slime, nice.

Great dining area ta boot. Inside is bright and not too loud, plus there is a heated glassed-in patio that they can open up on nice days.

I will back to hit up the entrees for sure. 

A nice addition to the Addition. Whoops, I mean NoPa.
author: Erin W.

description:
I think in the long run, Nopalito's rating will converge and settle around 2.5 to 3 stars.  Honestly I say this without bias.  Actually I really want to like it more because I live on the same street and it's a 3 mins walk to there.  However, I can say that it is over-priced for what it is both in terms of quality and portion.  

I went with 4 friends, ended up paying about $28/person and all of us left without being full.  In addition the quality while being good is not 4-star worthy.  The lamb stew was good though there was a dirth of meat.  I liked the home-made tortillas.  However at the end of the day, I feel most people are waiting in line to go here mainly because a) It's new  b)related to NOPA c)other people are waiting in line

For my money, I would take NOPA any day.
author: Hui C.

description:
I was probably expecting more because I LOVE Nopa.  Nopalito was good, but didn't blow me away.  

My dining companion had the carnitas, which was very nice.  I chose the cecina enchilada con rajas, which was unlike any enchilada I've ever had.  Maybe I need to expand my horizons beyond the neighborhood taqueria and Chevy's?  In any case, it was good, but could have used a bit more flavor. 

Nonetheless, I truly enjoyed the little dish of chick peas and the ceviche we shared as a starter was also quite nice.
author: Marcus C.

description: This place is overrated.  The mole sauce was too salty.  You just can't run an expensive Mexican restaurant and F up dishes such as that.  Their Caldo Tlalpeño(soup) was surprisingly good for a simple brothy soup!  Lacks dessert options.
author: AJ B.

description:
After hearing everyone rave about Nopalito for the last year, we finally made it in for an impromptu Wednesday night dinner...and the place definitely lives up to the hype!  The enclosed patio is really cool (it's really more of a greenhouse - it probably gets hella hot in the day time) and the free parking is a nice plus.  

But of course, what really matters is the food, which was tasty!  I love Mexican food but have to admit it's all kind of the same - the dishes are like pinto beans, cheese, tomato, and avocado playing a big game of musical chairs (hmmm...maybe musical tortillas).  But the ingredients and flavors at Nopalito are unique and just explode in your mouth. We had the taquitos de papitas (good), Taco de Pescado al Pastor (excellent), and Pescado a la Talla (awesome).  

The best part is that the dishes are so fresh and light that it feels like you're eating healthy (you probably aren't).  Not getting that I-shouldn't-have-gotten-the-combo-plate feeling after you eat dine-in Mexican is worth a star on it's own...
author: Rosers M.

description:
Underwhelmed by everything. The food was bland and there was not one veggie/fish/seafood entree, all were meat. The seating was freezing with an open window and door, the heating lamps were pretty much heating up the great outdoors. The tiniest pour of wine for the price anywhere I've been lately. The dishtowels for napkins. The waiters who kept removing dishes that were not finished - what's up with that? Aren't you supposed to at least ask first? To go the restroom you have to hike around the building (not covered, so be prepared if it's raining) to another door. 

We had what we could from the meat-laden menu and found that the cabbage salad was oily with way too much lemon, the fish taco dry (although the fish was well seasoned it was cooked to death) and the quesadilla supremely boring with no taste. I can have boring tasteless food at home - I want my Mexican food to be something else.
author: Finn T.

description:
After seeing the swarms for months, we finally bucked up and called to see how long the wait was so we could first hand see what the story is all about. After we told the host we were 4 blocks away, he gauranteed us a table upon arrival (and he delivered). We sat in the toasty covered patio and were promptly served chili garbanzos before our waitress came over. 

I tried the Quesadilla de Acelgas and Tamal de Frijoles con Queso y Huitlacoche. The corn tortilla in the quesadilla tasted extremely fresh, as did the green chile. The boyf once again chose the better dish, the Enchiladas Placeras. The enchilada had the tastiest half chicken on the side! Yes, I know it's just chicken but we both agreed it was some of the best chicken we've had in the city (up there with Zuni Cafe!) but the rest of the dish was bland. Besides Tecate in a can and Negra Modela, there were no Mexican beers. Corona? Pacifico? No señor.

I like the Nopa guys, and I sure love this location, but I prefer the food and variety at nearby Green Chile Kitchen.
author: Nicole L.

description: The food was really amazing. The only downside is your packed kind of close to your neighbor. I sat next to an extremely loud woman so it was hard to hear what my friend was saying at time. Other than that, I would, and I have recommended this restaurant to a friend.
author: Brittany N.

description:
My only reservation about giving 5 stars is that they don't take reservations, and the waitlist is kind of BS...
With that being said, their Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamari and Mole Manchamanteles con Pato (duck mole with sweet potatoes and apples) are amazing.
author: nick o.

description:
Good Margaritas.
Not bad food.
Great service.
author: Rupert D.

description:
I had lunch here last weekend.  The atmosphere was great and the food was tasty.  The meal options are very creative and fresh.  There is honestly something for everyone, veggie, meat-lovers, sauce and spice connoisseurs, and so on.  The service was a little on the slow side, which was tolerable because the atmosphere of the restaurant is so nice. Light airy, and set up for good people watching around the panhandle. And when our waiter did arrive he was very friendly and helpful and the food came in normal wait time after we ordered. 

My true hope is that at some point they go for that full liquor license. If they do that it will be interesting to see what kind of creative tequila cocktails they can make to compliment their dishes.
author: Kristin S.

description: Holy crap, I love this place. I've only been here once, but I already absolutely adore it. The decor is very cute and very green. Service is excellent. But my most favorite thing is the homemade salsa chips. Such an amazing burst of flavor. The taste is still stuck in my mouth. I want more! The tamale and the chorizo torta are also very tasty. I can't wait to come back.
author: April D.

description: A quesadilla with Brussels sprouts? Yes please. Carnitas? Why not... especially since they're by far the best I've ever tried. (Sorry, Southern California.) Fresh ingredients, friendly staff, great atmosphere. I went here with a friend and we had a delicious meal -- with awesome cocktails -- and the bill was only $25 per person. The call-ahead-to-get-on-the-list policy is extremely helpful, though if you're there around 6 on a weeknight you shouldn't have a problem. (8pm? Prepare for crowds -- though it's absolutely worth the wait.)
author: Ann H.

description:
Left hungry after spending $20 a person for a few morsels of Mex food at lunch.  

The food, such as there is of it, is workman-like. The $3.25 they charge for a glass of ice augmented with watered-down orange juice is a crime. 

This could have been a great addition to the neighborhood. But you can get more and better burritos for half the price at several other nearby spots.  You won't leave hungry at the other places, either. 

See: http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-little-chihuahua-san-francisco.

If truth in branding were enforced, Nopalito would change its name to Rip-Off-Alito.
author: Alan M.

description:
After 4 visits to Nopalito, I think I am ready to write my review.

The food is hit or miss. That being said the hits are AMAZING and the misses are very disappointing. Especially when served right after a hit.

The Totopos con Chile are amazing, and for $5 are a great munchie to start out with. However, similar to what Trinity M. stated, the price and portion are incredibly inconsistent, and its hard to tell from the price of an item what the size will be.

The tongue tostada was really interesting and huge, but the quesadilla was twice the price and half the size.

The gordita fell short and the exterior shell was so tough we left the entire thing there looking sad on the plate. The tostada had a similar toughness that is not palatable to me, especially when my knife cannot cut through it.

However, the taquitos we had last night we wonderful and crispy and packed a punch in the flavor department.

The clear chicken soup was great on a cold night, but was a bit bland and the chickpeas in it were not cooked through.

Everything on the menu is worth at least a shot, and if you go 4 times as I have, but the 5th time I think you will figure out what to order and what to skip.

I'll be back for sure because I still think its some of the most interesting Mexican food I've had in a while.
author: Abby Z.

description:
I agree that you just can't get it better than cheapies in the Mission. I came here when my old roommate was in town from NYC. She made a reservation for 7. It was cute inside with nice decor though it's weird that you have to walk outside next door to get to the bathroom. It's easy to get by MUNI from downtown too.

I honestly can't remember what I ordered, but the place is good for socializing and having a good time.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I was very excited to see a new Mexican place open up in this area.  The idea of locally grown, sustainable food was interesting as well.  We arrived here for a late lunch on a Saturday and were lucky enough to get a seat.  They have a heated indoor patio but we sat in the actual restaurant.  The theme is brown and green (surprise, surprise) and it's an open, welcoming space.

The menu is very small but with good selections.  However, if you're looking for recognizable "Mexican" food, don't come here.  They claim they serve traditional Mexican food which may be the case, but I only recognized carnitas and a few other items on the menu.

The food we had was good although some of the portions were small. I ordered the horchata which didn't really taste like horchata for me   The service was good and efficient and it was interesting to try some new dishes.  However, I don't know if I'll go back soon as I wasn't too enthralled with the menu.  But definitely worth checking out!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I love Nopalito! I think it is one of the best value's for delicious food in the city, and extra bonus as I love all Mexican food.

Went with a couple of friends to continue my quest to try all 100 things on the 7x7 list: http://www.7x7.com/2010-big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

On the list is the Carnitas...they are quite tasty, but I have to say not even close to my favorite thing on their menu. Maybe I'm missing something but my friends also agreed....so try before you die? Yes try Nopalito before you die...but the Carnitas...not at the top of my list.
author: Wendy W.

description:
Having spent the last 10 months living in Mexico, I was a bit skeptical about all the rave reviews about Nopalito. I was worried the food would be just another instance of pseudo-Mexican cuisine paired with a steep US price tag. I was, happily, quite wrong. Nopalito was truly a wonderful dining adventure. 

So here's what we ordered and my thoughts on each dish:
Hibiscus-valencia orange drink - Delicious, tart, fresh...don't order if you only sort of like the flavor of hibiscus. 
Michelada - My bf ordered this one and said it was a little underwhelming and could have used some more spice...
Totopos con chile (tortilla chips with salsa, cream and lime) - We ordered these because many of the previous reviews mentioned how great the chips were. No, no, no. I mean the totopos weren't bad but I would have rather tried dishes that stood apart from the average chips and salsa spread...my 3 dining companions agreed...
Panucho de Pollo al Pibil - One of the best plates of the night. Basically it was a corn tortilla stuffed with black beans and topped with shredded chicken and salsa.  The chicken was super moist and seemed to have some kind of citrus sauce on it.
Ceviche verde - Hands down the ceviche made the meal. Bits of halibut and calamari were marinated with lime, cilantro, tomatillo and avocado. It was tart and tangy but not painfully acidic. I've eaten many a plate of ceviche in Mexico, Peru etc. but still think that Nopalito's version may be the best I have ever tried. Yum.
Mole poblano con pollo - Good but not nearly spicy enough. Maybe time for the chefs to take a trip to Oaxaca to pick up some more spices? I would have also liked a bit more chocolate in the sauce. And I am not a fan of dark meat so how about serving the plate with a chicken breast instead of a leg?
Pozole rojo - Delicious version of one of the hardest Mexican dishes to make. The broth was not too oily and quite fresh. I am not a real fan of pork but it worked with this dish and was tender and flavorful. 
Cantaloupe popsicle - Fresh cantaloupe frozen on a stick. Need I say more? My bf ordered a Cafe con Leche popsicle - quite rich and creamy but yes, just like a nice cup of coffee with milk. The third option was chocolate with chili...

Ah and like others mentioned, you cannot make a reservation for Nopalito. You can however, as my friend learned, call about an hour before getting there and put your name on the wait list. Not a bad idea...
author: Erin W.

description:
Came here for date night with the hubs.  I'm trying to check everything off 7x7 Magazine's "100 Things to Eat/Drink in SF Before you Die" list and Nopalito's carnitas were included.  The carnitas were absolutely fantastic.  Pork was fork tender, tortillas were warm and tasty, salsas were spicy and fresh.  We also tried the grapefruit salad and ceviche.  The ceviche's seafood was yummy fresh but a little too acidic for my liking.

We'll definitely try this place again.  Bonus: parking lot attached.
author: Christina K.

description:
Yes, I know, it already has 322...323...324 reviews... and counting. But, I definitely had to write a short love poem from my recent trip to Nopalito.

Roses are red,
Violets are blue,
Nopalito is the sh*t,
This much is true.

Get the salsa flavored chips and enchiladas with chicken! I wish it had dessert other than the popsicles though!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Nopalito, run by the successful Nopa team, has failed to hit the mark. 

Drinks:  Most of us ordered the Michelada ($4.50), a refreshing beer concoction mixed with tomato, chili de arbol, a healthy rim of salt, and a lime. The waiter praised us for our risk taking, which surprised me, in that the drink, a cerveza preparada, or prepared beer, is a common Mexican beverage (that they actually got right). Even the major American beer companies jumped on the bandwagon with the (I think grossly failed) Miler Chill and Budweiser Chelada. 

When we finally got a seat, outside on the patio, well over an hour later, we were given their toasted chickpeas, which are on the house, a wonderful amuse bouche which provide delicious crunch and flavor. If anything, these are one of the best things that they do here, and I could eat them all day long.

After handing us the menus, and most strongly recommending the Carnitas ($14), the waiter headed back to the kitchen as we made up a game plan to try as many dishes as we could. When he came back to us, he profusely apologized but they had run out of carnitas, their signature dish!

We started out with appetizers, tasting the Totopos con Chile ($4), their home made tortilla chips, chili de arbol, cotija, with some sour cream, which were slightly oily, but made better by a healthy squeezing of lime. The Tamal de Frijoles ($4) arrived looking like a dessert, wrapped in a corn husk, made with homemade masa, and a squeeze of sauce and a grate of queso fresco. It was good, but somehow lacking in any sort of punch. The Ceviche ($9.50) was not a success, the small dish of rock cod was served in a delicious lime sauce that had completely failed to infuse in the fish (a sure sign that the fish had not been allowed to marinate for the hours that a traditional ceviche is given). The result was a slightly tasteless and overpriced dish, completely overshadowed in taste by the oily chips it was served with.

The two appetizer success stories however were the Ensalada de Repollo ($5), a lovely cabbage salad with carrots, pretty watermelon radishes and oregano, in a nice acidic dressing, and the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron ($9), served like a crepe, with a red pancake like corn tortilla, filled with crispy pork belly, which was delicious.

After a less than successful round of appetizers, we had higher hopes with the main courses. We started out with the Birria de Chivo ($13), goat stewed in a nice sauce of dried chilies, roasted tomatoes and spices, served with corn tortillas, and pinquinto beans and salsa de arbol on the side. We were instructed that this dish was one of the do it yourself assembly dishes, and so we poured everything into the pot and went at it. It wasn't a bad start, although I'd probably not order it again.

After a few minutes of waiting, we received our next dish, the Enchiladas Placeras ($13), a breast and drumstick of pan seared ancho chicken breast, which arrived with two tortillas that had a very small amount of potatoes, and carrots inside. The dish did however come with a pickled pepper which was delicious. Another put it together dish, the chicken was absolutely delicious and beautifully cooked, but like an all star pitcher playing on a team of seventh grade boys, had very little backup.

We were still hungry, and our last dish seemed to be taking some time in the kitchen, so we ordered a trio of Gorditas de Picadillo ($4.50 each) to tide us over. The gorditas, little  tortilla pockets were filled with ground beef, carrot and salsa, and while the meat was nicely seasoned, the bland and oily tortilla, and lackluster sauces failed to fulfill us. 

Finally, our Barbacoa de Borrego ($14) showed up, steamed adobo lamb tied up in a package made of banana leaves, with a bowl of consomme with a few chickpeas in it, and a side of salsa borracha. We were instructed that we could just put everything in the soup bowl, although after tasting the consomme and the sauce, I had my doubts about the flavor compatibility. Nevertheless, we combined everything and doled it out in another round of the small corn tortillas. It just didn't do it for us. The lamb was cooked well, but the flavors seemed mismatched, and worse, bland. 

By the end of the meal we were all still slightly hungry, and although they served complimentary cinnamon cookie bites at the end, a few well chosen desserts might be a useful addition to the menu. 

To be honest, two of our party went out after the meal to get drinks and burritos in the mission, and we went home and microwaved a bowl of swedish meatballs. For a Nopa sibling, Nopalito just doesn't seem to get it. Mexican food is about big flavors, heaping portons, and a lot of love. Americanized Mexican is fine in my book, but Nopalito has a long way to go even at that. Let's hope that they can work on these dishes before it tarnishes the wonderful work they are doing at Nopa.
author: Samantha T.

description:
I left this place with a taste of oddity. Not great, not bad - what was NOT there? 
The place is small, but clean. Servers are friendly, but a bit off. 
The menu small, and not described well. Dishes are arranged with appetizers on the left, entrees on the right. The reason I knew this was the prices of things. There was no telling what any given dish came with as a side, which is fine if you're not in a ravenous mood. 

Our radish salad, we were told was big enough to share. It isn't. With fresh, bland cheese, chili powder, radishes and mandarin, this salad was off in it's flavors and textures. 

The fried chickpeas are just what I love, crunchy, flavorful and fried. Yum. 

Ceviche was also a good choice, comes with homemade tortilla chips - I'll let you know since the menu doesn't. Ha. I broke their spell. The seafood was tasty in it's lime broth and I was happy with the avocado topper that made it a Green Goddess of a Grouping. 

No hot beverages, so don't ask for coffee or tea if you don't want to be rejected. Some of us are fragile, and to you my sensitive sallys, I beg - do not order anything that would promote steam. 

Let me mention the cutlery. It was nice, with a heavy feel. Remember this Kids, for later in the reivew.

The service was good, but a little funky. Like the chickpeas were brought after our "share-able" salad and the topper for me; the waitress was expertly stacking all our wares when I felt a silver bump on my head. She had dropped my fork on me - and kept going like the Champ she is. I know she didn't realize it, but did I need to leave with a concussion AND a confused stomach?? 

I won't be back, flavorings need a bit of help and the feel just isn't there. When you're in the city, with some of the World's best fare at your fingertips, who has time for taste tossups?
author: Katie W.

description:
Cute place, really tasty Mexican food.  Friday night wait was 1.5 hours for 2 people.  We grabbed a drink around the corner, came back and still had to wait.  

*Almond Horchata
*Mole

Both delicious, just the right amount of food.  I wished the mole came with a side of rice.  The tortillas didn't exactly go with the mole dish.

Great vibe, just in between neighborhoods.  We walked there on a rainy night and it was worth the walk.  It's hard to find mid level Mexican food, not too high end, and not a dive.  Recommended local date place.  A good number of couples.
author: Tina C.

description: Great sister restaurant, farm to table original Mexican food. Highly recommend it.
author: Mattin N.

description:
Gentrification at it's finest.

Today is my last day living in the neighborhood and I have to say, with places like Nopalito springing up, I'm happy to say goodbye. It's not so much them, but the crowds they draw. Last night as I walked by I thought I was in the Marina.

Maybe I'm bitter, or maybe I'm just protective over a neighborhood that I've loved and lived in for a very long time. Sure Divis is thriving with new businesses and as a small business owner myself it is a wonderful thing. But Nopalito is different from Little Chihahua, Green Chile or Little Star, because of it's price point it caters to a totally different group of people. Now is that good? or bad? Well, I don't know, but I can tell you one thing, when I walk by and see the people eating their $40 tortillas..... it makes me sad.
author: K B.

description:
This place is casual and hip. Not your typical Mexican place but I feel it is the best right now in the SF Bay Area. TIP* Call on your drive there to put your name on the list, they do not take reservations, and it gets packed most nights. Some things to try are the Fish Tacos, Empanadas, Mole, and the house made "Popsicles" most days there are 3 flavors and always amazing. 

For those of us with kiddies, try going for lunch or early (4-5pm) for dinner, they have a little pencil kit and coloring pages for them to keep busy.
author: Meg K.

description:
i held off on trying this place as i figured anything this popular this fast is more about trend than substance. boy was i wrong. OK, listen, i am Mexican. i love Mexican food. no body can make it like my mom. I love the things most white people will not try. is this authentic Mexican. yes and no. authentic ingredients with modern twists. they have taken Mexican staples and without getting too fancy introduced them to the gen public.
