great great great job. yeah i hate the wait, so i try to go during off peak times but it just, just may be worth it anyway.
author: Jorge E.

description:
I wish I could give 3 1/2 stars because I think that would be more accurate than 3, but I'm not ready to give 4. 

First, I'll mention the positives. You can call ahead to have your name put on this list, which is great because there always seems to be a wait. There's parking in the Falletti's garage. They have an outdoor seating area which is, for the most part, enclosed. The decor is clean & cute. The flavor of everything I tried was great!

Now the negatives. The parking situation is a bad thing for Falletti's as I've already had a difficult time parking to do my shopping on multiple occasions. The portions are SMALL!!!!! I went for lunch and paid $11 for enchiladas mole. All that was on the plate was 2 tiny enchiladas. They tasted great, but for 11 bucks can I have some beans or rice too? The prices range from $4 to $16, so a normal size meal would be $20 or more (tapas - order 2-3 plates per person). My server was really nice, but not that great. What I ordered as an appetizer was forgotten and came out well after I finished eating. 

So, I will give it a couple more shots and hopefully change my rating to 4 stars at some point. I definitely like it better than Nopa and think even though the portions are small they have significantly more flavor. I always love to see new places opening in the neighborhood and hope that Nopalito will be a solid, great addition.
author: Kandace K.

description: I always have an awesome meal here. The carnitas and carne asada rock. I really enjoy the white sangria as well. Weekends can be an hour wait and a little loud. Weekdays are great.
author: Doug K.

description: This was our first experience at Nopalito and we will definitely be back for more.  It seems like the wait can get pretty crazy at this place, but the nice thing is that they let us call ahead to get our name on the wait list so scored some points there.  I had a margarita which was pretty good... not the best I've had, but I would order it again.  The Totopos con chile were awesome!  We also had the carnitas which were melt in your mouth good and the chicken mole.  We were STUFFED by the end of our meal!
author: Jen F.

description:
I ate at Nopalito a couple of days ago and was blown away by their fresh and extremely tasty food. I had the cerviche and a helping of their chips and salsa. The cerviche was tasty and light. As I understand from our server, the restaurant makes as much of the food from seasonal, local ingredients; therefore, their menus reflects it....

Plus points: great drinks...my friend had a Michelada--while this is not normally thing--it was tasty and not salty...with an emphasis on the fresh tomato juice. I had a Finnish beer, and while I found out they would no longer be carrying, the served assured me they would carry local beers, which are also great.
author: Ericha F.

description:
We came here on the recommendation of a friend. It was a busy Friday night and we were told the wait would be about 30-45 minutes. Standard fare. We went to the bar and I ordered a margarita. Blech. My boyfriend ordered an iced tea, which came with an agave nectar in a bottle, but not just any bottle. It looked like what I imagine miracle hair-growing tonic was bottled in in the late 19th century. Besides the bottle being eye-roll inducingly contrived,  isn't agave syrup not really good for you? More fructose than high-fructose corn syrup... uhh... I'd rather have some real sugar.  But I digress.

Twenty minutes later and a table opened up. Score. At this point I'm two Winter Red Wine Sangrias in and feeling pretty good, the hair tonic bottle and the shitty margarita becoming fuzzier and fuzzier memories. Looking at the menu, everything looks so good. I finally settled on the Carne Asada y Cebollines a la Plancha. Boyfriend got the same. The food arrives and it's plated beautifully, but right away I know this isn't going to be enough. "Oh," I think to myself. "This is one of those places." I should have figured that out by looking around at the other tables, but my attention was elsewhere. I'm no stick, but I'm not about to have my own Discovery Health channel special either, so if these portions weren't enough for me, it probably wouldn't be enough for most people. The black beans were SO TASTY, but they were just a pretty, tiny plop on the plate. I thought about reaching over and stealing my boyfriend's beans, but by the time I conjured up that ingenious plan, they were gone. You snooze, you lose indeed. The carne asada was cooked perfectly--maybe too rare for those who prefer their meat well done, but I enjoyed it. For dessert I went with the cafe con leche popsicle, which arrived unassumingly enough but when ingested, quickly brought back memories of a five-year-old me stealing my mom's coffee when she wasn't looking. Like another reviewer said, there's no ladylike way to eat these delicious frozen confections, so just go balls out. Who cares if you look like you're ten cents a dance? I ain't gonna judge. 

So why only two stars? Because it's bougiefied Mexican food and that burns me to my core, like a tiny flame of inexplicable resentment. Two stars for the very nice waitstaff and the Roger Sterling look-alike seated next to us. Dayum.
author: Lilia M.

description:
Lunch at Nopalito.  Really good.  Really, really good.  And free parking nearby.  Hard to beat combination.  

Outstanding tortilla chips to whet the appetite. Then seared ling cod with rice over an outstanding chile sauce.  For ten bucks it would be hard to beat this plate of food.  

Great food. Great price. Great service.
author: David D.

description:
I really liked how they did the waitlist. You call and put your name on the list and you get a text message confirmation. Once you get there in person- check in so they know you are there. Once the table is ready, you get another text.

On Sunday at 7 pm - I called when I left my house and when I got there at 7:15 the table was ready. 

The horchata was super yummy and cinnamon-y. I didnt get the type around the totopos con chile, but I did like the fish taco (I added the sour cream from the totopos) and the chicken tostada thing. Nothing was blow you away great or I need to come back great - but it was all good, not horribly expensive, and a fun vibe.
author: Nors P.

description:
I am not giving Nopalito five stars because their food is sustainable. I am not giving Nopalito five stars because their food is organic. I am not giving Nopalito five stars because their food is local. I mean, all that stuff is great, it really is, but the bottom line is that Nopalito served me the best piece of chicken I have ever eaten in my entire life. 

I finally had the chance to eat here after an arduous flight home from colorado seated next to chatty kathy in a non reclining seat. Tired and grumpy and too late to cook, the MBGITW and I decided to eat out (yeah, big stretch for us...) Nopalito is situated in what used to be the checkout area of Falletti grocer. Don't let the appearance of a lunch time snack bar fool you, this is legit....LEGIT people. 

A couple of blue star wheats and a tamale kicked of dinner. I had the privilege of trying the Carne Asada the first night it was added to the menu. A perfectly cooked tasty skirt steak draped with a couple of charred cebollas. My lovely dinner companion ordered the enchiladas. Instead of stuffing them with the chicken, they just give you the worlds greatest piece of roast chicken to let you know the chef is rad and can kick your tasetbud's ass. In fact, I think that is the same reason they dress the plate with a roast chili that is actually fXXking hot! 

Next time i'd like to sit out in the patio area. The interior felt a little bright for dinner, but you quickly forget about that kind of stuff when you get your plate.
author: Zac H.

description:
Let's start with the food. ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! HOLY CRAP IT WAS YUMMY.
Now that I've gotten that out of the way: It was crammed there were a ton of people there on a Sunday night! (WHich means that obviously many people love it...). The waitress was kind of bitchy, she didn't really care about the customer as much as she did about herself. Not a fan.
ALSO, this made me so uncomfortable, you have to literally go outside of the restaurant to reach the bathroom. I mean, what the hell??? You charge so much money for your, granted amazing, food that you can't even make an effort to connect the bathroom to the dining room? Hm... That made me mad. OH WELL.
I will come back to get takeout at some point but dining in was not an experience worth repeating. 

Great food!
author: Antonia T.

description:
This is more like 3.5 stars. The blood orange drink was very disappointing, very watery and no blood orange. The goat was pretty good; and the homemade chips and tortillas were delicious. My friend also enjoyed the ceviche.

Hot servers.
author: Mark A.

description:
Food 4 stars.

Service, no stars.

7pm Saturday night, friends in from out of town, decide to take them to Nopalito since it's delicious and close enough to my house.  I call in to put our names on the list and am told 60-80 minutes.  50 minutes later (now 7:50) I call back to check on the status and am told that it would be another 20-40 minutes, putting us sometime between 8:15 and 8:30.  We left the house a little later and arrived at about 8:10, and again were told about 20-30 minutes, but that the bar was full and so we would have to wait outside.  In the rain.  We strolled around Falletti's for a while to grab some dessert for later (sorry Nopalito, you lost out on that purchase), and checked back in at 8:30.  Still no table, and several groups in front of us.  15 minutes later, my friend decides to ask if we can now move into the bar.  We were given permission to get a drink, so wander in, and wait 10 minutes before someone asks if we need something.  We ordered a pitcher of margaritas and some chips and salsa.  The margaritas came about 5 minutes later.  But no chips.  Another 5ish minutes pass and we watch as someone delivers our chips to two other groups (each time removing them) before finally realizing that they were meant for us.  We got them, they were delicious.  At that point, frozen pizza would have been.  Finally, around 9:10, the table that was supposed to be ours opened up, and then sat there.  And then got cleared, and set.  And then sat some more.  Starting to get a little tipsy, I decided to go check with the outdoor hostess, who saw me, realized what I wanted and told me that I could have the table.

We sat, we decided what we wanted in 2 minutes.  The waiter came.  He was quite friendly and offered water. 2 of us ordered bubbly, 1 flat.  No problem he said.  We got 2 dishes of food.  No water.  Finally we asked someone else.  The first waiter returned, all flat water.  Fine, whatever.  20 minutes later, and halfway through the meal, he comes by with a carafe of bubbly.  Ooops....

Meal continues, food is awesome.  We're done, he offered to box up our considerable leftovers.  Check comes.  No leftovers.  We pay.  No leftovers.  We wait.  No leftovers.  We decide it's not worth it to find him, and try to get our stolen food.  We leave without the leftovers.  Sad.

Will I return, maybe for takeout.  Will I continue to rave about this place to friends of visitors, probably not.
author: Julia S.

description:
We hadn't been out in ages, so it was really a pleasant surprise to get to go here with our "city friends". We were seated relatively quickly for a Saturday night (40 minute wait) with no reservation. In a city full of "foodies", that's pretty good I guess. 

Great service, really nice people, but most importantly, the food tasted fresh and hot. Can't complain about that. My initial response is "homestyle noveau Mexican food", sort of like a hip Mexico City restaurant. Lo and behold, that's exactly how it is described in reviews and its own website. Kudos for not falsely advertising and knowing its niche. It was really good and a great night out. I wanna go back and try those carnitas....The enchiladas were awesome.
author: Dyuti S.

description: Great service, all the servers were very prompt and super friendly. The ceviche and shrimp machaca were incredibly delicious, and ensured that I'm going to recommend this place to friends and come back in the future.
author: Matt D.

description:
My first impression was that this would be another new, overpriced, trendy restaurant based on its location and decor.  Being attached to an all natural grocery didn't help, but....

The food was quite good even if a bit on the pricey side.  One thing that I really liked is that this is not another "beans and rice" restaurant.  The portions are smaller (thank god) and what they put on the plate really matters.

If you plan on drinking here, bring extra $$.  Margaritas are good, but pricey.  The staff is exactly as described below: random.  We were seated by one person, drink order to another, food order to yet another, served by another, and our check delivered by, yes, another.  Who the hell do we tip?
author: Brian P.

description:
Love love love love it. So good

The ceviche with scallops, shrimp and calamari, the chips with salsa already soaked onto them, the pezole rojo...oh my god. Dont forget the strawberry sangria.
author: Sara A.

description: Delicious modern Mexican food with an authentic flavor. Expect a wait, great drinks!!!
author: Daniel G.

description:
Nopalito is one of those restaurants that makes me proud to live in San Francisco.  

It's affordable.  Friendly and responsive service. Sustainable and responsible.  And if that wasn't enough-- it is very inexpensive.

The wait for dinner can be over an hour.  The two times I have been there (successfully) was for a mid afternoon, mid week late lunch.  No wait at all.

I need more Nopalito in my life.
author: Scott H.

description:
Nopalito conjured so many images in my mind before I got there.  Reading reviews, seeing photos, and hearing stories I couldn't wait to get started.  I wanted a more thoughtful Mexican food restaurant and Nopalito delivers on several fronts.  First a respectful approach is completed on a larger than expected menu.  Tacos are not a common thing here which in the many Mexican cuisines is nearly impossible to leave out.  But Nopalito has a wonderful splay of dishes that make up for a lack of tacos.  

I ordered the Picadillo Gordita which Picadilo is a rare thing here in San Francisco; the Gordita part was expertly prepared; the Picadillo was good not great--the potatoes were cut a bit too large and needed be a bit softer to marinate with the sauce.  The Mole Enchiladas had a the second best Mole sauce in San Francisco--the best is at Casa Melendez.  The sauce was superbly chocolate-sweet with a bit of spice though I could go for more spice and heat in the Mole. 

The plates were nicely assembled and I had the fortunate to see the plates being made.  Each plate is made with the utmost professionalism and it was nice to see the tortillas being made.   There was an element to the plates that could go for a slight enhancement.  The minimalism was nice but a bit too stark. 

The service was gracious and checked in at the right moments.  The beer and wine list was diverse and eclectic.  

I would enjoy a return trip.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Came here with some friends the other day.  I ordered the Birria (goat stew), which had just a taste of chocolate in it.  I also tried their carnitas, which the waitress highly recommended (saying it's the best in the city).

I would have to strongly disagree on the carnitas that I had.  It was tough and chewy, which is not how good carnitas are supposed to taste.  Not having cooked it myself, I don't know if it was under-cooked, over-cooked, under-brined or whatever, but it wasn't the best in the city.  Had better at Chilango.

That being said, their birria was out of this world.  It was seasoned perfectly, and the goat was perfectly cooked.

I will definitely be back
author: Jay W.

description:
what a treat!

we tried their famous chips, carnitas, ceviche and pork belly enchilada. the service was great.

the only thing was that the ceviche which came with calamari was a bit questionable. I think they should have gone with fish instead of calamari, not that i'm not a fan of calamari, i just found it a little bit odd, also the sause was a bit too citric for my taste.

but overall, it was a great experience!
author: Sung C.

description:
To be fair, little Nopa has some BIG shoes to fill - I went into this dinner with high expectations. Its namesake, in my opinion, is one of the best restaurants in San Francisco, and while I wasn't looking for a duplicate experience, I had hoped that the quality of Nopalito's Mexican fare would match Nopa's New American. 

We called ahead to claim a spot on the waiting list - the predicted hour-long wait ended up being closer to two, which is not a huge deal except that the host was a total tease (just one moment...almost there...a little longer...). The patio would not be a bad spot to wait on a warm night, but it was cold so we hovered near the space heaters at the entrance. The host took drink orders, though, so I suppose that's one way to stay warm. 

The seating is limited, so if you're a party of two odds are you'll be seated at a communal table. Our waitress was pleasant, if somewhat forgetful - we had to ask for water and the complimentary fried chickpeas. 

The appetizers were a major disappointment. First off, the fish taco (singular) was severely lacking in flavor, which is a serious crime against fish tacos specifically and Mexican cuisine in general. The rustic corn tortilla was great, but it was all I could taste - the skimpy piece of fish needed some spice, and the whole thing was begging to be slathered with salsa, guac, something! The ceviche was likewise underwhelming ...fine, but not what you'd expect from Nopa's progeny. 

The entrees were an improvement. My lamb was tender, the sauce was delish, and it came with more corn tacos - plus I love the DIY approach to eating. The only component that didn't work was the bowl of broth with a few chickpeas floating in it - not interesting enough to eat on its own, and it didn't contribute anything to the lamb tacos except to make them soggy. My friend's chicken with mole sauce and rice looked good, but didn't elicit the mmms and oh my gods that a dinner at Nopa invariably does. 

One last complaint and then I'll shut up - the glasses (or more accurately, mini ceramic cups) in which the wine is served are tiny!! As someone who loves a boozey dinner, I don't want to have to down ten cups of wine to get a buzz.  

The cinnamon Mexican cookies were a lovely way to end the meal, but I wish there had been more of them. Overall, underwhelming, but Nopalito is just a baby...let's hope greatness is in its genes.
author: A M.

description:
It's one thing to wait 40 minutes for a table and then have a good meal.  It's another thing altogether to wait that long and then get served mediocre food.  And yet that's exactly what happened.  

The carnitas had little flavor and were very greasy -- like oily pot roast.  The "sangria" may be made in house, but that's all that can be said about it.  It tasted like tap water with red food coloring in it.  It's hard to maka sangria have no flavor, even when using cheap wine, but somehow Nopolito did it.  It's equally hard to make bad carnitas -- pork butt fried in its own fat is usually flavor heaven.  But not at Nopalito.  They bake oily pot roast without any seasoning and call it "carnitas."   Hint to the chefs:  add some salt to your pork, ditch the paper bag gimmick, get some lard, and fry up some real carnitas.  

The one thing that was actually good was the roasted corn salad.  Everything else -- from the tostada to the tamal -- was mediocre at best (and that's being generous).  i don't think we'll be back.  Why bother when there's so much better Mexican around?
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I have walked by this place maybe 50 or 60 times now....its in my hood
went there the other day after work with some coworkers to get a bite to eat for lunchish

so the entrance was a bit odd and uninviting but i can live with that
the food that i had was very good
they had beer that wasn't a million dollars that was nice 
(i am a huge fan of cheap beers) 

why the three.....i am hung over and feel like being harsher then normal
author: Trent D.

description:
Definitely not worth the hype. 
-Ceviche: meh. chewy fish with thick stale chips.
-Soup of crab: really spicy, no flavor.
-Carnitas: pretty good, earned the two stars.  
-Chicken Mole: tasted like boiled chicken. 
-Carne Asada: average. Had way better for a third of the cost.

In sum: Overpriced-paid over 100 bucks for 4 people, wouldn't call it traditional Mexican food, rather bland and lack luster.
author: Lucy N.

description: DELICIOUS food - sharing table could be distracting. Other than that great value for quality and portions:) Warning - we did come on weekday after lunch crowd - consider this option if possible.
author: JP G.

description:
We have been here five times with different groups of friends, and with each visit we appreciate the complexity of the flavors and textures more. We have been devotees of Dona Tomas in Oakland's Temescal neighborhood for several years, but now that Nopalito is open we haven't needed to travel across the bridge for an authentic Mexican food fix. 

When you are seated, the totopos con chile are are great way to start while buying time to ponder the menu -- tortilla chips, salsa de arbol, cotija cheese, crema and lime. And if they have the strawberry sangria, grab an order before it's all gone. 

We usually order a mix of appetizers and entrees, and then share with friends. The adobo fish taco with orange, tomatillo, and ancho is a slice of heaven -- it's an upscale Veracruz style with an outstanding balance of citrus and heat that doesn't overpower the sturgeon. The pork tamal with mole verde is also outstanding -- housemade masa, stewed pork, poblano peppers, jalapeños,  tomatillos, cilantro, epazote, sesame seeds and peanuts.

Other standouts include the squash blossom quesadilla and the radish/citrus salad. I'm quite fond of the pozole, and if you want to share the waitstaff will bring extra bowls, limes, and a ladle. The boyfriend adores the chicken mole poblano, and I admit it is lovely -- they make their mole from scratch and it tastes wonderful (most Mexican places use a pre-mixed mole paste as their base -- you can buy it in any shop in the Mission). And everyone loves the carnitas.

NOTE: if the only Mexican food you know and like is the Mission-style burritos or rice-and-bean plates on cafeteria plastic, don't bother with Nopalito. This is authentic Mexican, based primarily on Oaxacan regional style with other regional touches showing up as well. I recognize the complex flavors and high quality ingredients from my childhood in central Mexico. Nopalito is the real deal!
author: Modern D.

description:
I'm absolutely obsessed with this place.  I love the casual atmosphere (no reservations), semi-outdoor seating, the food, and the staff.  

A friend took me here on day 1 of a 5 day trip and I ended up eating here 4 more times.  

Definitely start with totopos - how do they get their tortilla chips so crunchy and yummy???  I love their juices, iced tea, carnitas (definitely has to be shared by 2/3 people), and some other dishes that I can't remember the names of - the only dish that I didn't love was the mole but I'm not a huge mole fan normally.

This is a must try!
author: Christina S.

description:
Hmmm, Where do I start?!  It's been a while since I've felt like writing a review.  For the past few weeks, I kept seeing Nopalito everytime I nabbed an item or two from Falleti's.   I would ask the cashier, "hey, have you tried Nopalito next door?"  Expecting, an of course I have, I work next door.  But each time, with different cashier's the answer was no.

So on my day off last Friday, I decided it's time to give it a try.  Sat in their covered patio, the seating was just ok, not super comfy, but nice.  I was given the option of Still, Mineral, Still-at-Room-temp water, just to start me off.  I decided to take a chance, water with ice!

Next the menu... Now, I'm a fairly educated, world traveled guy, so I'm reading this menu and I'm needing to whip out my electro-addicted gadget to find out what they mean.  My waitress comes to the rescue though... I ask, "what do you recommend, anything exceptional i should try?"  She responds, "everything is great, but I can make a recommendation if you want!"    Hmmm!

So, I'm going to stop here and not tell you the rest of the story. Instead, I would say try Nopalito with an open mind for creatively designed cuisine of possible south of the border.  However, if you're like me, and LOVE Mexican food, Love your burrito, Quesadilla, tamales, and Tacos...you'll probably be wondering why you didn't stick to your favs (and SO many in SF)...

My main dissapointment was that at about $15, I had a very dry yet oily quesadilla and left feeling not so nopa!
author: Mark K.

description:
*EXPERIENCE* = My family and I were coming off an energy high because my younger sister just finished her promotion for her third degree black belt... so this place couldn't go wrong for lunch, right?  4/5 of us didn't want spicy so we had to tread carefully.  I could tell my family was hoping for easy to recognize choices; but in the end, we had a really good experience.  Plus, they use local, organic ingredients :)

SERVICE = Thankfully, our waiter was a big help and he was nice answering all of our questions.

FOOD = Not your typical Mexican restaurant--or, I should say, Not your typical Americanized Mexican restaurant.. which I'm totally fine with, but I could tell it threw off my family hahaha...
My mom and I shared:  Carnitas ($15.00) - Long braised pork, orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer Cabbage salad, pickled jalapeños, salsa de tomatillo... AWESOME!  This was well worth the price because we were able to request more tortillas to make even more servings with the pork we had. 
My fiance chose:  Torta de Chorizo Verde ($8.00) - Sandwich of green chorizo, crema, cabbage, onions, queso fresco and guacamole on a housemade bun... He liked that it had a spicy kick to it

BEST PART:  our waiter offered us these "popsicle" style ice cream creations that I didn't see on the menu.. one was chocolate and the other was a coffee flavor.  I had the chocolate and I couldn't get enough.  I wish they came free because I would've asked for more!

PAYMENT/PRICING = Lunch menu seemed priced fairly.  Some items seemed a bit pricey.

PARKING = Street parking and I think I saw a lot next door.
author: Doreen M.

description:
three of my favorite dishes in the world are served here.  this is some seriously delicious food.  highly recommended!  

i especially love bringing friends from out of town and it's quiet at lunch and they serve mezcal vida which i hear is awesome.

love nopalito!
author: Genevieve B.

description: Nopalito is gourmet Mexican.   The food is packed with Insanely fresh and unique flavors, and contains textures I've never experienced with tortillas let alone any kind of mexican food.   And the prices are shockingly low for this type of restaurant and environment.  A big thank you to the staff at  Nopalito for making another memorable meal! (I'll be back soon).
author: John T.

description: Puzzled by mixed reviews here. Lovely place, great addition to the neighborhood, very cute, nice people. Carry out window super easy! Parking no problem. Excellent ingredients.
author: Joby P.

description:
As a local neighbor to this modernly hip, fresh take on Mexican food, I cannot hide the fact that I dine in there on an average rate of twice a week - which is often, given all of the other treasures that San Francisco has to offer its diners.  Each time I stop in and eat (or pick up), I'm treated with friendly service and get constant check-ins to make sure I have enough agua or totopos con chile.  Each of their entrees has a different flavor that's emphasized; thus, my palate never tires.  And little things, like spiced chickpeas and a free cookie at the end, gives your experience a nice touch.

Last but not least, the price is very reasonable (you can order a dinner for $5, but $10 will more appropriately satisfy your cravings), but this isn't really fast-food, Green Burrito territory - so it probably won't meet your requirement if you don't want to spend more than $3 for a dish.  These entrees are fluffed up with fresher ingredients and are a little more on the untraditional side in the Mexican genre; but obviously, someone who was craving the gritty, greasy flavor of a taco stand would have headed to the Mission - and if not, that's just poor common sense.

Yum!
author: Caitlin M.

description:
Nopalito is one of my go-to take out places in my neighborhood. I order take out from here at least once a week. They don't take reservations so be prepared to put in some time waiting for a seat. There is a Pete's coffee in the same parking lot so you can always get a tea while you put in the time. You can also put your name on the wait list by phone. 

Here are some of my favorite items:
-carnitas (OMG)
-quesadilla (changes seasonally)
-ceviche
-guacamole
-their salads are good but spicy
-margaritas are excellent
author: Katherine B.

description:
Sooooooo....first time here.....and took home about five or six different things on the menu.  Overall first impression is  pretty good...I'll be back...nice staff...good beers...better than meh grub....

...so...got later....got the munchies....I can truly say with every fiber of my being...

...that Nopalito's Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron is the best Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron that has ever been created since the history of time and like...forever.

PS. The Tostado too.  Gotta give props.
author: Chris D.

description: Food here was delicious (especially the complimentary garbanzo starter....i went home and googled the recipe).  however, there was nothing especially unique about the meal and it's hard to justify returning when there are so many amazing mexican places nearby at much more reasonable prices.
author: T Y.

description: If I were a meat-eater I am sure that the food would be very tasty. However, as I am a vegetarian there were not enough/not great vegetarian options on the menu.
author: Clementine C.

description:
I definitely don't get the hype.  The portions are tiny for what you pay, and the food isn't that special.  If you love Marin Organic Grass Fed Jersey Blue Carne Asada, then perhaps this is the place for you.  I really could care less how many snobby organic adjectives they can jam in front of Steak, it doesn't make it taste that much better.  Chesnut street would be a much more fitting locale for this place.

Getting a seat is a nightmare.  We called ahead, and it still took us TWO HOURS to get seated.  The bucket seats are also the most uncomfortable thing ever.

Save yourself a 2 hour wait, and a couple of bucks, and head over to Poc Chuc (or any of the mission taquerias) for truly authentic Mexican/Central American food.  I'll put my food faith in mexicans over skinny foodie hipster types any day of the week.
author: Spencer M.

description:
"meh." 

That pretty much says how I felt after having dinner at Nopalito. Living in the same building as Nopalito, I had high hopes and was very excited to have a new great restaurant to the neighborhood. I was highly disappointed instead. While the decor was beautiful and the staff, friendly, the food was mediocre. Had it been cheaper, maybe I would have been okay with it. The portions are small. Tapas small. The ceviche was a pool of shredded fish bits in lime sauce then smashed down by half of a sliced avocado on top. It was barely deep enough to dip the seven chips that came with it. The chips even were a bit greasy and heavy for my own liking too. The carnitas were grizzle-y but one of the more flavorful items. I think I'll still hit up Little Chihuahua for my neighborhood Mexican cravings next time.
author: Lindsay H.

description: I really enjoyed going to Nopalito, casual comfortable setting. We  ordered an App Totopos con Chlie with Guacamole to start with really good( Chips I hear are homemade but Damn they are hard to bite into!) Then the Carnitas came so lovely If your a fan of Pork gotta try this one!! So Happy they give you 2 corn tortillas which disappears so fast! Next Torta de Chilorio The sandwich was delicious it had a very tangy sauce and also yummy, highly recommend this place!!
author: Sera O.

description:
I have now eaten at this restaurant seven times in 2010.
Carbonated water for free, fantastic! Great selection of Agua frescas.
Highly recommend the totopos and ceviche. Main courses of Carnitas and Pozole are out of this world. The mole can also compete.
Sustainability. Ask them about it. They have something to say and they are running a pretty cool business model.

They also serve an assortment of Paletas ( ie popsicles ) for dessert. Great for hot days or to take home with the TAKE OUT you just ordered by phone.
author: Xia F.

description:
3.5 stars

I liked my meal at Nopalito a bunch.  The wait was just insane when we went on Tuesday for my birthday.  We were 6 folks and eventually squeezed at a smaller table after an hour +.  I'd hate to see the wait on the weekend.

The food was enjoyable but my favorite was the mixed citrus drink.  Refreshing and the best non alcoholic drink I have had in a long time. 

The chips with cheese were a good starter.  I wish the apps were designed for sharing, but I guess you can't have everything.

I believe they are a beer and wine only joint, but that was cool with us.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Add me to the list who doesn't get the hype about this place. I know good food and I know good Mexican food but this place while being decent is far far from "the best Mexican place in SF" as a recent SF Chronicle reviewer called it.

I went on a Friday with a group of seven. We had called ahead to get put on the waiting list. We order 12 dishes in all so I think we had a good chunk of menu and except for two meat dishes the general review was: meh. The portions were small for the price. The dishes while non-greasy and healthy tasting were bland and boring in flavour. The vegetarian dishes were judged to be flat out boring and bad. The two dishes we did like the most were the goat in mole and the pork shoulder. 

Would I go back here. Since the panhandle is not my neighborhood (and no I will not call it nopa) and since there are least a dozen mexican restuarants that are just as clean, attractive, affordable and have better tasting dishes I don't think we will ever go back.

I think if you are a Marina frat boy or girl who is afraid of going to the mission or even hayes valley this would be a great place for you to go for your mexican food desires.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: I simply love coming here. Whether its takeout or eat in, it's my favorite higher class mex. The vege quesadilla (changes with seasonal ingredients) is a highlight as is the carnitas. The tequila selection is small but well chosen. A solid choice for taking out of town visitors but go early.
author: Rachel H.

description: This is my favorite spot. It's consistently great. I've never had a bad meal. The waitstaff are helpful and know what they're doing. Order the carnitas!
author: Jennie B.

description:
Don't really get the hype about this place! My husband has been wanting to try it for awhile now. He was particularly excited about the tamales that he heard were good. We were disappointed that they only had one tamal on the menu to choose from. The food was okay but is overpriced and the portions aren't very big except for the soup I ordered. 

I tried the Hibicus Blood Orange drink. The first two sips were good and then it tasted bitter. I usually like drinks like this but didn't like this at all. 

One of the things that we really liked was the Totopos con Chile, chips with chile sauce. They were really good!

For an entree, I had Pozole Rojo. It was a big, steamy bowl of soup. It was okay but rather bland. The other thing I didn't like was that the pork still had fat on it. 

My husband had the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron and the Tamal Enchilado de Queso y Puerco. They were okay but again nothing really special. 

We also thought that the service was slow and our waitress wasn't very friendly. 

I guess that we prefer "Americanized" Mexican food.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The owners of Nopa/Nopalito are geniuses.  They are very savvy businesspeople whose success I applaud.  When they first started Nopa, I wasn't sure how long it would last, but it has turned into the most successful restaurant in the hood (aside from Little Star Pizza).

When I heard they were starting a Mexican place nearby, I was curious to see what they would do.  In the end, the menu at Nopalito is a bit eclectic for my tastes.  That hasn't stopped me from trying almost every item on it in a valiant search for something new; but, it has made me realize that their fish tacos are the only thing that will keep me coming back for more.  

Nopalito, like Nopa, is packed night after night, but Nopalito was set up with a side door for all the takeout business that they do.  It makes ordering for pickup a breeze.
author: Tim G.

description:
Hello Lover! 

So what if its a little upscale - the whole neighborhood is too now!
So what if its not 100% authentic - it taste damn good!
So what if its a tad pricey (and not really as by SF standards) - I GOT CRISPY PORK BELLY IN A QUESADILLA!

Very delicious maybe not the best but definitely deserves more stars than it currently has.

I recommend the ceviche, the fish tacos, and the crispy pork belly quesadilla.

Oh also don't forget to ask about their popsicle choices - Holy Mother of Milk! The Cafe con leche with Blue Bottle Coffee popsicle was divine -- also full of caffeine. Do not plan on sleeping soon after eating it.
author: Sara K.

description:
Went with a friend for lunch after getting the recommendation from a neighbor in the elevator. Was very happy with the meal despite the practically walking into the bathroom as I tried to find my way into the restaurant (I should note that while I am directionally challenged, the entrance and signage are not intuitive)... 

Split the Gordito as an app and got the mole chicken while she got the carnitas. The Gordito was excellent the beef, tomatoes and cilantro all working very well together. I thought the mole was a bit too sweet and powerful such that the chicken was a bit overwhelmed, but it wasn't bad. The carnitas was simply amazing and I ended up eating half of her plate. As much as I profess to be annoyed by women who eat daintily, I think it is just a cover as I love being able to have multiple dishes... 

Anyway, will definitely come here again.
author: Pierre C.

description: Can't say it is authentic Mexican but the plates are good and the spot is very cozy. Enjoyed the mole a lot.
author: Joseph H.

description:
I came here for lunch on a weekend as it was recommended by a friend.  Parking wasn't a problem and we were immediately seated. 

Happily sipping my delicious sangria, I ordered the carnitas and enchiladas de mole to share with my man.  The carnitas was probably one of the best I've ever had.  It was the kind that you could cut with your fork and melted like butter in your mouth.  We got the dish to share, but I was a bit hesitant to share the happiness in my mouth with everyone - I wanted it all!  I was also a fan of their michelada.  I'm sure there are still tons of unexplored territory for a SF visitor, but this was definitely one of the highlights of our trip. Highly recommended!
author: Ellen Sue B.

description:
Lucky enough I live down the street and went to the take out line or I wouldn't of eaten there that day cause the wait is so long. The take out line was cool cause you can just go to Falletti's next door, munch on some samples or grab a beer while you wait. Then when the food is ready find a spot in the panhandle to grub.

I like the tamales with cows milk cheese and the special chips are great (think homemade Doritos). Ceviche has mucho gusto citrus flavor and hits the spot on a sunny day. The Cotiha cheese is pretty standard on most dishes and happens to be one of my favorites. I only got appetizers cause I cant imagine spending that much on mexican food regardless of the quality of ingredients. I like my mexican food greasy and bad for me so the whole healthy lightness of the place wasn't  for me. Its all about the 50 cent Baja tacos cabron!
author: Sean B.

description:
We are number one fans of Nopa.
Nopalito does not compare.  Ingredients are amazing but it misses punch.  Ceviche is not bad. The best thing on the menu is the agua fresca Horchata, absolutely worth a special visit for it.
author: Emi C.

description:
Looking for a different Mexican cuisine experience to that of Taco Bell or the burrito van parked outside the office? Well, you won't get much farther than that as noh-pah-lee-toe's new offerings. Everything feels like a better version of whatever Mexican you may have tasted before. I recently had the privilege of eating an amazing Barbacoa de Borrego, its simple and honest presentation already advertising its delicate flavors. My wife went for dual appetizers (tapas' style) of Gorditas de Picadillo and Ceviche Verde de Pescado... Despite their familiar names and ingredients, they were all surprisingly delicious. 

The portions are prudent enough to leave you with a satisfied yet un-regretful finish. I also went for Michelada, which for any self-considered lover of beer is a road that must be taken: I will push your preconceptions of what a beer goes well with. It is served chilled, with salt, lemon and a generous dash of Tabasco sauce (They skipped the traditional ice cubes no doubt to push the limits of propriety).

We ate in the patio, and despite San Francisco's chilly night of winter, we were comfortable enough with the overhead heaters. The service was prompt and friendly. The unisex bathroom was impeccable (although it takes a walk around the block!) and the parking plentiful. They had interesting touches like napkins resembling traditional rags. Unfortunately they have no desserts... something I hope they correct as no doubt they are bound to be spectacular.

The pricing was fairly affordable and even generous to the quality given, so the only caveat I can say is that they take no reservations and seem to be in high demand almost any evening. It takes a good 30 minutes wait in the cold (they will serve you drinks while you wait though). You actually sign your name and leave a phone number, so you can take off, and for example, buy yourself that post-dinner treat in the wonderful Delessio Market & Bakery next door. Tip: Befriend the cashier once there (or at the nearby Peet's Coffee& Tea) so next time you could call them ahead and politely ask to write your name on the list :-)

I highly recommend Nopalito. You won't get more refined Mexican food this side of the Bay (Oakland has the highly polished Tamarindo Antojeria, but that will take another review altogether).
author: David G.

description: If you're not going to a taco truck you should go here.  Excellent mid-ranged south of the border fare.  The venue isn't great but it tastes great.
author: Matt T.

description:
Well done guys!  We have been anticipating the arrival of Nopalito and sadly, since we live in the South Bay (not for long!) we haven't had the opportunity to try it yet.  Until today.  

I was pleasantly surprised in so many ways.  First, it's much larger than I expected.  I remember walking by the space many times and thinking, this is going to be a tiny little burrito bar.  But it's not!  I LOVE that they created the outdoor space and it's gorgeous.  The decor is clean but fun and I love the live plants.  

The food is really good, of course.  I'm used to leaving Mexican joints way over stuffed and feeling greasy.  Noptalito serves just the right amount, doesn't fill you up on chips before your meal, has refereshing beverages and an amazing salsa.  I had the green one and I loved it.  The dish was also clean, a good size, and almost felt healthy.  Gasp.  

I'm happy for you guys!!!
author: Rachel C.

description:
Enjoyed a nice Sunday dinner here (carne asada norteno).  The margaritas were really good,  and the appetizers were as well.  I recommend the "Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamare".  Their popsicle desserts (chocolate or caffe con leche) were awesome.  That may have been my favorite part of the dinner.  

I wish the restaurant took reservations, but we were able to get in for a table of 4 with a call-ahead 'wait list' reservation without a problem.
author: Joel F.

description: Can't really go wrong with the food selection here, but if you had to try 1 thing off the menu, I would definitely recommend the carnitas.  The restaurant gets pretty crowded for dinner service, so you may want to call ahead of time and make reservations.
author: Herb F.

description:
Every time I go here I like it more and more. First impression- overpriced food and small portions. This is still true after multiple visits but the quality of the food is fresh and delicious. They are very flexible for vegetarians as well. I love the beat salad. 

Really wonderful beer list. Try the Duchess- worth every penny!

The desert selection is really a disapointment, but I suppose it's not the point.
author: Rena B.

description:
Hmm, not sure why there are so many low star reviews for Nopalito, because it's GOOD.  And for being fancy Mexican in SF, it's not expensive.  The first-come first-serve thing is a bit of a hassle, but they seem to have the system down.... it's a cute restaurant, though it can be noisy.  

Anyway, on to the FOOD.

We had halibut ceviche (delicate and tart, with creamy avocado), the totopos con chile (crunchy, smothered in crema), tostada de tinga (this was astonishingly savory and delcious), ensalada de repollo (good, nothing special), enchiladas de mole con pollo, and the quesadilla roja con chicharron (both very good). The horchata was AMAZING, the hibiscus-valencia orange not so much.   I think the whole thing may have been worth it for the horchata alone, seriously.

Anyway, very very very good, reasonable price, and pleasant, cheerful low-fuss atmosphere.  It's perfect for a brunch with a couple of friends.  We will definitely come back!

Almost forgot... the most hilarious part of our visit was that I had seen the waitress passing several times with trays of small golden pastry balls of some sort and I became irrationally convinced that they were teeny churro balls!  They turned out to just be cookies... we were so sad.  The waitress got this very bemused expression on her face when we asked and was like... churro balls... that's brilliant!  So I think Nopalito should make churro balls... with cinammon ice cream, can you imagine...?  Sigh.
author: Marie K.

description:
Get the carnitas, if only so you know that carnitas is a special tasty crispy way to cook pork, its not just "mashed pork" as the typical burrito parlor would have you believe. 
   Those places don't know how to cook pork pastor either, or more accurately they think WE don't know how they should cook pastor, WISE UP AND RISE UP PEOPLE, don't get me started...
author: Brian C.

description:
I didn't love it, but it wasn't bad, either. 

Atmosphere is nice, service is great. We had teh grapefruit salad, which was really just kinda boring. Chicken mole poblano - very good. The sauce may have been the first mole I've tasted where I felt like I could actually taste the chocolate. It was a much smaller portion than I expected. The rice was good, too. The carnitas were kinda boring to me. The meat was good, but it wasn't so flavorful that it shined through the corn tortillas. It was good, just nothing special.

Not a fan of the little ender - tasted like saltines but not as good.
author: Monika M.

description: I went there for my birthday and I was really impressed! The food was outstanding. I recommend the seared trout and their margarita.
author: Custi E.

description:
Turns out they weren't open for lunch today, so I had to wait until dinner time for the socio-culinary event of the month. An adorable woman and her infant child served Lizzy and I a couple of sweet and sparkling agua fresca.

Upon being seated, our waitress served us some roasted, salted chickpeas (which for some reason came with a teeny side of more salt). The little nuggets helped us through our menu decisions, which arrived in just a shade under ten minutes.

Lizzy's ceviche was fresh and tart, while my pork and roasted corn stew was savory and filling. We also split a very smooth tamale filled with fabulous fungi. Both of our plates were served with great tortilla chips that we watched get made by hand about ten feet from the bar.

Our check came with two halves of some powdered sugar-coated cookie, and we were out the door for twenty bucks a head. It remains to be seen whether that unforseen tax paid in order to eat 'local and slow' is worth it, but it's certainly a quality meal.
author: JD L.

description:
We had a great appetizer, dinner, and DARK CHOCOLATE CINNAMON POLENTA POPSICLE!!!

Sure it's a little pricey... but it'scute and all about local food... Live a little!

Service was friendly, food was fantastic and my company was tops!!! I will go and go again!!
author: Alissa P.

description: Good stuff. Went here on a rainy Sunday.  They accomodate non-animal product eater types and the cinnamon chocolate popsicle is vegan and awesome.  I'd go back for the popsicle anyday.
author: Chris W.

description:
Fancyish Mexican at reasonable prices w/ excellent service and reasonable prices.

Had a great dinner here w/ my super cool friend Mary.  Had a bit of a wait, but not too bad.  Staff was all very cool and knowledgeable, especially our suuuuuper cute server.  :heart:

Started with totopos, which are like chilaquiles if you've ever had those - basically v thick fried tortilla chips w/ some tasty sauce and cheese.  Yum.

Veggie (mushroom, corn, cheese) quesadilla was prob the low point of the meal.  It was not bad, but pretty uninspiring.  Just not a ton of flavor there.

Next up was the pork belly quesadilla.  OK, back in business here, that was rich and delicious and great, YUM!

Then had a citrus salad our server recommended for a little break - grapefruit, blood orange, pickled onions - this was EXCELLENT.

Finished the meal with AWESOME carnitas, juicy and rich and meaty and flavorful and DELICIOUS - this is a MUST ORDER item here for sure.  Really, really excellent carnitas.

Had a bottle of rosé wine that was nice and light and fruity, went really well with the dinner.

We were pretty stuffed after this, and it was $45/each.  Definitely well worth the price and I look forward to going back.
author: Deva H.

description: The first time I came here with a friend for lunch, I fell in love with their food!  Now my hubby and I come here a lot for lunch on the weekdays when the kiddies are in school.  Every item on their menu is excellent.  We love all their appetizers and our fav main dish is the carnitas.   Tender, braised pork served in parchment paper with fresh tortillas.  The service is great and atmosphere is warm, bright and inviting.  Patio seating is a plus.  I always look forward to their popsicle sticks for dessert.  The coffee flavored bars are the best but lately it's been chocolate.  This place is a must try!!
author: Sharon D.

description:
There's a rule when making movies: never be boring. A cheesy slasher film is always more fun that a dull classic, no matter how brilliant the style, acting, and direction. Nopalito needs to learn the same about food. I could tell the dishes we ordered used quality ingredients, but they were dry and bland and I didn't really feel like inserting them into my mouth (my date felt the same). The tamale should be been cooked with more fat, and served with more than a drop of sour cream (or some other nice, gloppy sauce). The carnitas offered tasteless meat, a bit of dry cabbage, and a bit of green sauce. I'm supposed to make delish tacos with this? The consommé broth was watery - chicken stock is not hard to make people.

Five stars for the genuinely friendly staff. Two for the cuisine. Maybe it was an off night?
author: Nick C.

description:
Nopalito is one of my go-to spots.

I'll admit, it's not always easy to get a table, the service isn't perfect, the menu could change more frequently, and the bathroom's location outside makes for a run through the rain in winter months... but the always fresh squid ceviche, killer vegetarian quesadillas, relative affordableness, laid back vibe, and addicting totopos more than make up for any deficiencies. I'm still waiting for the day that they serve something other than those little almond cookies with the check.

Brunch here is pretty incredible, too (try the huevos).
author: Allie H.

description:
This is NOT a taqueria so please do not treat it as one. This is more like the food they actually eat in mexico when you're not eating street food. From fine cuisine to wholesome recipes found in any home. 

Noh-Pah-Lee-Toe may very well be my new favorite restaurant. It's well rounded flavors and easy going price range along with it's casual setting make it a great spot for lunch or dinner.

Like most things in SF someone has taken the heart of the original food and remade it from organic and sustainable sources. 

I will be back again and again because everything on the menu sounded good. But definitely order the Totopos con Chile (Tortilla chips, chili de arbol, cotija cheese, crema and lime) - delicious!
author: scott w.

description:
Wow, two back-to-back reviews of Mexican food eateries.  Nopalito is a real favourite and stand-by for my wife and me.  We love starting with the Totopos that are the lazy-persons tortilla chips in as much as they come pre-dipped in picante sauce and sprinked with queso.

I would say that Carnitas is my favourite dish at this trendy little shop although I do find myself nowadays gravitating toward their fish tacos.  The Quesadillas are also wonderful, especially the vegetarian variety.

And to top it all off and finish a superb meal, allow me to recommend the Mexican chocolate ice cream popsickle.  Have I had a sweet served on a stick that is this tasty?  I think not.
author: Jay D.

description:
Nopalito is located in my neighborhood so I have been wanting to try this place out. When they first opened I asked my friend who was living in the condos nearby what she thought of the food...her response was "expensive Mexican." I agree somewhat with her statement. The food was fine but more then I like to pay for Mexican food, especially since we have a good selection of Mexican restaurants in SF that are good and inexpensive. Also, my lunch hunger was satisfied but I could have shared another small plate with my hubby and then I might have felt full.
If you are craving healthy, fresh Mexican food and you are in the area, then Nopalito is worth a try.
author: Camille S.

description:
I hate giving bad reviews ... so I'll start with the good points.

The waitress and staff were very friendly and attentive.  She was quick to respond to requests and questions.  The restaurant was clean and comfortable (super hot, but yesterday topped 90 degrees - can't really control for that in SF). 

I'm a sucker for fresh corn tortillas - and Nopalito's hit the spot!

We tried three appetizers and they were all great - reasonable price for that scale of restaurant, high quality ingredients and super tasty.

Okay ... so now for the bad news ... to quote some other Yelpers:  "Its not bad, but its not great either."  Generally, I expected more from a place with a high caliber reputation.

I ordered the grapefruit juice, which was refreshing and light on such a hot day - but it was incredibly watered down (likely 70% water and ice).  You could barely taste the actual juice for $4.

The entrees were generally too dry.  I had the carnitas - which were very tender with good flavor - but just dry.  The green salsa the dish comes with is ridiculously spicy, so I asked for the regular tomato salsa to lighten up the dryness - a little green and a little red went a long way.  There was no sauce on my friend's dry enchiladas and my other friend could barely eat the lamb because of how spicy the dish was.  

I know - its a Mexican restaurant, dishes are supposed to be hot ... but they should consider annotating the menu so people know what to expect.  

The collective opinion was that Nopalito is not worth what you end up spending.
author: Lisa B.

description: I went here last night really craving some quality Mexican Food. The server at the takeout window was finishing an order for some other customers. I reached for a menu and made my decision. When it was time to order, I politely asked for the enchiladas. She then stated that I was looking at a "sample menu". She then pointed to a menu that I should be ordering from. She then said, "do you still want the enchiladas?" I said I needed some time to look a the "correct menu". She then turned and walked away without saying a word. Why would any one want to spend a large amount of $ at a place that has uninterested and rude staff?
author: Timothy A.

description:
Definitely upscale taqueria...if you're looking for a cheap Mission eatery, you'll be very disappointed.

Visited last night with a friend and had a fantastic time! We arrived at 6:30 and there wasn't a wait at all. We sat at the communal table and we selected the Pinot Noir Rose which was a good deal at $28. 

We started with the chips with the salsa brushed on them and that was really tasty.

I chose the carnitas as my entree and I was really happy with it. A huge chunk of pork was roasted in parchment paper and it was served with a cabbage/carrot slaw that was sweet and tart as well as homemade corn tortillas. 

The carnitas were fork tender and had the right amount of fat to meat ratio. It was smokey without being too overpowering. 

We didn't have dessert, since popsicles were the only option. They did bring two tiny Mexican wedding cookies to finish the meal.

Our server wasn't very subtle about trying to turn the table over, which we found really offputting. However, the meal was delish and there was free parking. Two very big thumbs up!
author: Eva C.

description: I've been here a couple of times and ordered take out once. I would recommend the Totopos con Chile to start with... simple, but tasty. My litmus for any Mexican establishment is their carnitas. I can't respect a place that makes crappy carnitas... Nopalito passed the test. It was juicy and easily pulled apart with a fork. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it and I just ate already!
author: Steve K.

description: Went here for the second time last week with a group of 6. They don't take reservations so plan on either calling while on your way or putting down your name and heading to Madrone for cocktails. They'll call you when your table is ready. The food here is delicious. The service we had that evening was a bit off but she was trying and it was busy. Would highly recommend the vegetarian enchiladas, the nachos, and the guacomole. All nice and spicy as well as delicious. None of the dishes left you feeling overstuffed like traditional Mexican food.
author: Heather L.

description:
I Love Nopalito!!

I wanted to give it 4 and a half stars because well, you can find something wrong with any place if you search hard enough. I decided to go with 5 start instead of 4 to make up for the ignorant people who docked stars for things such as, chaotic parking sitch, HELLO AT LEAST THERE IS PARKING!! and the person who said you can get a better burrito down the street, WELL there are NO BURRITOS at Nopalito, that's kinda the point people. 

I agree with the person who said "for locals only", everyone else should go back to your generic "American" taqueria. Please tell me where you can get authentic, I mean REAL authentic Mexican food, here or anywhere aside from Mexico? Please tell me where you can eat Mexican food and taste and see every single ingredient. Please tell me where you can have a great meal (Mexican or otherwise) with quality ingredients, friendly service and a bight airy atmosphere for this price. The food here in my opinion is above and beyond average. Homemade bread, tortillas, cheese, non hormone meats = wonderful flavors in my mouth! They even squeeze their own juice for the agua frescas.

All of that being said, this is not a taqueria, do not go here if that's what you want. This is not for people who want quantity over quality. This is truly great regional Mexican food that is being cooked by 2 truly great "real" Mexican guys. This is the only restaurant of it's kind and I LOVE the food here!
author: Kara S.

description: Amazing dinner while visiting San Francisco earlier this summer. The wait was not long, the service was great and the food was phenomenal. The only downside is that you have to go outside and around the corner to a separate entrance for the restrooms but it's a small price to pay for a delicious meal. 5 stars!
author: Emily W.

description:
NUTRITIONIST APPROVED! 
pluses: very cute/great ambiance; outdoorish (covered patio) eating option; excellent service; sustainable, organic, delicious food; friendly neighborhoody vibe; good drink options (fresh squeezed blood orange-meyer lemon yummmm); tortilla chips and homemade tortillas are awesome!

minuses: limited menu (but one could make a case for 'do a few things only, and do them well'); expensive yuppie white people mexican-food prices. i'm allowed to say it since my boyfriend is part mexican and i learned it from him.

would return fo' sho' but this feels more like a lunch spot vibe and not really a dinner or date destination.
author: Mary V.

description:
I was a little nervous to go to Nopalito, especially after hearing all the gushing praise from the SF Chronicle reviewer -- going to a new restaurant with high expectations usually leaves me disappointed.  

However, I have to say that the Chronicle was actually pretty spot on with their review.  A group of four of us went to try it out, and the experience started off quite well with their call-in waiting list.  They gave us an estimate of about 45 minutes, and when we showed up 45 minutes later, we got a call from them to let us know that our table was ready -- Perfect!  

We ordered lots of things on the menu, so much food that the waiter kinda gave us a friendly face of disbelief.  We ordered two chicharron quesadillas, the black bean tortilla, the gordita, the ceviche, two orders of carnitas, and an order of chicken mole.  The carnitas were amazing -- a little bit of crispiness on the outside but very tender on the inside, and not very much fat.  The black bean tortilla with chicken and onions had a very nice late kick to it.  The ceviche was very fresh.  The mole had a very nice flavor to it, and the chicken was very tender -- it maybe could have used a bit more spice, but I definitely liked it a lot.  

Sadly, the dish I was most excited about -- the chicharron quesadilla -- was probably my least favorite dish.  The ratio of tortilla to meat was a little bit high, and the strong tortilla taste hid the saltiness of the pork belly a little too much.  It had some very tasty bites, but was not consistent.  

The only other drawback to Nopalito was the fact that they don't have a liquor license.  They serve beer and wine, but I stuck with the non-alcoholic drinks.  The citrus drink was very good, although the menu description made me think it was more like an agua fresca than the carbonated drink that was served.  The almond horchata was also really good, except that I think it was $4.  

Overall, it was a GREAT dining experience, and we are all looking forward to going back to try everything else on the menu!
author: Pilan C.

description: OK food but a weird caste system for reservations and seating. We apparently were among the untouchables. Your mileage may vary.
author: Douglas E.

description:
first off, if i could, i would breathe mexican food. but in reality, i would most likely die. 

this place is pretty friggin awesome. it was first mentioned to me by one of my good friends Mary H. (hey girl hey!). too bad it took me like a year to finally come here. and a year wasted let me tell you. 

its not supa fancy but its not your hold in the wall taqueria either. they are fancy enough to not give you free chips and salsa though. oh yeah they make you pay for that shizz, but soo worth it. i believe theyre called 'topotos (sp?)" basically tortilla chips smothered and infused with their special salsa with finely grated cheese and some creme fresh. awww yeah. soo good. 

apparently i really liked those haha... so yeah get those, the taquitos, the crispy pork belly (dont worry servings are small enough) & maybe a pitcher of their margaritas to share with your company if youre feeling like a little fiesta. 

ambiance is great, staff is friendly, parking can be rough (but where is it not in SF) but its really not that big a deal. EAT HERE. your stomach will thank you.
author: Renalen C.

description: Good food and strong margaritas!  I loved the green ceviche and the chicken mole. We also tried the carnitas and enchiladas, both were good.  A little pricey for what you get, but overall a very good time.
author: Justine S.

description:
I went here last week and it was very depressing. All the waitstaff are caucasian and exude the gentrified attitudes of the neighborhood, once called the Western Addition. 

I rarely even write reviews, however, I felt so angry and upset with my experience here that I vowed to share my experience with others in hope that they too will either save their money or drink their expensive, watery sangria with another take. 

The waitstaff seemed fake and detached from their own restaurant... as if they didn't really care about the food at all. They were all white americans, as I have mentioned, and all the kitchen staff is latino.  The set up of the restaurant allows one to see the "magic" of kitchen but instead reinforces class and social patterns that evoke colonial racism. I can guarantee most of the waitstaff (or owners) are not even from the Bay Area. 

I ordered the mole con pollo and the enchiladas de pollo. The menus exotifies itself to an extent of pretentiousness. The mole was overly sweet and not rich at all. Me and my friend are huge foodies and well versed in authentic mexican food and this ain't it, folks! The worst part of it all is that after a couple bites we decided to tell the backwaiter what we thought of the food. He shrugged and dismissively said,  "There are many mole variations..." filled our water glasses, made no eye contact and offered no solution.  The enchiladas were small but filling. They also were $14 and were kinda bland. nothing special. 

I should have told the frontwaiter also, but honestly just felt so oppressed there at that moment, feeling the bourgeoisie of gentrification in san francisco. 

All in all, the food was expensive, not new, exciting or even authentic. The environment sucked and felt comfortable for the middle class but actually depressing for anyone who is socially conscious. 

oh yeah, their bergamot mint lemonade is fuckin delicious, though.
author: Carlos R.

description: Third time here: Brought my husband here for his Father's Day lunch and again was so satisfied with the food! Place is just really small and I don't like feeling like a sardine packed in a can but the food makes it worth it. Definitely a fan of their Carnitas and their Strawberry Almond Horchata. The Flor de Calabaza Quesadilla is great too. Definitely not authentic "Mexican" food but it's still great food! So if you want authentic Mexican don't come here.
author: Tecochizpan J.

description:
Ok for those that don't mind spicy food.

I've eaten at both locations and each time I've enjoyed it but not been that impressed.

The main problem for me is that every dish is liberally sprinkled with red flakes, making the dishes too spicy for me to really enjoy them.  I always have to order crema to cover them with and drink a lot of water.  So if this isn't an issue for you, you'll probably enjoy the food a lot.

Other than that in my opinion it's just not as exciting as every says.
I'm glad I've tried it, I've even tried it a second time, but I feel no urge to go again.

The service has been good both times, although the first time I went, the Broderick location was sooo busy they had a hard time keeping up with all the requests.  I actually felt bad for the wait staff.
author: Kyra T.

description: Great food, great drinks, knowledgable staff. The Mexican coffee drink is the perfect dessert- not too sweet.
author: M S.

description: Such a great spot. Carnitas were amazing and definitely will be coming back again. Wish the place had a bit more ambiance, but other than that we were super happy.
author: Annie G.

description:
OK. I have been holding off on this one, not because I am not sure about it, but because I love it so and I am afraid it will get too crowded for me to be able to get in!

This is my go to place for either a nice slow lunch or a quick snack. They have food to go, too, so I usually stop here for a sandwich to go on my way out of town or to the airport.

It is also my comfort food spot, as it truly represents Mexican cuisine. If what you think of as Mexican food are $5 burritos, please read no further, as this place is not for you. No, this place features dishes you would eat at your grandmother's home on a Sunday family gathering in Mexico. 

All of their food is super tasty, and made with seasonal, fresh, mostly organic ingredients. Their tortillas are made right there and then, and come to your table soft and warm. The salsas you eat here are all different, and made for the particular dish you have ordered, so throughout your meal you will have tried many different ones. Their beans are heritage, hard to find varieties. Their meat is succulent.

As some people have said, the dishes are not too big, which for me is great, as I can try a few different things every time. 

The Mezcal selection here has to be the best in San Francisco by far, which is an added plus. 

Service is super  friendly and attentive, a reflection of the Nopa connection.

My guess is that Nopalito has to be crowded for dinner and on weekend nights, but that's not when I usually go, so I cannot say. What I do know is that they do not take reservations, so make sure to get there early!
author: Rebeca R.

description:
Many opposing forces make Nopalito's rating just average for me.

I have eaten the: 

civiche- excellent! like squid salsa, very fresh and limey but a slightly  expensive at $10

tamal de puerco - pretty tasty, yet lacking. very little pork. liked the pumpkin seed puree on top

enchiladas de mole con pollo - mole was great and the refried beans were awesome, but the shredded chicken was kind of tough and a little gamey. 

carnitas - the most worthwhile item I tried. outstanding flavors, pork was melty and luscious in its parchment cocoon.  the pickled jalapenos (onions and carrots too) were slightly sweet and nicely herbed and went very well with the salsa verde and cabbage salad.

horchata - another hit, I thought it was worth the $4 price tag. much lighter and less sweet than other horchatas I have known. 

hibiscus/valencia orange drink - not my favorite. it was pretty tart with not a lot of interesting flavor. I couldn't really detect any orange and it seemed to be watered down with sparkling water. 

complementary wedding cookies - tasty! loved these. they reminded me of halva they were so dense with nutty goodness. yum.

overall, it was "meh" with a couple high notes of wow. not enough to make me a dedicated fan but probably enough to get me back in the door for the carnitas, civiche and horchata.
author: neal h.

description:
I've only been here for lunch, but it was great and totally reasonable $ wise.  It serves Mexican food, but it's no typical Mexican restaurant - the flavors are delicate and the food is much lighter than typical taco joint.  

The carnitas were a real smash hit.
author: Mario G.

description:
High quality food at a price you can afford. 

The ceviche was refreshing and delicious. But the don't miss item is the carnitas. I have dreams about it. mmmmmmm. Homemade corn tortillas, cabbage and pickled vegetables are the accompaniments. 

Artisan popsicles made with real fruit juice are the perfect light and refreshing way to end a heavy meal. 

Let's you save more room for carnitas.
author: melissa n.

description:
Went here for the first time with my mom today. At first glance I was uncertain I'd be able to eat anything on the menu - I'm "seagan" i.e. I eat seafood but no dairy, eggs, or other meat. Our server was very helpful in altering some items on the menu to fit my dietary restrictions. 

The horchata was fucking on point, way more flavorful that the stuff you get at any old taqueria. We tried the Totopos con Chile with cotija cheese and crema on the side. very good and spicy. The Ceviche was fresh and loaded with fish. We ordered the Quesadilla de Hongos y Huitlacoche without cheese...it was alright but really needed the cheese. The Taco de Pescado al Pastor was AMAZING, by far the best thing I tried and worth going back for. My mom had the Tamal Enchilado de Queso y Puerco and said it was great. 

The ambience of Nopalito is lovely and the service is great. Our server (pretty girl with an accent) was amicable and knowledgeable.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description: The food was interesting, however, the wait was a nightmare.  We called in advance to put down our name, and they told us it would be 45-min wait.  We got there on time, but we ended up waiting another 45-min.  I also thought their horchata drink was way too sweet.
author: Elena L.

description:
If you're looking for authentic Mexican food, this isn't the place, but I think it does what it does well - I think of it as a cheaper, healthier, tastier and happier version of Mexico DF.  I love all the natural light that comes into this building, as opposed to the shadows cast by the tall buildings of the  Financial District

If you're gonna try something with a group, definitely start with the totopos - pretty delicious and actually pretty filling.  Carnitas are also plentiful and delicious.  There were a couple things that made this place well worth paying a little extra for and one of it was the home-made corn tacos that came with.  You gotta love tacos that are jagged on the edges and asymmetrical. The cabbage salsa and pickled veggies were a nice accent to go along with the carnitas.  I also had their hibiscus blood-orange juice - that was okay at best for me, as I was looking for something a tad sweeter.  The second thing that made it worth a little extra for this place is serving sparkling water free of charge!  More places need to do this.  

It was a sunny leisurely day in San Francisco, the wait staff is super nice, the wait was short for us and the food was very good, so I left completely happy.  Parking is also very easy in this area. The bathroom's a little weird since you have to exit to get there, but it's got the most powerful hand dryer in the US and a cool sink, so consider it even.

If you're deliberating this place, just try it.
author: Tsubasa O.

description:
It took awhile, but I finally gave Nopalito another shot.  It has definitely improved.  We had the ceviche again, it was much more flavorful than the first time around (maybe it was an off night, who knows?).  My fish taco was really good and flavorful.  J really like the pork belly quesadilla, he snarfed it up.  The guac was decent, nothing special, and the corn salad thing was tasty, and surprisingly spicy as well.

I've since ordered Nopalito's takeout, which I would not advise.  Soggy and falling apart--although it saves you from standing around and waiting for an hour.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Nopalito is a great addition to the neighborhood.  We were worried they might be redundant of Green Chile Grill around the corner, but they're definitely NOT.

Lovely, upscale Mexican fare.  My husband and I had dinner there with friends last weekend, and we tried the ceviche, a quesadilla, mole chicken, enchilladas, posole, and some other kind of roasted-pork goodness.  

Everything was fresh and delicious.  One of our friends also had the Michelada (kind of like a beer version of a Margarita) and it was super yummy. Entrees + a round of drinks worked out to about $25/person after tip.  So, this is definitely more spendy than your corner taqueria.  Also, for now it's best to go with a reservation.

We'll be going back.  Love the food, love the owners.  But for a quickie burrito run, we'll still be hitting Green Chile.
author: Wes P.

description: Good freshly prepared food for a decent price. Nice selections, clean place with a semi open kitchen and open for brunch/lunch on the weekends.  Good selection of drinks too and good for families, smaller parties etc. We had some great salads, enchilada's and flank steak - all pretty good.  We would come back!
author: Beth P.

description:
One word... Posole

Even though this restaurant is a bit on the trendy side I still think the food is pretty good. The posole is great  when you have a cold and comes with lots of fun herbs and spices things to add in. Pretty much all the items I have tried have been good even if they aren't traditional.
author: Jennifer F.

description: A nice place for a tasty, casual meal in a nice setting. I was little disappointed with the food but probably only because I'd head a lot of hype about this restaurant along with Nopa so I was expecting a lot. But overall the service was great (casual but friendly) all the dishes were good, if nothing extraordinary, and it's a nice room with good energy.
author: Syd S.

description: Granted it was a warm San Francisco night, so the wait was to be expected.  Nevertheless the food wasn't all I had been hoping it would be.  The ceviche was great, but the fish tacos were disappointing & the Pazole bland.  Perhaps some suggestions from the wait staff on sides would have helped with the tacos... Seriously though two $5 taco on a white plate with some orange and some cabbage was a bummer.  Would have paid more to have stuff added if it had been suggested & it would have made a huge difference in enjoyment.
author: Kelley F.

description:
just like at NOPA the staff is made up of adorable food dorks who are demonstratably happy to be there and encouraged questions and menu experimentation. where do they farm these sincerest of hip food cats? I have a crush on them all. 
I was not as smitten with the food. the chicken was dry, the chips a labor to eat, the mole was drenched, the ceviche made me feel as if i was eating nothing. 
the only thing that was completed at the table was the tamale. i would get that again. and the free cookie at the end.
author: Stephanie C.
