description: It's in my neighborhood, it's ALWAYS packed, it has amazing carnitas and delicious margaritas. Authentic Mexican food but not too upscale that it feels wrong. Must go back more but always get impatient with the wait.
author: Susan A.

description:
Let me clarify - 2.5 stars. 

Perhaps I need approach dinner with lower expectations.  The last few places I've gone to have been such letdowns after such hype.  Nopalito followed suit.

Atmosphere:  This place feels more like a little cafe than a actual restaurant - perhaps because its attached to a grocery store.  One star only because the host was so lovely - very understanding when I was running about 10 minutes late due to a Muni debacle.  We were seated at the bar - which was fun, but overall the restaurant was too loud to have a conversation at a normal decibel.

Service: Our server was extremely nice, but it seemed like she was covering all of the tables in the place - we had to wave her down every time we needed something.

Food: OK, this is where the screaming conversations and lack of service doesn't matter because the food is so good.  Um, not so much.  The ceviche was chewy and the chips were soggy.   The Panucho de Pollo al Pibil was flavorful, but the tortilla it sat on was mediocre.  The Mole Poblano con Pollo was actually quite delicious, but it was a rather small portion.

White sangria = fantastic, definitely a must-order.

My dinner-mate said that she had been there several times, and her other experiences had better food and service.  Either way - this was definitely a disappointment.
author: Julie E.

description:
My expectations were too high.  I love Nopa and I love Mexican food.  As it turned out, this was a recipe for being only moderately impressed.

FOOD: I came five hours after pilates and I was beyond famished.  Protein was a requirement, so I sprang for the carnitas.  They were lacking in flavor and moisture.  The slaw was crisp and fresh, the meat was pleasant and tender, and the avocado-tomatillo salsa was mild and "nice."  I was disappointed that to find spicy garbanzo beans in lieu of chips and salsa.  I mean, how can you call yourself Mexican without the free chips and salsa?

DRINK: Margarita was very boring.  It was fresh and natural (agave, orange, tequila, and lime) but certainly not as good as what you'd get at Tropisueno or Mamacita.

SERVICE: We were definitely taken care of.

PRICE POINT: $30 for lunch?  Carnitas $15.  Margarita $9.  Tax + Tip + Healthy SF $6.  

AMBIANCE: This is the kind of place I'd take my Mom.  It's very family friendly on a Saturday afternoon but still has the "cool" SF vibe.  Worth trying again on a Thursday or Friday night, but annoying that they don't take reservations!
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Gordita- great
Wine- a rip. $8 for what couldn't be more than 3 oz of wine in a tiny terra cotta glass.
Beer- cheap!
Ceviche- so-so. lots of fish, but would've been nice to have some crunchy veg or something else in addition to all that fish
Pozole- delicious. 
Naranja salad- good.
Other notes:  Didn't notice very many vegetarian options.
author: Laura L.

description:
I met a girl friend for dinner and we were pleasantly surprised when we walked in to the Nopalito. It has a lively atmosphere, fun modern, clean décor and above all the food is outstanding, the service was friendly and gave great recommendations for first time dinners with Nopalito. The portions are get and the menu is set up to share, I would recommend getting a couple small plates and sharing an entree!

I also loved that if you order certain wines, Nopalito will donate a portion of the proceeds to the earthquake relief efforts in Chile.
I would highly recommend dinning at Nopaltio, I'm hooked know!
author: Elisheba W.

description:
This is the meal that saved the day.  After 2 hours in the dmv and 30 more people in front of me I felt that there was plenty of time to get some lunch while I wait.  I walked across the street and saw wonderful looking plates of food and a menu that was not that pricey at all.  I am soooo glad that I took the chance.

We ordered the chicken consomme soup and the chicken mole enchiladas.... OMG They were amazing! The soup had pieces of avocado and an entire chipotle chile inside.  The corn was roasted to perfection and the little pieces of cheese sealed the deal

The mole was simmered to perfection with the perfect amount of spice.  The bf lived in Honduras  for some time and said that this was very similar to what  he had there.

The food is very healthy and yet still tastes really good!
author: Jennifer S.

description: So this place is what I like to call Fancy Mexican food. You won't get an authentic meal but you'll get a tasty one. Much of the menu is very street foodisque but you're taste buds will love it. Promise. Service was super friendly and I loved the location its kinda hidden near a grocery store. I mean its cute and different and I really liked it. The prices for Fancy Mexican isn't bad and the drinks are strong so worth the money on that too. Try it you'll thank me later.
author: Lisa A.

description:
I went to Nopalito last night and it was cold.  I live on the other side of the Panhandle and it is almost always cold at night.  WIth the exception of a few nights a year, this is a foggy neighborhood.  In the summer the fog rolls in from the sea and gets trapped in between Lone Mountain and Twin Peaks.  I mention this, because I am wondering why the good folks at Nopalito thought an outdoor section would work at night in the Panhandle.  

I forgot that you can call ahead and put your name on the list, and at about 7pm on an ordinary Tuesday night, there was a short wait for a table.  It seemed like their staff was working hard to get people seated.  The problem is that if you wait outside in the cold and then have to sit in the outdoor section, you are still going to be cold.  Sure there is a covered space with heaters, but there is also a big open window that lets all of the cold air in. 

I am only complaining, because I like Nopalito and want them to succeed.  It is ran by the same people who own Nopa, and I am sure they will work things out.  On a nice sunny afternoon their outdoor section will be a cozy place to have a bite and enjoy the weather.  When I had dinner there last night, it was just too damn cold.  This is San Francisco after all, when is it ever warm at night?

Otherwise, the menu looks great and the food was solid.  I would have liked the portions to be larger, especially the appetizers.  I had the gordito something and the pescado taco, which are about $4.50 each.  You only get one of these items per order, which is a little disappointing.  I know a lot of good taquerias where you can get two tacos for $5 and be totally full.  Of course, Nopalito is catering to a different crowd, but they are serving Mexican food.  For an entree I shared the Pozole with my companion.  Our server told us that it was like a stew, but when it arrived it was more like soup.  When I saw it on the menu, I imagined that it would have big chunks of slow cooked pork that you could eat with tortillas like tacos.  Sadly, in the Pozole I ate, there were a few tiny morsels of pork.

I am looking foward to going back to Nopalito and seeing how they adapt to the neighborhood.  I think their to-go window will be a really nice addition to the restaurant.  Until then, I will not be back to Nopalito after the sun goes down.  In the meantime, I will trek the extra five minutes to Valencia and eat at Regalito.
author: Ezra Y.

description: I love Nopalito! The seasonal menu, variety of items (both food and drinks), and friendliness of the staff are all something I look forward to.  Also, the drinks are great - especially if you like tequilas. While there can be a long wait, it's possible to phone ahead and be placed on the list, which is nice.  Also nice is sitting at the community table or at the bar, which can speed things up if you're dining solo or with two people.  I feel like there's an emphasis on fresh foods and good flavor combinations. Yum!
author: Kim S.

description:
Some things were a lot better than others, but overall the highs were strong enough to make me a fan. First of all, we called on our way and told them we'd be there in about 30 minutes, when we arrived they had a table waiting for us. 

Not so great:
Tamal de puerco - I love tamales, so was excited to see two different ones on the menu. We asked the waiter which one he recommended this one with pork. The masa part was excellent, moist and just flavorful enough. But the pork was bland and the peanuts on top were an overpowering flavor, great texture, but all I could taste was peanuts.
Ceviche - it was good, but just not great. I know that people love it, but I just wasn't wowed. Great chips though.

Great:
Panucho de pollo - looking at it, it appeared pretty standard, crisp corn tortilla, topped with black beans, stewed chicken and salsa, but it tasted better than I thought. I think the pickled onions really made it. They added a really bright flavor. 

GREAT GREAT GREAT:
Esquite Tostado - grilled corn, topped with crema, and their homemade queso fresco. WOW, I love corn and queso fresco so I knew I would like it, but this was out of this world. I would come back just to have another bowl (or two) of this!
author: Rose K.

description:
Amazing food. 
Free sparkling water on tap. 
Free almond cookies delivered with the check.
Get the carnitas plate or the skirt steak. 
They do take out too. 
Great staff. Really friendly place. My new local favorite spot.
author: Erika D.

description:
I didn't have the wait issues or crowds etc. everyone else talks about. 

But...

Way overpriced
Just OK tasting
Way too greasy and oily
Mediocre service.

Can't see myself going back.

I get what they are doing and absolutely love Nopa. I'm hoping they're still working out the opening kinks.
author: Jim O.

description: Yummy cocktails + casual fancy mexican food + heated/covered patio. Definitely on my repeat list.
author: Jennee D.

description:
I love this place for a couple of reasons.
1. You can't really beat the prices on their menu for the high quality and excellent taste of the food, especially in an expensive city like San Francisco.
2. Their menu changes sometimes, but always maintains a fresh, new feel to familiar dishes. Also, even if their menu changes, if you like something on the old menu, they often can make it for you anyways, which is a nice plus. 
3. Their drinks, alcoholic or not (their horchata is definitely one of my favorite things), are fabulous. 
4. I like bringing people here because I like the relaxed environment, as it is such a well kept, clean place,  and the kind, friendly, personable attitudes from the employees really shows and makes a huge difference. 
5. The little cookies they give with the check really lessen the blow, that is if I had to worry about an expensive check coming to the table, however that's not even usually the case! In this case, the cookies are just the cherry on top of the cake. 

A good place to bring out of town family if they want a good taste of San Francisco with low prices. In my particular case, my family is not particularly adventurous with cuisine, so Nopalito brings this feeling of adventurousness with the creativity of their menu items, but also keeps some of the traditional, recognizable side of Mexican cuisine.
author: Kayleigh M.

description:
2 stars are warranted by the friendly wait staff but my review is dragged down by the food.

There's no such thing as fancy mexican food, I'm sorry. There's got to be a white guy behind this place. Really disappointed by the amount of time I had to wait for mediocre mexican. You think it looks great from the menu but it's that kind of list of food items you have to read by the ingredients to figure it out. This place is buzzing with people and overrated. They don't take reservations, which makes them really hip!
author: Paul M.

description:
Went there with a friend, and we ate at the bar because we didn't feel like waiting for a table (it was a crowded evening).  I had the pozole, which was really fantastic--very flavorful.  Also tried the rice pudding and the grapefruit popsicle for dessert; the popsicle was pretty good, though there's no question now that I should have gone for the pudding.

Waitstaff were quite friendly, and the michelada was pretty tasty--a good amount of spice--though it was the first time I'd tried one, so I don't have much to compare to.
author: Jesse D.

description:
I'm only updating because it pisses me off that such a great restaurant can have such shitty service. 
 
Their food was outstanding once again.

But oh their dreaded fucking service. Seriously, it was so bad, we were never sure who our real waiter was. The guy that took care of us at the end was great. The first girl roller her eyes at us, didn't bring us the right drinks, and ignored us after that. Three times I tried to get the attention of this one waitress who seemed to be around a lot. She looked at me TWICE and never asked what I needed. Oh and she didn't just glance at me, she looked me dead on in the eyes. All four of us at the table agreed that service is crap. I wish I could remember the guy who did finally help us because he was great. 

Maybe if the service changes, I'll give it another star. But then again, I'm not sure if I'm going again. If it wasn't for the food, this place wouldn't be deserving of one single star.
author: Myra B.

description:
This is a great casual affordable sit down place for some jazzed up contemporary Mexican food.  The decor is lovely and the service is pleasant.  It a very small place and they don't t take reservations but even better, you can call 30 minutes before you want to get your grub on and they put you on a list and when you show up...TA-DA...your table is ready!  

I highly recommend the pork belly quesadillas, they crackled in my mouth and the carnitas...I thought they were delish!  I also recommend the white sangria with the little frozen grapes which they give you a little spoon so you can munch on them to cleanse your pallet!
author: Susan P.

description:
The food is great. I been here twice and I recommend the Carnitas with a hint of cinnamon and other spices and the meat is so tender. My friends had the Costillas lamb and Birria again meat was tender and delish. The only reason why I giving them 4 starts is because I wish they had more dessert options. Don't get me wrong I love their popsicles but sometimes you wish you had a tres leches cake or some Mexican chocolate cake.
I cant believe they have Negra Modelo on Draft that was a great surprised; great with the food.
author: Milton R.

description: Best carnitas I've had in recent memory. Super tender, generous portion and some tasty, rather expensive, margi's to wash it all down. There's definitely a reason this place is widely regarded for their carnitas.
author: David H.

description:
What drew us in was the sign outside. "Sustainable - Mexican Kitchen - Organic"

Now frankly, my companion and I were starving so we might have loved anything we found, but we loved this a lot more than just the love of a starving person.  The kitchen was bustling, the diners were clearly happy, and the food we took with us was delicious and just right.

Our quesadilla on blue corn tortilla was served hot and we didn't bother to wait for it to cool down at all.  The aroma had us diving in at the risk of minor tongue burns and happy that we did!  We'll go back when we're in the neighborhood - and we'll hate the people who live there, not only because they're beautiful.
author: Vincent L.

description:
OK, let me start by saying that I really hope this thing about not having a proper host/hostess is not a new trendy thing. (See my review of California St. Pizzeria Delfina). We sort of wandered in confused while there were plenty of empty tables left (5:50pm Tuesday) and a guy wearing a sweater and jeans who didn't look like he worked there told us to sit anywhere. Then he and a couple servers decided they should push some tables together for us. Fair enough when there's no line but this approach led to some chaos once things got crowded.

The food - excellent and not overpriced for a place that's in the "top 100". The server was knowledgeable and friendly and other than the weird table logistics I can't really complain.
author: Colin T.

description:
My boyfriend and I live in the area and we have been wanting to try this place for a while. I knew it was notorious for a long wait for dinner, so I called ahead of time around 7 to put my name on the wait list (which is so clutch!) and they told me it would be about 45 minutes. When we arrived 45 minutes later, we were seated immediately.

The food is fantastic! Very creative and unusual combinations of flavors, but they go together so well! We split the pork belly quesadilla to start. I couldn't tell from the menu that it was fried so when they put it down in front of us I was a little surprised, but it tasted great nonetheless.

I had the turkey meatballs for my entree and it was amazing! They serve them with mole sauce and Spanish rice with onions and egg - so delicious! It comes with tortillas but I didn't even use them because the dish is so good on it's own. My boyfriend ordered the chicken enchilada, which I didn't taste but he said it was great. We didn't have room for dessert, but the couple next to us were snacking on some Popsicles that I definitely could have fit in my belly.

The best thing about the meal is that is was only $48 (including two beers)! Definitely check this place out, but I recommend calling in ahead of time to get your name on there so you can avoid the wait.
author: Kelsey M.

description:
This review is for both Nopalito and Nopa catering.  My husband and I contacted Allyson at Nopalito regarding their catering services for our wedding in October.  Here's a list of the reasons why we thought they were AMAZING:

1) Even though Nopa doesn't traditionally cater, we asked Allyson whether it would be possible to have a Nopalito food station and a Nopa food station.  She made it happen.  Her husband, Laurence, the head chef at Nopa was there in the kitchen at our reception site making sure all the food was perfect.  

2) When we started talking about drinks, she got Yanni (head bartender @ Nopa) to work with us to make a few signature cocktails.  Yanni made us some awesome drinks and worked with us to make them perfect.  So delicious.

3) We brought in our own desserts for a dessert buffet.  The staff helped us set everything up beautifully.

4) We had many friends and family telling us that this was the best food they've ever had at a wedding. =)  [Granted, they might've been saying that to make us feel special! hahaa]

5)  In addition, folks came up to us during the reception to say how sweet and nice the servers and bartenders were.  They went above and beyond to make the experience amazing for us and the guests.  (Including making sure the bride and groom had a full plate of food to eat without prompting.)

6)  Behind the scene prowess.  The chefs had some electricity problems in the kitchen during set-up.  The team took care of everything and made sure that it wasn't an additional stress on us.  Seriously, I didn't really know what happened until after the event.  I'm sure Allyson was responsible for that.  She was great at making everything happen.  

Thank you Allyson, Laurence, Yanni and the entire staff!!
author: Cat B.

description:
We decided to give Nopalito a second chance and I am so glad we did! We didn't have any of the issues we had the first time. I'm chalking it all up to being a new restaurant.

They were out of the carnitas so this time we tried some new dishes (new to the menu) and were thrilled! We had the Esquite Tostado con Crema y Queso, Cecina Enchilada con Rajas y Ejotes and a salad of fresh vegetables.

This will be in the rotation...
author: Gina L.

description:
Ate here with a friend who likes eating out so much she keeps a restaurant journal.  However, neither of us said one word about the food while we were eating. We did have a lot of catching up to do, but I think it was more because the food was strikingly mediocre.  
Honestly, I am relieved because I love little chihuahua hardcore and I would hate for them to lose any business.
author: Alexandra G.

description:
After trying to get a table a couple of times, we were fortunate enough to actually get a table.  While I appreciate the "no frills" approach of their no reservation policy, the wait at times are a bit ridiculous...i'm not sure if they anticipated the popularity.  They have a small space, which adds to the wait time.  

The concept is straightforward, and simple.  Great space, and great staff.  The best thing on their menu by far is their cicharrone quesadilla...who can resist homemade corn tortillas, with crispy and moist bits of pork!  mmmmm...pork.
author: Vince B.

description:
Pure, tender, fall-apart on your fork-and-tongue carnitas --delicious! And the tomatillo salsa pairing is spot-on.

Hard to get an authentic birria dish right but the Nopalito version is superb. Great blend of spices simmered for hours to make the goat meat just succulent enough yet chewy to work your jaws.

Great lunch or dinner appetizer which is really quite generous in portion is the Panucho de Pollo al Pibil, a
black bean stuffed tortilla topped with  citrus-achiote chicken, cabbage, pickled red onions and salsa habanera. 
Awesome and memorable dish and looking forward to my next visit.
author: Shashi J.

description:
UPDATE: still in love with this place (service location and food - ohhhh the food) but I just had to let you know that they have their own coffee now and it's yummy too!   So you don't have to cafetieria it over to Petes for the caffeine hit at the end of those organic crispy tacos!

FULL REVIEW:

You know when you write a review and you can select the number of stars - the description for 5 stars says "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" - thats just about as accurate an accounting of Nopalito as you'll find.

Now I can hardly leave it there... the reason I think its as good as it gets is because in a rare combination of great service and well prepared and original food Nopalito just stands out.

There are no mariachi, no dancing elephants, no views of Sidney Opera House.  Alas there is not even any espresso (they are very good neighbours to Peet's next door!)  The restroom is even a little trip away.  Still, the things that make for a lasting impression - outstanding food & service - all I can say is "Go-palito!"

Others can recommend specific dishes they have enjoyed.  Each and every time I have been there I have utterly enjoyed it all so... order what you want.
author: Stephen M.

description: This hot, modern and fresh Mexican restaurant in lower haight has a crazy wait. Fortunately, my party of four got there relatively early for the dinner hour and only waited 30 mins. I started off with a refreshing house margarita on the rocks. My party shared an order of ceviche, empanadas, and quesadilla con chicharron. We also shared our entrees of mole poblano con pollo, meatball, and carne asada. We finished the meal with dark chocolate, cinnamon paletas, or mexican popsicle. My memory is a bit foggy, but I believe I thoroughly enjoyed the meal. I only remember the dishes because I took notes :D  I'll definitely be back for a refresher if the wait isnt too crazy.
author: Jermaine R.

description:
legend has it that nopalito came along because the staff meals at nopa were so amazing that laurence jossel decided to give his staff their own restaurant. nopalito = little nopa. love!

and what a fantastic decision that was... nopalito makes delicious, hearty homemade mexican food your abuelita would be proud of. 

if you come to nopalito looking for your average run of the mill tacos, burritos, and enchiladas, you'll be disappointed. nopalito makes authentic regional mexican food with interesting spices and unique flavor profiles. it's also organic, local and sustainable, much like it's predecessor. compared to traditional mexican food, it's pricey, but the quality of the food makes prices quite reasonable. portions are incredibly generous.

while everything is good, i'm partial to their pork dishes. the carnitas are the best in san francisco. a little intimidating, because it's a huge hunk of meat but it's so incredibly flavorful and tender. the quesadilla with crispy pork belly is equally delicious, but if you have a pork quota, i'd go with the carnitas. 

the sangria changes based on what's in season. i've had a few versions, and they've all been delicious.
author: Jessica S.

description: great food at a solid price - everything i had here was super tasty - will definitely be back here - my favorite item of all was actually not the food, but a drink i ordered - definitely try the horchata - can't wait to go back!
author: Jaki L.

description:
I have only had take-out.

I ordered one pork tamale and one beet salad. Both were incredible. 

I am soo happy this place moved in right next to Delessio and Falettie, not to mention Bank of America and the DMV. Such a perfect balance of mundane, necessary and spectacular.. Spectacular being Nopalito and Delessio.

I can't wait to return and try the rest of the food. I am not expecting authentic Mexican food.. This is local, fresh, contemporary Mexican-Ish food and I love it.

I am sure they take a bit longer than La Taqueria, but this isn't La taquieria or Rubio's.

The peeps that work there are a little hipster and if you have read my review, you know how I feel about hipsters, but I still don't care the food is great.... well, the tamale and the beet salad. More to come...
author: Claudia O.

description:
Not bad, but i dont see what all the hype is about. waiting hours to get a table... or calling hours ahead and they tell you that your table will be ready within a window of time...  

anyways, i am a fan of the horchata.  def the best i have had in the city.  
if you are still thirsty try the blood orange citrus soda.

i had the carnitas, and i would recommend.  cooked almost to perfection.  they give you just enough of the fat on the meat and its crispy...mmmm.  it came with a good chile verde sauce.  

dessert, strawberry popsicle, just like the ones from those carts, but way better.

i tried a few of my friends entrees and appetizers.  the ceviche was good.  the carnitas soup was good.  the lamb...aaa...not so good.

if you can get a table, give it a try. and dont sit by the entrance, sf gets too cold for you to depend on those heat lamps.
author: Sean K.

description:
A lot's been written so I'll just toss in my 2 cents.  Food is good, not great.  Flavors are pretty good and the ingredients are high quality.  Prices are reasonable.

Sercice and hospitality a 5
Food 3.5
Overall 4
author: Al K.

description:
had a fantastic lunch here...

had the enchiladas mole....so damn good! 

valencia orange hibiscus drink had a lot of promise and was pretty good but i found it to be very watered down...

nice touch with the housemade cornnuts and the atmosphere is killer.
author: Mohammad G.

description:
One star for being open during the hours of 2-5pm when most establishments feel that I should not be hungry and/or should just be denied food. Also bonus points for having an outdoor, covered, heated patio in SF and having PARKING (though limited). 

Service was phenomenal. Ceviche was tasty. The tostada was OK - the shell was a bit chewy. Overall, the food was pretty good and I'm all ready to try it again!
author: Sarcastic T.

description: Despite the hype, this spot is just OK, though my mom can whip up better chilaquiles in her sleep and the torta de cerdo is a little on the greasy side. That being said, the good thing is that they don't "gringify" their menu, so you have tons of authentic dishes...
author: M M.

description:
Always on the look out for authentic, not slathered in cheese and sauce, Mexican food, I sauntered to Nopalito for an adventure. Initially I wasn't too hopeful about my experience because outside the entrance (which I had to search for) was a "sign up sheet" for a table, but no host/hostess to be found. Not sure if this was to emit a "hey we're so casual around here, we don't need that type of structure" attitude, but it was odd. Nonetheless, we signed our name and put a time and crossed our fingers someone would notice we were there. 

After about 20 minutes, we were seated by a cheerful gentleman. At this point in my eating career, I've given up being self conscious about the large volume of food I order when trying a new restaurant. I have embraced my inner fat kid. That being said, we proceeded to order about 70% of the menu to sample. 

Highlights definitely were the Totopos con Chile, the Gordita and the Taquitos. And the show stopper: the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharron. Who knew crispy pork belly was so life changing? Finally, skip the silly "Popsicles" they have for dessert....the free Mexican wedding cookies they give you are better.
author: Mary H.

description:
Absolutely delicious! Everything we had was flavorful and fresh. Loved their housemade beverages! The only disappointment was the little complimentary cookie at the end of the meal which lacked flavor and the sweetness I would like to end a great meal.
Service was attentive on our visit and we were lucky enough to get seated at a communal table right away.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
I've been to Nopalito 3 or 4 times now, so i feel I can give it a fair review.

First of all - the place is now extremely popular and they don't take reservations. You can call ahead to be put on the list - but that list gets long at peak times. The wait for a table on weeknights has grown to 45 minutes and this past Friday our party of four waited 90 minutes. While I can't blame a place for being popular - note that there is no bar to wait at and no other place to sit in the vicinity - so you may be spending a lot of time browsing the grocery store next door and drinking wine in the parking lot and trying to stay warm (which is what we ended up doing.) 

The food is quite good, obviously. Maybe the only Authentic-ish interior Mexican cuisine in the City. The food is not fancy but instead typical cantina fare like carnitas, polo mole, and birria.Yes a lot of taquería in town have these dishes, but the quality, flavor, and presentation here is more like what you would get in Mexico. The prices are reasonable considering the quality and novelty. 

One of my dining companions ordered beef enchiladas and she was presented with a plate of rather tough and flavorless carne asada and a little paper bag of fresh corn tortillas. That's it. That does not constitute "enchiladas" anywhere in Mexico I've visited, but maybe they serve a regional variation I'm not familiar with. In any case it was a disappointing dish. Another companion got the mole which just had a small leg and thigh. It was yummy, but I felt should have been a bit more.

Service was relaxed but decent. So I guess I remain torn on Nopalito. I love that there is a place to find these flavors in San Francisco, but the food has been inconsistent and waiting so long for a table is kind of a bummer.
author: David C.

description: The food was great.  We had the cerviche and the  little gems salad that had an amazing tart smoky dressing. The short ribs were very moist and a large portion with a beer flavored sauce.  The trout was excellent but there were too many beans served with them and they were one dimensional.. I love the spicy chick peas that were served with the drinks.  The service was mixed.  They were very good at taking the drink orders and describing the food but we were never offered dessert or coffee but were just given the check.
author: margaret r.

description: Went for the hundredth time early June. It's great food, although the quality has gone down since inception in my opinion. Last couple of meals seemed overcooked, a bit too oily. Maybe they're too busy and too much in their groove now. Anyway the food is spoiled by the pretentious attitude, especially at Broderick. Staff in Sunset is super nice and chill. Broderick - you stick your nose up at your own customers. Annoying. And then there's "oh we don't take reservations, but let me put your name on this special list. What time? How many in your party?" WTF? That's a reservation - that's exactly a reservation! If you take my name, time and number of people, then I arrive and you seat me from a list when it's my turn, that's a reservation. You feel the need to correct your customers and say it's not a reservation - that's just pretentious and d*uchy. Maybe my last visit. The food is slipping and you just love the smell of your own farts too much.
author: Bill W.

description:
Nice restaurant.  It bills itself as a sustainable local/organic mexican restaurant.  It isn't the kind of cheap, hole-in-the wall mexican place.  More of an upscale, trendy kinda thing.

That being said, the restaurant is awesome.  The decorations and layout is pretty snazzy, the waitstaff are all knowledgable and friendly, and the food is awesome but on the pricey side.  I went with 2 friends.  We got appetizers, drinks, and main courses.  The whole bill was like $70 prior to tip for lunch.

Totopos con Chile appetizer is pretty freaking awesome.  The carnitas were great.  The albondigas were just a plus/minus.
author: D W.

description: Gotta have the empanadas! Negro Modelo on tap too.
author: Stacy W.

description: This was a really good, white washed Mexican restaurant. The pozole was really good, but as of tonight it was truly pathetic. It was so spicy i couldnt eat it. The three pieces of nickle sized meat was laughable. The two fish tacos were good but for $11 i can and will pass from here on out. There is nothing authentic about this place, 100 percent whiteification. I'm completely over the gentrified bullshit that has engulfed San Francisco. This place puts the opa in SodoSopa!!
author: Ethan S.

description: Getting a table here was a disaster. Throughout the process and after we were seated the staff were short and seemed annoyed with everyone and everything. The chicken was good, the margaritas were great, but I don't know if I will go back.
author: Shanna T.

description: Had a pretty tasty brunch here. I can't remember exactly what I ate, but I left satisfied. It's decent.
author: Michael H.

description:
Carne asada was heavenly - juicy, tender pork cooked till it melts in your mouth and roasted (?) in a parchment pouch full of flavor!  Get an order of roasted sweet corn too, so sweet and each kernel still plump...mmhhmmm! Grab a homemade corn tortilla, throw in the corn, tear off some carne asada, wrap it up and prepare for a party in your mouth!

Sangria isn't shabby, nice touch with the frozen grapes, more refreshing than your regular white sangria.
author: Ellen L.

description: At first, I was extremely happy that finally, a Mexican place that served actual Mexican food had arrived in my neighborhood.  The first few visits were a bit revelatory in the flavor combinations and profiles, but lately, it's been more weird than good.  It's like the kitchen has lost focus on what made it so good in the first place and is now churning dishes by rote, forgetting the love and creativity that made it so exciting in the first place.  Food is still ok, but I really miss when they opened.
author: Nathan R.

description: Had empanda and carne aside, both were solid. Ordered a choke hold, interesting but not amazing. Overall would come back if I was in the neighborhood, It's a sold place but with so many solid placed in the city this just doesn't hit the 5 star mark, but it's good, if the wait isn't too too long. They do let you call ahead and put your name on the waitlist which can be a life saver on a weekend night.
author: Anne M.

description:
Maybe I'm more of a food truck or hole in the wall Mexican food kinda guy, but I didn't find Nopalito to be that great of a place.  

Quick review: the food was bland, the mixed drinks were awful(how does an alcoholic beverage have a bacon aftertaste?), the margaritas were good, the hostess was awesome, the host(or manager?) was kind of a dick, and the waitress and bartenders were awesome.

Here's my story for those who are interested:
I called in to put my group on the waiting list with the knowledge that we'd still have to wait around for a while even when we get there, but the hostess tried to do everything she could to accommodate us.  Once half a large table was available, the hostess seated us, thinking that the other group would leave within about half an hour or so.  Half of my group sat down and we ordered a Margarita pitcher and we were gonna wait until we could get the full table before we ordered our food, since we were there for a birthday.  The other group ended up staying and ordering their own pitcher, so the estimated half hour turned out to be TBA.  Instead of telling us that we would need to get seated somewhere else, the male host, told us that we would need to order and eat our food now even though only half of our group was seated or get up and wait.  So, we told him we don't mind getting up and waiting for a full table to be free, but we still had a nearly full pitcher that we would need to finish and we weren't allowed to take the pitcher outside.  So he left to "try" to figure it out and 10 minutes later a bigger table opened up and we were seated.

I guess my main complaint is that we were essentially being asked to get up for doing the same thing the group next to us was doing instead in reverse order (Ordering drinks before the food instead of vice versa).  

Anyway, it'll be first and last time I go to this place and it's not that much of a loss to be honest with you.
author: Joe N.

description:
Eating at Nopalito, I was squarely confronted with the good and the bad of my impending move back to San Francisco.

Good: utterly stupendous and generously portioned carnitas; excellent horchata. 
Bad: the woman at the next table wore a sweatshirt that said "Om is the peace inside you."

Your takeaway: Definitely get the carnitas because they were the best thing our table ordered.  Please leave your new age yoga sweatshirt at home.
author: Rachel D.

description: Delicious food and a great wait staff. No reservations though.
author: Joe P.

description:
Finally got to Nopalito, on a fairly quiet Monday afternoon (and it seems that, finally, the crazy initial excitement has worn off & it's easy to get a table without waiting...)

We decided to order some appetizers, then get some entrees, but quickly discovered that portions are * very * big, so we limited ourselves, but still ended up with a lot of food. The halibut ceviche starter was big, but so-so (very lime-y, and the fish was a bit chewy.) However, the carnitas and the tostada dish (our entrees) were excellent, The pork in the carnitas, in particular, was deliciously crispy on the outside, but delicate and moist inside. Again, the portion was large, and accompanied by generous helpings of tortillas and pickled vegetables. Service was very friendly and helpful.  All-in-all, recommended (except for the peculiar "beer bloody Mary" -- an odd concoction.) And we capped everything off with a chocolate popsicle. Very enjoyable!
author: donal c.

description: Delicious food.  Good for kids.  Great on a nice day.  Nice service.  Love the fish tacos.  Could do without the barking dogs outside the market next door.
author: Carl A.

description:
I'm surprised by some of the reviews.  I love Nopalito!

This is a great sit-down Mexican restaurant that is reasonably priced.  

Everything I ate here was so good including:
- Gordita (not the taco bell kind)
- Quesilla azul de hongas y huitlacoche (oyster mushrooms are tasty)
- Pozole rojo

Wash it all down with a Michelada.  AHHHHH, that's what  I call hitting the spot.
author: Lisa K.

description: This is one of those places that I give the highest rave of "Food Porn-oriffic". I had never been here before and am so, so glad we did. My husband and I came in for lunch and had the carnitas and the mole enchiladas. Unbelieveably YUM YUM. It's like getting the deliciousness of Mexican street food along with the quality of a high end restaurant without any of the pretentiousness. Prices are fair, portions are right on (Not too big, not too small), service is fantastic and friendly, and cocktails are delish (I had the killer bee, a smoky lemony mezcal cocktail). Oh yes, yes YES! Ahem.
author: Celeste R.

description:
This place is good, would definitely go back for the Carnitas like everyone said. It is price and they don't take reservations so for the overall experience including food, 3 stars. We had a party of 7, and 4 apps, 2 orders of chips and 7 entrees plus dessert later was just enough. They don't serve hard alcohol, but you can get $2.50 Tecate cans with lime, or this yummy drink that's beer mixed with tomato juice and seasonings. 

I had the chicken enchiladas, which were good, but the Carnitas is AMAZING! Definitely get that if you're going. Very fresh food, presentation is nice and the style (casual but cute and trendy) is great. Order their habanero salsa on the side if you like spicy (we ate them out of their habanerdo salsa last time!).

Good place for a date or small girls night out.
author: Melissa C.

description:
in a group of five, ordering entrees and appetizers and wine, only one dish out of all of them was better than ok.  There was nothing wrong with the food per se, its just that it was not anything that an everage cook couldn't outperform given an hour.  

The prices are not bad, but for 15 an entree, I still want something that rates as better than "not offensive".  It was fine.  Thats all any of us could say.  It was fine.  

The wait, however, was not.  An hour on a Friday for mediocre food?  The service was also, average.  No one was unpleasant, but we all got the sense they would much rather be elsewhere.  

The carnitas, however, were very good.  The goat, enchaladas, ceviches, etc., were simply somewhat filling.  No plans to go back, but if I got invited there with a group set on it, I wouldn't complain much either.
author: Michael W.

description:
One year later update: The tastiness has improved 100 fold. And the newish items on the menu are a delight.


Was too hyped for this place. The tamal was dry and the chicken quesadilla was unremarkable. I think the sauces were all tasty, but there wasn't enough of it to indulge my senses and know for sure. More tastiness needed. Good beers.
author: Sumi Y.

description:
Like its sister restaurant NOPA, this place was absolutely fantastic. We arrived promptly at 7:30 to put our names on the list. There were 15 parties ahead of us. I was a little nervous about the timing, but my friends said that on such a momentous occasion that it would be worth it.

I'm glad we waited. Not only were the staff incredibly nice, but the food was absolutely spectacular. It was all so incredibly fresh, and the spices were really wonderful. It was really unlike any mexican food I've EVER had. 

Hands down, once they get their to-go side going, I will probably eat nowhere else.
author: Kenny D.

description: Phenomenal food, incredible service. Very reasonable prices for high quality Mexican food. Came from Connecticut and would take the trip again just for this restaurant- you will be impressed.
author: Colby P.

description:
Came here at 7:30 on a sunday night and was told by the hostess the wait would be an hour and a half. Seemed pretty unreasonable to me, but she turned out to have over-estimated by about half, so it was a reasonable delay in the end.

The feel of the restaurant is great... casual, upbeat, and bright, but nice enough to not feel like a cafeteria. The service was fine, except that the waitress asked me if I wanted water and brought a bottle and one glass, where I would have expected her to also bring one for my date (or at least ask if he wanted one). 

Food was pretty hit or miss. I had the tamal, which I thought was pretty top-notch. the pork was really juicy and well-seasoned, but it didn't overpower the masa flavor. We also tried to blue corn quesadilla, which was bordering on BAD. First, the tortilla was way too tough (i had trouble cutting it with a steak knife). It was filled with mushrooms, including plenty of tasty huitlacoche, which gave the only interesting flavor in the dish. The main problem was that there seemed to be almost no cheese involved. Big disappointment. I think I'd give the place another try and order differently next time, since the carnitas and posole on other tables looked pretty good. All in all, the best thing we ate was the free little cinnamon shortbread cookie they gave us at the end. I'd go back for more of those.
author: Julia G.

description:
Wtf?  All this hype some some disappointing, mediocre food...  The tortilla chips left grease marks on my fingers and were pretty flavorless.  The quesadilla was good, but the ones at Papalote or Green Chile Kitchen taste better.  The service was pleasant, the decor clean and modern (like every new place in town).
Nothing exciting, and it ain't cheap.  Adios, Nopalito!
author: marie m.

description:
It was a cute spot to meet up with friends or have a quiet date night. THe decor and servers are all friendly with pretty good service.

The food was fast (unlike the wait) and it was decent. It wasn't too expensive and wasn't too amazing. The fish taco had presentation but lacked in flavor. I was just expecting more kick. The Sandia con Chile y Limón was soaking in lime juice for too long and it was a little overwhelming for a summer fruit dish. BUT, the Esquite Tostado con Crema y Queso was pretty damn good I'd have to say.
author: Gabrielle P.

description:
So you would think waiting an hour to eat here would suck, but when you get to drink tecate with lime and salt it goes much faster. big thumbs up there. we started with ceviche and fish tacos, both of which were quite delicious. my buddy actually thought the tacos were pork they were so moist and juicy, and that is a good thing. sturgeon, the pork of the sea? take that tuna! 
for entrees we split the carnitas, which were super moist with some great crispy, just what carnitas should be. the mole was not great we felt, a bit too bitter? but the chicken under it was super moist. and we had the goat stew, which was also very good. finished with popsicles, of which i had the chocolate cinnamon. so great. and lots more tecates of course. is it worth waiting a real long time for, maybe not. but for the price, it is pretty friggin great.
author: Rich B.

description:
Went here for the first time the other night with a large group of friends. The service was great and they helped us get tables so we can all sit together.

The food: started with the Totopos con Chile; tortilla chips, cheese, and lime--very tasty with a nice kick. Next was the Esquite Tostado; toasted sweet corn with queso fresco, chilie lime and pico de gallo; that was pretty kick ass as well. So then comes my Enchiladas Placeras; enchiladas stuffed with squash and potatoes and pan seared chicken breast. I was confused by this dish; I wasn't expecting the gigantic piece of chicken breast to be accompanying my enchiladas. The enchiladas were good, but the chicken was just plain, dry, and did i mention humongous?

All in all, it was an okay experience. If I went back, I think I will try the carnitas that some of friends had.
author: Joe C.

description:
It's truly a pity to see bad reviews and an average of 3.5 stars at this place.  There are positives and negatives about their reservation system, but as long as you get it you're golden.  Really how many places let people do drop in reservations anymore.  It's sad to say, but if you want to go out for a date, or do a spontaneous dinner in SF, you should have booked in advance.  This is why I like Nopalito's system.  It's smart and simple, but you actually have to think an hour in advance for food (which I have no problem doing).

Onto the food:
In a word excellent.  I've always been a foodie for latin cuisine (I happen to think I make the best pico de gallo) and Nopalito has it dialed.  The appetizers are in short yummy.  Seasonal Sangria, mmmm....  But what I love most is that they have goat stew!  There are few places that would serve anything but the usual, beef, chicken, lamb, and pork.  To see goat on the menu, is amazing.  After all Americans are the only prude nation that is prude sexually and nutritionally.  Nopalito follows a local in season menu, so things change through the year.  I'm also a huge fan of chicken mole, which they do beautifully.

You can consider Nopalito a fancy Mexican restaurant.  You really don't get the quality of food that they serve at a local taqueria, so you really can't compare the two.  But, you can compare it to other places like this restaurant (Regallito in the mission, Andele in SFO an OAK airports).  This is a class or restaurant like Delfina.  You can't put Delfina in the same class as Dominos would you?

So, appreciate creativity and you'll love this place.  Good service (hot waitresses btw), good food, and an awesome ambiance.

H
author: Mr. O.

description: Awesome Carnitas! Very nicely cooked. Try the chips too, they're great. And the strawberry popsicle!!! Yum.
author: A. A.

description: Had a great meal there. Fantastic Mezcal based cocktails, as well as delicious food. Amongst the four of us we tried the Ceviche, Empanada, Gordita, Rock Fish Stew (cant remember the name, starts with a B), and Carnitas. Highly recommended. Also very busy... not sure you can make reservations, but try.
author: Jack V.

description:
We had the following for dinner:

Totopos con Chile
Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón
Carnitas
Guiso de Pescado al Estilo Toluca

The only dish that merits the hype at Nopalito is the Carnitas. Other 3 left me wondering what the fuss was all about.  I absolutely love and adore Nopa so needless to say, I came away from Nopalito disappointed.

On the positive side, we had great service, the atmosphere/decor was casually nice, and liked their beer selections.
author: Amy Y.

description: We had several small orders & split them.  Good food but the service was very, very slow.  Went for lunch...an hour & a half is just too long for lunch.
author: Donna W.

description: Ah joy. It has been a while since I have gone out to dinner and had such an overall fabulous experience. It really is the human interaction that makes or breaks any experience for me. My girlfriend and I don't go out a ton, because she has celiac disease and I'm tellin' ya...it is kind of difficult to go somewhere you can trust! We felt very taken care of, especially by the adorable bartender, Tim. So dashing and genuine, (all the waitstaff are friendly, by the way!), and really thoughtful. The food is very good - fresh and creative - the drinks were fabulous. Yummy sangria and wow, the margaritas. We kept fighting over our "shared" glass/es. I just love this place. Nice work!
author: Nathalie P.

description: There's no classy way for a woman to eat a popsicle. There just isn't. So order that Cinnimon Chocolate Popsicle, leave your lady-like sophistication at the door, pretend no one's watching and just go at it like I know you'll want to.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I go out to eat to be people and not "dogs". No matter how legal they are in SF.  A customer scowled at me, when I asked to place the said dog on a leash.  NO Matter what you say, pets are not hygenic in an eating establishment. It is a public health risk.

Home to the $5 taco? Yes, local and organic. Whew if the pint during lunch was not 4.50, would not return.  Not for the underemployed set.

Cute setting, sheltered from the wind. Intriguing small and pricey menu.
author: One P.

description:
I love my mexican food and this place serves up some tasty creations that I have never had.  I have not tried everything, but what I tried was definitely fresh and cooked properly.  It's all about proper seasoning here and they hit the nail on the head.  I don't have too much detail as I only tried 4 things, but everything else looked like I should be ordering it.   

The place is pretty casual, but gets busy.  When you show up there is a waiting list, unless they can sneak you in at the bar.  I would prefer to sit at the bar since you can watch them cook.  Service is great and very attentive.  Pricing is very reasonable considering the level of quality and service.  

I should rate lower so less people go...

Bonus - they HAVE parking!  and you don't have to pay.

UPDATE:  came back and had the carnitas and veggie tamale - both are excellent.  Also had the popsicles which were wicked delicious.
author: Simon Y.

description:
I actually thought this place was pretty good.  The chips, the handmade tortillas and the pozole were just what I was hoping for.

My only actual issue was that I could get all three of the above down the street from my house for a fraction of the cost.

What that said, for Nopalito using organic and sustainable food, I think the prices were fairly reasonable.

Our waitress was really great, the place was clean and well decorated, and it was awesome sitting near the kitchen where we could see all the action.

I'd definitely go back.

Hint:  call before hand to reserve a spot on their wait list.  We called 20 minutes before we arrived and were sat maybe 10 minutes later
author: louda l.

description:
Nothing is mediocre about Nopas sister restaurant. I really love the space - its bright spacious - and has parking! We were a party of 8 and our server was really attentive and gracious. 
Pluses were
-the Sturgeon Fish Tacos
-Pork Belly Quesadillas
-Veggie Quesadillas
-Ceviche
-Veggie Tamales
-Blue Star Wheat on Draft - :)

Dont listen to the haters - -give this place a try!
author: Christian S.

description: What a great way to kick off a staycation!  We were tired and almost about to order in and watch battlestar galactica, then last minute decided to walk over a finally give this place a shot.  Everything about the evening was enjoyable.  The hostess was pleasant, as were all of the waitstaff.  Margarita's were understated and delicious, and the food made both of us happy.  Perfectly cooked, and spiced.  The Bacalao with capers and olives made my night, although I wish that the pickled jalapeno were diced and added into the dish rather than whole and on the side.  The empanada was a win as well, "a taste explosion" to quote our server!
author: Lauren M.

description: Dishes look great and are tasty, but a little too small and deep fried or rich for my taste. Be sure to get there early or be prepared to wait in line. Excellent service!
author: Rob S.

description:
So we finally got to try the place. Weekdays are muchesier to get in then weekends. 

Food is okay. A bit on the greasy side, although all we had was an array of appetizers. Gordita and Quesadilla were very good. Next time we will try the entrees, we got full off of the appetizers and called it a meal. Nice ambiance sitting outside. Good service, not the best mexican food although they have pretty authentic ingredients which are fresh. I would say that the wait is definitely not worth it, but if you call in ahead of time and get in you without a wait it may be worth it.
author: D M.

description: Recently went here on a Monday night. Is this Mexican food? I mean I've had my share both around the US and in Mexico and this place rocks. The chicken was super soft, like a warm hug. And that crazy salad with all the colors was beautiful, tangy and tasty! I could see this spot being a regular hangout if you lived in the hood cause it's pretty cheap for what you get. It's great to see a fresh take on standard fare with surprises mixed in.
author: Ketan A.

description:
I'm biased as I work next door, but still - 

Carnitas - as good as it gets (we're talking what the little old lady makes in the back of a store in the Mission), delicious salsa verde, and of course, their mind blowing homemade corn tortillas. 

Taco de Pescado Al Pastor - Very well seasoned, and perfectly balanced. 

Gordita - The best Pico I've had in a long time. 

Service is amazing, and the decor is very tastefully done.
author: Edwin M.

description:
Super fresh wonderful ingredients.
Super nice staff.
Cute atmosphere.
I just thought the flavors were lacking.  Not bad by any means, just not zesty or wow.

I'll def go back and check it out again though.

We got:
Chicken enchiladas w/ mole sauce
Pozole pork stew
Pork tamal
Fish tacos
Chips starter
author: Melanie C.

description: This is definitely a place I can't wait to return to! We ordered the panucho, empanadas, taquitos and the carnitas. They were all standouts, we were enamored and bf confirmed this was the closest he's gotten to El Paso Mexican food this side of the west! The owners of this establishment might not know what to do with a review like mine that raves about them by comparing their cuisine to the culinary likes of El Paso's greatest and infamous (see Chico's Tacos).
author: Jane K.

description: one of my favorite restaurants. everything on the menu is delicious, and spicy! 4 stars because the wait for a table is difficult, but absolutely worth it.
author: Katrina M.

description:
I love the restaurant Nopa, but I was not impressed by Nopalito. The interior is cute, but the bathroom is a walk outside and around the exterior of the building. This wouldn't be a problem, but it started pouring during dinner. Engineering flaw. 

There is only the option for beer and wine. The wine selection is limited, so I recommend the tecate with the salted lime--that hit the spot. 

My enchiladas were dry, but the apps were good. Average night out.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Mexican Food is such a 'Generic' Term! It is varied and complex as the country itself. That being said it is hard to find authentic dishes and choices in one spot. Nopalito is a great find, worthy of a visit or even as a destination!
I Had the Birria de Chivo, amazing! Goat on the menu is A rare find for any restaurant. Wife had the Pozole Rojo, also...awesome.
Service was attentive and accommodating. But we got there early. Went back later to buy some more chips and Cerviche to go and it was hopping.
Really a great 'Locals' Joint that is worth a try!
author: Sean O.

description: i can't believe i forgot to yelp this place.  Nopalito is a GREAT restaurant.  I love everything about it.  nothing more needs to be discussed than the carnitas.  the single best porkal offering i think i may have ever had.  they are so flipping good and I love carnitas. They are sinfully unhealthy, i mean everytime you eat them it likely takes a week off your life, but oh so worth it... now that i mention it i think i need to go back.
author: ari b.

description:
It's not bad, but it's not great either. 
Had some pescado - it was okay - nothing to remember about.
ceviche was okay. Atmosphere was cozy - except for these kids...seriously, leave them home :) I don't think I will go back - Green Chile few blocks away is way better :)
author: ji k.

description:
Eh. I could've gone to a taqueria and gotten the same thing.  Carnitas was over cooked.

Wasn't horrible, but wasn't that great either.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Not great.  Not horrible.  And the best part about it I think was the beer selection including the "Michelada" which was interesting but awesomely good at the same time.

The Totopos con chile were good but not great.  Just chips with seasoning and they came with cream to dip them in.  The black bean Tamale was also just OK.  It tasted too healthy and had no meat.  The Gordita was probably the best thing that we had but still wasn't amazing.

Probably wouldn't go back.  If I want Mexican I'd go to Little Chihuauhua.

Also, beware if you go before 6pm.  We went for an early dinner and there were more tables with children than without.  Not used to that in San Francisco.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I love love love Nopalito! I grew up with mom's homemade tortillas, tacos and pozole and this restaurant is the most authentic Mexican food I've ever had. I took my parents to dinner here and observed their facial expressions intensely as they tried each dish. There's no one who is a better judge than my mom who's been cooking mole her whole life. It's  one of the toughest dishes to master in all cuisine's, period. She gave the nod of approval and I've been raving about it ever since. I've had nearly everything on their menu and these are the dishes that stand out:

1. Carnitas (juicy on the inside crispy on the outside)
2. Tamale (Comes pretty darn close to my Tia Lupe's)
3. Crispy pork belly quesadilla (need I say more???)
4. Mole (perfect spice to nuttiness ratio)
5. Pozole (hangover cure according to my dad. It's a spicy soup with hominy, meat and about 15-20 different spices)
6. Beer with the tomato juice and lime

They're prices are very reasonable and they serve homemade tortillas. My only recommendation would be to offer another tamale flavor.  For the vegetarians out there a cheese + jalapeno would be nice. Or even a tamale with mashed potatoes inside or the hard-to-find SWEET tamales (raisons and pineapple), YUM! Needless to say, I'm happy to FINALLY have an authentic Mexican restaurant I can eat at when I can't eat my mom's!
author: Venessa M.

description:
I've got high standards for my Mexican grub; and Nopalito's could've actually pulled another star outta me, if I hadn't grown up in a city where I could pick up good, authentic Mexican food, CHEAP-- and at a drive-through.  (And we're NOT talking Taco Bell here, people.  I'm talking sizzling-fresh carne asada, heaped onto a mound of outta-the-fryer french fries, drizzled w/ cheese, sour-cream, guacamole, and salsa-- for $4.)  But this review isn't about those other places; it's about Nopalito's.  

And although 'lito's lacks a drive through, and I didn't notice any carne asada fries on the menu, it is mm-MMM good.  The food's well-portioned (in the middle of our subsequent food comas, we realized that Nopalito's entree plates are deceptively BIG), delicious (if the mole doesn't make 7x7's "100 things you've got to eat in SF" list next year, then I have to question their research team), AND-- believe it or not-- 'lito's keeps it real.  Not real like Taqueria Can-Cun street-style; but real like what I had at the sit-down restaurants while I was living in central Mexico.  What I'm saying is, even if it's not dirt-cheap; you get what you pay for here, in terms of quality AND quantity.

The wait for a table's reasonable (we waited maybe 15-20 mins for a table for two on busy a holiday weekend), the entire staff is super-professional (the hostess was great, the cooks were friendly and on-top-of-it, and the wait-staff was so attentive, we never even had to ask for our water glasses to be filled); and, hey, it's right next door to Faletti's, so if you feel like it, you can go next door afterward and stock up on some groceries so you can cook your next gourmet meal at home :)
author: E R.

description: When my partner in crime and I needed a delicious hangover fix, this was the stop.  We have since moved to separate cities, but Nopalito remains her number-one craving.  I am not quite as enthusiastic as she, but let me say that after a night of hard drinking and general mayhem, nothing hits the spot like the progression of fried garbanzos, to totopos, to either a torta, chicharron quesadilla, or carnitas.
author: Nick B.

description:
Overall great place.

Very authentic and well done food.  I worked for a year in a Mexican restaurant owned and operated by a family from Guanajuato, Mexico. 
 
The chicken soup and carnitas at nopales were delicious. 

Friendly service.

I called ahead and didn't have to wait for a table.

The volume of chatter was a little louder than my father liked, but he still enjoyed his time there. 

If you like authentic mexican food (good beer prices too) check out Nopalito.
author: Daniel G.

description: I really can't get enough of this place. I love the chicken mole, the carnitas, the totopos (though don't get them to go.. they will turn soggy), the empanadas. I could go on.  The wait to get into the restaurant is long at times, but they have take out that's always pretty speedy!  Oh and the cookies they give you at the end of the meal. I wish they'd make them larger. Love 'em.
author: Erica L.

description:
For what Nopalito goes for, the restaurant deserves 5 stars.  

There was a 30 minute wait on a Cold Tuesday night, but it is a good popular restaurant in SF - such is too be expected.

Sat at the bar overlooking the kitchen which was a fun experience.  The $4 bowl of chips is a great starter, as are the quesadillas.  

For the main we had the Goat stew and the Carnitas; both were amazing and possessed a lot of flavor rarely seen in most Mexican food.

Service was prompt and friendly.  

The drinks are good, but a tad pricey.  I highly recommend the Sangria.   

I would skip the Popsicles.  

Ambience is different, nothing like a Mexican restaurant.  It has the ambience actually of the grocery store adjacent to the restaurant.  If I were to make a suggestion, I might add a tequila only bar that carries higher end tequilas; but that may impede the process of turning tables quickly.

As to the reviews saying the food took a long time, they were mistaken, or there on an off night.
author: Jack S.

description:
Best in class.

We were bold enough to try Nopalito on cinco de mayo. Called at 6:15, told them we'd be there at 6:45, and we waited maybe 10 minutes for a table.

With every dish that we had, I had the same feeling-- oh, this is what it's supposed to taste like-- carnitas, quesadillas, and carne asada. Even the nachos. Love the corn tortillas, too. 

My only beef was that the tamal was dry and not all that flavorful: tamal Enchilado de Queso y Puerco.  Service was efficient and friendly.  Prices are very fair for the quality ingredients that they provide.

If you're looking for the typical tex-mex gut buster burrito or combo plate, this is not the place to go.
author: Michael S.

description:
so, so good. my party consisted of 7 people and we paid 25 each (this included drinks, appetizers, main courses, tax and tip). its great quality mexican food; definitely not your standard taqueria (nothing wrong with those, tho). the free chips they give you are unlike those at any other mex restaurant! and the guac is so good.

there arent a lot of veggie options, but the staff is friendly and accomodating.
author: Tanya S.

description:
anyone who has given this place anything less than 5 stars must be nuts.

the service here is on a different level. we were asked 4 times while we waited for our table if we wanted drinks and they happily explained their cocktail list.

our server was the single best waitress i have ever had.

the ceviche, nachos, chicken with mole, and tamal were all unbelievably delicious...

...but the carnitas; it's like god is in their kitchen.

go here! or don't, so i don't have to wait as long for my pork
author: David O.

description:
My two dinner experiences there have been wonderful.

All the servers and the hosts greeted me with a smile and hello right away, which I can appreciate is hard to do when waiting tables and being so busy.

Pluses:
- Nice staff
- honest ingredients, fresh and healthy
- Tecate w. lime & salt for $2
- Fair prices
- The little cookies they give you at the end of the meal are DELICIOUS!!!  And made onsite.

I left feeling satisfied, not stuffed.  The chicken was sooo....moist and flavorful.  Love the pozole, the mole and the taquitos.

I most definitely will be back.
author: Yelper H.

description:
Very Mediocre. We have the Taquitoes (eh), the carnitas (meat with lettuce and salsa..boring) and the empenada. How the entire lacked flavor was astounding. 

Would not go back. Tommy's represents better value and better food.
author: Brooks D.

description:
How can you go wrong with a $2.50 can of Tecate? It is like I am back in AZ at Dos Gringos where the Coronas flow for a meager $2 a bottle. The Tecate was even served with a sea salt covered lime, what more could a girl want (well, maybe a margarita- damn those liquor licenses)?! 

From the hostess to the fried garbanzo beans and free petit fours at the end, Nopalito was a great dining experience. I thoroughly enjoyed everything we ordered and basically licked the plate clean. Between the four of us we devoured the ensalada, taco de pescado, gordita, panucho de pollo, pozole rojo, and enchiladas. We also started off with a perfectly seasoned batch of guacamole and finished with multiple plates of Cinnamon spiced wedding cake petit fours due to it being my friend Kelly's birthday. 

We had a great time and would highly recommend calling ahead to put your name on the list. I would not recommend however, the red wine. It was too warm for my taste and served in a terracotta cup (cool idea just didn't work for me- I'll stick to the Tecate!).
author: Megan M.

description:
I don't get why this place gets such great reviews. I was very excited about going there, but nothing was even close to being good, let alone exceptional. Chips WAY too thick, guacamole was terrible (seemed thinned out and flavorless)' salsa was so salty it was impossible to eat. Ceviche fish was mushy/flavorless and floating in a sea of tomatillo salsa that had a harsh flavor. My Fish tacos were over spiced sporting one piece of small flavorless white fish coated in too much chili powder and dropped on a corn tortilla.  
Even the margaritas were terrible (though the explanation was plausible...limes were on the sour side and they used agave and probably not enough of it to get the right balance). The only redeeming thing was our server who was smart and attentive. 
But the food was nothing to write home about and I can't find one reason to go back.
We travel to a Mexico often enough and the anticipation of high quality authentic food was definitely not met.
author: Debbie J.

description: Since my friends mentioned Nopalito, I checked it out with a girlfriend.  The tequila selection was grand.  The chips were good.  The food was good, but no wow factor.  This place would be good for groups.
author: Sonia M.

description:
Just popped in for a quick bite of cheese tamale and a gordita and Man Alive! was it tasty.  The crunchy chick pea starter and a cool and refreshing Hibiscus and Blood Orange drink were delightful as well.  I can't wait to go back and make my way down the menu because it all sounded YUMMY!  

It was great to see some familiar faces from their other place around the corner too!  The LOVE has been put in to this place and it comes through in many ways but most importantly in the food!
author: Chard M.

description:
Actually it was more than 3 stars. I say 3.5 stars.
Food - 4 stars. Unique tasty Mexican food.
Service - 3 stars.
author: t t.

description:
Top 100? Really? 

I just don't get it. The chicken mole was pretty good. Everything else was mediocre. I was starving, and didn't finish the lamb dish I ordered.  Everything we ordered was recommended by the waitress (lamb, chicken mole, cerviche, and a blue quesadilla with (I think) mushroom 

I heard rave reviews about the flavorful sauces, but found they were just not good flavors. 

The Magnolia brewed beer was cold and tasty!

PS- the waitress was super sweet, but seemed overwhelmed. I would NOT describe the service as attentive. Maybe they were understaffed that night?
author: Susan D.

description:
It's quite funny about all the reviews of Nopalito.  Yes, it's amazingly good food, the reason why....??  It's actually not for all the reasons reviews/patrons probably think.  It's because it's actually "real" Mexican food.  The way it is truly prepared in Mexico and not in the Mission district.  For all those burrito lovers and heavy lard lovers need not apply here.  Nopalito suprises most people because they are doing it right, and not a bastardized version of Mexican food. 
If you like and enjoy real Mexican cuisine, then definitely Nopalito should be on the top of your culinary list.
author: Maria N.

description: Sure, it's not authentic or whatever, but it's super tasty.  I like it mucho more than NOPA.
author: Henry A.

description: I absolutely loved this place! We just went today (Sunday) around 4:00 and only waited about 10 min. We still had the lunch menu because the dinner menu doesn't come out until 5:00 but the food was still amazing! It was a group of three of us, we ordered the quesadilla Chicharon, totopos, cheese and green chili tamales, carnitas, and three drinks. The total came out to about $60. The quesadilla was pretty delicious but a tad greasy, the tamale my husband said was really good (he's very picky!) , the totopos lived up to all the yelp hype and the carnitas, which included fresh tortillas and a type of coleslaw were juicy and tender without all the fat and grease you usually find in Mexican restaurant carnitas. The totopos comes with a delicious lime sour cream to dip it in which we also put on our carnitas. The service was excellent! I read a lot of reviews on here with unhappy customers because of the service so I was skeptical about what type of service I would find but our waitress Mary was very attentive and gave us lots of advice about the amount of food we should order and what type of taste we should expect from each dish. The rest of the staff looked in on us as well even though Mary had us handled. I can't wait to go back again! Definitely worth trying :D
author: Cristina G.

description: The carnitas are one of the best things I've eaten in San Francisco. Call ahead to make a reservation.
author: Daniel C.

description: The carnitas was amazing and the ceviche and chicken tamal were also very good.
author: m t.

description: Great contemporary Mexican cuisine. I little on the pricy side, but the food is excellent. The carbitas portion size is big enough for two, and the flavor is bar none. I recommend their sangria, which has candied jalepenos. I have tried to replicate the recipe and theirs is certainly worth trying
author: Benjamin M.

description:
One Star for the drink concoctions - excellent hibiscus/cran, horchata and thick chocolaty/chile amazingness.

One Star for the good faith effort on being green - looks like old hardwood floor adorns the base of the bar area, cloth napkins, recycled plastic seats, etc.

One Star for fresh made corn tortillas/chips (why is this so hard to find in a city with such awesome mexican food)?

The food is definitely made from local, fresh and delicious ingredients, but the execution is mediocre at best.  Spices lacking, too greasy in some cases and to dry in others.  

This place it not Nopa, or a "Little Mexican Nopa"

Also, something feels wrong paying the medium/high prices for mediocre tasting food and at the same time looking at the back of the DMV...  I'm just saying...
author: David F.

description:
Went here for lunch.  The food and service were great.  Some posters have mentioned expectations - I think that's a great point.  Nopalito is not a taqueria - ingredients, preparation & creativity are higher, portions smaller, and the food is not greasy or heavy on sauces.

For haute cuisine (grass fed beef in the tacos) it's cheap.  The mole is the best I've ever had.  Refried beans, house made lime sherbet popsicle and horchata were also standouts.
author: Stefan A.

description:
We went there for lunch on a Saturday and the overall experience was pretty good.

Gordita de Picadillo - Great.
Panucho de Pollo al Pibil - Good.
Carnitas - Good, but a little too fatty for us.
Enchiladas de Mole con Pollo - So so, mole tasted like sweet chocolate sauce.

The service was very friendly and attentive.  The only drawback for me is they don't have wine glasses.  I don't enjoy drinking wines from a small ceramic cup.
author: TopCat W.

description:
I really like this place.  The food is good and my husband and I have had great experiences the two times we ate here.  The first time was at lunch sometime after the grand opening of the restaurant in 2009.  I found the prices to be a bit high at that time but I was eager to try it.  I was very hungry so my enchiladas (you don't get rice & beans like at a traditional Mexican restaurant) did not fill me up.  However, I stopped caring how hungry I was when two reality stars from Top Chef sat at a table about 5 inches from us.  (I get star-struck really easily.)  We struck up a conversation about the current seasons's Top  Chef contestants.  Now, I'm mentioning all of this because we had excellent service that day.  Coincidence?  Read on.

The second time we came here was on my birthday, just 2 weeks ago.  We came for dinner.  The service was great and the waitress was very attentive.  I have a very sensitive taste for spicy foods -- btw, why does every restaurant nowadays use chipotle for everything? Okay back to Nopalito -- the waitress offered to tell me which selections they could make less spicy so that I could enjoy my meal.  (Normally I just chug water but if you get bad service, you don't get much refilled water.)  They refilled my water glass constantly so I was a happy camper.  Anyway, we ordered the Taquitos to start.  I thought they were really full of flavor.  I ordered the Empanadas.  For a food item that is normally greasy, I thought they did a good job.  I couldn't even finish my plate!  I didn't know I was ordering two large empanadas. My husband ordered the Carnitas, probably the best item on the menu -- I tried them and YUM!  I had the Sangria, and it was VERY flavorful and delicious.  Mmmm.  We decided we're coming back to share Carnitas and Sangria.  I love trying new items but their Carnitas sang to me!  P.S.  I'm half Mexican, so I sort of know Mexican food ... ;P
author: Gina G.

description: This is great mexican food which loses a 5 star from me only because their menu isnt very large. But the food is excellent and the prices are fantastic, Id say its great for lunch and a must try at least once.
author: Ash S.

description: The food was fresh and enjoyable, I would probably say 4 stars. Definitely a star down based on value, I simply found it overpriced. Nothing transcendent going on here with flavor explosions, etc. Always busy, so understandable that they charge what they do, I just won't be in a rush to return.
author: m m.

description:
So far I love this place but I've only gotten take out twice, so I  might not be the most informed.  My first bite of the chicken tostada was to die for, and I had a craving for it so I went back again and also ordered the tamale.
The flavors are intense and interesting, with the right amount of crispiness (for the tostada).  Mmmmmm, I can't wait to go back and try something new.
author: Pam R.

description: The best Mexican food in San Francisco, all made fresh. Call an hour ahead to get your name on the waiting list. Food and presentation is just amazing. Horchata is perfect. Highly recommend the tortilla chips appetizer, pozole, carnitas and albondigas. Chocolate popsicles are a chocolate-lover's dream.
author: Brenda G.
