description: The carnitas was a tad under-seasoned, but was otherwise cooked to perfection. The star of our dinner was the duck mole. Appetizer: Totopos con chile (awesome). Drink of the night: pomegranate/ jalapeño sangria (that's right). Excellent service. Will. Be. Back...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
The food to me was light and healthy.

We only ordered a few appetizers and they were perfect portion for two people.  We could try different things without pushing too much onto our stomach.

Parking was easy just in the garage of the plaza.  And it's not far from golden gate park so it would be a nice place for something good and healthy.
author: Ile F.

description:
Woohoo!  I just found a happy place today.........

and they fed me

 A Tamale - THE most amazing tamale I have had north of the border
A gordita - a phenomenal stuffing inside a house made corn tortilla
A Quesadilla - FAR superior and removed from the common taqueria quesadilla
And Carnitas so amazingly spiced and braised........

more than enough food for 30.00.  

AND, it was phenomenal.  AND it was great value.  AND the atmosphere is casual sans pretense.  AND it ain't a taqueria!  

'tis love, 'tis love
author: Roger M.

description: Great selection of drinks and awesome food.  Just put you're name on the list and go grab a drink at the bar.  The wait usually isn't as long as quoted.
author: Jay R.

description:
Lotta hype from a neighborhood local, and it actually came through.  Great tortillas to wrap up our steak enchilada dish - lotsa meat, and tasty ($15).  The pork tamale small plate was also great at $5.  Beer selection was eclectic - next time I'll stick to a Negro Modelo or a Bohemia, as the pricier unique beers (Mission Ale, and Death and Taxes Black Beer) did not really justify the extra few bucks in my opinion. 

We went on a Sunday night at 6:30, and it was full, but we only had to wait about 5 minutes.  Our friend says it is always full, and the wait is usually a lot longer (no doubt because they serve up a great menu in a nice simple atmosphere).  

Our waitress was nice and well intentioned, and that counts for a lot.  Her knowledge of the wine and beers was a bit suspect, however.  I'm thinking she must be new and just learning the menu (and this is not a 5 star experience, so one shouldn't expect a full on sommelier).  

When they brought out the food, one of the dishes was wrong, but they corrected the problem in under three minutes, bringing out the right dish with a smile and an apology...  

I will be going back...  Soon...
author: CityFish L.

description: AMAZING margaritas and AMAZING carnitas.....what else do you really need to know??
author: Dan L.

description:
OUTSTANDING. I took some foreign guests for lunch, they were unfamiliar with Mexican food. We were all blown away. It was really fun to see them discover the new flavours.

Watermelon salad was unbelievably good, and might have been the star of the show in my opinion. 

And the popsicles were really fun !

Easy parking and the call-in waitlist were the icing on the cake.
author: Dee O.

description:
As mentioned, this place is in my 'hood, and I've been back a few times (though somewhat reluctantly). 

The fish taco is tasty, as is the chorizo torta (get the green - it's a little spicy). I also tried another soup, the caldo, and it was pretty bland. 

So, where on one hand I see that the Nopalito folks are attempting to provide patrons with interesting and authentic Mexican cuisine options, I would have to agree with other reviewers that the portions are too damn precious; a veggie friend said she left starving. Yes, hungry! And - heaven forbid! - if you ask for salsa, you'll get a little scoff (from an otherwise very pleasant waitress) and, if you're lucky, they'll provide you with a tiny cap full of salsa (not sure if they realize, but tomatoes and peppers are sort of cheap - you'd think they'd be giving it away or something). 

But (!) I do love their beverages -  the serving pitchers of ice tea and the handy bottle of simple syrup? The horchata? And the canned Tecate? Oh, and the torta - yes, that was yummy, as were the homemade chips and  the citrus salad made with grapefruit, blood oranges and salty Mexican cheese. 

Either way, a friend blasted me for my previous two star review and it's not like I'm looking for another Popeyes outlet in the neighborhood (though I do love their biscuits), so here I am, upping my review to three stars...though I still wish they'd loosen things up a bit and be a little more generous with portions and spice.
author: Chrissy L.

description: WOW!  I brought my girlfriend here for dinner and we had an AMAZING MEAL!!  If you like spicy foods you'll love Nopalito!  We loved everything we ordered!! Make sure you call in advance for a table or you'll be waiting for a while!
author: Bobby P.

description: After an excruciating wait, I swore this place would get no more than two stars from me. However, the food was good. Really good. I wasn't as impressed by the carnitas as everyone else, but I LOVED every appetizer we got. The carne asada was delicious as well. Margaritas were incredibly yummy. The hostess isn't particularly great at handling disgruntlement and apportioning tables - a problem when the wait exceeds 2 hours.
author: Anonymous F.

description: There have been some really stellar reviews for this place... and I don't wanna burst your bubble.. but i"m going to tell it how it is.  First off, this place is tiny and in SF and popular.  So hence no reservations.. makes it a tad difficult.  They have a call in wait list.  So I call at 5 pm to be on the "wait list" for 7 pm.  They tell me that I need to come at 7 pm with my whole party and then thy'll tell me how much longer we have to wait... I just don't see the point of that.. the point is so we Don't have to wait?.. anyway so we were extra early and as promised, they did have our table ready about 10 min after 7 pm.  Unfortunately, our whole party wasn't there yet.. hence we could not sit down.. =(... minus 1 star.. they came after another 10 min or so.. and we also had 2 people in our party said they were going to be late so we did not assume they would need to sit down for dinner...  Getting seated and ordering took so long due to the very very slow service.. that by the time we Just ordered our meals, the other 2 people were here already ready to leave for dessert..  What's worse is that they would not accommodate the other 2 people even if we said we would squish our whole party on the bench and only requested 1 additional chair.  I saw plenty of chairs lying around but the manager refused to give us one...mind it was well past prime dinner time already.. like 8:30 pm.. OK.. minus 1 star.   onto the food.. their lemon ginger lemonade was OK.. a bit toooo gingery if you ask me.  the chips were actually decent and kind of unique tasting.  Seems like they are double fried chips coated with some salsa sauce topped with good cheese and sourcream.  The entrees:  the mole was NOT good.  It tasted Burnt to me ! mole does have some elements of burnt chocolate, cinnamon and dark flavors.. but this one literally tasted like they burned the sauce.  the rice had absolutely no flavor at all.. it was SO bland i had to add a ton of salt for it to taste like anything remotely good... the chicken was OK.. donno why they kept the soggy skin n it.  at least if the skin is on the chicken, it should be crispy.  The lamb was so dry!... the sauce was OK though.. however it did not make up for the small portion of lamb or the dryness. minus 1 star.. in addition, our waitress wasn't the most pleasant either.. she hardly came to check on us and took forever to take our orders and to give us our check.  The fact that we had a child at the table probably didnt' help the situation either.  All in all, the only saving grace for this place was the delcious complimentary cookies at the end of the meal.. otherwise, I don't think I"ll be coming back here for mexican.. i'll go to the taqueria down the street for a 1/4 of the price. !
author: Margie C.

description:
So I went to Nopalito this past saturday with my sis. This place does a strange twist with mexican food. Im usually used to the taco trucks back at home but good impressions set in.  We started off with their chips and salsa...man that was heaven.  Freshly made salsa where the chips had some personality (colored with sides of cheese, lime, and sour cream).  We started drinking margaritas.. YES it wasn't weak.  But then i had to get my 'darker than black' beer fix which would be called "Death & Taxes"... good stuff there folks.   We started ordering some actual food where most of the names were in Spanish. Lost in translation, we ordered chicken quesadilla, corn tostada, carnitas, and some really good green tamales (I am really killing it here so make sure u check out their lovely menu with detailed explanations).    Pretty much everything we ordered ended up being fantastically divine....o yes i said that.  Only thing I hated was their chile fruit cheese salad... I tried my best to eat it but my palettes didn't swing that way.    Lastly we ordered cinnamon fudgesticks... wow dark coco and cinnamon, it's monster (either you like it or don't).     I would like to come back and try some of their fish dishes... i hear its really good.  Great place and vibe was good!!
Next time for sure...
author: R K.

description:
The food is good as well as the service. Desert was not bad. 

I will be coming back.
author: James R.

description: Always Good!  Gordita and Blue Corn Veggie Taco's are the best!  Would love to see them add less pickled cabbage to things but overall great!
author: T W.

description:
The only good thing about spending a miserable hour and a half of your life at the DMV is that afterwards, you can reward yourself with an amazing lunch across the street at Nopalito and not feel guilty or like an alcoholic for drinking sangria at noon.

The servers are consistently so friendly and attentive and make dining there an absolute pleasure. I love the fried garbanzo beans that they start you out with and almost everything I've had there is really good.  

The meatballs deserve the biggest gold star but I also enjoyed the panucho de pollo (a tortilla stuffed with black beans stuffed tortilla, citrus-achiote chicken, cabbage, pickled red onions and salsa habanero. If you're like me and cilantro-adverse, skip the ceviche, but if you don't mind the herb, you might like it.

Even if the DMV isn't on your mandatory to-do list, Nopalito definitely should be.
author: Cher E.

description:
Oh boo. Such a disappointment. I had heard such good things about this place, so perhaps I experienced it on an off night, but it must have been a WAY off night. 

I went with three friends for our monthly dinner outing.  We waited over 45 minutes for a table on a MONDAY night (which is fine, except that I SWEAR they seated another party of 4 ahead of us when we were next on the list---also a forgivable oversight except that 50% of our party was visibly pregnant---the pregnant ladies just want their food, damnit!).  We ordered three apps (did I mention two of us are pregnant?), including the totopos con chile (basically soggy chips with a meager sprinkling of cotija cheese), chips and guac (not on the menu, but pretty good), and the quesadilla azul de hongos (basically a folded over blue corn tortilla with under-seasoned mushrooms and a hint of cheese).  Had we left it at that, I would have given the place a C+. But it declined from there... 

Then there were the entrees.  First of all, it took almost 45 minutes AFTER the apps for them to bring out the entrees, which seems a bit ridiculous in such a small place.  Amongst the four of us, we ordered the Enchiladas, the Pozole, the Pescado, and the Barbacoa. Let me break it down: 

1. Pozole: this rated a solid C. The chips that come with it are too big to really put in your soup like proper Pozole. There was a decided lack of meat in the dish, and it overall seemed kind of lackluster. 

2. The Pescado: a small-ish piece of fish that was probably still the best of the entrees, but nothing special. 

3. The Enchiladas: terrible. Or at least terrible if you're expecting traditional enchiladas.  Here's how they come: two dried out, bland "enchiladas" with no sauce, barely a hint of queso fresco, and spartanly "filled" with potatoes and carrots (nothing else).  But seriously, NO sauce (the tortillas were slightly red in color, so maybe they had sauce at one point), and none of the melted cheese that makes enchiladas so delicious.  The chicken breast that comes with the enchiladas is off to one side, completely separate from the enchiladas. The enchiladas themselves were luke-warm and super dry. Ugh. 

4. The Barbacoa: My poor friend who ordered the barbacoa! It sounds so great in theory, but it comes as this completely disjointed dish. There is this stew bowl on one side, then some other random sauce, and then the banana leaf with lamb inside. But when my friend opened the banana leaf, she found a whole mess of bones and fat inside.  Not a whole lotta lamb.  So she asked the waitress if this was normal, to which the waitress replied, "Well, all of our meat is really fatty which it what makes it tender.  As for the bones, sometimes there are a lot of bones, sometimes there aren't." To her credit, the waitress offered to bring my friend something else.  So my friend swapped the barbacoa for the enchiladas. Oops. 

I really wanted to like this place, and Michael Bauer's review gave me such high hopes! Alas, I'll probably give it one more try, but the first meal there was so utterly disappointing that I don't think it will make it on my top 20 list, as I had hoped.
author: Bess K.

description:
Pros:  Interesting, fresh, Mexican dishes, parking lot, and you no longer have to wait like when it first opened.  

Cons: If you are going for taqueria style Mexican you wont like the choices or the prices
author: John A.

description:
Best dessert in SF to date -- Nopalito's vegan dark chocolate cinnamon popsicle. Wow. Amazingly rich and delicious. I crave one everyday now. 

The rest of the menu is stellar too -- everything from the sturgeon fish taco to the chicken mole. Delicious, fresh, flavorful, and really memorable.

The only thing that was a bit disappointing was the wait . . . about 30 min on a Sunday night.
author: E. S.

description: I have only been here twice, but both times the food was amazingly delicious. The fact that the use local, sustainable, organic ingredients (grass feed beef, etc.) is certainly a bonus. The house margaritas are quite tasty too. And the staff has always been very nice and accommodating. I'm a big fan and will definitely be back many times.
author: andrew c.

description:
Two stars for using quality, organic, sustainably grown ingredients, one star for being in my hood.  

Minus one star for lacking flexibility.  My boyfriend wanted to order an entree (I think a quessadilla) with chicken, but he couldn't subsititute the pork, only the enchillada could he get with chicken.  I'm a fairly picky eater, so not being able to order a dish as I like is negative for me.

I ordered a soup with vegetable and chicken consomme.  It was quite tasty.  healthy, yet filling.  It had a smoked chile that I could squish to release more spice.  It came with three delicious handmade corn tortillas.

I asked for a salsa on the side, and it wasn't very good, but apparently they have about 100 to choose from, so I'd like to try more.

So there is one other star to account for.  Well i gave it three vs. four because on my first visit, it lacked that 'je ne sais quoi'.  The portions are small, and they don't bring out chips or salsa unless you order them, which i don't think is a bad thing considering all the food waste that typically happens at a restaurant.  The Horchata was tasty, yet overly sweet.  The service was sweet enough to forgive not being very prompt.  

I'm not yet convinced enough to declare myself a fan, but I'm intrigued enough to try this place again (I have fait in the owners, based on being a huge fan of it's high quality, albeit more pricey, older sister, NOPA)
author: Sarah G.

description:
My roommates have been talking about this place for a while and finally got a chance to experience what Nopalito had to offer

We had to call ahead to get on a waiting list, which took about an hour.  That's understandable for a place that doesn't take reservations.  Plus it does not have the biggest dining room, but don't let that take away from its cuisine.

Our waitress greeted us with a smile which is always pleasant, upon drink requests I ordered the Horchata which was quite tasty.  Different than other horchatas i have had in the past where there was a strong cinnamon flavor.  My roommate got the Grapefruit-Piloncillo which was light and refreshing.

For starters, they unfortunately ran out of the Ceviche which is apparently amazing.  We got the Esquite Tostado con Crema y Queso, which is pretty much corn and salsa.  It was very very fresh and tasteful.  we also got the Quesadilla Roja con Chicharrón, which is a fancy quesadilla with pork belly and jack cheese.  Soo good.

For an entree i had the Cecina Enchilada con Rajas y Ejotes which is basically steak fajitas but with numerous amount of spices and herbs.  I tried some of the Pozole Rojo which is a stew with pork and vegetables, now if you like hominy i suggest you get this b/c there is a butt load of it in it.
author: Dustin K.

description:
It was a cold and gloomy day.  After working endless hours on our Halloween costume my boyfriend and I were in search of a late lunch.  Our favorite restaurant in San Francisco is Nopa, so we decided to try Napolito out. 

-A great location, with plenty of parking too.  A plus since parking is so difficult at Nopa.  
-When entering, I was greeted by the waitress and she was very nice.  It was 455pm, and I told her how much I wanted to order off the lunch menu (which ends at 5pm).  She told me not to worry and take my time to order, that lunch would be no problem.  I thought that was very kind of her.
-I love the extension of the building.  I like that there are heated lamps which is suitable for the cold gloomy days in San Francisco.  Sitting and eating watching the rain fall.
-We ordered the Almond Horchata, torta, and the machaca.The almond horchata did not taste like a horhcata.  It tasted like a nutty soy milk.  I thought it was good, but I was expecting more cinnamon.  The torta came with fries that were very fresh.  The torta was very delicious.  The machaca was recommended by the waitress.  It came with black beans and the egg mixture with shrimp you eat with a corn tortilla.  I thought it was light and tasty. 
-Overall, I thought nopalito was good.  I can't say that the food was as good as Nopa.  But, you can't expect nopalito to be on that level.  It has a more laid back feel to it.  I plan to come back and try there other dishes like the totopos and end with some blue bottle coffee.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Food was well prepared and tasty, but I would only give this place 3 stars because:

1) Menu: first impression: SMALL and fancy-sounding.  Don't get me wrong, I like fancy (Gary Danko is one of my favorite).  So I was willing to see how their fusion-Californian spin would turn out. I was not entirely impressed.  I got the Totopos, Tamal de Frijoles etc., and the Mole Poblano.  Totopos = overpriced chips; Tamal = dry and bland, I have had better from the Civic Center tamales truck; and Mole = tasty but not good enough to write home about.  

2) Price and portions: I do not feel like I got my money's worth.  Portions are small, which is fine if the food is uber-fantastic but per point #1 above, it wasn't. So I was kinda annoyed at the prices.

3) Over-hyped.  I live above this restaurant.  I come home everyday to see tons of people crowding around in front of Falletti's and Peet's waiting for a table. Now that I have tried the food I can honestly say I would never wait as long as these people do.  The guy who manages the waiting list (short, dark hair, I think he manages the place), not very friendly and kinda stuck up.  Please, take that stick out of your bottom.

Decor is very nice, restaurant is very pleasing to the eye.  But, I'm there to eat, and my mouth and stomach both vote to not go back, even if it is convenient as hell to eat there when my lazy-ass doesn't feel like cooking.

Only reason I am not giving it a two is because the food isn't bad.
author: Helen C.

description:
http://postgradchic.blogspot.com/2011/09/nopalito.html

Good food but I felt like it wasn't the full restaurant experience I would have hoped it would be. Full review on my blog, link posted above.
author: Shermineh G.

description: Organic this, grass-fed that. The things that make Nopalito more than a Mexican joint with a bunch of food buzzwords are the quality of the ingredients and the precision of the technique. I've had a lot of dirt cheap Mexican (and love it!) but you cannot tell me that the pork in your street carnitas is anywhere near the quality of what they're serving at Nopalito (roasted en papilliote! genius, I have to try that...). What's more, the seasonings are bold enough to satisfy but clear enough to allow higher-quality ingredients to speak up. I've also had a couple of the beef dishes and they're similarly well-executed. Prices are high if you're expecting Mission taqueria food but pretty cheap compared to similar restaurants.
author: David Y.

description: Tonight was the third time we have been here and I have to say every time our food has been amazing and the wait staff is unreal.  I can't remember the last time the staff of a place made such an impact as they have here.  We have had 3 different waiters and each of them have been amazing.  I highly recommend eating here and everything on the menu is amazing.  We have loved the gordita, empanada, and torta.  One more thing, the prices are great here as we had 3 adults and a child with 4 beers and it was under $50.
author: Joel F.

description:
Eh, maybe it was hyped too much.  Went last Friday night with a few friends.  We were seated surprisingly fast, but sadly next to the door of the patio so people were constantly walking by.  Nice atmosphere, though a little on the chilly side for me (I'm a wimp, though...).

I liked that they keep it real and serve tecate in a can.  Friends ordered the carnitas and the enchaladas - looked good, though the portions were a little small.  I'm cheap and love cerviche, so I ordered that and tasted my other friend's soup (caldo de res ala pasilla).  Like I said, I love cerviche, so it's hard to find fault in that for me.  It was soaked in lime and served with thick corn chips.  Couldn't really taste the cod through all the citrus, but that didn't bother me so much.  Did like that they served it with avocado to cut the acid a little.

The soup had a nice spicy broth and lots of veggies floating in it.  Tasty, but not very filling, it seems.  Actually, the soup seemed forgettable as my friend forgot there was a piece of chicken in it when asked if she liked it later on and then also finished the soup and bought a bbq sandwich on the way home.  ouch.

Overall, the food is good, not great.  And for the price you're paying, not really worth it.  But, that's just me.  Nice to be trendy for a night, though.
author: Leslie G.

description:
Delicious all around. Really fresh flavors, high-quality ingredients, and exactly how Mexican food should be. 

I fell in love with their dark chocolate cinnamon popsicles, and now make it a point to end my jogs near Nopalito so I can get a post-workout treat.
author: E. S.

description: The food here is awesome and reasonably priced. I like how the space is bright, airy, modern and casual. Try the carnitas if it's your first time - you'll fall in love with it. The cocktails are yummy, too. Definitely worth checking out, especially if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Bryant T.

description: I simply didn't care for the menu, the food, or the options. Very meat-heavy, no nuance, few vegetables.
author: Jason V.

description: Decibel rating at dinner: 75: too loud to talk comfortably. Food delicious but limited choices. Service so-so. Better to do take-out.
author: Jane M.

description: Nopalito gets better with every dining experience, which is saying something, since the first time we went there it was amazing. I highly recommend getting the Totopos con Chile, which are delicious.
author: Laurelle H.

description: Albóndigas al Chilmole is so delicous!
author: Gaël L.

description: I'd been wanting to try Nopalito simply for their potato taquitos, but wasn't impressed. Yes, this is a yuppie, over priced mexican food establishment. You'd be better off going to Tacolicious for similar style, Little Chihuahua or better yet the Mission. We came during the week for lunch so the place was not busy and our service was relatively friendly and fast. Prices were decent for appetizers but not so much for drinks and entrees. I ordered a michelada and the potato taquitos. I really wish chips and salsa came with your meal rather than fried chickpeas. My taquitos were good but they weren't what I was expecting. They were a rather small portion, granted they are on the appetizer side of the menu. The potatoes were also not mashed like I've been accustomed to at delicious San Diegian eateries like El Zarape. The potato-chile mixture had flavor, and was complemented by some crema and cojita cheese, and maybe 2 tablespoons of guacamole. I really like the mexican wedding cookies that came with the bill. The food itself was good but Nopalito doesn't really strike me as somewhere I'd eat often.
author: Cori W.

description:
For the price of Enchiladas, this place is way over-prices.  I should know.  I am Tejano and know when the price is right for pozole.
For the best Mexican Food, go to Los Jarritos-20th and South VanNess
author: Jose G.

description: I had the chicken mole and my friend had the carne asada with asparagus. The food was good but there was something missing in their mole sauce. The tortillas were supposedly hand made and they were mediocre. Big let down but overall a decent attempt at authentic Mexican food.
author: Genaro R.

description:
Nice casual place with reasonable prices.  Food was good, but nothing really noteworthy.  Perhaps our expectations were too high.

We split four small things:  Tamal Enchilado, Tostada de Tinga, Taco de Pescado, and Panucho de Pollo.  The two latter items were the tastiest.  I didn't care for the Tamal much as the chipotle flavored masa was a bit overpowering for me.

Service was efficient and friendly.  I guess if you're driving by and happen upon a parking spot, it's worth stopping for.  Likely not a repeat for us.  Still, the lunch was executed well enough.
author: D V.

description: Stopped by for an early-ish dinner on Saturday night with a friend, and was able to get seated immediately.  Service was excellent and the food good, if unusual, Mexican. I had the duck mole, which tasted like pure fall to me, but my friend's pork carne was mouthwatering.. overall a good meal. Will definitely be back to try more.
author: Lydia T.

description:
My girlfriends and I ate here before a night out, and it was quite good.  We arrived around nine o'clock, and there was a wait of about 30 minutes.  We took a stroll over to The Page (eh, good enough) had a pre-dinner drink, walked back, and we were seated.  While Nopolito does not have the most vegetarian friendly menu in the city, they are extremely accommodating!  While we were looking at the menu, the waiter asked what we were in the mood to eat and we told him that two of us were veggie--he said no problem.  He asked if we were ok with the chef (Gonzalo Guzman?) picking out our dishes, and we said sure.  Well, here is what we had--
Fresh tortillas off the grill with salsa--I love that!
Taquitos de Papas--small but yummy!
Quesadilla de Primavera--I am not a huge fan of a ton of veggies in my quesadilla's but this was very well made.  I would order again..here anyway.
Vegetarian Enchiladas Verde--not on the menu but delicious!
Sparkling Wine with Housemade Fruit Juices--yum!

Our experience was great.  I thought the staff was friendly, the chef makes excellent creations, and the overall setting of the restaurant was pleasurable.  It definitely isn't your local cheap taco stand but I recommend eating here.
author: emilie p.

description:
I've been waiting to go to this place for sometime with some hesitancy because I really like tapas and/or mexican food and I'm really particular and their menu proposes a more lofty version of mexican food which makes me question whether they actually can make it better than regular mexican food.  Strating off the staff were nice and I liked the general decor.  We order margaritas and they were good, yet over priced at $9 a pop.  Still, with a slightly modern decor this price is too be expected in SF where food is often priced on decor rather than quality. We ordered Ceviche Verde de Pescado y Calamare, Tamal Oaxaqueño de Pollo, and Gordita Campechana.  
            The ceviche was alright.  I have a friend from Mexico who makes his own ceviche and this tasted very similiar to his, but the sauce was a little bit more dull and the fish not as flavorful, but this ceviche was still decent and I would order it again.  
         The Tamal is not your usual tamal, so I fought the urge to compare it to the tamlie lady's.  This tamal has a thicker, grainier consistency which I liked, but the mole sauce was unholey.  To me Mole is sacred when made correctly and this one lacked refinement and made me want to get up and go somewhere else. The chicken under the tamal was dry.  The score for this dish--1.5.  An interesting tamal does not save the day.  Sorry.  
          The gordita was tasty.  definately the best dish, but a little heavy with the oil at a place trying to show refinement.  
        My favorite part of the entire meal was actually my complementary mexican chocolate.  It was really amazing, I just wish the food I paid for made me feel the same way.

Summary: My actual score for this place is 2.5, but they rounded me up.  I would not recommend going here if your looking for anything special.  I would probably only recommend going here if you were walking by the place and you were hungry or if you were tired of the other restaurants in this neighborhood.  If this was regular street food at a decent price I would give it a 3 max, but because this place is trying to show refined mexican food and increasing both food and drink places to reflect the refinement of their establishment, I have to say, "Nopalito, you are not all that."
author: mick H.

description: Thanks Nopalito for being so friendly to me and my giant carseat with loud messy baby inside - you are my go to place for comfort -read: great!-food that doesn't break the budget. I always go on slower days/ times, not sure about the experience when it is mad busy....
author: J T.

description: It has a cute atmosphere for the ladies.  Its bascially a local taqueria turned into fine dining.  If you don't mind paying more for a taqueria menu that you can get at your local neigborhood, its worth a try.  As for me, I'm glad I tried it but don't plan on going back.
author: LIVE to E.

description: Food is impressive and drinks are good. The almost outdoors atmosphere really brightens the place. Service is average. People tend to leave their dogs outside while shopping at the supermarket next door and they can get noisy.
author: Erdmann R.

description: God I love this place. The staff is so funny and down to earth, the food is unbelievably tasty and the atmosphere is straight and to the point. Nopalito is authentic, spicy, and great. Highly Recommended
author: Jennifer M.

description:
If you've had traditional enchiladas, you know they are not supposed to be drowning in cheese, Nopalito serves up casera enchiladas con papa, with a side of chicken that was tender and super flavorful.  The chile verde ceviche was on point. 
There is lots of buzz on this place, so expect to wait. Big thumbs up on having a parking lot!!
I hope for spring/summer, they'll have a tasty Nopal salad.
author: Erika M.

description:
Food was good, but not great. Tasty, spicy, adequate...nothing wowed me. The interior is modern and well put-together and the lighting is super cute! One thing that bothered both myself and my date is when we asked about the sizes of the appetizers we had this conversation with one of the waitstaff:
us - "so, are they about the size of a tapas plate?"
her - "it's mexican, they're not tapas"
us - "got it, but is it about the same amount of food as a small plate of tapas?"
her - "they're not tapas."

We were well aware that we were not at a Spanish restaurant...we have eyes. We were just asking about the portion size relative to something we have experienced before...sheesh! Maybe we should have been more scientific and asked for the exact portion amount in grams or ounces (or whatever unit of measure is appropriate in Mexico)? 

Whatever, I'd rather eat at The Little Chihuahua anyday...
author: Kitten W.

description: Nopalito is one of my favorite mexican restaurants in the city! I discovered it a couple of weeks ago with a couple of friends. We decided to go early because we figured it would get crowded on a Saturday. We went around 6pm and were seated right away at a common table. The prices were very reasonable for such good quality and portions. Our favorites were the tostada, empananda and gordita.
author: Courtney D.

description: Delicious. If you don't like Nopalito, I don't like you. In fact, I would trade your life for a plate of carnitas.
author: Ryan T.

description:
please get this lame overpriced small portioned, bland ass wanna-be bourgeois "fusion restaurant" the f*ck out of my neighborhood.... please? 

"fusion"... get the f*ck outta here with that bullsh*t.

oh and the obnoxious clientelle that is just dying for you to listen in on their lame ass conversation about "Lost" or whatever lame HBO tv show is "hot" at the moment. "hey you!... at the table next to me! you are way too close to my food!". "say it don't spray it ok?" 

dude, they charge like $8 a mouth full. and a flavorless mouth full at that. hard ass benches and sh*t wtf?

ZERO stars.
author: Calama T.

description: I went to Nopalito when I visited SF last month.  My BFF and I are both foodies - we started with the ceviche with home made chips.  We shared the carnitas - it melts in your mouth and it is to die for, it is served with home made tortillas.  They don't take reservations so try to avoid the peak hours or expect for a 30 -45 min wait - but the food is worth it!
author: Tania G.

description: Very inventive authentic Mexican.  Loved the idea of tortillas for our order being grilled a la minute.  Flavors were great, some items needed a little salt, drinks were great.  Service was on point and very welcoming for our first San Fran vacation stop
author: Jim K.

description: I'll make this short and sweet. I thought the food was decent at Nopalito - great for a fun afternoon get together. I had the ceviche and a fish taco. However, about an hour after lunch was finished, I "lost my lunch" three times. Clearly food related as now I feel much better after getting Nopalito out of my system. Be care with the ceviche/fish at Nopalito or you could end up driving the porcelain bus!!!!!
author: Lauren L.

description: I want to pay rent to live in Nopalito. First off I love feeling like I am in another country when I walk in. Secondly, their selection of tapas rocks my world. Carnitas, meatballs, quesadillas and cocktails, service is always chillinist, mo'nillionist! I guess I'll be back for mores!
author: Annie A.

description: Nopalito had long been one of my favorite restaurants until recently when my entire family got food poisoning from take out. I called to alert them to the fact that we had all woken up very sick, and they never called back. I didn't get the feeling that this is an issue they were addressing. Be careful here!!
author: Emily H.

description: Went here last night with a friend and really enjoyed it!  It's a great place to go if you're not that hungry (its tapas) and just want to have a snack and a drink.  The ambiance is nice (you may get stuck in the entrance curtain if you're a little tipsy) and there's indoor and outdoor seating.  I highly recommend the ceviche and the little cookies they bring you at the end; I bought 15 to take home!  Great place for a second date, catching up with a friend, or just a quiet evening alone for a glass of wine or one of their Mexican cocktails.
author: A. W.

description: Good mexican food with great service. They serve tequila, Del Maguey Vida, that tastes smoky. Delicious carnitas (the kind that's tasty without being super greasy) and good pozole rojo. And I love the fact that parking is hassle-free and free (it's at Falletti's).
author: Karen L.

description: This place is perfect for lunch on a nice day. A friend and I sat in the patio, it was a little chilly that day but they put on all the heat lamps so it was the perfect temperature. The service was amazing, very attentive and genuinely friendly.  I ordered the Chilaquiles, which was very delicious, but a tad spicy. My friend ordered the Pork Belly Quesadillas, I think I would order that next time, it was delish! Be sure to get there a little early for lunch, it gets pretty crowded around 12pm.
author: Jen C.

description:
I finally made it over to Nopalito, and I'm so glad I did. 

Yummy horchata, although pricey at $3.95 (read $4).

I started with some cheese- and parsley-filled "cigars" (I don't see it on their menu now, so I hope I remembered it properly; my visit was a week ago) which were tasty.

But the albondigas (beef meatballs over rice) were excellent!

And for dessert, the chocolate cinnamon paleta (popsicle) was intensely chocolatey and bittersweet.

The only thing I didn't care for were the corn tortillas, which I found too thick and not particularly interesting.

I will definitely try this place again.
author: Charles B.

description:
This place is great!!!!!
Carnitas and Ceviche are just a few of the wonderful dishes that are 
a must try. The host is wonderful and so friendly. Makes you feel really good about being there.
author: Lorraine C.

description:
The food dishes at Nopalito were created with thought of traditional Mexican. I went on a Monday afternoon with three people and waited about fifteen minutes for our table which was ok just not expected. The place itself had very cool decor with a interesting rustic sign and nice heated indoor/outdoor seating but just didn't seem to fit the location.

We wanted to try a bunch of dishes so we ordered a lot that came out like tapas style for the appetizers. Their take on chips and salsa was interesting with a spicy sauce "chile de arbol," on the chips and was good with lime squeezed on top. But I don't know about the crema and lime that came with it. We also had the sturgeon fish taco that I liked because it had a spicy ancho chili and chipotle-tomatillo salsa on it. What made this taco different was the soft crisp shell and being topped with an orange. Among other dishes was the torta that I enjoyed, verde chorizo with avocado, cabbage, onions, and queso fresco (mexican cheese). The thing that makes a torta is the bread and the did it well, housemade bun that was nice and soft.

Things that we really didn't enjoy were the quesadilla de hongos y huitlacoche that seamed to be a little weak in flavor - needs some work with that veggie dish. Also the Pozole Rojo seemed to be bland in flavor even though it came with a side car of seasoning, by the time it got there they didn't remind us of what was which one.
author: Nathan H.

description: I could take it or leave it. It wasn't the worst meal but it also wasn't memorable, which is a shame because I live so close to here. I tried several dishes and most of them were bland. I probably won't be returning. If you want legit gourmet Mexican, go to Colibri or Mamacita.
author: E. N.

description: I'm delighted to see that Nopalito now boasts a modest cocktail list as well as a fine selection of mezcal.  Five stars!
author: Sven E.

description: Great mexican food! and has decent prices. But its not for hungry beasts, their food portions are small.
author: Sulaiman B.

description:
Love this place - it is easy, the food is delicious, and the build-out unique.  

My favorite is the popsicles for dessert!
author: hello l.

description: Small but nicely organized mexican american modern cuisine. Very nice and friendly service. Have now tried half of the list during my six or so visits and I think overall the whole menu is pretty tasty even for multiple visits (lunch or dinner). Even for kids. Parking garage next door helps a lot if traveling from further away or want to start your evening here or just have a lunch meeting. Price is right. Restroom slightly weirdly located.
author: Jari S.

description: I came here with a cold and ordered the Caldo Tlalpeño (veggie soup in chicken broth) and felt better for the first time in weeks. Then I tried the carnitas and found heaven. Its rare to find such amazingly fresh, organic and authentically simple Mexican food. Along with the food, the service, atmosphere and beer selection are incredible.
author: Sara W.

description: Was very excited to try this place, the menu looked fantastic and people were raving about it on yelp. Does not live up to the reviews in my book. The only person who loved their food was my husband, who had the chicken in mole sauce, but for $15 I feel it was pricey for what it was.  Nothing else we had was great, in fact, I would consider it mediocre at best. I had the carnitas, and I have had much better elsewhere and a lot cheaper. It was very bland and the cabbage that was with it did nothing to enhance the flavor. My son's enchiladas were cold, as was my daughters empanada.  On top of it, it is very loud inside, when we were first seated it wasn't busy so it wasn't too bad, but as it filled up it grew horribly loud. I understand food reviews are subjective, but this is one place I just don't understand the rave reviews. I won't be back.
author: Cindy G.

description:
Great food. Great Service. Great Vibe.

I love this place. It is really nice to have a Mexican upscale option to the more traditional fare of burritos con frijoles or quesadillas de queso...
Their menu is creative and inspiring. The use of fresh and local ingredients and the friendly (sometimes a little casual) service makes it worth the wait for a seat.

If you have the time and can be patient, give them a try. YOu will love them!
author: alex s.

description: I thought the Quesadilla roja con chicharron was slammin! OMG, The corn y cojita cheese amazing and our server was perfect.
author: Erica C.

description: awesome food!!! great service! go a little early and you don't have to wait
author: p v.

description:
Update 6: It has been over 4 years since my original post and I stand by it 100%. Say NO to NOpalito

Update 5: I still can't get over not only how rude the service was -- Wouldn't give me WATER -- but the food SUCKS. "Authentic?" Then it was changed for a reason. GROSS. 

Update 4: it has been 2 years since i first posted about Nopalito. Yep, I still think it's awful...the WORST. 

Update 3: after further consideration and soul searching I've decided this place actually sucks more than I thought it did 4 months ago when I did update 2. 

Update 2: This place still sucks. 

Update: this place still sucks. 

This place is awful - I would so much rather have plain-old mexican food than the 'authentic' & 'organic' junk they serve here. I like white chicken and big portions - not gross dark chicken and slimy finger food...if that's authentic then it was changed for a reason. 

Now, what really bothered me was that I did a take-out order of 2 different very medicore taco-type things for about $11 and when I asked for a Coke or soft-drink they said they don't carry any - just their $3.50 home-made juice drinks. So I said fine, I'll just have a WATER - The guy told me to go to the grocery store down the way to get WATER. Thanks for lame food and no water - Don't go here.
author: JOHN O.

description: I tried Nopalito for the first time today for lunch with a friend who recommended it.  It was so cozy.  I really enjoyed the atmosphere.  It's decorated very interestingly.  I liked the curtain of hot chocolate mixers in the back.  The menu was very diverse.  It was hard to choose what I wanted to try.  I ended up with the tamal dulce and the enchiladas de mole.  Wow!  Both were outstanding.  The mole was just like the mole I had when I was in Oaxaca.  The service was very nice too.   I will definitely go back  to try their dinner menu.  The only thing I didn't like was the bland mexican wedding cookies given with the check.  Over all, a great place!  5 stars!
author: Pixie D.

description: I've probably eaten here 3 or 4 times. It is always packed and shows how much demand there is in the neighborhood for inexpensive, yet nice meals. Only complaint is that you don't get free chips while you're waiting for the food.
author: Ryan H.

description: I think the food is of very high quality and the flavors are spot on. But it sure is pricey for the amount of food you get. One taco for 5 dollars? I think overall the experience was good though, I ordered an al pastor fish taco that was extremely spicy, had the ceviche which is delicious, and tried one of the potato stuffed fried taquito things, also very good. I also tried a lemonade flavored with bergamom that was especially delicious. Oh and the dessert was REALLY good, a dark chocolate fudgsicle that was pretty much the best dessert I've ever had. Overall, I think the food is great, it's just the quantity of food, is well, left much to be desired. Fortunately I was not very hungry, having come from The Sycamore (which I am about to review on here as well).
author: Gina R.

description: A-MAZ-ING Mole sauce. RIDONKULOUSLY good chicken enchiladas. DELISH citrus ceviche. Add that with a cold Negra Modelo and you got Nopalito, one of the best sit-down Mexican restaurants in the city. Nopalito is the WOW factor when it comes to quality food and presentation, that's why it attracts a large crowd and a 30 minute waiting line. Small, clean space with both indoor and outdoor seating. Food is fresh and light. Prices are decent. Nopalito is a must-try for all the Mexican food lovers in the city.
author: Alex H.

description:
really enjoyed this place last night.
very tasty menu: dulce [something], taquitos, empanadas & duck mole
each one was excellent.
not very expensive.
good service.
recommend for a datenight.
author: Fred C.

description:
Was the environment fancier than a smoothie shop sans wheat grass? NOPE.
Was the cheese on the $9 quesadilla melted and yummy? NOPE.
Was the 1 tiny bacon bit I found on that $9 quesadilla enough? NOPE.
Was the blue corn tortilla unlike a failed corn pancake experiment? NOPE.
Was the $14 carne asada unlike everlasting flavorless beef textured gum? NOPE.
Was the $3.5 fresh citrus soda any different than a melted sno cone with fizz? NOPE.
Was the small smudge of arid black refried bean paste yummy? NOPE.
Was the food any more flavorful than the cute dish towel napkin? NOPE.
Was the cute baby onion garnish enough to make up for a total lack of yum? NOPE.
Was the tiny dish of salsa I requested to combat the bland unlike Old El Paso? NOPE.
Will you likely see a Mexican family having dinner here? NOPE.
Would I feel different about the flavors if the prices were taqueria style? NOPE.
Was the cost to value ratio even CLOSE? NOPE.
Will I be going back to try the rest of the menu? NOPE.

Am I bummed that an over-hyped restaurant is raising property values in my neighborhood? NOPE.

NOPE A LOT O
author: merkley m.

description: Worst restaurant in San Francisco.  Hands down.  Rude staff.
author: Olivia H.

description: All good! Price=Fair, Service=good, ambiance=casual and good, food=great. Basic but worth the trip and they support their community so I support them( even though I don't live there).
author: David A.

description:
Get a new hostess before you go out of business!

I have gone to Nopalito at least 10 times and I've never been disappointment with the food.  However, the hostess is just awful enough for me to never want to go back. 

The first time I had put my name on the call-in list.  I recieved a call saying that my table would be ready in 10 minutes.  I walk over only to be told that there would be a 45 minute wait... 45 minutes later, I was told the wait would be another 30 minutes.  Now I'm a tolerant person but the ENTIRE time I was waiting, there were ALWAYS empty tables. To make it worse, a group that showed up after my party arrived was seated ahead of us.

Thinking this was just a fluke I went back but I had a repeat performance with the same hostess.  It's not that she is unpleasant, she is just terrrible at her job and does not know how to manage a crowd.  Once again, at least 3 empty tables but the wait... 45 minutes which really translated into 1.5 hours and you need to constantly remind her that you are there.  

I love the food but I won't be going back anytime soon.
author: Tracy S.

description:
come here for the small plates.  the main dishes were not that great.  my hubby got the mole and it tasted as if the cooks were on iron chef and the secret ingredient was chocolate.  mole should be complex.  nopalito's was one note.  i got the birria.  when i ordered it, i pronounced the double "rr" like your supposed to and the white waitress didn't understand me.  i don't know why i expected her to.  anyways, the birria was pretty good, but fancied up so much, it didn't seem right.

we love love love NOPA and wanted to love it's baby sister, but were really disappointed.  don't think we'll be back.
author: Jennifer D.

description: OK... went back w/ some friends and had a bad experience.  We paid in cash, the lady picked it up, and we sat there chillin for a bit and left.  Then after 40 minutes later, someone from the restaurant calls us (we called and made reservations.. that's why they had our number) telling us that we didn't pay in full???? What da crap is that?  We paid in FULL plus tip and they took the money from us probably like an hour ago and then calls us to say that we didn't pay???  I dunno what happened, but someone betta regulate.  Don't think i'll ever go back there again.  Ain't worth paying that much for something u can get much cheaper in the Missions.
author: Young K.

description:
I've been wandering around the city looking for a good Michelada. Sadly, I have to say my search continues. Nopalito does serve micheladas, and it was alright; but I was looking for something more. My friend liked it, but he had never tried one before. I told him I could probably make a better one at home.
On the other hand, the rest of the food was fantastic. We ordered the Totopos con Chile as an appetizer. The cotija cheese shaved on top made the entire dish. Usually you'd just get nachos with a spicy salsa to dip with. These already had a salsa on the nachos and it comes with sour cream to dip with. Delicious!
As a meal, I ordered the ceviche. I was impressed with the ceviche, as that has been another hard thing to find in the city. The marinated cod was fresh and had just the right amount of spice. My friend ordered the Quesadilla Roja. At first glance it seemed a bit small (he's a big eater) and didn't have any side dishes. However, with the appetizer, we both ended up taking leftovers home!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
what we ordered: 2 margaritas, ceviche, carnitas, side of rice, horchata.

food: food was amazing. perfect. i mean perfect.
drinks: bartender has a heavy hand. you take it as a good or bad thing.
decor:  clean. nice.
service: spot on. no complaints
price: around 20 bucks a person.
verdict: i will be coming back for sure. and again. and again. this place is amazing. seriously.

sidenote: bathrooms are out side and enter thru the togo door. and the salsa needs work. but the food really doesnt even need hot sauce or salsa. really.
author: Ricky Y.

description:
Tucked away between Faletti's grocery store and Starbucks is Nopalito. The bebe and I met my friend Aimee there a few days ago for lunch. Following the advise of other Yelpers, I called an hour ahead and gave them my name and to let them know that I was bringing in a stroller. And what?! It was a great surprise to find what that the complex has parking! Yay! 

Aimee and I decided to half share everything so that we could try more things. We started off with the esquite tostado con crema y queso. The corn was sweet and spiced slightly with the chile and pico de gallo. It reminded me of the elotes (or corn on the cob) that you would get from a street vendor. It was absolutely delicious! Aimee ordered the ceviche verde which came with tortilla chips perfect for scooping the calamari and fish out of the bowl and into our mouths. I ordered the quesadilla roja con chicharron. Anything with pork is good! And although pork is the other white meat, this quesadilla was dark and luscious with the chile ancho tortilla and the crispy pork belly. To wash everything down with, I ordered the hibiscus-valencia orange drink. It was sweet, fruity, fresh, and perfect to compliment the spiciness of our meal. Lastly, we shared their chocolate and cinnamon popsicle for desert. How decadent and kid-like at the same time! 

The staff was very friendly. The location is perfect (with parking). The décor is simple, yet elegant. I highly recommend Nopalito and will be returning again soon.
author: Jan Z.

description: This place is awesome.  I usually cringe at the thought of a nice mexican restaurant.  Mexican food is some of my favorite and usually the uglier the restaurant, the better the food in my experience.  I recently went to NOPA and loved it, so I had to give this place a try.  It kind of sucks that you can't make a reservation, but the call ahead thing works well as long as you call in twice the amount of time in advance as you think would be necessary.  The food, though, is entirely worth the wait and difficulty of getting in.  The chips are really good, the quesadilla is awesome, and the carnitas is phenomenal.  The service is really good and the wait staff is really friendly.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I was recently visiting San Fran for a conference and was looking for a great place for Mexican food. Nopalito had just the right menu of small plate delights. The mole was delicious, so were the gordito & empanada. The highlight was probably the organic almond horchata...so yummy I got a second.
We ended up doing take out because they were packed on a saturday night and dont take reservations...they say you can call ahead and get on their waiting list...but I called about 5 times and no one ever answered the phone :( 
I would go back for sure! Take out or dine in.
author: Leslie J.

description: Food is good. The carnitas are GREAT. Be sure to call ahead for a table. Things are a bit cozy.
author: Brian C.

description: I ALWAYS order the same thing when I'm here so I can only rate the Carnitas and the White Sangria.  The carnitas always comes out juicy and flavorful.  Tastes even better when you take the leftover home and reheat it.  The white sangria is really light and refreshing.  The service is great too.
author: Cindy B.

description: Checked the carnitas from  here off the Big Eats list and man that was so damn tasty pork. I wasn't expecting anything as good as what you find in the Mission but this blew my mind. It was amazingly good. The pork flavor was so deep and flavorful, I couldn't get enough. It was obvious the pork had been cooked for a long time and the meat was super tender and easily pulled apart. Came with a tangy cabbage salad and corn tortillas which were tasty as well. My only gripe is that the portion is kind of small for $15. I guess we did manage to create three hefty tacos out of it which comes out to $5 a taco but still.... We also tried the Gordita which was not as good. Next time I'm just going to get two orders of carnitas. YUM.
author: Cathy T.

description: Great fresh food with a great view of the kitchen (if you are interested in watching)! Also one of the best margarita's I have consumed!
author: Beth K.

description: Great service, wonderful food.  I also have food allergies, so the Chef was especially accommodating, which is huge.  Go early on a weeknight if possible; we didn't have a wait at all.  Would definitely return again!
author: Karen N.

description: There were 4 of us and we tried just about all of the small plates and really liked most of what we ordered.  The taquitos and chips (top of the menu) were our favorites.   Also loved the sangria.  Will go again, and really appreciated the waiting list / phone service deal - had a great round of drinks at Nopa beforehand.
author: Lindsay B.

description: love this place.  refined, sustainable, flavorful Mexican food. Great beer, horchata and simple design make it a great place for lunch or dinner. The shared plates make eating a fun, interactive and hopefully enjoyable experience for you and friends.  The pozole is fantastic as well as the home made, stone ground corn tortillas.  This place is a must for those who love the SF eating experience.
author: Cory A.

description: Amazing!  We ordered the carnitas and the birria de chivo.  Both were absolutely delicious.  My favorite was the carnitas because it was just so tender.  For the appetizer, we ordered totopos con chile.  It was decent but didn't wow us.  It's got a nice kick to it though as the spiciness builds up, so that was good.  But the carnitas, mmm yummy!  I will definitely be going back for more of that.  And as a nice added bonus, the entire staff was just so wonderful, helpful, and pleasant.  Never meet a nicer staff.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I have to say, I was ready to have a less-than spectacular experience at Nopalito, for two reasons: 1) anything that's hyped that much is bound to be a letdown and 2) pricey Mexican? c'mon, this is San Francisco!  But  Nopalito exceeded my low expectations, by a lot.

1.  Reservations--Called to put my name on the list while we were at a bar in Lower Haight.  The hostess said, "So like, 45 min to an hour?"  I said, "That would be perfect."  And lo and behold, as we were walking up the hill on Haight approaching Divis, I got a call from Nopalito, saying our table was ready.  We literally walked in and sat down.  Sweeeet.  Did I mention it was a Friday night?

2.  Service--Prompt, efficient and friendly.  We ordered a pitcher of sangria, and the waitress accidentally brought just only one glass of sangria.  Instead of taking it back and bringing the pitcher, she left us with the glass to share while they made up the pitcher.  Very nice.

3.  Food--The totopos could have been more cheesy, less spicy, but were a nice departure from the usual chips and salsa/guac.   But the highlight were the enchiladas.  Yummy, yummy.  I usually prefer green sauce, but the smoky, mole-esque red sauce here was mighty fine, especially when complemented by the cotija cheese.

4.  Prices--Very reasonable.  I was surprised.  We probably could have spent less than $20 per person (maybe not incl. tax and tip) if we didn't drink so damn much! ;)  (Oh, btw, they didn't charge us for the extra sangria.)

5.  Ambiance--Noisy but not an overwhelming vibe.  We were seated at a communal table, which could be annoying if you don't like your tablemates, but I liked chatting with the folks next to us.  What can I say, I'm a talker. 

Overall, a surprisingly nice experience.  I would give it five stars, but it's not Dona Tomas on Telegraph in Oakland, which holds the highest place reserved for gourmet Mexican in my heart.   (Limited spots because of availability of delicious cheap Mexican in easy distance.  See above.)
author: Martine D.

description: Great, fresh Mexican food (which I love), however a little lacking in flavor. I guess that's why LA Mexican food is better. The chips could have been crispier, the salsa spicier. Great horchata. The carnitas was incredibly tender, and the tortillas divine. The ceviche is great, just, again, a little bland.
author: Gina Q.

description: This is a great little restaurant. I only go for lunch and try to avoid the worst of the crowds - it can get really packed. But this place is my favorite local go-to spot for eating alone, with my hubby and with friends and family. Fish tacos, tamales con mole, y  El Gordo - Carnitas! Perfection worth the prices. Much better than your local Taqueria  - this is really good food, carefully prepared and thoughtfully served. Worth a detour.
author: Da H.

description: Tried to eat lunch here today and had a really bad experience. I've been to Nopalito several times since they opened and really liked this restaurant. Our friend arrived there before us and put our name on the list, we were told we had a 30 min wait. When we got there, the host told us it was very full inside and didn't want to let us go in to the bar. We said we had a friend already waiting and walked in. Then we encountered another staff person who also said the bar was too full and we shouldn't come in. I said we at least needed to tell our friend we were there. There really was was space for us at the bar with our friend and we ordered a round of margaritas. At that point things really went south. We waited for 45 min and saw people who arrived after us get seated before us. When we asked, the host said we would be seated next and she was sorry for the mix up Then a nice table cleared up and we thought we would be next but they said we couldn't sit there because a table with children was coming in. That party arrived and had NO children with them. When we asked what was going on, the staff said the party had told them they had children but then turned up without them. We said, then fine, call them on it and give us that table. They said it wasn't their place to call people on things. We finally said we'll sit at the bar but at least comp us something for the long wait and putting other people in front of us. They basically said no and they didn't care that we had been treated poorly. We paid for our drinks and walked out. Although Nopalito is popular and the food is good, there are other places in town in the same range that are equally as good if not better. I will never go there again due to the terribly poor service. I wish it hadn't come to this as I love their food and have so many good memories there. I will miss you Nopalito but like I said, there are other places in town with great food and good service.
author: Charlene D.

description: Nopalito is a decent nuevo-mexicana place.  While it's not Mamacita, the prices are a little more reasonable and there was no wait at 6:45 on a Fri nite.  The carnitas is the flagship item on the menu for good reason - it was one of the best carnitas i've had.  it cut like warm butter when i sliced through it.  The white sangria with frozen grapes was also dope.  Besides that, the other items on the menu were average.  The cebiche was average and the enchiladas was disappointing.  I will likely come back here again at some point, but it's not going on my rotation.
author: Toby C.

description: Awesome place. We went there on a Tuesday night and had no wait. They allow dogs inside the patio area. Great waiter who gleefully informed us that they now serve tequila (just got their liquor license). He also was well versed on which menu items would upset my dining partner's gluten allergy. We had the gordita, a beet salad, and the pescado with rice. All were scrumptious although, next time I will ask for some hot sauce. Didn't try their desserts but the rice pudding and homemade popsicles both sounded great. Excellent all around!
author: Eddie R.

description:
Nopalito has terrific food!  

Here are some of our favorite dishes:
- Quesadilla Roja
- Ceviche
- Carnitas
- Albondigas

The key is to call and put your name on the list before arriving.  The restaurant will call and let you know when to arrive.  When you do this, wait times are usually less than 10 minutes.

Mickey (one of the managers) is awesome, attentive and committed to high quality service.  Service from the rest of the staff is a bit variable (consider this an area of opportunity for the restaurant).
author: Adam B.

description: The food was ok, pretty bland. The service and atmosphere were good. Carnitas were cooked well but plain, the mole was chocolatey but not spicy enough. The habenjero salsa was mush and not nearly hot enough. The server was attentive and knowlegable.
author: Krista I.

description: Yikes, I don't know where the harsh criticism is coming from!! I've been here a few times with family and friends. The food has always been quite tasty, much like our family back in D.F. would make. The staff is courteous, atmosphere relaxing. The prices really aren't that bad, factoring in the fresh ingredients. Compare this to what we are used to in Ireland, and it seems like a steal!! We'll definitely be back.
author: Eileen R.

description: The draw of this place is the amazing quality of the ingredients and creative, flavorful dishes. There's more authentic, cheaper Mexican over in the Mission. This place is all about fresh food that's so flavorful the aromas drifting from other tables will make you want to order more even after you're stuffed. Plus, they have phenomenal beverages at reasonable prices, including my favorite beer (Death and Taxes) and creative seasonal sangrias by the pitcher (mmmm, persimmon pomegranate!).
author: Shoshana D.

description: This is some of the most delicious and inventive Mexican food in SF. The staff is great and the vibe is mellow with a welcomed neighborhood feel to it. One of my favorites!
author: J F.

description:
i recently went back to nopalito the night after eating at tacubaya.

the food was just not as good to my tastes and a couple dollars more per item. of course, it's sf, but...

i think tacubaya takes the cake as the best mexican food in the bay!
author: Sarah G.

description: Ate here for the first time today. Very good flavors and nice how they have a rotating menu that is actually updated online daily. I haven't tried the branch on 9th street yet, but would for sure based on the delicious food I had at the Broderick location today. The taquitos were amazing!
author: Maureen B.

description:
It is not a great food experience when your favorite dish is the complementary dried chickpeas.

Started with the fish taco and the squash blossom quesadilla. The taco contained a very small piece of fish and was just OK. The quesadilla consisted of mostly zucchini and you really had to look for the blossom.

I ordered the chicken enchiladas which did not resemble enchiladas at all. The dish consisted of a chicken breast (an airline breast) and what appeared to be two enchiladas next to the breast. I was excited thinking that I was getting more protein than I bargained for. However, what appeared to be enchiladas were actually two tortillas which had been dipped in a sauce and filled with a few bits of carrot. The tortillas dried out quickly and that part of the dish was really disappointing. So basically I had a chicken breast.

My dining partner had the carnitas which were good, not great, but good.

The service was fine but the food is really over-hyped. I will not be returning as I know that I can easily find a better Mexican food experience in SF.
author: Alexander G.

description: Really good Mexican.  Interesting menu, great selection.  I love the atmosphere too, and the parking in the lot is a HUGE plus.  The carnitas are amazing, and the pork skin quesadillas.
author: Oliver S.

description:
Nice idea, nice space and decor,  but really did not pull it off.  It is a dis-jointed mess of a place.

First off, I am a mexican-aholic and I guess this restaurant  is trying to be "modern mexican" which I can go with, but the food was small and marginal and unauthentic.  No free chips and salsa at the start which is always expected at a mexican restaurant , you just get a weird and really small dish of  dried garbonzo beans supposedly dusted with cayenne and spices--- but they lacked any flavor or spice and dried our mouth out.  Bleh!!!!
The food we actually ordered was very greasy! the starter we had,  cerviche, seemed like it had been marinading so long in citrus that it was thouroughly "cooked".   Food overall  lacked flavor and spice--very gringo and  quite tasteless and bland, bland, bland.  Also, please dump the "small plates" concept.  It does not work here especially when even the "large plates" are so small...this is insulting and misleading and makes for lots of disappointment.

Beverage choices non-existant in the alcohol area, one choice of red, white and rose wine each.... and they ONLY have a beer and wine license which means, NO margaritas.... sad.   I was served the one choice of white wine (chardonnay, which was awful) in a tiny toothbrush holder type of cup made of rough pottery, gross!   I asked for a glass, because that is just tacky.  They do have glass in Mexico.  I have had many beverages served in all types of glass there paying 10% of these prices so I didn't feel I was being snooty by asking for one--- although I still didn't get a wine glass.

Another one of the many turn-offs and disappointments here is that the seating  is all "communal" for the most part , unless you want to wait for a table on the front porch which is outside.   The communal seating at that is very, lets say, "cozy".  Hey, I don't even know these people, I  certainly don't want to sit at a table with people and hear every word and feel awkward about talking to my companion sith no sense of privacy.  They tried to cram us between two couples on a high table and stool with no back, we refused and opted to wait for a table at least on ground level with real chairs.  There would have been no elbow room without impacting others at the tall table so we waited for this table for an hour on a weekday night.  Unfortunately, even the coveted tables are so close that the converstation from the table next door was distracting.   Prices too expensive for this, the food, the lack of hostess/  " write your own name on a list " hanging outside.

Service was ok, they asked, but what can a waitress really do when the whole concept of the restaurant from top down is wrong???  Hard to know where to start to complain ...When asked, I just sent the waitress away with a sad smile.... Expensive and a bad experience.  Don't go.
author: Anibel B.

description:
this place is seriously delicious. apart from the fact that we waited entirely too long for our seats (the hostess told us about 45 minutes, we sat down 1.5 hours later); it was near perfect.

loved: the totopos con chile (essentially chips covered in a spicy sauce with a sprinkling of cotija cheese and lime)--seriously, these were divine; bacalao fresco (lingcod--perfectly prepared..moist, flakey, flavorful)

the pom-candied japeno sangria was also a total treat. i'm normally not a fan of spicy-sweet beverages, but it works in this instantiation. 

can't wait to come back here; maybe next time i'll make reservations to avoid the trouble with seating
author: sfgal g.

description:
We like this place a lot!  Not only my husband and I (middle-agers), but my daughter and her boyfriend (mid-20s) are fans.  I've been here twice for late Sunday night dinners.   We like how fresh and flavorful the food is.  We appreciate the organic ingredients, the healthful preparation of the food and the price!  Excellente!

The Caldo Tlalpeño is wonderful - it's a large bowl of broth with veggies, queso fresco.  The chicken mole, beet salad, carnitas, and quesadillas are all fantastic!  Order a few items and share.  Fun place to dine - casual and yummy!
author: Casey N.

description: Just moved to SF and went here for the first time last night.  Promises to be a staple in our lives when we need reliable, tasty Mexican and creative delicious drinks at what two former New Yorkers think are very reasonable prices.  We loved the carnitas, really outstanding, and also liked the ceviche and taquitos (just don't go looking for the meat in them!).  Better than cousin Nopa in my opinion, and if you time it right, you can get Humprhey Slocome ice cream afterwards for dessert.  Mmmm.
author: Brendan K.

description: The only reason I haven't gone to Nopalito is because I hate how they don't take reservations.  But finally got to go today.  The food is divine!  Not just the best Mexican, but one of the best overall restaurants in the city.  The taquitos were fantastic, but my least favorite of the three things we ordered.  Came with sour cream and guac to dip them in.  We also ordered, the carnitas which were perfect with the right amount of fat.  The carnitas were my fiance's favorite.  The pork quesadillas were my fave.  Crispy on the outside with a lot of filling.  Amazing!
author: catherine g.

description:
Nopa Junior! This is a sheek, outpostish version of Nopa itself. Instead it serves fun mexican tapas. And I had no idea they serve organic foods, which upps its cool factor.

Usually restaurants as miniature versions of its older siblings aren't as refined. I'm glad to say that the decor and set up of this place is fun if not encouraging for more of a sociable time than its sister restaurant. For example, both inside and outside cute wooden benches and stools with high tables which makes the environment less formal. We went during the evening and the inside was very well lit. Outside seating was a little more dim and chilly because of the weather, but the heat lamps helped. I can see this restaurant being a really good summer spot.

Attention is also paid to little details of the decor. I love how they served our wine in little clay mugs, probably similar to the effect of drinking vino in Mexico. Cute. I had their  syrah, which wasn't as full bodied as syrahs I usually drink but it went well with the dishes we ordered.

Good service. Our waitress was very attentive and came back several times to see how we enjoyed our dishes. Even a different waitress who served us our drinks chatted with us because she caught a part of our conversation.

We ordered
[panucho del pollo al Pibil] deep fried tortilla with black beans, chicken, bay leaves cheese and onions. I'm glad I ordered this because the flavors went together really well. I just wish we received more than just one. 
[totopos con chile] homemade deep fried tortilla chips flavored with refried beans cheese and lime. I've never had anything like it before- a bit heavier than your regular chip. I liked eating them with some of the other toppers we ordered, like the
[Ceviche Verde de Pescado] translates as Green Fish Ceviche! I thought this one was okay, the taste of the lime was a bit overpowering. The fish was good. The rock cod they used had a good strong consistency that stood out and didn't become runny with the sauce of the ceviche. 
[Carnitas] Also really really good with the totopos. I love the way these were prepared- not greasy and full of flavor. Came with a chile verde sauce that brought out the taste of the carnitas. Soooooo yummy!

We finished off the meal with polvorones that our waitress brought us with our bill. Sure beats a dinner mint! They tasted even better than the filipino kind my people's bring back from the motherland as souvenirs after trips. Hollerfront.

It tends to get busy, so if you can call in advance. There was just two of us, but we had to call an hour before on a monday night. One more thing about this place that I like: there's lots of parking! In the nopa/lower haight area parking can seals the deal for me.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Evening dinner date with friends. Didn't have to wait too long for a table on a Wednesday evening - we had not called ahead. Plus we were served the delicious seasoned roasted chickpeas while we waited for our table.  The atmosphere was really great - warm and friendly. And there's a lovely heated patio for additional seating.

Everything on the menu sounded delicious so it was difficult to choose.  We did order the highly recommended Totopos con Chile to start and the dish did not disappoint - note it's a bit spicy which makes it all the better! I couldn't decide on an main dish so ordered two small plates - Taco de Pescado al Pastor (Seared fish in adobo, chile ancho, orange, onion, cilantro and salsa de morita y tomatillo) and Panucho de Pollo al Pibil (Black bean stuffed tortilla, citrus-achiote chicken, cabbage, pickled red onion and salsa habanera).  The Taco de Pescado al Pastor was good but a bit dry and I didn't care for the coarn tortilla it was wrapped in, I probably wouldn't order it again.  But the Panucho de Pollo al Pibil was outstanding. I recommend it if you want something light but surprisingly filling.  I love small plates, so I recommend taking a risk on a few in place of one main course.  Also ordered by friends were these main course dishes: Carnitas, Enchiladas Placeras and Mole Poblano con Pollo.  They all seemed very happy with their orders - clean plate club.  Overall, great place, even for a small group and I look forward to visiting again!
author: Kavita M.

description: Alright Nopalito..you really let me down on Saturday. What is the point of a call/wait list if they never call you? We called around 7pm, checked in at 8pm, our phone # was written perfectly on the sheet. We waited another 30 minutes in the parking lot, then another 15, still no call. Then we walk up to the sheet and a couple walks up and says, we had a reservation (their name was way after ours) and the server says," right this way". WTF?! So, we point to our name then get stationed to the VIP drink wait area (where you wait longer) but I guess are their priority people to serve. Who knows? All in all, I was happy with the food that nite but not the lack of apology and getting skipped in line. Please get more organized with your call wait list Nopalito. I'm not sure if any dinner is worth a 2 hour plus wait.
author: Kristy H.

description:
The best part:
-The Carnitas
-The drinks (Sangria! Local beers on tap!)
-The spicy dried chickpea thingies they bring out when you're first seated

The bad part:
-Being told the wait is 5 minutes and waiting for 30 - eat faster people! :)
-Having to walk outside and around the corner to use the bathroom 

Seeing as the wait/bathroom situation wasn't that big of a deal, and the food and drinks were good, I would definitely go back.
author: L. B.

description:
The little brother of Nopa, Nopalito has the same concept but totally different execution. Mainly, Nopalito is a Mexican modern execution to Nopa's American modern.

Ambiance (4): The place is nicely set up and there is lots of wood all over the place including some nice wooden tables and bench setups. Modern, warm, and very inviting. Wide open layout and the only thing missing would be to have outside seating. They have some covered seating which is nice but no direct sunshine.
