Food (4): Authentic fusions, if you will, with lots of traditional ingredients but with that American touch. We had the sweet pumpkin tamal which was great, simple and well executed. You get the hint of traditional corn tamal but can definitely pick up the pumpkin. The ceviche was good but it didn't go well with the chips which were too thick and salty and overpowering the subtle flavors of it. It was still good but I prefer it more limey. The totopos were ok, but maybe too far from the original and not enough fresh cheese action. The carnitas were amazing. Perfect, perfect, perfect. Just make sure to scarf them down while hot, that's when they are at their peak. They get served with traditional corn tortillas, a damn good slaw, and a green tomatillo salsa which I wish was the one they used on the totopos. The horchata was good, but they need to get some hot drinks in that place for when it's chilly outside.

Service (3): It was ok. Very little personality though.

Value (5): The pricing of the small plates are spot on and the large plates are decent. We only had one large plate and it was worth every penny, but can't vouch for the other ones.

Overall: Food was great, price was good, heading back there soon.
author: Alvaro H.

description: Great spot for business lunches - easy parking and great food.  Loved the nachos, Carnitas and fish taco's.
author: Kevin K.

description:
Went for dinner on Tuesday 4/7/09. I was worried it would be really crowded given it's recent write-up in the Chronicle followed by a spot on the Chronicle's Top 100 list. But when we called ahead at 5:00 PM, there was no wait.  We got there about 5:45, street parking was easy, and we had a choice of tables to sit at. About 15 minutes later all the tables were gone, and traffic on the street had picked up, so I think we timed it perfectly. 

For drinks, my friend and I ordered a Tecate with a salted lime. We had  no idea what to do with the lime so we plopped them into the can. Then I found this explanation: http://www.ehow.com/how_2110218_drink-tecate-mexico.html. Even though we didn't follow these directions, it was still a good beer.

Two of us are vegetarians (I eat fish, she doesn't). The waitress helped us navigate the menu and explained that the kitchen would also make a vegetarian version of the enchiladas (not an option on the menu). We didn't end up ordering them, but they sounded pretty good. On the right side of the menu are small plates that you can mix and match and on the left are dinner-sized entrees. I went with the small plates and got a fish taco and a mushroom quesadilla. Overall the food was delicious, especially the mushrooms and the corn tortillas. The fish taco was a little bland for my liking, but still very fresh and tasty. For dessert, they gave us some interesting cookie-like-ball.  As soon as I popped it in my mouth it felt like I was trying to eat a ball of saltines filled with peanut butter. The taste was fine, but  you are hereby warned to save a sip of water in your glass if you plan to consume this, otherwise you will feel like that poor dog in the old got milk commercial.

Around 6:15 a small crowd had formed outside and I started to feel a bit like I was inside a fishbowl, people peering in, eyeing how much food was left on my plate (downside of the outside seating). As mentioned in other posts the bathroom was indeed hard to find. You have to exit the front door and walk around the building to the "To Go" entrance. Even then it was not labeled but I saw a "vacant" sign on the door handle which was my clue.

Overall good food and good prices, but would recommend going for early weekday dinner if you don't like the wait. We will definitely go back again.
author: Katie S.

description: Checked this place out on Labor day for lunch. Service was awesome, setting was cool but the food was just fantastic. I am Mexican and I appreciate some good Mexican food when I come across it. It's such a shame SF has horrible Mexican food and no, I am not talking about  Taquerias in the Mission. Good on you Nopalito. PS. being next to a Bank, Shopping, Parking, was also pretty cool (but I don't want this to turn in to LA, so let's keep the parking plus on the down low)
author: Jason P.

description:
Still consistently amazing.

Be sure to check back once in a while as there menu slowly changes over time.
author: Brent S.

description: This was our second attempt to dine here.    Again we were told it would 45 minutes to an hour wait, so elected to try the take out.  I agree with some of the other reviews, the food was not that noteworthy.  Definetely not a place to go out of your way for a meal.  Not bad, just not great.
author: Rob F.

description: The totopos = the best doritos ever. Love this place. Everything I've tried is good with the exception of the tomato juice/beer/salty mess drink.
author: Constance C.

description:
Super friendly customer service and cute ambiance! I wish I could be as excited about the food as I was about the place. 

Came here on a Sunday night for dinner. I ordered the braised lamb (Costillas de Borrego al Mezcal). The meat was tender, but a bit bland. It came with some salsa on the side, but even then I only felt the texture of the meat, but not the flavors. 

My friend got the Mole and it was much tastier. Maybe a different dish could have made this a better review. 

I also ordered a cocktail, the Mezcal Paloma, because the combination of alcohol and grapefruit soda sounded refreshing (I don't like overly sweet drinks). When it came it tasted just like grapefruit soda and nothing else. I'm not a connoisseur of hard liquor but mezcal de oxaca should taste like tequila, yes? Maybe the bartender forgot to mix it in. There's no way it could be that smooth. I should have brought it up, but felt a bit rude to ask.

I would still want to come back eventually to try some of their other dishes...and an alcholic drink!
author: Moe M.

description:
Que rico!  I totally dig the comida at this place.  Clean, straightforward, homey, and pretty authentic.  If you're looking for thigh-like burritos, look elsewhere.  But the grub is pretty great.
Margarita was disappointing--no triple sec?  Bloody Maria was much better.  Staff is engaging and alert.  The confusing entrance is a test to filter out the dim customers from those who deserve entry.  Will you find it?
author: Kyle F.

description: Great food! Very tasty and complex flavors. The desserts not as good as the mains. Great host and staff. I will go back!!
author: Douglas H.

description:
Its as good as it gets.  Its not your every day Mexican food so don't expect the cheesy enchilada or greasy taco with refried beans and rice.  Expect fresh, great tasting, quality food that you share with everyone.  Well worth the wait.   I've been there 4x in 6 months and the menu has something new and seasonal on it.  Don't worry if your "favorite item" is no longer on the menu...you'll find something just as good if not better.  You're better off ordering a bunch of plates and sharing rather than eating one or two by yourself.  

Downside, everyone likes it so you'll have to wait.
author: Christopher J.

description: Really good food and great service!! I had the chicken with mole sauce...really tasty! Nice and relaxing atmosphere.
author: Brandon U.

description:
believe the hype.

technically i'm half mexican, but since i'm tex-mex and don't know spanish outside of my 3 years of edumacation at Sonora Union High School, my friend B calls me white-washed.  still, i like to think i know good mexican food.  in terms of production, so far i have been able to emulate my grandma's refried beans and rice, though my flour tortillas are closely related to flatbread.

Nopalito is a charming, unassuming, stellar restaurant specialising in mexican food and good service.  I started with the grapefruit pinoncillo, a refreshing if not slightly-too-sweet drink and wished immediately that i'd ordered the chile chocolate milk.

Lady J and i shared a few things in order to maximize our taste-to-dollar ratio.  we split the esquite tostado con crema y queso, which is like a a deconstructed version of mexican corn-on-the-cob and waaaaaay delicious.  i ordered the ceviche verde, despite having been a little disappointed the last two times i ordered it (la mar and limon); i was impressed with the lovely presentation complete with half of the most delicious avo, and the overall tartness that was perfection.  We are both pork-o-philes so had a hard time finding the right dish to fill that need, but in the end LJ ordered the quesadilla roja con chicharron.  we were not disappointed.  it was tender and flavorful and all things a pork belly soft taco should be.

we ordered the paleta, aka popsicle, for dessert.  it was a painstaking choice between the mexican chocolate, cantaloupe and cafe con leche.  in the end the cinnamony goodness won out, and i felt like i was eating a rich frozen truffle.  heaven!

all that for around $30!  i can't wait to try more.
author: Aimee B.

description:
It's still early...far too early for final pronouncements but initial indications are that the Nopa folks have hit on something good with Nopalito.

A long time fan or Laurence Jossel and Nopa, I'd been dying to try his new Mexican restaurant out. We arrived and were seated at the bar which in my estimation is the best place in the joint to sit. The place was hopping on a Friday night and the guys in the kitchen were at full speed but the chatter seemed upbeat and friendly. A good sign. 

This was a whole different scene than Nopa. This isn't a place where you're going to spend an evening getting together with friends for a few drinks and a leisurely dinner. Rather this was a place for the food...authentic, sustainable, organic...all the right words. We sat and perused the folded paper menus. Wanting a drink, there is no bar service and the wine selection is a red, a white and a rose. That's it folks. The beer menu is obviously where your attention should be focused. They have four drafts and six or seven bottled selections. I went for a Michelada which is a combination of a tomato paste concoction with chili del arbol, salt and lime added to a draft beer. I'd never seen anything like it. Throughout dinner I never really made peace with it. I'm glad I ordered it but don't know that I'd order another. Along with the drinks we were served a small dish of seasoned, fried garbanzo beans. These aren't what you might think. Think about an airy flavorful bite...almost like what a corn nut should be. We asked for a second dish. I should have brought some home. Yum.

For starters we ordered Quesadilla de Acelgas (corn tortilla, erbette chard, jack cheese, caramelized onions, queso fresco and cilantro salsa) and Ensalada de Repollo (cabbage salad, carrots, radishes and oregano). Both were awesome. The quesadillo was crisp and the salsa was spicy and really fresh. I wish I'd ordered another. The salad too was super fresh with large thinly sliced discs of pink and white radish. All good,

Next came the entrees. We ordered Carnitas (long braised pork, orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer...cabbage salad, pickled jalapenos, tomatillo salsa) and the Birria de Chivo (goat stewed in dried chillies, roasted tomato, spices, chocolate, pinquinto beans and salsa de arbol). Let me start by saying that Carnitas in SF...it had better be good since there are plenty of places to go for it. Here is was considerably better than good. It was fantastic. Crisp on the outside, moist inside, steaming and not too salty. Pretty damned perfect. The goat? Well...not quite as successful. There was too little meat and the broth it was served in was bland. Trying to assemble the ingredients in a corn tortilla led to a mess and it all fell apart. I think this one needs to be rethought.

Our server, Miki, was damn near perfect. Service all around was snappy and friendly. It's obvious everyone cares what the customers think of Nopalito. I really enjoyed it. In a few months I expect it to be even better. Highly recommended.

BTW...unlike Nopa, parking is easy.
author: Gary C.

description: It is very good. Tommy's near Geary and 25th Ave. is better. I had chicken enchiladas...The chicken came on the side, a half-bird of deliciousness!
author: Andrew K.

description: I was turned on to this gem by a dear friend.  I always thought that Mexican food was cheap and fast and definitely not gourmet.  Well Nopalito's has consistently provided me with some amazing delicacies from various parts of Mexico served by a very knowledgeable and happy to be working there staff.  From the moment you walk in you are taken with the amount of work these folks do.  From the making of your tortillas from scratch to parchment filled, fall apart carnitas this place rocks!  The ever changing menu and delightfully fresh ingredients lovingly prepared by people who know what they are doing never fails to impress me and my guests each time I visit.  I am happy to pay whatever they want after tasting food that has completely changed the way I think of Mexican Cuisine.  If you want to impress somebody this is the place to go!
author: Irv S.

description: My boyfriend and I went into this place with a very good opinion of its sister location, (NOPA) and were excited to check it out. It was horrible. I ordered the chicken soup and it was the most tasteless soup I have ever encountered. Besides the expensive prices, the atmosphere is lacking in personality. We left without eating, although we still paid our 50 dollar bill. Our server simply ignored the fact that we did not eat anything and never once asked how it was. So much for delicious food in the lower haight! DO NOT waste your time or money!
author: Shawnana S.

description:
Nopalito es necesito.  Little sister to nearby Nopa, it is also a tiny space that doesn't take reservations, so be prepared to wait or order from the takeout counter at the entrance on the side.  Or you could call ahead and put your name on the wait list....

Food:  3 stars.  For upscale Mexican, the prices are relatively cheap so we tried alot of different things.  For starters, we tried the totopos con chile (tortilla chips topped with cotija cheese served with salsa and crema), gordita de picadillo (served with grass-fed beef and refried pinquito beans), panucho de pollo al pibil (black bean stuffed tortilla with citrus-achiote chicken, pickled red onion and habanero salsa), quesadilla azul de hongos y huitlacoche (with mushrooms, corn truffles, jack cheese and queso fresco) and naranja y cebolla con chile, limon y queso (salad of grapefruit, blood orange, pickled red onion, chili, lime and queso fresco).  My favorites were the quesadilla azul and panucho, both are so freakin' good.  The tortilla chips are crisp and spicy (one of my fellow diners was so enraptured by them I had to stop my conversations to eat some before they were gone).  The gordita was okay and the salad was average yet would be refreshing on a hot day.  For the mains, we ordered the pozole rojo (stewed pork shoulder with hominy and ancho chile), carnitas (served with orange, bay leaf, cinnamon and beer with cabbage salad), mole poblano con pollo, barbacoa de borrego (steamed adobo lamb in banana leaves), enchiladas placeros (with pan seared ancho chicken breast) and birria de chivo (goat stew).  My favorites dish was the goat stew (the one I ordered, of course), followed by the enchiladas placeras (juicy, tasty chicken) and mole poblano.  I thought the pozole rojo was nice, but didn't have that much pork, while the carnitas and lamb were a litle on the dry side.  For dessert, they serve different flavors of popsicles (chocolate/cinnamon, lime and blood orange), all delicious and refreshing (at least the citrus ones).  We also ordered some housemade beverages for dessert - the chile chocolate milk, which was spicy but a little chalky, and the organic almond horchata, which was nice.

Service:  5 stars.  Service here is top-notch for a neighborhood eatery.  They do a really good job of managing the wait list and providing everyone with reasonable estimates of the wait (even if you don't like what you hear).  Our server was super, super friendly and well knowledgable about the dishes (including recommending the goat stew and panucho).  Even when things go wrong, they right the ship pretty quickly.  My friend got up to use the restroom and it was actually fortunate that she did.  The server that cleared the table dropped a few plates exactly where my friend would have been sitting.  A little bit of food spilled on her purse, but they were quick to offer her a free voucher to get it dry cleaned.

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  The restaurant has two rooms:  the trendy colorful inside space and the rustic enclosed patio (which is heated properly on cold days).  This place is great for people watching as there was definitely lots of eye candy on a Friday night.  There is only one bathroom (next to the takeout counter) with a very weak flush (hopefully you don't get an unpleasant surprise) and super loud hand dryer.  When waiting outside for your table, be careful not to block the way - you may get some evil stares from Falletti Foods shoppers or the residents from the complex upstairs.

Hits:   Quesadilla azul, birria de chivo.

Misses:  What, no guacamole?  Also no reservations, weak toilet.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Nopa, Mexico DF, Maya, Mamacita, Colibri, Zazil.
author: Keith C.

description:
Fresh, flavorful, soulful! Nopalito is not a Mission taqueria serving an Americanized version of Mexican fast-food. The robsut flavors demonstrate the care the Nopalito kitchen takes in preparing its food. 

After a trek from the Academy of Sciences, the Tecate in a can, topped with a salt crusted lime was just the ticket! Originally, I came thinking that I wanted to try the Pozole Rojo, but we were so warmed from the walk that we opted for the small plates. Started with the ceviche, fresh locally caught rock cod marinated in lime juice, cilantro, tomatillos, and jalapeno. It was served with hearty homemade tortilla chips. I could sense the corn flavor of the chips before the dish hit the table!  A perfect refresher after a long morning at the Academy. 

For our entrée, we each ordered the pork tamale, gf ordered the sturgeon fish taco, and I ordered the Panucho de Pollo al Pibil. The masa of the tamale seemed to be flavored with broth from the cooked pork, which impressed me because my mother does the same when she makes beef tamales. It helps to liven up the masa. My only complaint about the tamale is that I prefer more meat to masa ratio. That's how mom does it!  The sturgeon taco had a meaty flavor and texture. It was a generous portion and I especially liked the smoky heat of the adobo sauce. The panucho, served like a tostada, had a smear of mashed black beans stuffed into the corn tortilla.  It was topped with a slow cooked chicken which you could see was not manually shredded so much, but simply fell apart. This made for tender, juicy chicken. The pickled red onion added a slight tang which married well with both the chicken and the habanero salsa.  I like more heat than some, so I asked for a little extra, which I used sparingly. 

Overall, excellent food and attentive service made for a lovely dining experience. I can't wait to go back and try the pozole, or maybe carnitas!
author: S A.

description:
this is mexican? the only mexicans that i know that would love this place live in luxury condos in the polanco district of mexico city. they tend to summer in ibiza and have fair hair and last names that sound about as mexican as an oompa band. don't get me wrong-- this place is not bad at all. ingredients are of the highest caliber and execution is thoughtful. it's just that it was a bit too chi-chi for me to take it seriously as a mexican joint, and i am half mexican! how it made the chronicle's "top 100" list i do not know; the fact that it did obligated wakako and i to dine there. 
ps- features the awesome xlerator hand dryer in their (single) bathroom.
author: Brett W.

description: I love this place. This is how I imagine it would be to eat in a non-Americanized great restaurant in Mexico. The service was responsive and helpful with good suggestions. The Carnitas at Nopalito was terrific and should be shared by two unless you are a big eater. One thing I like is that they serve right through. I love late lunch. Since they do not take reservations, this is a great time to eat to avoid the crowds of people that are keen on this place, Ample parking in the lot across the street, next to the complex, or in the garage - a nice bonus in this neighborhood.
author: David C.

description:
Locals only, everyone else go back to your shitty burrito place in the mission. How DARE a restaurant do something new! Right yelp? 
The Tamale-Verde would make the Tamale Lady say 
"oh fuck".
 Only wish it was spicier.
author: Jon R.

description:
i know, im being a little hasty here giving this place 5 stars since this was my first time.  but there was nothing i was disappointed with!

-little roasted garbanzo bean things.  so good.  salty, crunchy, burnt, awesome.

-organic almond horchata.  this was the best horchata ive ever had!  so unsatisfying, because there was only like 10 ounces of it, unlike horchata at the cheap mexican places

-carnitas.  this is how meat should taste.  so tender, perfectly seasoned.  sitting in a little paper bag full of its own delicious grease.  paired with a fresh corn tortilla, some verde salsa, and some cabbage stuff...perfect

must revisit and try the goat stew!
author: Robert S.

description:
Loved it overall. Home made chips tossed in salsa were excellent. Spicy. 
The carnitas were awesome and a lot of food. The chicarones quesadilla was good but not great.  
No Coke which is annoying. But the house made horchata was good. The citrus soda wasn't great. 
Server was cool. Ask for extra tortillas if you take leftovers to go. 
About $30 for two people with drinks and appetizers and the whole thing.
author: Jacob K.

description: Smack yo mama good. Nah, but seriously, the carnitas rock. And the quesdillas, posole, and gorditas were all really yum. Okay so I'm probably not the best at describing everything, but you should eat here, because not only are the staff and servers awesome, but the food is good. AND, the place is cute too.
author: Sabina And Pete V.

description: Eh just generally underwhelming all around. I haven't been to Nopa, but from what I hear this place doesn't come close. The fried chickpeas they gave us were so-so. The totopos were tasty, but one person thought the chips were similar to doritos. The fish taco was just eh. The ceviche was decent but I've had better. And the lamb was kind of dry and not that flavorful. Apparently the pork dishes were better, but since I don't eat pork that didn't really help me much.
author: Humaira M.

description: FINALLY went to Nopalito tonight with the vball crew and had a great meal.  All were happy.  I had the best carnitas I've maybe ever had, he had the mole and she had the fish taco.  All super good.  Can't wait to go back and try every dish.
author: Matt S.

description: If you're vegetarian, you won't find lots of options (hence the rating). BUT I have to say the tamale and quesadilla (w/ spinach) was delicious! I really love corn tortillas over flour now.  I haven't tried the drinks yet so my rating may change because they sounded and looked really good.  Also, I used to be a meat-eater and those dishes sounded good too.  They also give you these fried chick peas for an appy which are yummy!
author: Liz F.

description: I might get some heat for this, but Nopalito doesn't meet the hype that foodies/bloggeratis have made it out to be.  The setting is perfect for a neighborhood joint but the food doesn't deliver.  Not because the food isn't tasty, but it gets as good as mileage as a Hummer H2.  Vegetarian choices are limited, fresh masa based tortillas were just ok, and salsas at our local taqueria is tastier.
author: Sheetal S.

description: Had some very nice meal with a friend last night. We didn't have to wait as long as I feared, but ended up sitting at the bar, which is very cramped. It was very uncomfortable to try to carry on a conversation (I still have a major crick in my neck) and we kept getting bumped into by others seated at the bar and by wait staff. The food was good but didn't knock my socks off. I ordered the chicken mole which I liked though the portion was small. My friend had the carnitas, which I thought was dry. Since I live a block away, in the future I will hit the take out window and forgo the sardine can environment of the restaurant.
author: V. R.

description: I really like this place because it reminds me of eating street food in Mexico City...haha only difference is the price is higher! but that is to be expected...great food, more relaxed environment. they do get busy, just keep that in mind! *just grab a beer or champagne from Fratellis next door while you wait!!! haha now go and try it!!
author: Sarah F.

description: Great atmosphere, friendly staff, food was super delicious. Loved the Eames chairs and heat lamps. I'd go back for sure as a regular spot to hit up.
author: Nicole L.

description: This is a cool, casual, clean place with good food.  The portions are kinda small and it doesn't cost a lot to make Mexican food.  The service was a little slow and I don't know if I would come here again.  3 stars!
author: H. A.

description:
Very, very disappointing, especially after the fact that my friend and I were in the Mission and could have had dinner there, but instead chose to go all the way out to this neighborhood to try Nopalito. What were we thinking?!?

First off, it's ridiculous to wait an hour and a half for a seat at this place. We were told about an hour, which already would have been too much, but anything over that is just plain ludicrous! I don't understand why they don't take reservations. It's just masochistic of them to make patrons wait this long just to let them down.

There's nowhere to wait after you've put your name down on the list. You can wait out in the cold, dark SF night along with the dogs people tie up to the post outside the supermarket as they shop. Yeah, we sympathized with those dogs whimpering outside. Or you can perhaps wander around the supermarket yourself. There is a Peet's Coffee as well and truthfully we should have just picked up something to nibble on at either place rather than wait for a table at Nopalito.

Once we finally got a table, the waitress explained what they were out of. The menu isn't that extensive to begin with, so points docked for being out of items, one of which is the one that my friend had wanted to order. My friend also thought the waitress was a bit brusque. 

Although it was quite cold, some of their heaters in the patio-like area weren't turned on. We had to specifically request the wait staff to turn them on since we were afraid of freezing. The patio area is too open. It feels like you're eating under a tent. That might be ok on a warm day, but this is SF. How many such days do we actually get?? Shouldn't you want to shield your patrons from the elements? 

The food was just ok. I had the mole and my friend had the enchiladas. Interestingly enough, her enchiladas were spicy (although neither of us remembers that the menu description aptly portrayed this fact) but the mole sauce was not. That's the opposite of what I would have expected. I've had better mole sauce at a hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint. I will say that the chicken was fairly tender. I think the food here is catered toward people who want a watered-down version of Mexican food. This is not authentic Mexican food and it's definitely not worth the price ($14 per entree). Way too pricey and I think the restaurant is hypocritical to market this place as cheap Mexican fare. That's a joke.

Since it was a cold night, my friend wanted tea. No such luck, they don't serve that. Hmm, it tries to be an "organic" restaurant, but apparently tea is not organic enough for this place. Strange.

The set-up is weird as well. We thought it crazy that you had to exit the restaurant and go around to the take-out area to access the one and only bathroom. The larger eating area looks like a diner and I've already mentioned the drawbacks to the patio-like eating area.

The restaurant's website touts the free parking. Yes, they have about 10 spots in a lot in front of the restaurant, shared with all the patrons visiting the supermarket and Peet's Coffee. This means that you won't be able to find a space in the lot. Parking is also hard to come by in the neighborhood. Be sure to drop someone off in front of the restaurant to put your name down and then drive off to find parking. 

You'll be waiting a long time to get in, so be sure you're not in a rush if you go here.

One star for the food at least tasting fresh and one star because there was cool, lively music playing throughout the evening at the restaurant (although, like the food, it wasn't Mexican either). It's sad that I have to stretch as far as giving credit to a restaurant based on its music selection.

I won't be returning to this place. It doesn't have enough going for it to make it worth my while. There are so many restaurants in SF, that you can have a better dining experience elsewhere. If you're in the mood for real Mexican food, head to the Mission.
author: O K.

description:
Everything was amazing! I lived in Mexico last year, and I miss so much of the good food, but this is definitely a good way to keep the cravings down.  
I went with some friends and we wanted to try a bunch of stuff so we ate family style, which I think is the best way since the plates are served solo, no accompanying rice or beans or anything.  This way you get full and variety.

Food: 
Carnitas A+ soft and tender and with hot tortillas and a fresh salsa, you can't go wrong. sooooo good!

Enchiladas Placeras A : The mole was really good, not too sweet and the serving of two enchiladas was enough for us to each get a bite

Quesadilla with Huitlacoche A: I'm not a big mushroom fan, but the others really liked the combination of creamy cheese and this corn fungi

Tamal Enchilado A: This was a good tamal, not soggy and a little spicy, though I would have preferred the cream be left off the top

Cod Ceviche A+ : Oh man... I had never had ceviche of cod before, nor ceviche with salsa verde, and it was soooooo good. I wish I had ordered one just for me!

Since they put a California Organicish flare on things, their menu changes with the seasons and what is availible locally.  I was sad that nopales (cactus) is not in season, so I will have to wait to get some of that.  

Drinks:
We tried the Horchata - good, has a touch of almond

Jamaica/Habiscis - very fresh, nice with the blood orange and sparkling water

They have a list of local beers, and Tecate in the can.  Of course that's what I ordered... :) They also make micheladas, but with the local beer it tastes a little off, maybe request it with Tecate.

Overall it was a great dining experience.  I enjoyed every plate that we tried, it was all very fresh, and though some things weren't 100% authentic, the California touch didn't take away from any of it.

We had great service as well.  One of my friends knew the waitress, but it didn't seem like we were getting special treatment, they are just nice people.  

Anything else... I think that's it, go and enjoy!!
author: Jaylene S.

description: The food was very bland and uninteresting ... but it tasted fresh.  The hostess was very unfriendly ... but the waiter was nice and efficient.  My party of 2 was seated at the same table as 4 other loud strangers.  Overall the experience was unpleasant and certainly not worth the price.
author: Cliff D.

description:
when things like "the best mexican in town" and the such are said, expectations can be quite high.  nopalito is pretty small and can get really crowded quickly.  we came here after a stroll thru GG park w/ friends around 2pm and were surprised w/ how crowded the restaurant was.  we were able to score seats at the bar that overlooks the kitchen which provided a lot of entertainment.

they started us off w/ these lil spiced up garbanzo beans which were good.  i got the horchata and was very impressed by it.  clean flavors without being overly chalky which horchata could be.  our friends got the lemonade and the pinocillo which they thought was OK but had too much soda water.

i got the ceviche and taco pescado al pastor.  both were good with my fave going to the taco.  the spiciness and flavor were spot on.  the tortillas reminded me of the beautiful tortillas we had in puerto vallarta.  the ceviche was very well done and the tortilla chips that came with them were very well made.  wifey got the quesadilla azul and tostada de tinga.  she ordered the quesadilla w/ no cilantro but they put in beet greens instead w/ out telling her.  she felt the greens took away from an otherwise pretty good quesadilla.  she wasn't a fan of the chicken in the tostada but thought the rest was OK.  our friends got the quesadilla azul and the piquita which was a pinched tortilla w/ chorizo.  they thought there dishes were OK.

while everyone was very friendly, the service was awfully slow.  bar seating seemed nice at first but since all we saw was food being prepared, the slowness is service felt that much slower.

as we got our check (which took a while too) we were given almond shortbreads.  good stuff for sure but WAY heavy on the butter.  not sure if we'd jump back here but who knows..
author: Swarup B.

description: Gringo Mexican, but it's fine.  I'd certainly go back if I were in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't make a special trip.  Definitely get the panucho, which was tasty.
author: Freccia S.

description: this is my favorite restaurant on earth. The food is always delicious and clean. I suggest sitting at the bar and watching them prepare the food for you. The tastes are crazy good
author: Joyce G.

description: If you enjoy waiting an hour and a half (according to the hostess who's clock is obviously off by about a half an hour) for Mexican food that really is nothing special, I have found the place for you. This really belongs in the Marina because it's a place to say you've been to rather than an enjoyable dining experience. I've had an easier time getting into Nopa and the food is ten times better! The staff tries hard with limited resources but unfortunately the experience is still less than stellar (and definitely not worth the wait in a city with so many better choices)! As fun as it is to get an eyebrow raise from the hostess every half hour or so, it doesn't quite equate to actual food (even if mediocre) in my stomach! Find a taco truck or a Triple Threat Burrito from Papalote and enjoy an evening not at a "stand-up bar!" The parking is fairly easy with a small lot/garage for Falletti foods right in front.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Yes it is pricey for Mexican. get over it.  I love the taco truck too, but I wouldn't put recommend it as a date spot. we came here for dinner - service here was wonderful and the space is light and contemporary. 
the pork belly quesadilla was fatty pig goodness. the pozole rojo - stewed pork shoulder while misleading - more of a soup - was still darn tasty. the chicken mole was a bit bland though. good stuff overall.
author: Kevin W.

description: Yum.  I have gone there two weeks in a row to order new yummy things.  Great flavors and spicing.  Parking easy too.
author: Megan j.

description:
i'm not sure how qualified i am to write this since:
a) i got some food to-go
b) i don't know "authentic" mexican food like some of these reviewers (i will not comment on them)
c) i like flour tortillas...okay, i said it...i don't care if you judge me...

anyway, the cashier person was really not in a good mood, but nevertheless, the sophisticated doritos were really yummy (even after travel time, so i'm assuming it would be really tasty if eaten freshly made)...and the carnitas...the carnitas...this is really how i judge a place, and let me tell you...it was excellent!  a little crispy, a little fatty....come on, how could one not like that?  not a big fan of the cabbage salad, but not a big deal.  honestly, i would have enjoyed an option to order some carbs, but that's probably because i don't really know what authentic is or whatever...i'm a carb whore, so suck it....nevertheless, i am planning on coming back here to try out some more dishes....
author: Miss P.

description: Great place to have a late lunch or dinner....no full bar yet but I heard it's coming.. but Yummy Carnitas! N' Quesadillas! Visit Nopa sister restaurant just down the street...
author: Michael P.

description: It has been pointed out to me that this review may have been too harsh.  Well, I stand by my review for that particular night, but I will say that (1) the people at Nopalito are the nicest, and very warm and friendly, so that deserves a star bump (2) my 8 year old wanted chimed in that she loves the Pozole, and so do I, so that deserves another star bump.  I'm sure my previous review isn't dissuading anyone, as the place is packed every time I walk by there.  But will I anxiously return?  I'm not sure yet.  But I'm raising my stars to 3, for the reasons above.  Did I mention how nice the people are?
author: Kathleen B.

description: Best Carnitas I've ever had and definitely worth the price tag. The michelada was really good too. Other highlights were the quesadilla with pork belly and the Panucho de Pollo...
author: Nicolas H.

description: So far the drinks have been good, the bartender is very knowledgable and helpful with the aspects of tequila as well and knowing the menu of drinks. However the managerial and hostess is conducting a train wreck. Also seating people  who just got here rather than other who have been waiting for an hour. Now to the food the guacamole and chips were good. Tototapas con chile was full of flavor packing a mild punch of heat and covered with cheese,( which should of been layered through out not just on top) my only down fall is the chips were overly thick , hard to chew and even bite. After letting the chile sauce sit the chips become soft and dough like. Horchata is a great alternative to the standard traditional horchata we are all used to. The Carmel asada con chorizo plate was great the carne asada was cook perfectly while the chorizo was hot enough to make you wanting to go back for more. The home made tortillas were perfected and delicious. The chocolate ice cream was out of bounds. Our waitress was extremely nice and very helpful. If it wasn't for the wait and the lack of coordinating the wait for a place where we sat( which was open the entire time we were waiting ) I would give this place four stars.
author: Tom W.

description: Everything is fresh and flavorful and tasty and yummy. Well worth the wait and the price.
author: Lauren H.

description: Yeah yeah yeah, so the portions are on the small side BUT it tastes so damn good.  Try eating smaller amounts of quality food and less of the overstuffed burrito from the place where you're not 100% sure you're eating said meat.
author: Jen H.

description: I'm officially addicted.  Going about 3 times a week and Nopalito delivers every time. Lately my favorite is the Huevos en Caja followed by a cantelope or cafe con leche paleta.  Great service and love their patio!
author: Veronica P.

description: I loved this place.  First, I thought the prices were quite reasonable.  My husband and I had a tab that came to about $60, which in the bay area for dinner is unheard of.  We started with the Totopos con Chile which I highly recommend.  I have certainly had enough of the boring chips and salsa starter and will go for this any day!  I loved the salsa and shredded cheese.  None of it was over done.  We then moved on to a Gordita Campechana and Tamal Oaxaqueno de Pollo.  The Gordita was great, I could have eaten a few more.  I was less impressed with the Tamal  I felt that the majority of it was the masa, there was not enough actual meat.  The mole was just ok, it was not something I would order again.  We then had the Carnitas.  They were great, all components together were delicious.  I think the next time we go I most likely will order from the left side of the menu and get a hodge podge of the stuff there.  The mains were pretty big and it is more fun to share!
author: Jaime C.

description: For a place that's just opened up, dinner went remarkably smoothly last night.  I would work on the wine list but the food was all excellent.
author: Michael W.

description:
Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me.

Being apparently just about the only Nopa resident who's not a fan of our namesake hotspot, I had heard such good things about Nopalito I decided to try it anyway.

The food is good (mole is delicious and the popsicles are awesome), but  you don't need to wait in the parking lot of Falletti Foods for 45 minutes to pay $45 dollars for good Mexican food in this city. 

Shame, shame, shame on me....
author: Katie C.

description:
I finished dinner here and thought, ooh, I like Nopalito! Not wanting to make rash judgments, and to preserve my reputation as a non-biased food critic (by who, I wonder?), I decided to sleep on it. And this morning, I thought, ooh, I liked Nopalito. And so that was that. 
It may be because of all the green. I happen to be a green-happy person, and the interior of this restaurant reminded me of a granny smith apple. Also the clothes the servers were wearing. Anyway, such was my mood when the strawberry sangria arrived. And can i say, I would gladly drown my sorrows in such beautifully alcoholic fruit. 
Nopalito's version of chips and salsa has my approval as well. The chips are actually tossed in the salsa and served with fresh queso and crema. Along with the spicy fried chickpeas, these should keep any customer occupied for a while. When more hunger strikes, if you are vegetarian, they will gladly make you a herbivore's version of the enchiladas (quite delicious), a very well made squash quesadilla (excellent in-house tortillas), and some really addictive mix of toasted corn, cheese, chili and lime. I could eat this last item by the tub-full, but then we all know the results would be unpretty. 
So instead I just drank more sangria. I think this was a no lose situation.
author: Purnima M.

description: Maybe it's all the booze from beforehand, but our quesadilla roja con chicharron was epic! I approve.
author: Jesse M.

description: Had a quick lunch here today, but had heard a lot about this place and have been curious for a while.  The homemade non-alcoholic beverages were refreshing, and the salad a great appetizer.  I tried the gordita and carnitas as well, and I must say, I will definitely be back for more Carnitas!!!! yum.  Can't wait to try some other dishes as well.  Nice uses of chilis, which is always a plus in my book.
author: Maximilian P.

description:
really fresh, good, creative mexican food.  the chicken chipotle on the tostada was amazing.  it had just the right amount of smokiness and the tostada was thick and crunchy.  the carnitas was another winner.  super rich, next time get that to share.  can't believe we blew it ordering the same thing but that's what we felt like.  the ceviche was also great.  portions are on the big side so you wont leave hungry.

the drinks were also good -hibiscus/valencia orange was just the perfect acidity with the carnitas and the organic almond horchata balanced out the acidity of the ceviche.

quick, attentive service and easy parking (but maybe only because it was burning man week).

dessert popsicles are sick!  chocolate cinnamon rocked but i liked cafe con leche made with blue bottle coffee the best!
author: X X.

description: Hmm, It was just aaaight.  The carnitas (which were supposed to be amazing) were hard and dry and should have been moist and fell apart.   We also ordered the tamal which was dry as well, and some tortilla-stuffed appetizer that left something to be desired. I did enjoy their chips and beans, but these 2 items were not enough to send me back.  The couple next to us ordered the carne asada which looked very good.  Another minus was what kind of mexican restaurant doesn't have margaritas??   All in all, it wasn't a very memorable experience and too overpriced.  If I lived in the area I would rather hit up Chihuahua.
author: anne m.

description: I'm so happy to have quality Mexican food that doesn't cost a fortune.  I love Colibri and Mexico DF, but they're kind of a splurge. Don't get me wrong, I love a taqueria burrito or quesadilla, but Nopalito offers something in between street mexican food and upscale dining which is definitely needed.  The carnitas were my favorite. The masa in the tamal was the best I've had.  Service was fantastic.  I did feel a bit squished sharing a table with strangers, but the food made up for it.
author: Anthony C.

description:
i loved my experience at nopalito!  here is a hint - go on st patty's day, for some reason mexican is not too popular then... but i loved it after a few green beers!  
its all about sharing - get lots and try everything.  we ordered a bunch of little appetizers.  the totopos were great, the quesadilla i liked, and the tostada was good too.  we also got the carnitas - a must.  so delicious!  our service was delightful.  i will definitely be back!
author: Carolyn B.

description:
if you ask for simple syrup with the iced tea, it comes in the cutest little jug thing.

also, holla at the filipino boy with spiky hair who looks like an anime character and works in the kitchen. he's adorable and single ladiessssss!
author: Melanie C.

description:
felt like some mexican food and got some. i couldn't say the food i ate was up to the hype. we were sat at the table right near the entrance (on one of those stormy evenings) and it was so cold i wore my jacket while slurping the soup and the dish with pork and beans (both very good actually). our table of 4 had a taste of many tasty dishes, i'd give 3 and 1/2 stars if not for my pain due to the wind from the curtain at the entrance.
their popsicle (as the only dessert) was really disappointing!
author: Thuy G.

description:
First the name - sounds Italian  
This place is new and sadly pretty blah. Disappointing.
Our food was greasy, greasy, greasy - grease dripping on the plate as we were eating. The tortilla shell our food was wrapped in was very hard and slightly burned (I really thought I was gonna break a tooth), the servings are tiny (we left hungry and broke), and it is pricey. 
If this is the food they eat in Mexico - like the white waitress carrying a baby tries to make you believe - them all the people must be hungry in Mexico. By the way - not one Mexican in sight.
Our dish was supposed to have pulled pork in it but it had only one small piece of meat - we sent it back and was given another which had slightly more meat but was still lacking and rather tasteless, and the cheese that was part of the dish was almost non existent and so finely grated that you could hardly taste it.   
There was nothing else on the plate - no garnish, no lime, no sour cream, no avocado - nothing, just the (small and expensive) dish we ordered on a bare plate.
If you want good Mexican food that is hearty, delirious and reasonably priced - do not eat here. (Don't' be fooled by the pretty pictures - the food is and looks nothing like it).
author: Flower P.

description: I came here a few months ago with friends who had heard rave reviews. The prices seemed pretty decent, anywhere from 8 - 16 dollars for each of their choices. When I got what I ordered, I realized that I probably should have ordered 2. Who knew that the 'lito' in Nopalito was referring to the tiny portion sizes. The food was pretty good, but nothing really stands out in my mind. All I remember is that we left hungry and went to KFC to fill the void in our stomachs.
author: Danny L.

description: Authentic. Locally sourced. Organic. Delicious. Best tamale I've ever had, served by a familiar, friendly, wonderful staff in a comfortable, vibrant setting. I can't wait to move back to the hood so I could eat here on a regular basis. Nopalito for lunch, Nopa for dinner. Who could ask for anything more?
author: Tal K.

description: Somewhat limited menu, and it's a bit heavy on the sauce, but it's still a welcome addition to the neighborhood. The appetizers are fantastic and the entrees quite good. I still like numerous other places better in the city, but these guys do a very good job. You can call ahead of time and place your name on the wait list so you don't have to wait for a table to open up, which can take forty-five minutes sometimes. You can always also put your name on the list and go across the street to the Fly for a beer. Service is friendly and relatively quick with a normal selection of basic beers, wine and Margaritas.
author: brant f.

description: this is not a favorite spot for me - I don't like the space (it's small, antiseptic and lacks warmth) and the food is highly overrated.  The carnitas in particular is dry and lacks flavor - Gordo tacqueria serves much better carnitas at a fraction of the price.  This is yuppy Mexican and you can wait for a long while for them to call you on your cell for you to eat some.  to say something nice - I would note there are some good regional small plates to start and the waitresses are super cute.
author: Eric S.

description: I'm a little surprised by some of the lukewarm reviews of this place. I will say it's kinda pricey for the portions but you could easily fill yourself up on a couple of the $4 small plates. Anyway, the totopos are amazing. A much better version of chips and salsa. Imagine your chips with spicy enchilada sauce baked onto them...and you dip them in what I guess is their version of queso fresco. We had the ceviche with avocado, the panucho de pollo (chicken on a black-bean stuffed tortilla), a quesadilla de roja, and the pork pozole (soup). All were great...with flavors and preparations you never see in a typical Mexican restaurant. Very excited it's in the neighborhood as we were lacking a good Mexican place.
author: Bill R.

description:
I was really excited when this place popped up in my hood.  It's vibrant interior is inviting.  The open kitchen lets you get in on the action.  On a busy night expect to wait.

The kitchen produces dishes that are a twist on traditional Mexican fare, obviously influenced by California cuisine and the green standard of local and organic ingredients.

Some suggestions?  The Rock Cod Ceviche (Ceviche Verde de Pescado) was quite tasty.  I needed some extra tortillas to savor the sauce of the Birria de Chivo (stewed lamb).  The kick of habanero from the Panucho de Pollo al Pibil (citrus-achiote chicken) was washed down nicely with an Allagash White brew.  The plates are best if shared (in my opinion). Sharing is caring.

P.S. For those of you that insist on driving everywhere in SF (like my friend whom I dined with) there is a parking lot!
author: Ashley Q.

description:
In Mexico, my husband and I would go once a week for pozole and tacos dorados.  Since we moved back to San Francisco, we've been hunting for authentic pozole.

We finally found it at Nopalito.  They serve pozole rojo with lettuce, raddish, and oregano (no avocado or chicharron -- fried pork cracklings).  It was a huge portion and it definitely hit the spot.

However, it was the carnitas that really won us over.

They melt in your mouth -- so deliciously flavorful and so incredibly moist...best carnitas hands-down we've ever had and worth every penny. 

It doesn't get the full 5 stars because the menu is a little random and they don't actually serve nopales.  Also the restroom is located by the To Go counter, so you have to go outside and around the restaurant. I know.  Nit-picky.
author: Debra H.

description:
I came here with friends for my Birthday dinner. Great space with tons of windows to let in natural light. Everything is accented in green and the place has a nice casual feel. We opted to sit inside (rather than the heated patio) next to the kitchen so we were able to see all the food going out. The list of house-made drinks was so tempting - I wanted to order all of them. I ended up settling on the almond horchata which was sweet and addictive. My friend had the spicy Mexican coco - it was really rich like a milkshake but had a great spicy kick of cheyenne at the end. 

We started with the halibut ceviche which was served with Nopalito's super thick tortilla chips. The ceviche was tart from the lime and seasoned well with cilantro. I ordered the carnitas. Now it wasn't cheap, but the reviews don't lie - this was some rad pork. As my hands were covered in pork fat and I was loudly praising the virtues of the heavenly pig, my friend reminded me how much I love the pork chop at Nopa and that perhaps I have a thing for pig done by these guys. The carnitas was wonderfully seasoned and shredded perfectly. I realized I was supposed to eat the slaw and tortillas that came with it, but a third of the way in I gave in to the temptation and just ate the tender meat. The rest of my dining company did not seem as thrilled by their meals (although everyone liked their selection), but maybe I was too blissed out in a porky fog to accurately assess the situation. Bonus for the free house-made cookies at the end!
author: Dana H.

description: Love this place. Inventive menu and very affordable. The service is always really good as well.
author: Casey C.

description:
Appearances can be deceiving. Initially the chilaquiles looked delicious but they were flavorless, oily, and too crunchy believe it or not. The environment was quite frantic and we were forced to sit with another party at a pretty small table. They forgot to make one of the dishes we ordered but we were happy to not have to pay for or eat it. 

This yuppie restaurant is a poor man's border grill. The flavors were very bland and it was far from traditional Mexican cuisine. I would prefer Taco Bell or Del Taco. The prices and portions are not satisfactory. The best part of the experience was watching the hot cooks in action.
author: kitty c.

description:
The strawberry sangria was delish!  The chicken entrees (Mole Poblano and Enchiladas Placeras) were ok, but all of the pork dishes were super yummy.  The atmosphere was chill and comfortable with cute details such as the Molinillo wall above the takeout register.

I just think it's a bit strange that the restroom is located outside of the restaurant.  I'm happy to dine at Nopalito anytime, except when it's raining.
author: Hannah R.

description: I would have given this place 4 stars, but I thought the selection was lacking and a lot of the food is fried....which I don't care for.  The nachos were a pleasant surprise, not your typical nachos.  Delicious sauce (just the right amount of spice) and very lite mexican cheese.  My Tamale was bland, but the Masa is homemade and was delicious. The best part was the wonderful beer. Brand called Duchess.  Absolutely divine. The people were very friendly and pleasant and I liked the freshness of the food and the atmosphere.  You have to call in for a reservation and then take a walk.  Would eat there again.  Appetizers too small to share with more than 1 person.
author: Judi O.

description: First off, to be fair the 1 star is not about the food or the service or the ambiance.  1 Star is in solidarity for 1 Diner.  I've been coming to support Nopalito in my neighborhood, just as I supported NOPA.  Both great additions and the people behind these restaurants are awesome.  But I've had several repeat instances of watching people that have arrived well after me get seated.  It just pisses me off.  I'm willing to wait, and I have.  But it gets to the point of ridiculous.  It's the same girl who is in charge - has she no recognition skills at all?  Does being a regular mean nothing?  You know those people you seat ahead of me?  They may come once or twice.  I've not only been a consistent diner, but I've recommended your spot, I bring friends there for brunch and for dinner, I've brought clients there.  You're not only losing me as a single repeat diner, but also all of the business I steer in your direction.  Too bad.  So sad.
author: Sharon K.

description: The dinner was just as good as the lunch.  I really dig this place.  It's perfect for a casual yummy dinner with friends or a cute intimate date.
author: Mister G.

description: Yum. I love that everything is organic. The food was absolutely delicious.  The Gordita de Picadillo was my favorite. The margaritas were tasty but a bit pricey for the size. Other than that , it was great and will definitely be back.
author: n d.

description: The food was absolutely fantastic.  Very small portions so be sure to order a couple of things.  Perhaps order a few things and share them.  I made the mistake of not ordering the carnitas!  I guess I will just have to go back...
author: P T.

description: i'd been meaning to try this place ever since it opened and I finally made it out to nopalito last saturday!  i was surprised we had to wait for a table at 3:30 pm but the wait was well worth it!  after a day of errands everything tasted so good and home made.  especially the corn tortilla shells.  we ordered several dishes including the ceviche, gordita campechana, empanada con deshebrada de res, quesadilla roja con chicharrón and tostada con tinga de pollo.  the gordita and tostada were my favorite. both burst with flavor and each dish, although similar, were different and distinct.  to drink, i thought i'd try something different and had the horchata.  even the drink was yummy!
author: Vic S.

description: Everything I've had here is delicious and I love the casual/unpretentious ambiance -- well worth the long wait!
author: Tadeek P.

description: great find in the lower haight neighborhood. recent mid-week early lunch found the place half full at noon but with a great table available for our party of 3. loved the innovate menu and we chose many different dishes which were all delicious and unique. ADORED the chilequiles and have been craving since we left. lots of yummy heat and layered flavors.  the strawberry lemonade is a perfect accompaniment.  wish i could eat here all the time :+}
author: l c.

description: I dont know many "healthy" yummy Mexican restaurants in SF.  I'm a fan of the new Nopalito. (same owners as Nopa)  Everything is Organic, and bought local. (prices are great too)  The take out is always ready for pickup in 10 minutes. I'm going to pickup dinner right now actually. mm mmmm.
author: Jon S.

description: So not worth the wait, the walk, and the price. I'm not sure why this place it always crowded, especially when it's just as overpriced as Falletti's next door (which I want to love since I can walk to it, but I don't have the budget for the $2 markup on even kraft products). I wanted to love it, as I love Mexican food, and I wanted to like the oh-so-trendy shared seating arrangements inside. We had a drink at the bar while we waited for our table, which we ended up sharing with three other people, which wasn't all too bad. Except, the bathrooms are at the other end of the restaurant. Which you can't access from INSIDE the restaurant. It was pouring rain and freezing. Do you really want to get up in the middle of the meal, put on your jacket and umbrella and then wait in a three-deep line for the one-holer bathroom behind a crowded takeout corner? What planner approved that one? I was excited for the food when we got the appetizer, those thick-cut tortilla chips were really good. The salsa/sauce they were in was bland and only served to soggify their goodness. The albondigas were so unfortunate. The sides served with them were even worse. It seemed like no one had ever heard of garlic, cumin, chile, onion, or even . . . salt. It was like eating wierdly, creepily, dyed black meatballs made of rice and charcoal dust. I most likely won't be back.
author: emmeli p.

description:
Conflicted about giving this a four or five - it's not a "five star restaurant" - it's very casual, etc. - but the waitress was really friendly and it was a great value, so I'll round up.

Went here with parents visiting from DC who wanted Mexican food (not burritos; we'll do that too.) We ordered two apps to share, and then all had appetizers instead of mains, but were all full. The pork belly quesadilla was great; my dad's vegetarian quesadilla was as well.

What really made this a 5-star experience was the service - in a casual place like this, where many people are actually grabbing takeout, the waitress took the time to patiently explain the menu and was otherwise friendly and accomodating of a few changes. All in all, a great, cheap place to eat.
author: Vivek T.

description: Three stars for being good. Not great but solid food. Staff was very friendly and accommodating would certainly go back.
author: Boo R.

description: GREAT staff.  Very friendly and everyone says hi, bye, thank you to you.  They made everything on their own from their tortillas, salsa verde, cheeses, cookies, and popsicles!!  Wish I could've eaten more, but was only there for a snack.  I had the Carnitas which is SO GOOD!  The meat just crumbles and melts in your mouth!  So flavorful without being too salty and smoky.  Everything just tasted so fresh and flavorful.  I would definitely go there again.
author: Gina S.

description:
wondering what'd be good for lunch while waiting for my # to be called& crazy lines @ DMV.
So i was really hungry & i thought i want to try nopalito, hopeful tht i will have a good lunch at least.
So they have 2 part of places, inside & outside. They have like a tent-like  for the outside & it's all covered by tent-side as well & they provide u with heater on the top, so it's definitely still warm if you choose to seat on the outside part.  It's a cozy, clean small place i would say.
they have organic mexican food.
they give you sm small fried garbanzo bean snack after you ordered your food.
I ordered: Quesadilla Azul de Acelgas for $8, it has
Blue corn tortilla, braised greens, onions, jack cheese,
queso fresco and salsa pasilla serrano 
hmm yum yummm, loving it, good food i can enjoy my lunch while renewing my license! :D
the drink that i liked: lemonade, it's a very subtle unique taste.
heyy, so far i'm lovin' it! 
So far, it's the best mexican lunch i've ever been!
& the staff is really friendly & knowledgable too!
Nothing is pretentious here, so nice!
will come back to try other food in the menu :)
author: Ms C.

description: So I guess the two star review isn't really Nopalito's fault, its my own personal problem.  I just don't really understand the fancy Mexican food movement.  My favorite Mexican food is anything but fancy, it is simple.... its cheese, its delicious tortillas, its simple sauces and straightforward spices.  Everything just seemed to get muddled up here.  The one nice thing was the size of the orders... finally a Mexican restaurant where every item doesn't feed 5.  Unfortunately, after taking the first bite of my quesadilla, I found myself wishing there was less.
author: Mike G.

description: Nice healthier spin on classic Mexican dishes. Everything we had, which was like almost the entire menu, was super tasty!
author: Rikki D.

description:
ok, ok, try before you rate. so i tried it, para llevar, and i say no. their fresh tortillas turn into a soggy mess after 5 min. all seemed rather basic. fish tacos were tasty. but i don't get the hype. michael bauer needs to stop his madness. 

go to the little chihuahua on divis!
author: casey c.

description: best Mexican food I've ever had! and everything is gluten free which is always a plus. prices are decent, nothing too expensive. definably my new favorite Mexican resturant
author: Stephanie M.

description: Finally.....Good Mexican food in SF!  Met a friend for a late lunch who had been wanting to try it.  So glad that I made it!  It was a light lunch with just sharing an appetizer of dipped chips (interesting) and the carnitas.  So much flavor and perfectly tender!  The rest of the menu looked incredible and I am looking forward to returning with a few more peeps so we can really make a dent!  Best of all, parking is right there!!!
author: Allen V.

description:
*great outdoor seating
* great service
*dominate fish tacos and carnitas
*homemade lime popsicles
author: around town e.

description:
Nopalito is a worthwhile dining experience despite the occasional growing pains of a new restaurant.

Lunch review
Highlights
+ Outdoor patio.  Really gets a lot of sunlight but doesn't get too windswept.  Nice colorful, no-frills decor
+ CARNITAS.  This was absolutely delicious.  A very large portion of cinnamon/orange/bay leaf smoked pork comes with housemade organic corn tortillas, cabbage slaw, roasted vegetables and salsa for a make-your-own experience.  I was tempted to just eat the carnitas alone, it was so good, but I used up all 3 of my tortillas (and asked for one more since I had unwisely skimped on meat in my first)
+ Hot sauce.  You have to ask for it, but I think adding the salsa molcajete to the tortillas gives it a great taste.  This salsa was hot, smoky and textured.  I got the habanero salsa puree too, but as warned, it was a little bit too spicy for my taste.
+ The fried chickpeas served at the beginning were nice- I had to ask for mine, though other tables got them delivered instantly.  Might have been an oversight of my server.

Drawbacks
- Michelada (essentially a beer-based bloody mary).  I didn't love this as much as I thought I would.  Weird flavors and not as spicy as I was hoping, although quite peppery.  They do have a nice selection of beers on tap that I might get next time.
- Menu.  I found the menu kind of confusing and needed to pore over it and talk to the server to understand.  I think one side of the menu are smaller appetizer dishes, while the other side are more savory but this isn't labeled or especially obvious (prices aren't too far apart).  Also, I didn't know what came with tortillas, etc.
- Bathroom:  You have to go outside and down the block to enter on the other side of the restaurant to use the loo.  Probably outside their control, but makes for a slightly disjoint restaurant experience.


I know others think that it is pricy, but I think it is fairly priced for the quantity.  It's only a few dollars more than Chevy's and the portions are pretty reasonable (and organic/ house-made).

I would definitely recommend the place and am hoping to go back sometime soon.
author: Jeff A.

description: Very good - healthy (read: not greasy) and tasty. Loved the mole. Service was very good, even on a busy Friday night. Nice selection of drinks, including excellent beer selections.
author: Karin S.

description: I love this place, the Gorditas are so good ,you can just eat those and be done.  The Carnitas I had were excellent. I do wish they had guacamole.All in all it was good, the servicxe was excellent and everyone is upbeat.  The bathroom our outside around the corner. But I will go back and they do have take out.  Give it a try!
author: Susie S.

description:
Amazing. One of the best overall meals I have had in the city. I reccomend going late in the evening after all the hype has died down. (they dont take reservations) Its more quaint and you can actually talk. Great food, great prices and excellent presentation. One of my Top 10 meals I have had in San Francisco.  

They also do delivery which is great.
author: David S.

description: Very yummy. Mind the portion sizes, we were totally satisfied with two apps and one shared entree, for two of us. Also try the delicious white sangria with FROZEN GRAPES, mmmmm. I will definitely be returning for seconds.
author: audra k.

description: Amazing!!!! The food is incredible! You have to branch out when exploring the menu, but the Tostado is an awesome starter and the carnitas are delicious. I love everything they serve!!!!
author: Heather S.

description: Food wasn't  _bad_  per se, but really, it wasn't all that interesting. Extra star for the food being light, so I didn't leave feeling weighed down with beans and cheese. But then again, I take that star back for its utter lack of authenticity and overpriced menu. So we're left with 3 stars and a shrug.... I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.
author: Kay H.

description: Here is the key to ordering food at Nopalito: Don't order an entree. Order 2 or 3 appetizers and have those instead. The tamal is super tasty, as is the quesadilla with pork belly, and the tostada. All YUM. The people sitting next to us got gorditas, and those looked good too. But the entrees were just ehhh. I've had the chicken in mole which is fine, and the carne asada which is completely boring.
author: Selin K.

description: Truly delicious food. Spectacular carnitas. Mind bending chocolate popsicle. Impeccable quality.
author: Branden B.

description:
My girlfriend took me to this place, having heard good things about it. She is Mexican (not just Mexican-American, but born and raised in Mexico) and is usually very reluctant about going to Mexican places as the food isn't very authentic, she says. Like previous posters have said, this definitely isn't authentic Mexican food--I almost feel that this is the P.F. Chang's of Mexican food (although it's not really a chain). None of the staff  appeared to be Mexican/Latino and none of the guests were either. When we tried ordering in Spanish the waiter had trouble understanding us.

But whatever. I think most people have gotten the idea that this really isn't a Mexican restaurant in the authentic sense. So that's not why I gave this place two stars. The main thing has to do with the quality of the food. It was okay--certainly eatable, not horrible. But if I'm going to pay $15 for carnitas that would cost $6 a few miles to the south in the Mission--they had better be superlatively tastier. My girlfriend order the tostada plate, which was acceptable but certainly not phenemonal.

I guess it's all a matter of opinion. If ambiance and decor is very important to you, and you're willing to pay twice as much for mediocre food just because you're eating at a chic, stylish place--then you'll probably like Nopalito. Personally, I don't care that much how 'authentic' a place is, as long as its food tastes great. With that said, I don't really understand the buzz behind this place and will go to the Mission next time I want to eat Mexican.
author: Eric J.

description: one of the last NEW restaurant's I've tried before leaving SF, I'm a huge fan of NOPA, Lawrence and Jeff can do no wrong.  Nopalito was fabulous, fresh and pure, love the grapefruit salad, enchilada, chips and salsa, carnitas and several other dishes I tried, all amazing!  My drink of choice?  The Michelada, which has a twist of the bloody mary feel but light and dangerous in a good way: easy to drink:).
author: Amanda P.

description: 4 stars for great food, great value, friendly service. I would bestow 5 stars if the wait wasn't sooo so long and one has to go outside next door to use the bathrooms (not fun in rain) & lastly only one white wine & one red wine but several beers from which to choose.
author: Ms. T.

description:
Pros:
Super friendly wait staff who try amusingly hard to pronounce Spanish correctly
Yummy spiced garbanzo beans when you sit down
Dangerously good wine
Cozy, covered, and heated outdoor seating
Quesadillas that give a whole new meaning to the word

Cons:
Downward slope of said outdoor seating
No vegetarian entrees on the menu (though they have more options if you ask)
Confusing bathroom situation (especially after aforementioned wine)
author: Rose P.

description: Yummy, yummy food and surprisingly kid friendly.  We had the quesadilla, mole poblano and chicken enchilada with strawberry sangria.  Everything was fantastic, down to the tiny almond cookie at the end of the meal.  We called ahead early for a table, got right in and had a wonderful time.
author: Bea A.

description: Fabulous food and excellent service.  Very child friendly.  House margaritas were delicious!  We ordered the Totopos con chile.  It was a little spicy for our girls, but my partner and I enjoyed them.  The Ceviche is my favorite.  We also loved the Carnitas and the Lincod dish.  The food is fresh and flavorful and the variety of dishes offered makes sharing entrees easy.  I only wish they had a green salad on the menu.  There is only one salad offered -- beets salad with blood oranges.
author: Beth K.

description:
Incredible food-- and while $$ for casual mexican, for the quality and freshness, cheap. 

I had the chorizo sammy,my husband a pork quesadilla,my son tacos and a cheese quesadilla. I've never had quesadillas that tasted so much of fresh corn, and my torta was incredible-- both rich and fresh. Definitely be back.
author: kate h.

description: i can't think of anything that went wrong at our dinner here.  all the entrees are amazing and come with a side of warm tortillas.  the drinks are great, and their home made chips are better than i've had anywhere else; i.e. not just greasy strips or tortillas.  it appears they use some multigrain tortillas as a base, so the chips are meaty.  I'm definitely going here again.
author: Ash T.

description:
Ok so I never actually got try this place.  Ill give it two stars instead of one because other people have said its so good. 
My girl friend and I went to go eat there the other night around 915 pm.  The place was crowded, but it looked like we got there just when things started to calm down.  There were about four parties waiting outside.  We walked in to put our names down on the list and the owner stopped us and told us they were not talking anymore names. When I observed that there did not seem like much of a wait, he said they had been slammed all day and were looking to close.  
The owner made two mistakes:
1. a new restaurant should not turn away patrons that want to pay to eat there.  Especially 45 minutes before  closing (or five for that matter) and certainly not during a recession!
2. You should never turn away patrons because you've been slammed.  Isnt that what you want?  Why is that the customer's problem?

So food issues aside, I think management needs some service training.  I have certainly worked at many food joints that I would have been fired for saying that.  

I dont know if Ill ever go back to Nopalito, but I have certainly spread the word about my experience.
author: John C.

description: The pozole tasted much, much better on the way down than it did on the way back up.  My guess: improper storage and refrigeration.  I suspected when my bowl was hotter than its contents that it had just been microwaved.  But, given all of these glowing reviews, I was wholly unprepared for that bout of painful, albeit undiagnosed, food poisoning.  I enjoyed everything else about the experience. At some point I'll be willing to experience and review Nopalito again - hopefully just once and in the intended direction.
author: Sarah E.

description: My go-to place for a semi-nice dinner with friends from out of town. Call-ahead seating is very helpful and the prices and food are great to boot. Minus one star mostly because the menu seems pretty static except for a few things here and there.
author: Richard K.

description: 5 stars for the carnitas--you must try it--now! The fish was nothing special. Popsicles are yummy. A little loud inside, but otherwise, a great place to eat good food and catch up with friends.
author: annie s.

description:
I was craving Nopalito this afternoon so stopped by for lunch to go.  I've been here a couple times before and both were delicious.  The first time I had a fish dish that was extremely flavorful and spicy.  I think I like this place so much because the flavors really pop - lots of citrus and spice.  I typically order a couple small plates - I love the fish taco as well as the achiote chicken small plate (topped with yummy pickled onions).  I have also been craving the consomme for some time now - my mom ordered it when she was visiting.  It was served in a gigantic ceramic bowl.  On the menu it sounded rather boring- a lot of veggies.  While it is, essentially, broth with veggies, somehow it turned out to be so much more!  The veggies really stood out - they were incredibly flavorful - it was as though they came fresh from the garden.  My fiance had the Pozole and despite the fact that I typically don't eat pork, I tried some of the hominy and broth and almost fell over in my chair - it was like the ultimate comfort food.  In thinking about it today I picked up some hominy at Rainbow so may attempt to make some myself.  Unfortunately, I don't think mine will turn out as good as theirs.

I think the prices are decent here (I filled up on two of the small plates).  Main downfall is that the service is not top-notch.  Last time our server seemed pretty out of it and we had to flag her down multiple times.  I also wished they had "real" dessert (in my opinion popsicles aren't dessert).
author: Sarah F.

description:
Very healthy tasting food with fresh ingredients. Some people come here expecting to have bursting flavors of salt like a taqueria but Nopalito tastes healthier. Although it was healthy, it was missing a little zing. I think it depends on what you order though 
EASY PARKING , open till 10
Service- fast and helpful
Atmosphere- clean, warm outdoor seating, you don't realize theres a grocery store next door. 

My Dinner-
Tamal Enchilado de Puerco y Queso(5$)- Too thick, overpowered the inside flavors.  Would not order again. 

Taco de Pescado al Pastor (fish tacos) (4.75)- Tasted very fresh and zesty.  

Enchiladas Placeras:Pan seared chile mulato chicken breast, tortillas, potatoes, carrots and queso fresco (14$) good but the sauce was lacking a little. The Chicken breast on the side was moist and juicy, cooked to perfection. 

Pan seared chile mulato chicken breast, tortillas, potatoes, carrots and queso fresco

Next time I would like to try their Carnitas specialty and the chicken soup.
author: John c.

description:
i was there for the early bird special get a table without waiting at peet's for two hours.  basically getting a table=amazing to start with.

it was this gorgeous sunny afternoon and the tables in the patio were perfect--sun and fresh air but no bugs or traffic exhaust.

bathroom was a walk around the block but totally worth it in design and cleanliness.  probably one of the best bathrooms i've seen in the city.  soap smelled good too.

service was very solicitous in demeanor, slightly off with execution.  like bringing wine and courses out really quickly but making us wait for ever for tap water=weird.

delicious rose.  standout dish had to be the blood orange salad.  simple sweet fresh deliciousness.  pork and a veg quesadilla were good too.
author: threeholepunch y.

description: The food here is alright, but not at all worth the 1.5-2 hours wait every time I have been here. The wait list system they have here seems worthless. Save your time and go elsewhere.
author: Brian B.

description:
